fields.headline: An impossible choice
fields.standfirst: Chris Reid on the difficulty of selecting five cricketers of the century
fields.trailText: I have examined the results of this most interesting and inevitably controversial poll. To remain as objective as possible, I have analysed only the names and votes released in the count, and not the guidelines for each panel member.
fields.body:
I have examined the results of this most interesting and inevitably controversial poll. To remain as objective as possible, I have analysed only the names and votes released in the count, and not the guidelines for each panel member.

I looked at the list of 100 panel members, then examined the names receiving votes. I myself picked Don Bradman, Garfield Sobers and Jack Hobbs in that order for the first three. I wrestled for hours over the last two - and resolved that Hammond was No.4 and Hadlee No.5. The most striking and obvious conclusion is that the votes distributed to Bradman (100) and Sobers (90) are indicative of a universal belief that they are the two finest cricketers ever seen, and that the remaining nominees (none receiving more than 30) will forever provide the substance for discussion and conjecture.

It is difficult to gauge the extent to which performances and statistics in isolation (rather than impact, leadership, inspiration, public acclaim or quality of opposition) should be a primary factor of influence. For example, on what basis would Sir Viv Richards's record be elevated beyond that of Wally Hammond? Hammond scored 7,249 Test runs at 58.45, Richards averaged a tick over 50, but his cavalier approach to batting may, deservingly, remain the signature of the 1970s and 1980s.

Shane Warne's place is deserved, which also suggests that performance was the main criteria. However, Richard Hadlee's figures and impact are still staggering and largely understated (which gives rise to an argument for others in the fast-bowling fraternity such as Dennis Lillee and Malcolm Marshall).

Another surprise was that Greg Chappell was not among the 49 cricketers who received at least one vote. On figures alone he was one of few who were clearly in the elite batting class (Test average 53.86). This makes me wonder if he is subject to the hangover resulting from the 'underarm' delivery in 1981 to New Zealand's Brian McKechnie.

Further, the top five between them cover each decade of the 20th century. The cynical observer may remark that this feat would not be accomplished if Richards (the only player to represent the 1980s) was omitted in favour of, say, Hammond or any number of equally worthy candidates. Additionally, if a similar poll is taken next in 10 years' time, Sachin Tendulkar may well remove doubt for one of the two positions under debate.

Moreover, can such a poll escape the influence of English history? Those in the top five have a magnificent record playing in England (while England and Australia account for 48 of the 100-strong selection panel). For instance, could a rampaging Viv Richards in 1976 on tour in England be enough to attract a number of votes from English panellists?

The magic of cricket is that it poses questions without providing answers. What I do propose is that a large percentage of debates have been created by the global nature of modern society, where so much activity takes place simultaneously. This is particularly relevant to the development of cricket in the 20th century. The task of picking the best five cricketers in the last 100 years with any confidence is simply not possible.

In this regard, your efforts have come remarkably close to being as definitive as possible.

fields.headline: The transcript
fields.trailText: These are excerpts of an official transcript which the Indian police allege is a conversation between the South African cricket captain Hansie Cronje and an Indian charged with match-fixing.
fields.body:
These are excerpts of an official transcript which the Indian police allege is a conversation between the South African cricket captain Hansie Cronje and an Indian charged with match-fixing.

The allegations have been vigorously denied by all of those mentioned in the transcript. Last night the United Cricket Board of South Africa's managing director Dr Ali Bacher said: "Hansie Cronje is a man of enormous integrity and honesty. He and his team-mates Nicky Boje, Herschelle Gibbs and Pieter Strydom are emphatic that there is no substance to allegations that they were involved in match-fixing during the one-day series in India. The UCBSA believes that these players have not been involved in the practice of match-fixing.

"The UCBSA and the players concerned have had no contact from police in India and learnt about the allegations through media reports."

Cronje said: "I have been informed by the UCB of the statements that have been made in the media and I am stunned. The allegations are completely without substance. I have been privileged to play for South Africa since 1992 and I want to assure every South African that I have made 100% effort to win every match that I have played. It has been an honour to play for South Africa and I would never do anything to let my country down."

The cricketers' response to the accusations suggests that the authenticity of the tapes and transcript will be challenged.

Chawla: Is Strydom playing?

Cronje: Yes, he is playing, yeah.

Chawla: Boje?

Cronje: Boje is playing.

Chawla: Yeah, Boje is playing . . . and who playing? Gibbs?

Cronje: Gibbs and myself.

Chawla: Ya, what about anybody else?

Cronje: No, I won't be able to get more.

Chawla: You won't be able to get more?

Cronje: No.

Chawla: OK, just tell me. But you have only four with you and not anybody else?

Cronje: No.

Chawla: Klusener and no one?

Cronje: No. No. Impossible. Impossible . . . No. No. They were saying that they were already doing Cochin. The other guys are already angry with me because I have not received their money, you know.

Chawla: No. But I told you, I have already given him altogether 60.

Cronje: OK.

Chawla: And tomorrow I can deposit the money in your account. It is not a problem because of the time difference. Tomorrow itself I can deposit the money.

Cronje: OK . . . OK, I have spoken. Yes, everything is fine. Spoken to Gibbs and to Strydom. Everything is fine.

Chawla: Already, OK? And how many runs for Gibbs?

Cronje: Less than 20.

Chawla: Less than 20?

Cronje: Yeah.

Chawla: OK. So everything is according to plan. They have to score at least 250?

Cronje: Yeah.

Chawla: And if you score 270, it is off?

Cronje: OK. And financially the guys want 25. They want 25 each.

Chawla: All right, OK.

Cronje: So that's 75 for those three and . . . what can you pay me? I do not know how much you pay me . . .

Chawla: You say.

Cronje: If you give me . . . 140 for everybody.

Chawla: 140 altogether?

Cronje: Yeah.

Chawla: OK, that's fine.

Cronje: OK.

Chawla: And we will sort something out for the previous one as well.

Cronje: OK, sure.

Chawla: Yeah?

Cronje: All right. So we definitely are on.

Chawla: OK, and one last thing I want to ask you . . . you know just in case India bat first and if they get out for less than 250 and when you come into bat for the second innings, is it possible that you could ask Gibbs to . . . his . . . wicket . . . we will score him out and try and score slowly and not so fast so that, you know . . . Maybe we can get out of it.

Cronje: OK.

Chawla: And just in case India is out for less than 250 if they bat first?

Cronje: OK, I will tell him.

Chawla: Yeah?

Cronje: I will tell him.

Chawla: And because if he starts scoring so early then we won't be able to get out of it.

Cronje: OK. Not so early for the first five or six in the Indian innings.

Chawla: Yeah.

Cronje: OK.

webTitle: Cronje hits back over police claims

fields.headline: Cronje hits back over police claims
fields.standfirst: Bacher insists South African board will stand by captain
fields.trailText: Pressure was intensifying last night for cricket's authorities to launch an urgent investigation into the alleged Hansie Cronje tapes which, whatever their validity, have left the game teetering on the edge of potentially the most explosive match-rigging scandal in its history.
fields.body:
Pressure was intensifying last night for cricket's authorities to launch an urgent investigation into the alleged Hansie Cronje tapes which, whatever their validity, have left the game teetering on the edge of potentially the most explosive match-rigging scandal in its history.

The key difference between this affair and the other match-fixing episodes that have ravaged the international game for the past decade is that, for the first time, police are claiming that surveillance has produced what they say is taped evidence of a betting conspiracy involving illegal bookmakers and international cricketers.

The release of these official police transcripts in Delhi yesterday, which are allegedly excerpts of a phone conversation between South African captain Hansie Cronje and an Indian businessman, Sanjay Chawla - alias Sanjiv - leaves international cricket facing a crisis that surely cannot be ignored.

The questions that must be resolved are as follows: is the tape genuine, is that the voice of Cronje, and, if so, what was the true purpose of the conversation? Chawla, alleged to be in hiding in London, might also, if found, throw some light on the matter.

Cricket officialdom's initial reaction was understandably cautious, ranging from guarded avoidance of an issue awash with legal implications to loyal protestations about Cronje's innocence.

The International Cricket Council insisted that, under an agreement reached by the Test nations in Christchurch last year, responsibility for any internal cricket inquiry that might shadow any criminal investigation rested with the home nation.

Jagmohan Dalmiya, president of the ICC, in Dhaka with a host of international delegates for a floodlit international between Asia and the Rest of the World, the centrepiece of a week intended to celebrate cricket's global expansion, was flustered by the development.

"I am not aware of anything," he said. "I don't want to talk about it. If there is any grey side to it, we will take care, but one should not talk about anything hypothetical."

From the United Cricket Board of South Africa, even as it considered details of the alleged transcript, came only unreserved protestations of Cronje's innocence.

A statement issued on behalf of Dr Ali Bacher, managing director of the UCBSA, said: "South African captain Hansie Cronje is a man of enormous integrity and honesty. He and his team-mates Nicky Boje, Herschelle Gibbs and Pieter Strydom are emphatic that there is no substance to allegations that they were involved in match-fixing.

"The UCBSA and the players concerned have had no contact from police in India and learnt about the allegations through media reports."

Bob Woolmer, the former South African coach, planning for a new season at Warwickshire, said his initial response had been to regard it as "a bad April Fool's joke".

"However, I realise that this is a genuine charge from India," he said. "I am convinced that Cronje is not guilty and that he would not even contemplate such a series of actions."

Cronje himself described the allegations as "totally without substance". He continued: "I have been privileged to play for South Africa since 1992 and I want to assure every South African that I have made 100% effort to win every match that I have played. It has been an honour to play for South Africa and I would never do anything to let my country down."

The furore could further tempt Cronje to contemplate retirement. He has been disillusioned by clumsy attempts to introduce a non-white quota, to quicken moves to a true multi-racial South African side, most recently when Jonty Rhodes was dropped for the Boxing Day Test against England in Durban.

His standing in the game is considerable: the deeply respected, God-fearing, staunch captain who has developed South Africa, since their return to the international fold, into one of the most united and consistent sides in the world.

But South Africa - and Bacher, in particular - will need no reminding that a series of allegations against Pakistani players, foremost among them Salim Malik, led to a protracted government inquiry, as well as a less wide-ranging investigation by the Pakistan Cricket Board. Malik was accused of trying to bribe Australian players to throw the Karachi Test in 1994.

The Australian Cricket Board, after successfully hushing up the incident for several years, also fined Shane Warne and Mark Waugh a total of £7,500 for conversations with "John" an Indian bookmaker during a tour of Sri Lanka the previous year.

They admitted that they were "stupid and naive" in providing team news and weather forecasts, but no accusations of match-fixing were ever seriously made.

This is the first time that South Africa has become embroiled in match-rigging allegations. Cronje is a sporting icon in a land that regards sporting achievement with a passion. If these allegations prove to be entirely without foundation, the shock waves will be immense.

fields.headline: New year brings higher bills
fields.standfirst:
The abolition of five reliefs will hurt millions, says David Brodie
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Thursday marked the beginning of the new tax year and millions of tax-payers will see a hike in their tax bills as five long-standing reliefs are abolished.
fields.body:
Thursday marked the beginning of the new tax year and millions of tax-payers will see a hike in their tax bills as five long-standing reliefs are abolished.

The guillotine has fallen on the married couple's allowance (MCA), the single parent's allowance, the widow's bereavement allowance and relief for maintenance and mortgage interest payments. These have all been subject to reductions in recent years - the MCA knocked just £197 off most claimants' tax bills in 1999/2000, as against £397 10 years ago - and their final demise was announced last year.

However, there are important transitional provisions to protect older taxpayers from this year's changes. The MCA is being retained for couples where at least one spouse was 65 or over by last Wednesday (April 5).

For 2000/01, the MCA has been set at £5,185 where the older spouse is between 65 and 74. This is given at 10% which cuts £518.50 off the tax bill, or almost £10 per week. As before, the MCA reduces if the husband's income exceeds £19,810, falling to just £2,000 (saving £200 in tax) once income exceeds £27,136. If either spouse is over 75, the MCA is £5,255, or a tax saving of £525.50.

While most people paying maintenance will now get no help from the taxman, if you are over 65 and pay non-voluntary maintenance, your tax bill will be reduced by 10% of what you pay, up to a maximum of £200 a year, and the money is tax-free to the recipient.

This is the same regime that used to apply to all maintenance arrangements entered from 15 March 1988.

This is far less generous than the old relief for maintenance paid under pre-March 15 1988 arrangements, which is now completely abolished. Until this week, such payments were relieved at 10% for the first £1,970, and then at the payer's top tax rate.

This meant that a 40% taxpayer paying £10,000 a year would get £3,409 back from the taxman. While the maintenance was taxable in the hands of the recipient, if they had no other income it would be largely covered by al lowances, and their tax bill could be less than £660. After tax, this meant that they received more than £9,340 at a net cost of £6,591 to the payer. This generous subsidy has now ended, and anyone previously benefiting should urgently review their arrangements.

For many years, relief has been available to those over 65 for interest paid on loans of up to £30,000 secured on their homes to purchase annuities. These loans are commonly known as home income plans. While this relief has been abolished along with mortgage interest relief, it will continue for plans entered before March 10 1999.

Against any loss of tax reliefs, you may detect some compensating gains in your net income this month, as the basic tax rate is reduced by 1 point to 22% and the national insurance contributions threshold rises by £10 to £76 per week, reflecting changes announced last year.

The latest Budget rises in allowances and tax rate thresholds, to reflect increases in the RPI, will not filter through until next month, so you may expect a small rise in net income in May.

From this week, employees claiming the working families' tax credit or disabled person's tax credit will be told that this must be paid through their pay packet, rather than directly by the Revenue.

Businesses have complained about the administrative costs of this change, while voluntary organisations fear discrimination against tax credit claimants and possible delays or mistakes by employers in delivery of the benefit.

Lord Haskins' Better Regulation Task Force has pressed the government to remind applicants with non-working or self-employed partners that they may reduce the risk of problems by identifying their partner as the claimant on the form, in which case they will receive payments directly from the Revenue.

David Brodie is director of TaxAid, the charity which provides free tax advice to people who cannot afford professional fees. Phone 0171-624-3768 between 10am and noon, Mondays to Thursdays

webTitle: Loan plans won't cure chronic ills

fields.headline: Loan plans won't cure chronic ills
fields.standfirst:
Public sector workers feel the proposals fall short of what they need, says Jessica McCallin
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Poorly paid public sector workers remain sceptical of government proposals aimed at helping them get on to the first rung of the property ladder in expensive areas like the south-east of England.
fields.body:
Poorly paid public sector workers remain sceptical of government proposals aimed at helping them get on to the first rung of the property ladder in expensive areas like the south-east of England.

John Prescott's Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) announced its housing green paper on Wednesday, suggesting interest-free loans, cash incentives and development grants, as ways of helping helping poorly paid professionals buy their first home.

But union representatives for nurses and teachers - two of the key professions the proposals hope to target - said it falls far short of helping workers.

Karen Jennings, head of nursing at Unison, the public sector union, said most nurses earn £14,800 a year and that even with interest-free loans they will still fall far short of being able to buy anything in London or the south-east.

Even the 200-odd nurse consultants, who earn £40,000 a year, would be unable to buy a home in most parts of the capital.

Assuming a salary multiple of three when buying a house, £40,000 would only result in a mortgage of £120,000. A quick look through the Land Registry's property price index shows that this would only buy you a house in half of London's surrounding boroughs and nothing at all in the centre of the city.

It is possible to get cheaper properties in London, but they are hardly ideal for a first-time buyer, let alone anyone with a family. The internet property website www.propertylive.co.uk found one property within a nurses's salary range - a studio apartment in east London for £36,000.

Teachers don't fare much better. More than half the profession earn £23,958 a year or less, which, again, will only stretch to a one-bedroom flat in one of the peripheral areas of London.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers said: "This is a headline-grabbing proposal and I'm sure that any teacher who benefits from it will be delighted, but it doesn't get to the heart of the matter.

"We keep getting proposals from the government which just fiddle round the edge of the issue. What they should do is deal with the real problem - inadequate teacher salaries."

The teachers' union also pointed out that other areas of the country have been hit by house price rises and that teachers need to be able to buy their own homes in these regions as well.

The public sector pay issue has gained momentum over the past year as booming house prices have effectively priced low-paid workers out of the property market, leading to staff shortages as many either leave the property hotspots or quit the profession altogether.

The government's green paper proposals are still in their early stages and the DETR is keen to point out that nothing concrete can be said until the end of the consultation period and the chancellor's spending review - probably towards the end of the year.

If all goes to plan, Mr Prescott wants to extend the support to jobless home-owners moving back to work by paying their mortgage interest for their first month back in a job.

In the meantime, housing authorities and local councils have been asked to draw up costing plans for several of his proposals.

Research from the Council of Mortgage Lenders found that three-quarters of those surveyed want to own their own homes within the next two years.

Unfortunately, Mr Prescott's proposals will be unlikely to turn this dream into a reality for low-paid workers.

As such, they will have to take consolation from his commitment to improving the rental market, although many public sector workers have been priced out of this as well.

fields.headline: A lite night out
fields.standfirst:
Mint Royale
Brighton Beach, Leeds
**
fields.trailText: The promoter is suicidal. "I've only sold 30 tickets," he sighs. "I can't understand it. They've had a No 15 hit! I thought the place would be heaving." Instead, Mint Royale are forced to enter battle with more gaps in the audience than there are craters on the moon. This could be a reflection of difficult times for pop, or of the fact that in an overcrowded, overpriced live scene, people are starting to demand value for money.
fields.body:
The promoter is suicidal. "I've only sold 30 tickets," he sighs. "I can't understand it. They've had a No 15 hit! I thought the place would be heaving." Instead, Mint Royale are forced to enter battle with more gaps in the audience than there are craters on the moon. This could be a reflection of difficult times for pop, or of the fact that in an overcrowded, overpriced live scene, people are starting to demand value for money.

However good they are musically (one critic called their album, On the Ropes, "Indie dance album of the year"), as a live act Mint Royale would have difficulty extracting plaudits from their mums. Their hit single Don't Falter came on the back of a typically bittersweet vocal from the former Kenickie warbler Lauren Laverne. But live, there is no sign of Laverne, just a couple of men with boxes. As entertainment goes, it's a bit like watching some body fix a car. In fairness, the Manchester duo do their best to rev up their engine with a stream of bouncy, sample-laden pop, big grooves and pianos and horn stabs that could (and probably did) come straight from a 1970s cop programme.

They show their 80s roots with chunks of Indeep's Last Night a DJ Saved My Life and Wham!'s Wham Rap. It is very knowing, flawlessly executed and excruciatingly dull. There are no mistakes, no improvisations, no embellished chord sequences - nothing, in the absence of a printed copy of Mint Royale's contract and rider, to show why they bother playing live at all.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Millions face poverty
fields.standfirst:
A comfortable retirement is expensive and many of us are not saving nearly enough to live above the breadline, reports Jessica McCallin
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A comfortable retirement is expensive and many of us are not saving nearly enough to live above the breadline.
fields.body:
Want to retire with £25,000 a year? You'd better start saving now and start saving lots. A 25-year-old man hoping to retire at 65 would need to put away £212.47 a month to secure a pension of £25,000 a year. If that sounds like a lot, then you'd better hope you're not much older than 25.

Assuming a pension fund growth rate of 4.5% a year, a 35-year-old would need to put away £372.27. And if you're older than 35 I wouldn't recommend looking at the box on the right (showing how much a man hoping to retire at 65 would have to save to get £25,000 a year); you probably have more chance of winning the Lottery than meeting the monthly payments.

In short, for a variety of reasons, including the fact that we are living longer and are accustomed to a higher standard of living than our predecessors, retirement is an expensive business.

The problem is that many of us don't appear to be aware of this. New research from AXA Sun Life found the target group for the government's stakeholder pensions - the self-employed, part-timers and those who move jobs frequently - is putting away nowhere near the required amount for a comfortable retirement. Four out of six respondents said they were confident about their financial well-being in retirement, but the survey found that only one in six were making sufficient savings.

And while half of all respondents expect to retire before 60, the survey found that unless they start saving significantly more, most will be retiring at 65 with an income below the poverty line - ie an income of around £8,000 a year, barely enough to cover the basics.

Interestingly, most of those surveyed seem to have accepted that the "rolling back" of the welfare state is set to continue and that they should make private arrangements for a variety of services which, until now, have been provided by the state. For example, four in 10 of all respondents anticipate having to pay in part or in full for hospital treatment in retirement, whilst 73% expect to pay for residential care and 63% for transport. Why this has not prompted people to make adequate private arrangements for their retirement is unclear. A lack of awareness of the amount of money required is an obvious explanation. But there is also evidence that people are considering other financial products instead of a pension.

The AXA Sun Life study found that bank or building society accounts, endowment policies, Isas, unit trusts, and life assurance bonds are all popular savings vehicles for retirement. In addition, 42% of respondents expect to work part-time during their retirement to supplement their income, while 30% expect a windfall or inheritance lump-sum and a further 30% plan to sell their property.

The findings make bleak reading for the retirees of the future. The pensions message was always start saving early and reap the benefits later on, yet the 41% of AXA respondents who have been putting away a set amount each month since their 20s will not be reaping sufficient benefits later on.

Most people in the stakeholder pension target group put about £65 a month into a retirement plan, a far cry from the amounts that are deemed necessary for a comfortable old age, and cannot afford to increase their instalments. The figure for average monthly payments into other pension funds, such as company schemes, also falls short at £150 a month.

fields.headline: The ball's in his court
fields.standfirst: Mike Corby went from being a to athlete to found The Fitness Exchange, now the most successful chain of its type in Britain. Martyn Seal talks to him
fields.trailText: Mike Corby went from being a to athlete to found The Fitness Exchange, now the most successful chain of its type in Britain.
fields.body:
Of all the former British sportsmen who've turned the passion they had for their game into a money-making venture, Mike Corby is probably the most profitable. He's the outright owner of The Fitness Exchange, the highly successful nationwide chain of health and leisure clubs.

Mr Corby admits that he's led a charmed life. Even at school he was a top-class sportsman, winning the Drysdale cup for squash, the junior Wimbledon cup for tennis and playing schoolboy hockey for England.

After school he took a job as an insurance broker at Lloyds Bank, but it wasn't this career that became the main feature of his life. He was asked to play hockey by the premier team in London and part of his prize for winning the Drysdale cup was a year's membership of the RAC.

"The RAC also asked me to play squash for them," he re calls. "So from playing for them and playing hockey with Hounslow, I got into the England squash and hockey teams and went to the 64 and 72 Olympic games as a hockey player. I also worked my way up the rankings as a squash player and became England number one, which I was for eight or nine years."

His break into the world of fitness clubs came in the early 70s when playing a game of squash with an engineer called Robin Anderson, who was rebuilding London Bridge.

"I'd played squash in the world championships in 1967 and 1971 and I'd seen the growth of squash clubs in Australia in Sydney. It got me interested in the idea.

"At the time I was the British number one and it seemed a way to expand upon a passion of mine. So I asked Robin if they had any area to build some squash courts. He said 'no, but we have a bloody big hole on the north side that's certainly big enough.'"

Three years later he opened the first squash club in the City of London area. During that period Corby had to face a barrage of scepticism. The feeling was that he wouldn't get any membership, since nobody would have time during a lunch break to play a game of squash. "I knew how the City worked at that time," he remembers. "It wasn't re ally a strict regime of nine-to five, as they now have; it was far more relaxed. People could have two-hour lunches. I knew also that by being in the City it would be close to a huge body of people.

"I didn't really have a business plan per se, other than one on the back of an envelope. I didn't get anything verified by an accountant, I just worked out how much money I could take and what my outgoings were, and that's literally how it all happened."

Potential disaster struck, however, when one of his backers pulled out. "To start with I had 49% of the shares and a company in the City had 51%," he explains. "They kept them for two months and then decided they were going public and told me they wanted to sell. I was out on a limb, nobody backing me. I went to see the banks but nearly all of them said they knew me as a sportsman, thought it was a good idea but asked me to come back when I was going to open the second one.

"In the end a man who worked for NatWest thought I'd been given a raw deal and said that he couldn't give me money, since I had no security, but for every 50 memberships I sold he would give me £10,000.

"The next day a man came asking about membership and thought we must be full. I told him I was looking for memberships and he said he could get me 10. The day after that he gave me a cheque for 50 memberships, so I got my backing."

After the success of the first venture he was offered a site in Spitalfields by the City of London. "It was the old fruit and wool exchange which had been empty for half a dozen years. I took the lease and built four squash courts."

After building another five clubs around London, Corby realised he needed a brand to cover them all, which is how The Fitness Exchange was born. Corby is now looking to expand the business quickly, but his dealings with venture capitalists have left him thinking of other ways to do it.

"They start out with big, smiley faces and promise you the earth. Then you find out that's what you've given them and you're left with crumbs. I'm very happy to be in the position where I own 100% of the company and have virtually no borrowings."

webTitle: Springing into a new fixed rate

fields.headline: Springing into a new fixed rate
fields.standfirst:
As base rates stay the same, new mortgages are tempting first-time buyers, reports Nick Pandya
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The first spring house hunting season of the new millennium got off to a flying start after the Bank of England's monetary committee decided not to raise base rates. And right on cue, several mortgage lenders unveiled a new range of fixed-rate mortgage packages.
fields.body:
The first spring house hunting season of the new millennium got off to a flying start after the Bank of England's monetary committee decided not to raise base rates. And right on cue, several mortgage lenders unveiled a new range of fixed-rate mortgage packages.

Halifax is drawing first-time buyers into the housing market through a special deal fixed at 5.59% until December 31, 2001. And Lambeth Building Society is offering mortgages at 4.09% fixed for two years to first-time buyers with the usual 5% deposit, but they will have to stay with the lender for at least five years.

Cash poor house hunters with steady incomes need not hesitate to get on the property ladder. At least five lenders including Sainsbury's Bank, Scottish Widows Bank and Yorkshire Building Society are offering full 100% mortgages with interest rates ranging between 7.09% and 7.79%. Sainsbury's Bank, for example, will lend 100% of the value of the property at 7.39% fixed until May 31, 2003 and Scottish Widows has a variable rate at 7.09%, while the Yorkshire is charging a variable rate of 7.79%.

Alliance & Leicester, is offering a two-year deal fixed at 6.19% to borrowers who can put a downpayment of at least 10% of the value of the house, otherwise the rate is fixed at 6.29%.

And for those buyers seeking houses to let, the bank is lending at 7.39% fixed for five years, provided they can fund 20% of the value of the property themselves. Chase de Vere is also wooing budding landlords with a buy-to-let mortgage fixed at 6.99% until March 1, 2003. Borrowers will need 25% of the value of the property and the lender takes a cut of 1% of the amount of the advance on completion.

As ever it's a smaller regional rival that has come up with this week's hard to beat deal, for typical buyers with just a 5% deposit. Stroud & Swindon, which in 1996 gave us the first flexible mortgage, has come up with an innovative combination of a fixed-rate flexible mortgage. The terms of the deal include a fixed rate of 6.29% stretching until June 1, 2002, with the society picking up the tab for legal bills. There are no early redemption penalties.

The loan is flexible, so borrowers can opt to make overpayments to reduce their debt quicker, or if they hit hard times underpayments are charged back at the fixed-rate until the end of the term.

For housebuyers with a deposit of at least 10%, Newcastle Building Society is offering a two-year cut price mortgage whereby the rates are capped at 5.85% until June 1, 2001 and thereafter the rate will not rise above 6.25% until June 1, 2002. Loyal borrowers who remain with the society then benefit from a discount of 0.75% off its base mortgage rate for the rest of the life of the mortgage.

Savills Private Finance, has come to the aid of overstretched borrowers. Its two-year fixed-rate deal is priced at 4.75% until May 1, 2002. This rate will trim around £4,750 off mortgage costs over two years for borrowers currently repaying a £100,000 loan at 6.49%. But they are handcuffed to the lender until May 1, 2004: the price of freedom is a hefty 3.5% of the value of the mortgage.

fields.headline: Scardino's Euro-TV coup
fields.standfirst: Media group to dominate continent in £12bn broadcasting deal
fields.trailText: Marjorie Scardino's reshaping of media group Pearson took another enormous leap yesterday with the £12bn merger of the company's television production business with Luxembourg-based broadcast and radio group CLT Ufa.
fields.body:
Marjorie Scardino's reshaping of media group Pearson took another enormous leap yesterday with the £12bn merger of the company's television production business with Luxembourg-based broadcast and radio group CLT Ufa.

The deal brings together 160 Pearson programmes including Baywatch, Neighbours and The Bill, with a network of 22 television channels and 18 radio stations, creating Europe's biggest broadcasting business.

The combined company will have revenues of €3.8bn - higher than Canal Plus, KirchMedia or BSkyB. Shares in Pearson climbed 251p to £23.04, around twice their value 12 months ago, as the market gave the merger its resounding support.

Ms Scardino said the business is going to be "a real pow erhouse with the scale and resources to take opportunities" in both the conventional and new media sectors. "This deal creates great value that we could not create alone. It puts Pearson TV at the heart of one of Europe's most extensive and most popular broadcasting networks," she said.

The merger also had the effect of building a dominant 65% stake in Channel 5 by combining the assets of Pearson and CLT.

webTitle: Fair shares for the part-time professionals

fields.headline: Fair shares for the part-time professionals
fields.standfirst:
Splitting a job between people frees valuable employees to live fuller lives. What's more, it enables companies to retain skilled staff who might otherwise leave and is now being introduced at senior levels. Jill Papworth looks those who are making it work
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Splitting a job between people frees valuable employees to live fuller lives. What's more, it enables companies to retain skilled staff who might otherwise leave and is now being introduced at senior levels. Jill Papworth looks those who are making it work.
fields.body:
Job sharing, where two people share the duties, pay and benefits of one full-time post, is becoming the upmarket face of part-time working.

Where part-time working in the UK has tended to be associated with low-skilled, poorly-paid and insecure jobs: "Job sharing has become an accepted way of introducing part-time hours into jobs which have traditionally only been available on a full-time basis, particularly at senior and managerial level," says New Ways to Work, a London-based organisation advising on more flexible working arrangements. "It opens up the possibility of doing professional and skilled work on a less than full-time basis, which may not otherwise be possible."

This was certainly the case seven years ago for Lindsay Porter, now a job sharing district personnel manager for Sainsbury's. After taking a four-year career gap to have a family, Ms Porter had rejoined the group on a part-time basis as a temporary personnel manager working on new store openings in the north. When the project finished, the company wanted the job to become a full-time post, something Ms Porter was not interested in as the mother of a young family.

"My boss at the time was very forward thinking and suggested that I and another part-time personnel manager, who also would have left the company rather than go full-time, formulate a job share. The company was able to retain the skills of two people who otherwise would have left. It was the first job share at that level in Sainsbury's," she says. "Job sharing meant I was able to secure a permanent appointment and dovetail my homelife and raising my family with a career. It has also allowed me to be promoted to the next level."

For the past three years Ms Porter has shared the job of district personnel manager, responsible for 16 stores in the north east, Yorkshire and Humberside, with partner Karen Gregory, who made a deliberate choice to go part-time to improve the quality of her life.

"We work in a world where jobs and careers tend to predominate to the exclusion of other things," Ms Gregory says. "By job sharing I'm able to pursue the career I want and yet grow outside of the role through pursuing other interests. I feel I've gained from having a balance in my life."

At the last count (Labour Market Survey autumn '97), some 0.8% of UK employees - 177,000 people - were working on a job sharing basis, of whom 89% were women. And an increasing number of organisations are now offering job sharing at management levels.

The major high street banks, Marks & Spencer, Nationwide (see panel), Oxford County Council, Boots, BP and PowerGen and most local authorities in London now have official job share schemes, while many others offer job shares on an ad-hoc basis.

But still the majority of job shares exist at administrative and secretarial levels, according to Angela Baron, an adviser at the Institute of Personnel and Development (IPD). "There are some high-profile examples of job shares at senior levels, but they are few and far between," she says. "The reality is that the idea of splitting senior jobs frightens many organisations. They argue that jobs with a high level of responsibility must be done full-time by one person and can't be split between two part-timers, who will be less committed and will lose control of things during hand-overs."

But these arguments don't stand up, says Ms Baron, who cites the examples of senior, round-the-clock jobs such as ward sister or hotel duty manager. "These are highly responsible, 24-hour-a-day jobs which have traditionally been 'job shared'. One person is in charge, but it's not the same person 24 hours a day. So it shouldn't be that hard to share the responsibilities of senior management roles in modern, flexible organisations. Job shares tend to work very successfully and bring many benefits to the employer."

Job shares give employers the chance to bring two sets of skills and experience to a post and retain qualified and trained employees who might otherwise leave.

As job share partners typically arrange their holidays at different times and fill in for each other when ill, employers get better cover and continuity than they would from one person doing the job.

As Karen Gregory and Lindsay Porter each do three days a week and stagger their holidays, the advantages to Sainsbury's includes six days a week cover for most of the year with at least three days a week during holiday periods. The partners are very flexible in terms of the days they work. All important meetings and events are covered by at least one of the two women and, on occasions where the business requires it, both will agree to work full-time temporarily.

The only cost to the company for these extra benefits is doubling up on some employee benefits. Both women get a company car, private health cover, a mobile phone and a home computer system which allows them to retrieve e-mails from work.

The onus to prove to employers that job shares can succeed, particularly at more senior levels, inevitably falls on pioneering partners. Ms Porter and Ms Gregory share their job by each performing the full range of tasks, with no division of duties, though they occasionally play to their individual strengths by taking charge of different projects. "It's important that when staff come to us they have access to someone who knows all the job, whichever one they speak to," says Ms Gregory.

The partners say that the key to making things work is good communication. "Communication is crucial," says Ms Gregory. "You have to know what one another are doing and what advice each has given on different issues, or you end up duplicating work. We don't have a situation, as can happen in some job shares, where people play us off against each other. That's because our communication system is watertight."

The two women operate a handover book in which they record a summary of events, use e-mail extensively and talk a lot on the phone. As they live close to each other, once a week one will call in on the other for a quick update chat. "We also serve as a useful sounding board for each other. We can share ideas and stresses," says Ms Gregory.

"It's also vital that you respect, trust and get on with your job share partner. You should get the chance to meet, get to know and establish a rapport with your partner before starting the job. "Be wary of having a jobshare partner imposed on you," Ms Porter says. "And try to agree with your employer that if your partner leaves, you will be involved in the recruitment of their replacement."

If the partnership does not work, you risk covering up for the inefficiencies of your partner or doing twice as much work as them in the same amount of time.

Making it work

Be honest and direct with each other from the outset, airing disagreements as soon as they come up.

A seamless handover is vital if your shared role is not to disrupt clients and co-workers. So think "handover" all the time and have clear communication channels.

Minimise the amount of handovers you need, so ideally work clumps of days each rather than splitting hours each day.

You need to maintain some kind of face to face relationship. So arrange the occasional meeting or lunch.

Think carefully about how you split your stints. You don't, for example, have to divide a standard week or work one week on, one week off. You could work Wednesday through to the following Tuesday and maintain contuinuity over weekends, something valued by employers.

When at work, don't phone your partner unless it's vital. You'll be intruding on their non-work time.

If you find it hard to share responsibilities, ideas and tasks, think twice about doing a job share.

Partners in time

Job sharing has been an exciting and enjoyable experience so far for Michele Guerrini and Sharon Kilcoyne, joint senior branch managers of Nationwide Building Society's Ealing branch in west London.

Both are mothers of young children and appreciate the fact that sharing allows them to continue their careers, retain promotion prospects and have time for their families. "It's also good to have someone to bounce ideas off and discuss problems with. It's less stressful," Ms Guerrini says.

Six years ago Ms Guerrini was working as a part-time financial adviser for the society while Ms Kilcoyne, in customer services, was considering going part-time when a line manager suggested they apply for a branch manager job share.

"The job wasn't advertised as a job share but we applied together and were interviewed together," Ms Guerrini says. "We presented an action plan as to how we'd approach the post and the management agreed. It helped that we both had very good track records."

Since then they have shared three posts, the last being the only job share at such a senior level. They each work two-and-a-half days a week, with a lunchtime handover on Wednesdays. "We have very good communication," Ms Guerrini says. " We speak on the phone at the beginning and end of each day and keep a work in progress log. As the years go by, we no longer need chapter and verse on everything. Our staff say they don't know when one is in and the other isn't."

The partners share benefits on a pro-rata basis, though each has their own company car. Neither one is expected to fill in for the other if they are off sick or on holiday, but they make sure that someone is always in at least half the week.

"Our employer benefits from having two enthusiastic people coming in fresh," Ms Guerrini says. "I see no downsides to job sharing from either the employee's or employer's point of view. It's down to the sharers to show it can work once they have been given the opportunity."

webTitle: Job-seeking goes online for beginners and returners

fields.headline: Job-seeking goes online for beginners and returners
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Career guidance experts Working Future have set up an electronic shop for anyone beginning a new career or kick-starting a stalled one.
fields.body:
Career guidance experts Working Future have set up an electronic shop for anyone beginning a new career or kick-starting a stalled one. The website offers links across the employment spectrum including tips on job search, managing a career change, financial advice and CVs. There is an online database with more than 80,000 opportunities. Downloading costs start at £25 a throw: www.workingfutures.com

The challenges faced by professional women restarting careers after a break to raise a family or nurse an elderly relative may not be aired as often as the difficulties faced by their unskilled sisters. Yet the loss of employees in whom organisations have significant investment represents a waste of talent. To address this issue, Women Returners' Network (WRN) carried out a study into the role of professional associations in easing the return to work of professional women. The findings show that two out of three women do take a career break and the decision blights their career. Turning to professional associations for help is less than satisfactory, as most do not have measures in place to support their female members. For copies of the report contact Val Hammond on 01293-851644.

Take a look at the minutes of any board meeting and you will find that "training" often features under "any other business", so before closing the meeting, the purse-keepers can say "sorry, there's no money for that". Now, with the development of cost-effective online study packages, training can be delivered to a desktop through CD-Rom or in-house networks. And no one has done more to push the cause of interactive online learning than Xebec McGraw-Hill. It is the UK-based Lifelong Learning Division of the US media giant McGraw-Hill, which has been publishing educational texts for 100 years. Organisations like House of Fraser, London Borough of Newham and the Department for Education and Employment have installed Xebec Online's business and manage- ment skills learning program.

Its management and communications skills library is aimed at front-line staff and managers at all levels. And the course material on its executive development package is designed for senior managers on fast-track career paths. For details tel: 0800-585-889 or www.xebec-online.com

fields.headline: Wayward charm
fields.standfirst:
Birmingham Royal Ballet
Birmingham Repertory Theatre
Rating: **
fields.trailText: The two Royal Ballet companies are taking time to look back on their founding choreographer, Frederick Ashton. The Royal in London has just revived two major works, while Birmingham is devoting two complete programmes to his ballets.
fields.body:
The two Royal Ballet companies are taking time to look back on their founding choreographer, Frederick Ashton. The Royal in London has just revived two major works, while Birmingham is devoting two complete programmes to his ballets.

Ashton's art ranged from witty modishness to quiet profundity, from distilled abstraction to robust comedy, yet his best works were always charged with the force of his wayward, romantic personality. So frankly emotional was Ashton's engagement with his material, that ballets that ought to be dismissable as nostalgic, sentimental or even slight continue to resonate with the charm and passion of their creator.

Take Two Pigeons (1961), with which Birmingham opens its mini-season, is a rewrite of Mérante's 1886 ballet about the precariousness and preciousness of young love, its two lovers symbolised by a pair of live pigeons on stage. It ought to be as naff as a Hallmark card, except that Ashton drew his characters' emotions with such delicacy and detail. The agitated footwork and railing gestures of the Young Girl's choreography say everything about her uncomprehending distress at her boyfriend's temporary defection, her buckled knees and bent arms a graphic image of a wounded heart.

Dorcas Walters, a mature dancer, is cast slightly against type. Yet her trenchant character makes the Girl's capriciousness look interestingly like wit, and her adoration like grown-up passion. She also makes an excellent foil to Robert Parker's testosterone-dazed Young Man, who seems so much at the mercy of his own confused cockiness.

The act two gypsy scene was less well served by the dancers, who looked physically and dramatically ill at ease. The four divertissements completing the programme seemed stilted too. While there was nothing technically wrong, the dancers' timidity of scale made certain potentially sublime moves look trite.

Until Monday. Box office: 0121-236 4455

Dorcas Walters, a mature dancer, is cast slightly against type. Yet her trenchant character makes the Girl's capriciousness look interestingly like wit, and her adoration like grown-up passion. She also makes an excellent foil to Robert Parker's testosterone-dazed Young Man, who seems so much at the mercy of his own confused cockiness. The act two gypsy scene was less well served by the dancers, who looked physically and dramatically ill at ease. The four divertissements completing the programme seemed stilted too. While there was nothing technically wrong, the dancers' timidity of scale made certain potentially sublime moves look trite. Until Monday. fields.headline: Tender but tough
fields.standfirst:
Hard Fruit
Royal Court, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: A hard man, said Mae West, is good to find. And that is the view of the hero of Jim Cartwright's strangely beguiling new play. Choke is a martial arts fanatic who doesn't go much on women. "I don't like the feel of 'em, everything gives, all pushy instead of pressy," he says.
fields.body:
A hard man, said Mae West, is good to find. And that is the view of the hero of Jim Cartwright's strangely beguiling new play. Choke is a martial arts fanatic who doesn't go much on women. "I don't like the feel of 'em, everything gives, all pushy instead of pressy," he says.

Choke is what you'd call a man's man. He struts around his junk-filled backyard like a fighting-fit bantam cock; his instinctive way of greeting his only friend, Sump, is with a head-butt or karate chop. But Choke's tragedy is that he cannot admit he is gay. Almost everyone else in Cartwright's play, from Sump to the glass-painting Friar Jiggle and the flouncing Yack, who wears a stuffed cat for a hat, is only too happy to remind us it's queer up north. In a way, the play takes us back to Road, with which Cartwright made his galvanic debut. There's not a lot of plot, and some minor figures are shoehorned in like cabaret turns.

Cartwright's great gifts are for mood and language. He pins down a certain kind of tender-tough, equivocal northern maleness with deadly accuracy. He also has a talent for demotic poetry. He's a strange mix of Ben Jonson and a soap-writer, and the two elements merge harmoniously in James Macdonald's production and Geoff Thompson's fight choreography, in which the climactic battle is clearly a form of sublimated sex.

Nicholas Woodeson's Choke is a powerful mix of repressed solitude and bullish posturing and there is strong support from Richard Hope as his fighting partner and Hilda Braid as a caricature northern neighbour. But possibly the real hero is designer Rob Howell, who is responsible for a backyard overflowing with rusty Heath Robinson contraptions. Since he also designed The Graduate, you might say he's moved from one kind of junk to another with mind-boggling versatility.

Until May 6. Box office: 0171-565 5000. A version of this review appeared in some editions yesterday

fields.headline: Once more, as farce
fields.standfirst:
Lautrec
Shaftesbury Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText: This is a good time for a show about Toulouse-Lautrec. The Victoria and Albert Museum has just opened its exhibition of art nouveau, that curvilinear movement in which the French artist figured prominently. This musical could have helped us reflect on how Toulouse-Lautrec learned to use bold simplification in his lithographs and paintings. That way Lautrec could have become a pendant to Sondheim's Sunday in the Park with George. But Charles Aznavour's new musical instead teems with skirt-waving bawdiness, allusions to split-crotch panties and vertically challenged sex.
fields.body:
This is a good time for a show about Toulouse-Lautrec. The Victoria and Albert Museum has just opened its exhibition of art nouveau, that curvilinear movement in which the French artist figured prominently. This musical could have helped us reflect on how Toulouse-Lautrec learned to use bold simplification in his lithographs and paintings. That way Lautrec could have become a pendant to Sondheim's Sunday in the Park with George. But Charles Aznavour's new musical instead teems with skirt-waving bawdiness, allusions to split-crotch panties and vertically challenged sex.

There are 22 vapid songs, including two can-cans, a bump-and-grind tune involving squatting prostitutes and something called Doing It. There's even a drinking song: "Who gives a shit what people think?" shout the ensemble as they wave glasses of absinthe. Brave words.

This slickly directed show began brightly enough with a sarcastic ensemble number about incest. Little Henri was the product of an ill-advised encounter between first cousins. To find his identity, he plunged into the vice dens of Montmartre, fell in love with a prostitute, Suzanne. Later in the show, Suzanne wonders in song "Should Quasimodo's Esmerelda stay or go?" Each lyric is very nearly laughable and overburdened by psychological freight or crass allusion.

The principals are blameless. Sévan Stephan sings well; in lieu of a script that unfolds Henri's psychological development plausibly, that is the best he can do. Hannah Waddingham as Suzanne won the warmest applause for her belting solo in which she pleads with Henri's mother to let the by then syphilitic, alcoholic artist out of an asylum. She, too, deserves to be in a better musical. Only Robert Jones's imaginative set and costume designs truly distinguish themselves.

To spare everyone further suffering, Lautrec should be recast with Ronnie Corbett and Denise van Outen as the leads, the thing played as farce. It's halfway there already.

Until July. Box office: 0171-379 5399

webTitle: Ridsdale proves a chairman who will not sit back

fields.headline: Ridsdale proves a chairman who will not sit back
fields.trailText: Most football club chairmen will have some enthusiasm for the club they run, but there cannot be many who can match the passion, and compassion, of Peter Ridsdale.
fields.body:
There are usually two reasons why football club chairmen get involved. They are either looking for a bit of profile after years of drudgery running boring businesses, or they want a quick return on their investment.

Most will have some enthusiasm for the club they run, but there cannot be many who can match the passion of Peter Ridsdale, chairman of Leeds United Sporting Club plc and Leeds United FC.

It's in his bones. As a young boy he was so desperate for a ticket for the 1965 FA Cup final against Liverpool that he spent the night in a sleeping bag outside Elland Road to be among the first in the queue.

And these days, when confronted by fans in various forums, his encyclopaedic knowledge of all things Leeds puts most diehard supporters to shame.

When supporters tell him about poor conditions or treatment at various grounds, it is Ridsdale who is apparently the first to volunteer to stand on the terraces and get first-hand experience. The job is not given to some unfortunate lackey.

Therefore it came as no surprise when Ridsdale agreed to talk to me on my Radio 5 Live programme Late Night Live on Wednesday evening, only an hour or so after the first Leeds supporter lost his life.

He was at the hospital in Istanbul having left a dinner with Galatasaray officials within minutes of hearing the tragic news. I don't wish to portray him as football's Mother Teresa but his actions showed a man with an enormous amount of compassion and understanding of the mayhem going on around him.

"This has been a terrible evening and one that I never wish to see again," he said. Should the match with Galatasaray be played? "If you want my gut feeling now, I don't think it should be. It would seem inappropriate."

He had accompanied the dead man's brother to identify the body. By all accounts he made it his business to know the condition of the other five Leeds supporters who were injured in the incident in Taksim Square, and he stayed up through the night to comfort and cajole.

On another level, he showed again his appreciation of why the news media need to be kept informed.

His critics (and I cannot believe there are many of them) will suggest that he is too much of an open book, and some will even say that his willingness to talk is almost self-indulgent and unhealthy. Many of us who have dealt with him since he became chairman of the plc and the FC in June 1997 would prefer to stand back and applaud his honesty and straightforward dealings.

In common with all those who have a hands-on responsibility with their respective businesses, Ridsdale's role is largely that of a firefighter. It is not often a man in his position has time to sit back and enjoy the fruits of his labour.

Just take the past few weeks. His club were punished with a record fine by the Football Association for that on-the-pitch scuffle with Tottenham players; some of his brightest young assets are facing assault charges; and now two of his club's supporters are lying in a mortuary in Turkey.

And still he has to put on a corporate face, one that satisfies shareholders, investors, sponsors, supporters and the press.

Within a few months of his elevation from a director of the football club to running both businesses, Ridsdale was confronted by George Graham's defection to Tottenham. He dealt with it astutely, promoted David O'Leary, and has reaped huge rewards.

Ridsdale, who is married with two young children, established his business acumen in retail management with the Burton Group and, more specifically, with the Top Man brand.

When Caspian bought the club from the former chairman Bill Fotherby and two other directors, it immediately installed Ridsdale in a challenging dual role.

He is also a rising star among Premiership chairmen and is definitely in the "one to watch" category in football's hierarchy.

Arsenal's David Dein narrowly beat him to the vice-chairmanship of the Football Association recently. The newish kid on the block will not have to camp outside the offices of the Premier League or the FA when new opportunities arise.

webTitle: Hughes loses taste for scrambled Egil

fields.headline: Hughes loses taste for scrambled Egil
fields.trailText: Egil Olsen has apologised for calling Michael Hughes "not good enough" defensively, but the rift between the Wimbledon player of the year and his manager seems irreparable.
fields.body:
Egil Olsen has apologised for calling Michael Hughes "not good enough" defensively, but the rift between the Wimbledon player of the year and his manager seems irreparable. "If Egil stays," Hughes said yesterday, "I'll be looking to move."

Hughes made his first start since August in a 2-1 defeat at his former club West Ham last month and scored a spectacular 30-yard goal. But Olsen accused the Northern Ireland international midfielder of making "big mistakes" in defence and being responsible for the first West Ham goal.

"Defensively he isn't good enough for the team," Olsen said. "We probably have to use him in a position where he doesn't do too much damage in defence."

When Hughes sought a meeting with Olsen, the former Norway manager admitted that he might not have expressed himself in English as precisely as he would have liked.

"I'm not strong defensively but I'm not weak," Hughes said yesterday. "If you want to play with a left-winger who is a better defender than an attacker, then play a left-back."

He has three years left on his contract but looks likely to be one of several players leaving this summer. Jason Euell has made his disaffection public and John Hartson, Ben Thatcher, Carl Cort and Neil Sullivan are the subjects of persistent speculation.

 Jens Jeremies has been suspended for one international match for calling the German national team "pitiful", but other members of the team have come out in agreement with the midfielder.

"Basically he is right," said the defender Markus Babbel. "Everybody is dissatisfied," said the striker Ulf Kirsten.

 The Internazionale and Brazil striker Ronaldo became a father yesterday. His wife Milene gave birth to a 6lb 4oz son they have already decided to call Ronald - because they both like McDonald's.

webTitle: Chelsea find ideal blend for Europe

fields.headline: Chelsea find ideal blend for Europe
fields.standfirst: Barca beaten by combination of British grit and foreign flair
fields.trailText: Martin Thorpe The laboratories of Stamford Bridge are leading the way in creating what may be the perfect footballer: a hybrid combining the touch and vision of the foreigner with the passion and spirit of the British.
fields.body:
When Stamford Bridge reverberated to the stirring strains of Land of Hope and Glory after Wednesday's heroic win, it bordered on the surreal.

Here were 30,000-odd Chelsea fans celebrating a mighty triumph over a foreign foe - by a team containing nine foreigners. But international understanding and cooperation in SW6 is nothing new. In fact, entente cordiale is the reason for Chelsea's new place in the world order.

The laboratories of Stamford Bridge are leading the way in creating what may be the perfect footballer: a hybrid combining the touch and vision of the foreigner with the passion and spirit of the British.

Chelsea's ability to knock Barcelona out of their aristocratic stride was built on a classic domestic foundation of pressing the man on the ball all over the pitch. That achieved, Chelsea's foreign legion turned on a few native tricks: Gianfranco Zola's delightfully curled free-kick: 1-0; Zola's perfect cross to Tore Andre Flo: 2-0; Didier Deschamps' clever volleyed pass for Flo to lob the keeper: 3-0.

To the purist Chelsea's performance may not have been an awesome spectacle but as an exercise in fitting a strategy to a task it was near perfect. It is this tactical adaptability which potential semi-final opponents will have underscored in their notebooks.

The one blot on the blue horizon was the away goal scored by Luis Figo. It was the lifebelt to which a shocked Barcelona clung after the match. "We have scored a goal that I think will have a great value in the return match," said the midfielder Xavi. "It was a very bad result. But now, with the 3-1, we are convinced that we can win."

Barca would be foolish to underestimate Chelsea again. Gianluca Vialli's men enjoy playing on the counter-attack in Europe and, with Barcelona needing a 2-0 win to deny Chelsea a semi-final place, there should be space at the back for Flo and Zola to exploit.

Flo is flowing. His Champions League tally of seven goals is only two behind the leading scorers, Porto's Jardel and Lazio's Simone Inzaghi, and he is also three goals away from becoming the first Chelsea player to hit 20 in a season since Kerry Dixon in 1990.

Of course, the other bonus that comes with Chelsea foreigners is their vast experience. So the intimidating atmosphere of a packed Nou Camp a week on Tuesday may not be so intimidating after all.

One word of caution: Barca's midfield playmaker Josep Guardiola is likely to return for the second leg, having failed a late fitness test on Wednesday. He was badly missed.

Overall, though, Chelsea go into Sunday's FA Cup semi-final against Newcastle increasingly confident that their Frankenstein team are heading for... well, a monster season.

The odds on an all-English Champions League final have been cut from 12-1 to 9-2. William Hill makes Bayern Munich 5-2 favourites, with Manchester United at 11-4, Chelsea 4-1, Valencia 5-1 and Barcelona 9-1.

fields.headline: Bergkamp only scratches Lens
fields.standfirst:
Arsenal fail to capitalise on the Dutchman's sweetly taken early goal
Bergkamp 2
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger always insists before Uefa Cup ties at Highbury that he would be happy with a victory and a clean sheet. The Arsenal manager got both last night but he must have been less than pleased with a poor performance that lacked fluency and a cutting edge.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger always insists before Uefa Cup ties at Highbury that he would be happy with a victory and a clean sheet. The Arsenal manager got both last night but he must have been less than pleased with a poor performance that lacked fluency and a cutting edge.

After Dennis Bergkamp had given them the perfect start, scoring inside two minutes, Arsenal stuttered against a hard-working, defensive Lens. The return in a fortnight does not promise to be easy and would have been far trickier had Pascal Nouma not wasted a glorious chance near the end.

Wenger must have expected a victory to avenge last season's Champions League defeat by Lens at Wembley. The Arsenal manager regards that as one of the most disappointing moments of his time at Highbury, along with October's defeat by Fiorentina and losing to Leeds at Elland Road last May.

Everything had pointed to an Arsenal win. In their three previous Uefa Cup ties at Highbury Wenger's side had scored 10 goals and conceded only one. A run of five successive victories suggested that they had finally recaptured their best form after a season riddled with injuries and inconsistency.

Arsenal, deprived of Thierry Henry because of suspension and Tony Adams through injury, were not at their strongest. But no sooner had a botched attempt at a one-minute silence for the dead Leeds fans passed than they took the lead. Only 96 seconds had gone.

Emmanuel Petit was the creator deep in the midfield, sliding through a pass for Bergkamp to accelerate on to. Showing a cool head and his usual impeccable technique, the Dutchman clipped the ball beyond the reach of the oncoming goalkeeper Guillaume Warmuz and stroked it into the empty net.

Quicker than you could say Lens, never mind anything more complicated, the French side's gameplan had been ripped up. They had arrived hoping to keep a clean sheet, as they had at Celta Vigo in the last round, by getting as many bodies as possible behind the ball. Now they had to be more adventurous.

There was no mistaking Arsenal's adventure. With Marc Overmars making encouraging ground down the left flank and Bergkamp flitting around dangerously, they should have increased their lead inside the first 25 minutes. Nwankwo Kanu, free to play after getting dispensation to arrive late for Nigeria's World Cup qualifier against Eritrea, had two good headed chances.

The first came in the 10th minute. Picked out by Silvinho's left-wing cross, the tall striker was less than six yards out with only Warmuz to beat but headed down to the keeper's left rather than back across goal and the Lens captain plunged to keep the ball out.

Yet Arsenal were not at their fluent best. Passes regularly went astray and, as Lens recovered and gained momentum, they gave Wenger plenty to worry about. As the first half drew to a close they were on top, playing with great determination and knocking the ball around quickly and neatly.

Kanu and Bergkamp both drop deep to look for the ball and Arsenal missed the outlet that Henry's pace offers them up front. And although they began the second half in brighter fashion than they ended the first, the spark still seemed to be missing. Bergkamp showed his annoy ance by hauling back Coridon, earning himself a booking.

Lens's yellow shorts, which clashed with Arsenal's yellow shirts, may have had something to do with home side's unusual tendency to give the ball away. This was not the Arsenal side who had scored 18 goals in their previous six matches in this competition. Indeed, when Ray Parlour picked out Overmars at the far post, the Dutchman shot over.

Arsenal should have been made to pay when Lens broke quickly, but from Philippe Brunel's cross Nouma shot against the bar from close range with only Seaman to beat.

Arsenal (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Grimandi, Keown, Silvinho; Parlour, Vieira, Petit, Overmars (Ljungberg, 74min); Bergkamp (Suker, 83), Kanu.

Lens (4-1-3-1-1): Warmuz; Sikora, Coly, Mawene, Queudrue; Nyarko; Moreira (Sakho, 79), Blanchard, Brunel; Coridon; Nouma.

Referee: G Benko (Austria)
