The Arsenal manager regards that as one of the most disappointing moments of his time at Highbury, along with October's defeat by Fiorentina and losing to Leeds at Elland Road last May. Everything had pointed to an Arsenal win. In their three previous Uefa Cup ties at Highbury Wenger's side had scored 10 goals and conceded only one. A run of five successive victories suggested that they had finally recaptured their best form after a season riddled with injuries and inconsistency. Arsenal, deprived of Thierry Henry because of suspension and Tony Adams through injury, were not at their strongest. But no sooner had a botched attempt at a one-minute silence for the dead Leeds fans passed than they took the lead. Only 96 seconds had gone. Emmanuel Petit was the creator deep in the midfield, sliding through a pass for Bergkamp to accelerate on to. Showing a cool head and his usual impeccable technique, the Dutchman clipped the ball beyond the reach of the oncoming goalkeeper Guillaume Warmuz and stroked it into the empty net. Quicker than you could say Lens, never mind anything more complicated, the French side's gameplan had been ripped up. They had arrived hoping to keep a clean sheet, as they had at Celta Vigo in the last round, by getting as many bodies as possible behind the ball. Now they had to be more adventurous. There was no mistaking Arsenal's adventure. With Marc Overmars making encouraging ground down the left flank and Bergkamp flitting around dangerously, they should have increased their lead inside the first 25 minutes. Nwankwo Kanu, free to play after getting dispensation to arrive late for Nigeria's World Cup qualifier against Eritrea, had two good headed chances. The first came in the 10th minute. Picked out by Silvinho's left-wing cross, the tall striker was less than six yards out with only Warmuz to beat but headed down to the keeper's left rather than back across goal and the Lens captain plunged to keep the ball out. Yet Arsenal were not at their fluent best. Passes regularly went astray and, as Lens recovered and gained momentum, they gave Wenger plenty to worry about. As the first half drew to a close they were on top, playing with great determination and knocking the ball around quickly and neatly. Kanu and Bergkamp both drop deep to look for the ball and Arsenal missed the outlet that Henry's pace offers them up front. And although they began the second half in brighter fashion than they ended the first, the spark still seemed to be missing. Bergkamp showed his annoy ance by hauling back Coridon, earning himself a booking. Lens's yellow shorts, which clashed with Arsenal's yellow shirts, may have had something to do with home side's unusual tendency to give the ball away. This was not the Arsenal side who had scored 18 goals in their previous six matches in this competition. Indeed, when Ray Parlour picked out Overmars at the far post, the Dutchman shot over. Arsenal should have been made to pay when Lens broke quickly, but from Philippe Brunel's cross Nouma shot against the bar from close range with only Seaman to beat. Arsenal (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Grimandi, Keown, Silvinho; Parlour, Vieira, Petit, Overmars (Ljungberg, 74min); Bergkamp (Suker, 83), Kanu. Lens (4-1-3-1-1): Warmuz; Sikora, Coly, Mawene, Queudrue; Nyarko; Moreira (Sakho, 79), Blanchard, Brunel; Coridon; Nouma. Referee: G Benko (Austria)

webTitle: Tragedy that awaited two fans on a journey to hell

fields.headline: Tragedy that awaited two fans on a journey to hell
fields.standfirst:
Early relaxation gave way to brutal battle as rivals taunted each other
Murder hunt as match goes on
Shocked supporters pay tribute
History of intimidation and violence
Brian Alexander on Peter Ridsdale
fields.trailText: For players and supporters alike, Ali Sami Yen stadium has become one of the most fraught and difficult venues in Europe. But nobody thought the prospect of playing there could lead to murder.
fields.byline: Will Woodward, Rory Carroll, Daniel Taylor  and  David Ward
fields.body:
Hello Hell, We Are Leeds, read one banner carried by fans piling through Istanbul airport on Wednesday night. In fact, the Leeds United supporters, arriving for the first leg of their Uefa Cup semi-final with Galatasaray, were at first greeted in a way which mostly belied the Welcome to Hell banners which have traditionally greeted English teams there.

For players and supporters alike, this has become one of the most fraught and difficult venues in Europe. Fatih Terim, Galatasaray's coach, had whipped up his side's supporters. "Their chanting should make Ali Sami Yen [the Galatasaray stadium] hell for Leeds United."

The manager of Leeds, David O'Leary, had voiced fears of being met at the airport by "a 100-strong rentamob". But he was not and the atmosphere was initially warmer than normal.

But from 10.30pm local time, any sense of complacency seemed tragically misplaced, as a brutal battle began between Leeds supporters and a group of Turks, with running fights in the streets. A few hours later two Leeds supporters, Kevin Speight, 40, and Christopher Loftus, 37, were dead from stab wounds. Mr Loftus from a plunging wound to his heart; Mr Speight, a few hours later after receiving a wound the length of his stomach. At least nine other people, including six Leeds fans, were injured.

Though the versions of Leeds fans and Turkish witnesses are almost entirely at odds, it appears the trouble started in the city's entertainment district outside the Riddim reggae bar in Buyuk Parmakkapi Street. From 5pm local time more than 100 Leeds fans had arrived shouting, singing and demanding beer, according to Batu Dedeler, the bar owner.

"They were screaming all sorts of things. They ordered us to pump up the volume, so we did," said Mr Dedeler, 24. "We did amazing business in one hour. They knocked back as much Elfe (lager), Jack Daniels and Bacardi as I could pour."

"Most were kind, but there were five or six really crazy guys. They carried beer glasses outside, we couldn't stop them, and others followed." Outside, Leeds fans reportedly taunted Turkish men.

More than a dozen police watched but initially did not intervene. According to one witness, a Turkish man was pushed to the ground and smashed his teeth on the pavement. The police claim he was punched.

Scuffles broke out but the police moved in and fans scattered. Some headed for the James Joyce pub 200 metres away and joined a sing-song against Galatasaray. Staff said many fans were drunk by 10pm, intimidating Turkish families drinking in the lounge.

"They were using very bad language," said Abdul Garlad, a manager. "Maybe they thought they were being funny but to Turks who do not speak good English, it was very offensive."

By 10.30pm some of the rowdiest fans left the James Joyce and joined a crowd outside McDonalds just off Taksim Square. A group of rival fans gathered and jeers were exchanged.

According to a waiter at a nearby restaurant, the Turkish club's fanatical fans had heard through the grapevine that trouble was brewing. "They came into town to see. I am not sure if the first few expected fighting but I saw one guy running to a telephone to call his friends after he saw the English. I think those who arrived later knew what to expect."

Within minutes, a pitched battle erupted. British fans were outnumbered and chased up side streets. Fans in nearby bars remained unaware of the violence.

How the violence started is unclear. Some claimed the English sparked it by throwing beer glasses at passing women pedestrians. Others that the Turks precipitated it by throwing chairs.

The Turkish media blamed the Leeds fans. "Once more English hooligans, once more, blood," said the mainstream Hurriyet newspaper. Those killed were "attackers", it said.

But the Leeds fans do not see it that way. They reported that as one of them tried to give the kiss of life to Mr Loftus, he was set upon.

"This was a premeditated attack," said Steve Wilkinson, who suffered knife wounds to one leg and a wound to his hand. "We came out of a bar and there were 100 people waiting for us with machetes, knives, bits of chair and table legs and they just attacked us. The police did nothing, in fact they were helping them beat us up." Others suggested a group of Leeds supporters had attacked a lone Turk, possibly a taxi driver, who had then returned with a mob wielding knives and machetes.

Peter Ridsdale, the Leeds chairman, had been dining with directors from Galatasaray when reports of trouble came through.

He rushed to Taksim hospital, near where the men were stabbed. As injured and angry Leeds fans came through, he did what he could. When the hospital said they were short of blood supplies, Ridsdale sent his chauffeur off to get more. He was with Darren Loftus, Christopher's brother who had travelled with him, to identify his body.

Asked shortly afterwards whether he thought the tie would still go ahead, Mr Ridsdale said: "It's too early to say. I am just trying to come to terms with the fact that I have seen a dead body for the first time in 10 years.

"When you see a man having to identify the body of his brother with a massive stab wound in his chest it just isn't what you'd associate with football."

But eventually the issue of what to do about the game had to be addressed. Uefa, after consultation with the clubs and the Turkish authorities, wavered but eventually decided to go ahead. David Davies, the Football Association's executive director, called it "frankly, the least worst option".

Leeds supporters in Istanbul were told to stay in their hotels. The city centre was tense but, thanks to a massive police presence, mainly empty. Bouncers guarded the bars from any English fans. By last night's kick-off, the pools of blood, shattered glass and debris had been cleared away. "I haven't seen a single Englishman all day," said a newspaper vendor.

Turkish police, according to British of ficials, appeared to be taking the killings as seriously as they would hope. Forty Leeds fans arrested in the scuffles were released without charge.

Twenty Leeds fans, witnesses to the fight, were interviewed. Peter Hunt, the British consul general in Istanbul, had been prepared for potential trouble, as are all consuls and embassies when English fans travel abroad. He had been in touch with the Turkish authorities, and with Chief Superintendent Steve Matthews from West Yorkshire police, who travels abroad with Leeds fans on away trips, and his team of three or four officers acting as "spotters".

"There was nothing in the days running up to this match to suggest there would be this level of violence," Mr Hunt said.

fields.headline: Most wanted:  Gucci toothpaste
fields.trailText: In a recent survey, 68% of respondents admitted to snooping in bathroom cabinets when at other people's houses.
fields.body:
In a recent survey, 68% of respondents admitted to snooping in bathroom cabinets when at other people's houses.

So spending £40 on Gucci toothpaste could be considered a sound investment in your public image, couldn't it? Before you rage too hard against the idiocy of fashion, I should own up that it's not actually £40 just for the tube of toothpaste - it's £40 for a toothbrush and the toothpaste in a monogrammed pouch, and the brush has a Gucci-stamped, matt-black rubber handle. Just don't squeeze too freely, or your smile could end up as expensive as Britney's.

Gucci, 33 Old Bond Street, London W1. Enquiries: 0171 235 6707.

fields.headline: Archer arrested
fields.standfirst: Former Conservative mayoral candidate questioned by police over alleged attempts to pervert the course of justice
fields.trailText: Disgraced Tory peer Jeffrey Archer was arrested and questioned by police today over allegations that he asked a friend to lie for him in the run-up to a libel trial.
fields.body:
Disgraced Tory peer Jeffrey Archer was arrested and questioned by police today over allegations that he asked a friend to lie for him in the run-up to a libel trial.

The millionaire novelist and former Conservative mayoral candidate spent several hours being quizzed at a London police station. He was later released and bailed to return in June.

Scotland Yard confirmed they were interviewing a 59-year-old man over allegations of attempts to pervert the course of justice.

Lord Archer was forced to drop out of the race to become London mayor after admitting he had asked a friend to provide an alibi for a night which the Daily Star alleged he had spent with prostitute Monica Coghlan.

The scandal prompted the Conservative party to expel its former deputy chairman for five years. Conservative central office continued to disown the peer today, saying he had "nothing to do with us".

Lord Archer refused to comment to journalists as he arrived back at his luxury London riverside flat shortly before 5pm after visiting the unnamed police station.

The former Tory grandee has admitted he was a "fool" to ask Ted Francis to say they were dining together when in fact he was dining with "a close personal friend", later revealed to be Andrina Colquhoun. He said he wanted to shield his former personal assistant from publicity.

In the event, the false evidence was not required because the Daily Star changed the date it alleged the encounter with Coghlan took place before the matter came to trial in 1987.

Lord Archer won the case and was awarded a record £500,000 damages.

The Daily Star asked Scotland Yard to investigate whether a criminal offence had been committed when news of the false alibi emerged last year, demanding a £3m repayment of the damages, including interest and costs. Lord Archer has refused, insisting the matter did not affect the trial.

But the paper claims that, had the jury known he was prepared to ask a friend to lie to cover up his meeting with a young woman, it might not have been so ready to accept the heavy play made during the trial by the peer that he was a happily married family man.

Mr Francis said he felt obliged to go public on the false alibi after Lord Archer won the Tory nomination for mayoral candidate.

The Daily Star said it was watching developments "with great interest".

webTitle: Chelsea apply for the Intertoto Cup

fields.headline: Chelsea apply for the Intertoto Cup
fields.trailText: They are fifth in the Premiership, hold a commanding position in their Champions League match against Barcelona, and on Sunday play their FA Cup Semi-Final against Newcastle.
fields.body:
They are fifth in the Premiership, hold a commanding position in their Champions League match against Barcelona, and on Sunday play their FA Cup Semi-Final against Newcastle.

But Chelsea are not yet certain of European competition next season, which perhaps explains why their multi-million pound stars might be trotting out for next season's Intertoto Cup.

Seven Premiership clubs have applied to compete in the universally-derided competition, the FA confirmed today. They are West Ham - who reached the Uefa Cup after winning one of three finals in last season's competition - Aston Villa, Everton, Newcastle, Middlesbrough, Coventry and Chelsea.

The Intertoto Cup is open to the highest placed English club who does not qualify for either the Champions League or Uefa Cup. The English applicant will go into the competition at the third round stage in July. Yet again no Scottish side applied for the tournament.

fields.headline: Bradman honoured, Warne shocked
fields.standfirst: How the players received the news that they were among the five best cricketers of the 20th century
fields.trailText: There was a quick response from two of the four living members of WisdenÍs Five Cricketers of the Century. Don Bradman, speaking from his home in the suburbs of Adelaide, said he was "very honoured to be recognised by Wisden in this way." But the Don, who polled the maximum 100 votes, was equally thrilled for the only member of the elite five still not alive. "I am very pleased that Jack Hobbs was also chosen," he said, "as he was one of my boyhood heroes." Hobbs played his last Test in 1930, two years after Bradman made his international debut.

Don Bradman, speaking from his home in the suburbs of Adelaide, said he was "very honoured to be recognised by Wisden in this way." But the Don, who polled the maximum 100 votes, was equally thrilled for the only member of the elite five still not alive. "I am very pleased that Jack Hobbs was also chosen," he said, "as he was one of my boyhood heroes." Hobbs played his last Test in 1930, two years after Bradman made his international debut.

Shane Warne, the other Australian to be chosen and the only current cricketer among the five, admitted he was shocked but delighted by the decision. "Obviously, it's been a huge couple of months for me, breaking Dennis Lillee's record, being named in the Australian Team of the Century, 10 successive Test wins and now named as one of Wisden's Team of the Century," he said, revealing a slight misunderstanding of the nature of the tribute.

"It's a huge honour being in such company while I am still playing and it's hard to wrap my head around it," Warne went on. "I'm very shocked, as I've not known about it or expected it, and if I had known about it, I would not have expected to be chosen."

fields.headline: When America was well red
fields.standfirst: Peter Lennon on the rise and fall of the leftwing playwrights whose story is dramatised in Tim Robbins's new film, Cradle Will Rock
fields.trailText: It seems hard to believe today that theatre could shake the political system of a continent. But as the Depression hit America, the jobless, the homeless, the exploited and degraded began to forge a mighty weapon to assert their right to justice and just reward, and theatre was that weapon.
fields.body:
It seems hard to believe today that theatre could shake the political system of a continent. But as the Depression hit America, the jobless, the homeless, the exploited and degraded began to forge a mighty weapon to assert their right to justice and just reward, and theatre was that weapon. For a few short years, America was ablaze with such theatrical-inspired leftwing passion that the government had to call out their judicial marines to douse the fires - senator Martin Dies's House Un-American Activities Committee (HUAC). This was a dozen years before the infamous McCarthy era.

Tim Robbins's new film, Cradle Will Rock, is a recreation of one of the legendary moments of this period, when leftwing theatre took a spectacular stand against the growing censorship which was eventually to stifle the entire movement.

There had been radical theatre in the 20s, but this reflected no more than bohemianism and had no notion of propagating political doctrines. As theatre historian Joseph Krutch of Columbia University wrote in his "informal history", The American Drama in 1957: "If theatre looked with a jaundiced eye upon the rich it was more often to expose their vulgarity."

The Depression (which ran from 1929 virtually to the outbreak of the second world war) changed all that. By the mid-30s Uncle Sam was besieged by a startling proliferation of leftwing theatre, an activity which, for a time, was ironically totally government subsidised.

In July 1935, President Roosevelt added the Federal Theatre Project to his New Deal work relief agencies. Hallie Flanagan was appointed national director. Flanagan had produced plays at Harvard and Vassar, but had no experience of the commercial theatre. Her boss, Harry Hopkins, head of the national Works Progress Administration regarded this as a virtue. The intention was not profit, but to get theatre people back to work in the same way as bricklayers and plumbers. But Flanagan had been to Europe to study on a Guggenheim grant (a background later to be the target of the HUAC) and learned about modern theatre. She was given a $46m budget. Seats at the theatres would range from 10 cents to $1. Producers were paid about $200 a month; actors about $55.

The left was in ferment following the rise of Hitler and Mussolini and in 1935 they were presented with the most romantic liberal cause of the century - the Spanish civil war. The Communist party in America had craftily toned down its dogmatism to accommodate hitherto despised socialists and liberals in the Popular Front against fascism. All across America the workers - mostly strikers and the unemployed - began to preach revolt.

Flanagan had no objections. Thrashing around in there with the activists, salvationists and trades unionists were names which were to become legends in Hollywood: Orson Welles, John Houseman, Elia Kazan, Lee J Cobb - even Duke Ellington made a guest appearance. Hemingway briefly became an idol of the Communist party when he created the narrative for Joris Ivens's film, The Spanish Earth.

The first great agitprop play was Waiting for Lefty, written by 28-year-old Clifford Odets, then a member of the Communist party. It was set during the taxi-drivers' strike of 1934 and is essentially a series of turns in which taxi men deliver their stories of poverty, oppression and injustice and clamour for a world "free of fear and falsehood and craven servitude to stupidity and greed". As they wait for Lefty (a Godot of the 30s who never turns up) a taxi man called Agate - his name a play on the word "agitiate" - delivers a passionate speech: "These slick slobs stand here telling us about bogeymen. But the man who gave food to me in 1932, he called me comrade! The one who picked me up where I bled - he called me comrade too!" When the word comes that Lefty has been murdered it is Agate who gives "the birth cry of the 30s": "STRIKE!" "Louder," shouts Agate." "STRIKE! STRIKE! STRIKE!"

Perfidious Destiny must have been sniggering up her sleeve, as Agate was played by Elia Kazan, the future director of On the Waterfront and later reviled as the man who betrayed his Hollywood comrades to McCarthy. Waiting for Lefty was a triumph - a measure of the huge surge of emotion that had seized America whose industrialists - steel in particular - were, literally, making a killing, selling materials to Hitler and Mussolini while grinding the workers underfoot (a popular phrase at the time). Sensationally, Lefty invaded the commercial theatre, moving to Broadway for 78 performances. At one point, Odets wrote, it was playing simultaneously in 62 American cities.

Flanagan replied with a straight face: "Put in the record that he was the greatest dramatist in the period immediately preceding Shakespeare."

"Because it put the fruit of its labour - the productions - before a mass audience, it brought down on itself the implacable hostility of conservative legislators of both parties," wrote Malcolm Goldstein in his 1974 book The Political Stage: American Drama and Theatre of the Great Depression.

fields.headline: The Grand National
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the most famous horse-racing event in the world
fields.trailText: 1. On Saturday, more than 300 horses, 1,000 owners, 100 jockeys and 100,000 visitors will gather for the world's most famous steeplechase, The Grand National. The race, which marks the end of a three-day hoopla at Liverpool's Aintree race course, will be the subject of some serious betting with around £60 million changing hands.
fields.body:
1. On Saturday, more than 300 horses, 1,000 owners, 100 jockeys and 100,000 visitors will gather for the world's most famous steeplechase, The Grand National. The race, which marks the end of a three-day hoopla at Liverpool's Aintree race course, will be the subject of some serious betting with around £60 million changing hands.

2. But the deaths, on Thursday, of four horses at Aintree - one on the National course itself - have cast a shadow over the event and raised fresh questions about the potential risks for horses taking part in Saturday's race. The course is a brutal one. Nearly two and a quarter miles long, it has 16 fences. The horses have to complete almost two circuits followed by a 494-yard finish, which has proved the downfall of many in the past.

3. Among the most dangerous features of the course are the famous drop fences, where the landing side is lower than the take-off side. The horse is unaware of the drop until it is hurtling through the air. Eudip, a top-rated horse, died at the most famous of these, Bechers Brook, last year. That is why groups such as Animal Aid dislike the event.

4. The first official races at Aintree were organised by the owner of Liverpool's Waterloo Hotel, William Lynn, who laid out a course, built a grandstand and staged the first flat fixture in 1829.

5. In 1839, Lottery - carrying 12 stone - became the winner of the first true Grand National, although it was hardly grand in those days. The horses had only to jump a stone wall (now the water jump), cross a stretch of plough land and finish over two hurdles. Since its inception, the event has become famous throughout the world, inspiring, among other things, a number of games.

6. The 1913 race was particularly memorable for tragic reasons. Emily Wilding Davison, a suffragette, rushed on to the course at Tattenham Corner, bringing down the King's horse and killing herself in the process - an event captured on black-and-white newsreel.

7. In 1949, Lord Sefton sold the course to the Topham family, who appointed former Gaiety girl Mirabel Topham to manage it. The redoubtable Mrs Topham built a new track within the established course and opened it in 1953, the same year as the motor circuit which still encircles the track.

8. The motor circuit, another of Mrs Topham's bright ideas, quickly gained a reputation as one of the best in the world, hosting a European Grand Prix and five British Grands Prix. Stirling Moss won his first Jim Clark won in 1962.

9. Aintree suffered some lean times in the post-war years and in 1965 it was announced that the course would be sold to a property developer. Thus began a prolonged period of speculation, which, every year, brought solemn warnings of "the last Grand National". It is now sponsored by Martell, part of the Seagram drinks and entertainment empire.

10. Past winners include L'Escargot and Red Rum. This year, Paul Carberry has been cleared to ride last year's winner, Bobbyjo, which is bidding to become the first horse to achieve back-to-back successes since Red Rum in 1974.

fields.headline: The new karaoke
fields.standfirst: Ever felt the urge to burst into song during Grease? Well, now you no longer have to be gay or a granny to enjoy singing along to musicals in public, says Rupert Smith
fields.trailText: Ever felt the urge to burst into song during Grease? Well, now you no longer have to be gay or a granny to enjoy singing along to musicals in public, says Rupert Smith
fields.body:
Parents: place your infants in front of the television screen one afternoon when BBC2 is showing an old musical. If, within 10 minutes, the child has wandered off to play with its toy cars, you can look forward to grandchildren in about 20 years. If, however, it appears riveted to the screen and performs little dramatic hand gestures - congratulations! You have a homosexual.

Gay people have a special affinity with musical theatre and its louder cinematic incarnation. Scratch even the most hardline post-queer dogmatist and you'll find a chorus girl struggling to kick out. It's a cliche, of course, but like most cliches it's rooted in fact: let us not forget that back in the days of Ivor Novello, "musical" was a euphemism for homosexual. ("Do you think s/he's musical?" "Oh yes, ever so.")

In recognition of this happy fact, the London Lesbian and Gay Film Festival is staging an evening of communal jollity entitled Cine-oke, a sequel to last year's pioneering Sing-Along-A Sound of Music (a phenomenon which, snapped up by some canny West End producers, now has them Edelweissing in the aisles from Land's End to John O'Groats). Brave souls choose in advance their favourite numbers from screen musicals; the NFT's subtitlers get to work, and, on Sunday evening, the whole concept comes together in what the organisers are hoping will be "a raucous cross between a church service and a drag act".

Last year's event was, according to NFT programmer Bryony Hansen, "Extremely emotional. Even the projectionist was crying. I've never known anything that's simultaneously so funny and so moving."

But why? Nobody's kidding themselves that these particular films or songs are in themselves superbly moving works of art. We're talking about Funny Girl, not La Bohème. Musicals are by definition absurd, a strange hybrid form where Salvation Army girls burst into song and dozens of sailors do fancy dances. Gay people in general have a finely tuned sense of the ridiculous, which explains the laughter - but whence the tears?

"Musicals generally present a version of life that is not only camp but also out of the ordinary," says comedian and Cine-oke host Jackie Clune. "For most gay people growing up, life seems pretty extraordinary, and that's what musicals tap into. And it's a very celebratory form, which also appeals. I'm not saying, 'Gosh, all gay people are huge fun!', that's too simplistic, but we do have a real flair for celebration."

For David Blackburn, a 30-year-old administration manager at a Staines software company, the appeal of musicals is even more direct. "As a teenager I was fat, I had terrible acne, I thought I looked like Quasimodo and I dimly realised that I was gay. That's not a great combination to grow up with. The only thing that I could do well was sing. I fell in love with musicals because they seemed to be the only thing that offered me a chance of being happy."

On Sunday evening, Blackburn will be giving the world his interpretation of Don't Rain on My Parade from the 1968 film of Funny Girl, starring Barbra Streisand.

"A few friends suggested that I should drag up," he says, "but that's not the point. It's about me as a man singing along with Barbra. Besides which I'd have to shave off my beard if I was going to do it properly. I shall probably have a few judicious hand props, like the big bunch of yellow roses she brandishes. And I've got the hand gestures off by heart: she screams at the beginning of the song, then it's hands down, hands up to the face. I shall probably have to do a little circuit of the stage in the middle of the song, as Babs indeed does."

Clearly this is a scene that Blackburn has watched more than once. "I saw Funny Girl on BBC2 one Saturday afternoon when I was eight or nine, and I've been a complete musical-theatre diva ever since. Of course, at that age I didn't know who Babs was; I just knew the music was fantastic. The music always comes first. I'm also a huge Judy [Garland] fan, and I'm forever explaining to my friends that it's not just because she's a gay icon. I love her voice, that raw quality. But my house isn't a tragic shrine to Babs and Judy. I don't have a single picture of either of them on the wall, although I do own a lot of soundtrack recordings."

Pressed a little further, Blackburn admits that there's more to musicals than music. "There's a great quote from Elizabeth Taylor: 'The trouble with life is bad lighting, no score.' I often wish that on a cold, grey afternoon I could burst into song and the whole cafe would join in with me and know the choreography. It's partly to do with escapism, but also because all the great musicals have an element of defiance in them. When you've got Babs up there singing, 'Don't tell me not to fly, I've simply got to . . . ,' then obviously that's going to have massive resonances for gay people. It all boils down to 'I am what I am'. You have to remember that a lot of these shows were created by gay people at a time when it wasn't easy to express your sexuality directly, and so there's a huge repressed energy to do with love and identity that's just bursting out of these songs. Plus, when you're writing for someone like Ethel Merman, you're upping the camp quotient by about a million."

This is not to suggest that musicals are strictly a gay art form. The Sing-Along-A Sound of Music shows, now touring the country, appeal to old ladies, mothers with children, drag queens and businessmen alike.

"Last week I hosted a show in Wolverhampton where a huge group of middle managers all turned up dressed as Nazis," says a worried Jackie Clune. "For them I think it's not so much the emotional or camp appeal of the musical, it's the event itself. It's the dressing up. For a lot of middle England, this is the most daring thing they've ever done in their lives, and it's really fantastic for them.

"When I go on local radio stations to promote the tour, I get nervous presenters asking me, 'This isn't just a gay thing, is it? I mean, we don't want our listeners to be surrounded by hundreds of screaming faggots.' But it's really not. It's grannies sitting next to drag queens. It's the new Britain - at least for those three hours."

Returning to its festival roots, however, the singalong phenomenon will rediscover its primary audience. "When we came up with the Sound of Music thing, we didn't realise what we'd stumbled across," says Bryony Hansen. "Other people took the idea and made a lot of money out of it. This year, obviously, there was a lot of pressure on us to repeat the trick. We considered Cabaret, but that was a bit too close to The Sound of Music with the Nazi content. And really, there's no other film that has such universal appeal, where everyone knows the songs and has an emotional connection with the story. So we've broadened the scope, and we're hoping for great things. I'm expecting to be amazed by the passion that people bring to the event, because these songs, these moments from films, mean a great deal."

Jackie Clune, meanwhile, is considering her own Cine-oke choice. "I haven't quite decided," she says, "but I'm tending towards Sandy, the big John Travolta number from Grease. I just want to hear the whole of the NFT bellowing 'Oh Sandy, bay-ay-bee, can't you see? . . .'"

 Cine-oke is at the National Film Theatre, South Bank, London SE1 (0171-928 3232) this Sunday from 6pm.

For David Blackburn, a 30-year-old administration manager at a Staines software company, the appeal of musicals is even more direct. "As a teenager I was fat, I had terrible acne, I thought I looked like Quasimodo and I dimly realised that I was gay. That's not a great combination to grow up with. The only thing that I could do well was sing. I fell in love with musicals because they seemed to be the only thing that offered me a chance of being happy." On Sunday evening, Blackburn will be giving the world his interpretation of Don't Rain on My Parade from the 1968 film of Funny Girl, starring Barbra Streisand. "A few friends suggested that I should drag up," he says, "but that's not the point. It's about me as a man singing along with Barbra. Besides which I'd have to shave off my beard if I was going to do it properly. I shall probably have a few judicious hand props, like the big bunch of yellow roses she brandishes. And I've got the hand gestures off by heart: she screams at the beginning of the song, then it's hands down, hands up to the face. I shall probably have to do a little circuit of the stage in the middle of the song, as Babs indeed does." Clearly this is a scene that Blackburn has watched more than once. "I saw Funny Girl on BBC2 one Saturday afternoon when I was eight or nine, and I've been a complete musical-theatre diva ever since. Of course, at that age I didn't know who Babs was; I just knew the music was fantastic. The music always comes first. I'm also a huge Judy [Garland] fan, and I'm forever explaining to my friends that it's not just because she's a gay icon. I love her voice, that raw quality. But my house isn't a tragic shrine to Babs and Judy. I don't have a single picture of either of them on the wall, although I do own a lot of soundtrack recordings." Pressed a little further, Blackburn admits that there's more to musicals than music. "There's a great quote from Elizabeth Taylor: 'The trouble with life is bad lighting, no score.' I often wish that on a cold, grey afternoon I could burst into song and the whole cafe would join in with me and know the choreography. It's partly to do with escapism, but also because all the great musicals have an element of defiance in them. When you've got Babs up there singing, 'Don't tell me not to fly, I've simply got to . . . ,' then obviously that's going to have massive resonances for gay people. It all boils down to 'I am what I am'. You have to remember that a lot of these shows were created by gay people at a time when it wasn't easy to express your sexuality directly, and so there's a huge repressed energy to do with love and identity that's just bursting out of these songs. Plus, when you're writing for someone like Ethel Merman, you're upping the camp quotient by about a million." This is not to suggest that musicals are strictly a gay art form. The Sing-Along-A Sound of Music shows, now touring the country, appeal to old ladies, mothers with children, drag queens and businessmen alike. "Last week I hosted a show in Wolverhampton where a huge group of middle managers all turned up dressed as Nazis," says a worried Jackie Clune. "For them I think it's not so much the emotional or camp appeal of the musical, it's the event itself. It's the dressing up. For a lot of middle England, this is the most daring thing they've ever done in their lives, and it's really fantastic for them. "When I go on local radio stations to promote the tour, I get nervous presenters asking me, 'This isn't just a gay thing, is it? I mean, we don't want our listeners to be surrounded by hundreds of screaming faggots.' But it's really not. It's grannies sitting next to drag queens. It's the new Britain - at least for those three hours." Returning to its festival roots, however, the singalong phenomenon will rediscover its primary audience. "When we came up with the Sound of Music thing, we didn't realise what we'd stumbled across," says Bryony Hansen. "Other people took the idea and made a lot of money out of it. This year, obviously, there was a lot of pressure on us to repeat the trick. We considered Cabaret, but that was a bit too close to The Sound of Music with the Nazi content. And really, there's no other film that has such universal appeal, where everyone knows the songs and has an emotional connection with the story. So we've broadened the scope, and we're hoping for great things. I'm expecting to be amazed by the passion that people bring to the event, because these songs, these moments from films, mean a great deal." Jackie Clune, meanwhile, is considering her own Cine-oke choice. "I haven't quite decided," she says, "but I'm tending towards Sandy, the big John Travolta number from Grease. I just want to hear the whole of the NFT bellowing 'Oh Sandy, bay-ay-bee, can't you see? . . .'"  Cine-oke is at the National Film Theatre, South Bank, London SE1 (0171-928 3232) this Sunday from 6pm.

fields.headline: A Lowe, dishonest decade
fields.standfirst: John Patterson's weekly guide to the US movie chart-toppers
fields.trailText: John Patterson's weekly guide to the US movie chart-toppers
fields.body:
Remember the Brat Pack? No, me neither. Well I wish that were true, but the memories are all too clear. One spirals back down through a decade and a half to the blistering summer of 1984, when dinosaurs really did rule the earth. Ronald Reagan, then in the thick of a jingo-tastic, triumphalist re-election campaign, crowed that it was "Morning in America" (the B-feature was Mourning in Nicaragua) and that he and his fellow Republicans were engaged in the construction of "a shining city on a hill".

It all fell apart about a year after the Gipper was sworn in for his second term, what with the 1987 Crash, the feelgood fascism of Oliver North, and the indictment of a record-breaking number of Reagan appointees formerly engaged in the construction of said shining city, which now looked more like a stinking privy in a swamp.

But the 18 months from the 1984 campaign to the end of 1985 were the high tide of every stereotype one associates with what Robert Hughes (quoting WH Auden) called "that low, dishonest decade": plinkety-plink, computerised synth-pop confected by back-combed, style-phobic clones in narrow lapels and those ghastly skinny leather ties; shark-like yuppie insects in red braces selling dumpster-sized apartments and junk bonds to credulous grandmas at obscene prices; and aesthetically offensive art from the likes of Robert Longo and Julian Schnabel (neither of whom flourished in Hollywood - have you seen Longo's Johnny Mnemonic? Don't). And it was the dawn of MTV, which back then had a playlist of about 15 videos, most of them apparently by A Flock of Seagulls, the Bush of their time.

And at the movies we had the Brat Pack, which for the sake of convenience we shall limit to the combined casts of The Breakfast Club and St Elmo's Fire, a double bill I know Satan is saving especially for the day I arrive in Hell - he's got my Clockwork Orange eyeclips all ready. It's a bizarre-looking list: Judd Nelson, Molly Ringwald, Emilio Estevez, Ally Sheedy, Demi Moore, and Rob Lowe. If you examine their respective destinies in the years since, it's like reading a dozen riches-to-rags Preston Sturges scripts one after another, chilling evidence of the transience of success and cheap renown. I was privileged to hear both Ally Sheedy and Molly Ringwald reading their moronic confessional poetry aloud in snooty LA bookstores in 1985. Since then, nothing from either, until Sheedy did High Art. Estevez has long since been outshone, out-drunk, out-drugged and out-hookered by his indefatigable brother Charlie "Call Me Charles" Sheen. They'll soon be seen together - for the first time since, uh, Men at Work - as feuding 70s sex-club kingpins Jim and Artie Mitchell for Showtime (zero dollars on that gig). Charlie will don a baldie-wig. Emilio will shoot him.

Demi Moore subsequently rose to the highest point in the Hollywood landscape and is currently plummeting all the way back down again. Judd Nelson, who now plays Brooke Shields' boss on Suddenly Susan, later hooked up with 90210's champion tantrum-flinger Shannen Doherty, who once screamed at their neighbour, "You don't live here, bitch! You only rent!" The neighbour was Molly Ringwald.

And finally, Rob Lowe - whom I must thank for all the hours of amusement I and millions of others have enjoyed at his expense. I have a copy of The Tape, the cheesy sex-vid that cost Rob his career when it was circulated at the 1984 Democratic Convention. Whenever I throw a party, that tape is playing on one of the TVs in the house. I always make sure I turn the sound up to 11 when Rob's incredibly wasted mate exhorts the incredibly wasted Rob to "Fuck her, Rob! Fuck her real good, man!"; even though it's horribly apparent that Rob can't muster enough wood for the task in hand. The dub copies I end up making for enthusiastic guests are just part of my ongoing revenge for Oxford Blues.

The Pack were interviewed en masse by Premiere in 1985, about a year before their collective consignment to the shithouse of oblivion. I remember nothing of what they said - why would I? - but I do recall they all owned the same kind of Jeep and they all had only one album: Bruce Springsteen's Born in the USA, the emetic, terrifyingly ubiquitous soundtrack to the era.

Which brings us not very neatly to High Fidelity, which at number five, wasn't the week's biggest new release - that honour goes to the numbskull thriller at number three, The Skulls - though it was certainly the best. Springsteen appears briefly in the movie as himself, in a Play It Again Sam cameo, dispensing advice to a lovelorn John Cusack, the one young actor I liked in 1985 - for The Sure Thing - and still like today.

There was all sorts of proprietary whingeing about Nick Hornby's novel being relocated to Chicago, but the book's appeal is sufficiently universal to survive the transition. Who knows, if it had been made in England we might have had another Fever Pitch on our hands or, God help us, another Metroland. As it is, the presence of director Stephen Frears ensures that the spirit of the novel arrives onscreen intact.

Cusack is carving out a niche for himself with what I hope will be a long series of mid-budget movies like this and the hitman comedy Grosse Pointe Blank. As an actor in, say, Pushing Tin or Con Air, Cusack always looks a bit lost, but on his chosen ground, he's comfortable and energetic, all charisma and perfect timing. Plus he always clears a space for his sister Joan, the funniest actress on the planet (she's the nearest thing we have to Eve Arden).

In High Fidelity he's supported by, among others, Lisa Bonet, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Lily Taylor, Sara Gilbert and his friend Tim Robbins. The real discovery is Jack Black, playing one of "the musical moron twins" who work in Rob's record store. He's the quintessential rock'n'roll Stalinist, issuing diktats on what albums it's OK to like and which are the veriest shite, always saying things like, "Belle and Sebastian suck ass!" and "Well, if you must know, my band's influences are mainly German." ("Like what?" Cusack retorts. "Krautrock? Falco? Hasselhoff?"). Jack Black, I predict, will be back.

Which leaves us waiting for the film of Bridget Jones's Diary, High Fidelity's female doppelganger, which may not fare as well with drippy Renee Zellweger as Hornby has with Cusack. I predict another London tourist movie in the Notting Hill mould from what's fast becoming the Helen Fielding-Richard Curtis Britcomedy cartel. I bet that it too will "suck ass". Any takers?

webTitle: Met joins family in new Telford hangings appeal

fields.headline: Met joins family in new Telford hangings appeal
fields.standfirst: Two men found dead suffered racially motivated death threats, family tells police
fields.trailText: The head of the Metropolitan police's racial and violent crime taskforce today joined the family of two black men found hanged in a new appeal for information about the deaths they believe may have been racially motivated.
fields.body:
The head of the Metropolitan police's racial and violent crime taskforce today joined the family of two black men found hanged in a new appeal for information about the deaths they believe may have been racially motivated.

John Grieve, whose taskforce investigated the murder of Stephen Lawrence and brought about the successful prosecution of the killers of Michael Menson, said the deaths of Harold "Errol" McGowan and his nephew, Jason, posed "a series of unanswered questions" and were now being investigated under the presumption of foul play.

The McGowan family claims the police initially assumed the hangings were suicides. Harold, 34, was found dead on July 2 last year and Jason, 20, was found hanging from railings on New Year's Day. Neither had any history of depression, but family members reported both men had suffered death threats and harassment from far-right groups.

Jason's widow, Sinead McGowan, urged people in Telford not to be "bystanders" during the police inquiry and to contact officers if they had any information.

West Mercia police detective superintendent Mel Shore appealed for information about two people said to have visited Errol's Telford home on the day he died.

"Obviously, these people are crucial to our investigation. So far they have not come forward."

He added that detectives were anxious to establish Jason McGowan's movements after he left a Telford pub on New Year's Eve.

Officers need to "fill in" the gap between when Jason left the pub shortly before midnight and when he was found hanging from railings at about 6am on New Year's Day.

Earlier this year, the dead men's family met home secretary Jack Straw to discuss alleged police mishandling of the investigation.

The family was told in February that Mr Grieve would provide "support and advice" to West Mercia officers, who have failed to find any evidence of foul play.

webTitle: Dyke pledges to double ethnic minority staff in top BBC jobs

fields.headline: Dyke pledges to double ethnic minority staff in top BBC jobs
fields.standfirst:
Race in the Media awards: Meera Syal named personality of the year

The winners in full
The nominations in full
fields.trailText: The BBC's new director-general, Greg Dyke, today pledged to double the number of BBC management staff from ethnic minorities.
fields.body:
The BBC's new director-general, Greg Dyke, today pledged to double the number of BBC management staff from ethnic minorities.

Mr Dyke, who was speaking at the Commission for Racial Equality's annual Race in the Media Awards, co-sponsored by Guardian Unlimited, said that the BBC "could do better" in its portrayal of ethnic minorities, and he intended to ensure that the corporation reflected "the society in which we live". He also announced a new 10% target for ethnic minority staff at the BBC, up from the present target of 8%, which has been reached.

Actress and writer Meera Syal won the media personality of the year award, Yasmin Alibai-Brown received a special award for outstanding journalistic contribution, and the Express was the winner in the national newspaper category for its Save Ben James campaign.

The Race in the Media awards recognise journalists, producers and organisations which promote issues of race equality in the most balanced and responsible way. "Everyone who works in the media industry has huge influence. Huge responsibility," CRE chairman Gurbux Singh told the audience at the Savoy Hotel in London.

Mr Dyke said recruitment policies were "only part of the equation".

"We still too often portray ethnic minorities as problem centred - bugged by crime, bad housing, poor schooling, poverty. We rarely rate the high performers, the entrepreneurs, the innovators, the risk takers, the campaigners. We need a new model that reflects today's world."

Other winners were BBC Online's Network Asia website, the Big Issue for its asylum seekers campaign, Channel Four's A Blagger's Guide to Black History and Nightshift and Granada's documentary, The Murder of Stephen Lawrence. HHCL & Partners took the advertising prize for the Egg campaign, I'm The Token Black Man.

fields.headline: All things to all worshippers
fields.standfirst: After 15 years, the Church of England has finally released a version of its new prayer book, Common Worship. Stephen Bates, the Guardian's religious affairs correspondent, asks if the church has finally got it right
fields.trailText: The Church of England's agreed new prayer book, Common  Worship - currently in an abbreviated paperback version dropping through the  letterboxes of all 24,000 members of its clergy - is a handsome work.
fields.body:
The Church of England's agreed new prayer book, Common Worship - currently in an abbreviated paperback version dropping through the letterboxes of all 24,000 members of its clergy - is a handsome work.

It has been 15 years in the making, undergoing 22 liturgical revisions, and will be available in a range of leather, leatherette, plastic and paper bindings, and sizes, for church attenders from Advent in November, when it will replace the much derided Alternative Service Book.

The Church has been desperate to get it right, not only theologically and spiritually, but also ergonomically (the book has had to go through what is known as the baby-in-the-arm test - readable by anyone holding it in one hand while wrestling a small child under the other) and - perhaps more importantly - politically and literally.

The ASB, originally issued as an interim 10-year stop-gap 20 years ago, has been much criticised for its flat, modern language and consequent deadening of the magisterial 16th and 17th Century English prose of Thomas Cranmer, the archbishop who composed the Book of Common Prayer in 1549.

Some even say it has alienated congregations and led to an exodus from the pews, as if believers have diminished on Sundays solely as a result of the absent rich cadences of Tudor English.

Common Worship restores some of that but it also retains modern prose, in an attempt to bind the internal liturgical divisions - symptomatic of other splits - which continue to bedevil the C of E.

It is, in other words, an attempt to be all things to all communicants - expressing belief in so many ways that perhaps content is sacrificed to form.

And that, some would say, is the nub of the Church's current problems.

webTitle: No more excuses, says Hague, as Tories set Romsey poll date for May 4

fields.headline: No more excuses, says Hague, as Tories set Romsey poll date for May 4
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservatives yesterday combined the launch of their effort to humiliate Labour in next month's local elections with a less confident decision to stage the Romsey byelection on the same day.
fields.body:
The Conservatives yesterday combined the launch of their effort to humiliate Labour in next month's local elections with a less confident decision to stage the Romsey byelection on the same day.

William Hague went to the racecourse in Liberal Democrat controlled Windsor to urge voters in 152 council areas to "send a message to Tony Blair" on May 4 that "they are fed up with his pathetic excuses, that it's time he started doing what he promised".

But Tory HQ's decision to use May 4 - the date of the London mayor election - to stage the Romsey byelection suggests they may be seeking to "bury" a tight contest with the Liberal Democrats in affluent south Hampshire.

Romsey was held, since the mid-80s, by Michael Colvin, who died in February with his wife in a fire. His majority was 8,585 after an 11.8% swing to the Liberal Democrats in 1997.

With the Tories enjoying a modest revival in the south, Liberal Democrat hopes must be slender, but they have a local candidate against an "outsider" from Dorset, and Labour's 9,632 votes could be the object of tactical voting in the first direct Lib-Dem/Tory contest since 1997.

In reality the Liberal Democrats are braced for some losses to Mr Hague's troops in southern England on May 4, though they hope to make gains at Labour's expense in the Midlands and north. Mr Hague refused to be drawn on target numbers yesterday, but wants to boost his prestige and party morale with 400-plus gains. He repeated his theme that the government had failed middle Britain and was piling on stealth taxes.

In reality the Liberal Democrats are braced for some losses to Mr Hague's troops in southern England on May 4, though they hope to make gains at Labour's expense in the Midlands and north. Mr Hague refused to be drawn on target numbers yesterday, but wants to boost his prestige and party morale with 400-plus gains. He repeated his theme that the government had failed middle Britain and was piling on stealth taxes.

fields.headline: What took you so long?
fields.standfirst: Having spent years enduring poorly fitting clothes, disabled people are finally being recognised by designers. Red or Dead, Helen David English Eccentrics and Marks and Spencer are about to take part in a groundbreaking fashion show.  Michael Shamash  welcomes it
fields.trailText: The word "style" is everywhere. It seems to be applied to every nuance of life these days. Every newspaper in the land now has a style section, and many department stores have in-store style magazines. But although the concept of "style" is ubiquitous nowadays, who exactly is it available to? Disabled people have been conspicuously missing from this upsurge of interest in all things fashion-related. None of the numerous television programmes, labels and magazines seem to have paid much attention to the aesthetically conscious disabled person. It's as if such a group doesn't exist.
fields.body:
The word “style” is everywhere. It seems to be applied to every nuance of life these days. Every newspaper in the land now has a style section, and many department stores have in-store style magazines. But although the concept of “style” is ubiquitous nowadays, who exactly is it available to? Disabled people have been conspicuously missing from this upsurge of interest in all things fashion-related. None of the numerous television programmes, labels and magazines seem to have paid much attention to the aesthetically conscious disabled person. It’s as if such a group doesn’t exist.

Disabled people all have their own ghastly fashion anecdotes. For myself, as a person of restricted growth, it was poorly altered trousers that made me appear to be single-handedly launching a campaign to bring back loon pants. Yet all of us would like to dress better than we do. We do have flair and élan - it just has not been recognised.

Happily, things are now changing. It is belatedly being acknowledged that disabled people can make a vital contribution to the fashion scene. One major sign that the narrow scope of the fashion industry is becoming widened is that Artsline, London’s arts and entertainment information service for disabled people, is holding a disability-aware fashion show next week. Called In Our Fashion, it will set out to examine the disabled person’s contribution to fashion, and in doing so will hopefully encourage more disabled people to get involved in the industry.

“In Our Fashion, like the core of Artsline’s work, is concerned with awareness, attitude and education,” says the show’s producer, Barrie Addenbrooke. “It gives a platform for disabled people to show their individuality through personal style in an integrated arena.” The list of participants includes well-known designers such as Red or Dead and Helen David English Eccentrics, high street giants Marks and Spencer, avant garde designer Bourhan Basma, young designer Samantha Noble, who is a deaf person, and specialist disabled persons’ clothing company, Wearable Clothing. The show will be hosted by the disabled actor/musician Mat Fraser, who is currently presenting the Channel 4 series Freak Out and is appearing in a new series, Metrosexuality. The models will be both disabled and able-bodied. The intention is to show the involvement of disabled people at every stage of the process of creating fashion.

Red or Dead’s Wayne Hemingway, one of the key participants in the show, says: “Fashion needs a kick up the arse. The fashion industry needs to be more accepting and adopt a more ethical stance on who it dresses and how. Fashion has always been an extension of personality, and fashion styles need to be created which reflect the richness of disabled people’s lives.” Instead of constantly rehashing the same over-simplified concept of beauty, Hemingway says, there should be a greater emphasis on the particular beauty of every individual person.

But how can this be realistically achieved? Hemingway concedes that the economics of the fashion industry will not allow all sizes and shapes to be catered for. He sees the industry as too reliant on long production runs for people of uniform shape. He believes, however, that a more responsive alteration service should be provided at fashion outlets by trained staff free of charge.

This is certainly a move that would be welcomed by disabled people. For my part, I have to go to the teenage section in any department store, where I make do with scaled-down versions of adult clothes. Some teenage sections, of course, stock clothes that look too young for me - John Lewis and Selfridges are among the better ones, with a good mixed range. But services in menswear departments could be more flexible. Selfridges does have personal shopping services available for the disabled customer, and says it is examining how the store can best develop services for its disabled clientele.

There are, of course, people with physical impairments who need specially designed clothes. Can these clothes still have real fashion sense? Patricia Watson, owner of the Scottish company Wearable Clothing, creates clothes for wheelchair users and people with a range of other physical impairments. “Fashion makes an immeasurable improvement to the lives of disabled people. It’s very important that clothes fit properly and feel comfortable.”

Wearable sees its clothing as practical and stylish, but not as high fashion. The company was started up after a chance conversation with a man who was having trouble buying clothes for his wife, a wheelchair user. Watson felt she had discovered a niche in the fashion market, and after three years of market research, the company started manufacturing in November 1996. She likens ill-fitting clothing for disabled people to “a jockey wearing a dinner suit”.

She felt that stylish but practical clothing would move the perception of the disabled person away from the widely held stereotype of them wearing tracksuit bottoms and being wrapped up in a tartan rug. Wearable now makes clothing for people with a wide range of disabilities. Among other projects, it is currently designing bathing clothes with the needs of carers in mind, specialist garments for people with behavioural difficulties, and skiwear for the disabled person.

The fashion business could also do with employing more disabled designers. Samantha Noble, a talented young fashion designer at the Somerset College of Art and Technology, is deaf but views her disability as a source of inspiration. “Deafness makes me do more art than others. I do more creative things as I can’t talk.” The creativity of disabled people has not been fully explored, but it needs to be encouraged and supported. Noble’s college has provided help for her in lectures and tutorials in the form of communication support with a signer to ensure her commitment to the course. As David Harvey, the inclusive learning manager at the college, said: “I was happy to recommend Sam for the Artsline show as one of a number of very talented students. She is an excellent example of successful inclusive learning.”

“Disability needs to contribute to a breakdown of the traditional ideals of beauty,” Mat Fraser states unequivocally. “The traditional concept of beauty is far too restrictive - emaciated people looking unhappy with themselves.” Fraser hopes that greater participation by disabled people will reclaim the body beautiful for all. “Ignorance is the real killer.”

One fashion show may only make a small tear in the fabric of the fashion world, but at least it is a step in the right direction towards rethinking disability. As Mat Fraser says: “Let’s hope it breaks down elitism in fashion and gets rid of negative attitudes.”

fields.headline: Swirl power
fields.standfirst: It was once the uniform of moaning Morrissey, but this season's bright paisley is anything but dour - and a top way to update your spring wardrobe.  Laura Craik on the high street's best finds
fields.trailText: Paisley Park is in my heart this season, although as a Prince lover, I need little excuse to don this most majestic of patterns. What a happy day that it's fashionable again this season. As part of a general embracing of all things bold and colourful, file paisley alongside Pucci and polkadots in the pattern lexicon. Taking its lead from the spring collections (which were so loud that all the sunglasses in the front row were justified, for once), the high street is agog with it.
fields.body:
Paisley Park is in my heart this season, although as a Prince lover, I need little excuse to don this most majestic of patterns. What a happy day that it's fashionable again this season. As part of a general embracing of all things bold and colourful, file paisley alongside Pucci and polkadots in the pattern lexicon. Taking its lead from the spring collections (which were so loud that all the sunglasses in the front row were justified, for once), the high street is agog with it.

My first encounter with paisley was through the window of a train on the way to Glasgow airport. Looked all right. My second was as a 15-year-old pseudo Smiths fan with nothing to wear to indie night at the student union (misfits branch). It was 7pm, and I was desperate. I'd just come out of my goth phase: colour still frightened me, so that clothes were only appealing if they were black. From a drawer under her bed, my mother produced a sleeveless silk paisley blouse patterned with swirls in every shade of green. Morrissey's girlfriend herself would have been proud to wear it, had such a creature existed. That night, I was the indie queen, feeling the beat on Mozza's tambourine.

Whatever. Paisley the pattern does in fact come from Paisley the town, so my lousy joke earlier isn't as irrelevant as you thought. In the 19th century, Paisley was chiefly famous for producing fabric; as part of a fad for Indian shawls, many firms there adapted the Kashmiri cone motif and wove it on to large shawls in bright colours. The pattern became known as paisley, and has remained unchanged to the present day. Although now you'll find it on garments as diverse as tights, bikinis, braces and scarves. Inexplicably, it is a particular favourite on old men's pyjamas: presumably as a last ditch attempt to make them look dapper in bed.

As far as the high street goes, the newly revamped River Island has a good selection of paisley stuff at reasonable prices. Some of the best designer fare is by Etro. Looks smashing with jeans, you know.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  one earring
fields.trailText: Last spotted on thugs, Grange Hill pupils and Wham! in the 80s, the single earring is back.
fields.body:
Last spotted on thugs, Grange Hill pupils and Wham! in the 80s, the single earring is back.

Even Posh is a fan, as anyone who spotted David's expensive Van Cleef and Arpels number in OK! will know. The long and dangerous-looking creation pictured is by Wouters & Hendrix, priced £65. If you're too sensible to spend whole money on only half an accessory, why not splash out on some fabulous big round Foxy discs by Givenchy? Keep one and sell the other to an unsuspecting friend. Simple. When it comes to wearing one earring, the longer and more visible the better. Swing your head round swiftly, aiming the earring at your boyfriend's face. If you knock him out, you're too cool for words.

webTitle: A change, a gig and a fit of depression

fields.headline: A change, a gig and a fit of depression
fields.trailText: ALL CHANGE
fields.body:
ALL CHANGE

Cast your mind back, if you dare, to the late 1980s. A time when Maggie's Den was No.10, Yazz ruled the airwaves, and a Hoddlesque light perm and a filofax automatically made you the man. In this time of swirling uncertainties, only football seemed to offer a few unalterable truths: Liverpool won everything, Arsenal were boring and Spurs were sexy. Manchester United? They didn't win a sausage.

Since then everything has changed. Arsenal have become the old Spurs, Liverpool have become the old Arsenal, and Manchester United have become the old Liverpool. Now that's confusing enough, so we don't need Professor Arsene Wenger trying to morph into Fergie. Last night, the Gunners boss blamed his yellow-shirted side's poor performance against yellow-shorted Lens on colour-blindness. "The players saw the yellow and passed towards it," whined Wenger in his best Glasweigan accent. "We asked the referee if we could change our colour but he wouldn't let us." Strangely enough, the Lens players didn't seem to be as worried.

As older readers will recall, Wenger's protests are strikingly similar to Fergie's moaning three years ago when United were thrashed 3-1 at Southampton. Then, the Fergster blamed the defeat on his players not being able to spot each other in their grey shirts. All we need now is for Wenger to buff his nose into a purple-red sheen and start shaking a stopwatch angrily at the referee at the end of each match, and the transformation will be complete.

SATURDAY CAN BE SWEET

Think of us as an tightwad ambassador trying to force cheap chocolate down your scraggy neck. "Why Fiver! With Football Unlimited's unrivalled Saturday service - latest scores, match reports by 7pm and the very best in comment from the Observer - you are really spoiling us!"

NEW MUSICAL EXCESS

Yo, kick-and-rush the show! Trendy music guru MC Fiver is back, keeping you abreast of the latest news whilst simultaneously keeping it real in your homies and hanging with your hood. The latest word on the pavement concerns the Football Association of Wales, who are planning a pre-match musical carnival before their friendly against Brazil on May 23. According to an FAW spokesman, this is because they want to "give the crowd a lift and give the whole stadium a party atmosphere".

So have they planned a joyous samba shindig which will create that special Brazilian festive spirit? Not exactly... step forward earnest troubadours Manic Street Preachers, who will kick off the good times with fun single If You Tolerate This Your Children Will Be Next, a song addressing both the Spanish Civil War and the repeated selection of Mark Pembridge.

Also lined up to "keep the Welsh football buzz going" are the Stereophonics - an inspired choice given that Welsh football is one-paced and without spark or direction. And that's not all - the FAW hope the krazy karnival will also feature pot-head popsters Super Furry Animals, whose single The International Language Of Screaming is likely to be revisited by Welsh manager Mark Hughes after the final whistle. MC Fiver is already queuing for his ticket.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"When I look at my squad and look at all the other squads - and I saw Italy play Spain last week - I can honestly say that with the players we've got, nobody else has got that strength in depth" - Kelvin Koogan's analysis of all the Euro 2000 finalists was just about audible above his loudly flipping lid.

THE ONLY WAY IS DOWN

This week the previews concentrate on the bottom of the Premiership. God we're depressed.

Bradford v Southampton
Bradford can't afford anything but a win, while Southampton hope and pray for the three points which would see them all but safe. Someone's going to go home feeling really low. Robbie Blake is in line for a recall, so either Jorge Cadete, Dean Saunders or Dean Windass will have their day ruined. Saints fans will be slightly cheered by the return of fat-but-loved Matthew Le Tissier, but any momentary happiness will be ruined by the sad news that Claus Lundekvam is still fit. Where's the Prozac?

Sunderland v Wimbledon
Sunderland's 37-year-old defender Steve Bould returns from injury to make his 500th league appearance. It's awful when the best times are behind you. Meanwhile, relegation-haunted Wimbledon welcome back Ben Thatcher and Hermann Hreidarsson, but Carl Cort is still out of action. So where are the goals going to come from? Keep the warm water running!

Watford v Derby
Watford are as good as down, but you never know... a couple of good wins could help. What's that? Suspensions to Mark Williams and Paul Robinson and injuries to Paul Kennedy, Nordin Wooter and Heidar Helgusson have decimated their squad? Aaargh! Derby are unchanged after their pleasing 3-0 trouncing of Leicester, which means Dean Sturridge keeps his place up front alongside Branko Strupar. But they're not out of the woods yet and they're living on their nerves. It's hell living like that, we tell you, hell!

Chelsea v Newcastle (Sunday)
Not technically a relegation battle, because it's an FA Cup semi-final. But misery still waits in the wings. Frank Leboeuf and Jon Harley replace Emerson Thome and Celestine Babayaro in a Chelsea side on a high. The problem with feeling that good, though, is that you've got further to fall when everything goes wrong. As it inevitably will. Steve Howey, Nikos Dabizas, Kevin Gallacher, Nolberto Solano and Diego Gavilan all return to Bobby Robson's squad, but Newcastle, the FA Cup and inner torment always go hand in hand, don't they? Must these black clouds always follow us around?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leeds will bid for Bayern Munich striker Carsten Janker, according to Planet Football. The striker is unlikely to leave his native Germany, however.

Fenerbahce are stepping up their chase for Chelsea's Gianfranco Zola.

NEWS IN BRIEF

A man has confessed to stabbing one of the two Leeds fans killed in clashes before the Uefa Cup semi-final against Galatasaray in Istanbul on Wednesday. Ali Umit Demir told police "I stabbed him" and led them to the knife used in the attack. Police in Istanbul would not say whether Demir was suspected of stabbing Christopher Loftus or Kevin Speight. In all, 13 men are in custody over the trouble including seven being questioned specifically about the killings. Another man is said to be still at large and police are hoping to track him down via one of the other suspects.

Meanwhile, the Turkish Football Association have written to Leeds United to express their sadness at the deaths of Loftus and Speight. "It is not in the spirit of sport and we do not want to see anything like this happening again," said the letter. The TFA's action comes after the FA branded Galatasaray's failure to hold a minute's silence or wear black armbands during last night's Uefa Cup semi-final as "inappropriate".

Jean Tigana has confirmed he has been in contact with Fulham over the vacant manager's job. "If anything's going to happen it will be next week," said the former French midfielder and Monaco boss.

Southampton goalkeeper Paul Jones will undergo surgery this weekend in a bid to cure a back injury that is threatening to end the Welsh international's career. Jones, 32, will have an operation over the weekend to have a disc removed from his back. He will be sidelined for at least the next three months and has been given an 80% chance of making a full recovery.

Falkirk manager Alex Totten has won his third consecutive Bell's Scottish manager of the month award.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm)
Let nation bring fut onto nation.

Cup Heroes (7pm, 11pm)
Featuring David Mellor, Tony Banks and Sepp Blatter.

Hold The Back Page (11.05pm, 3.30am SS2)
In the absence of all things McCaff, it's time to wheel out Brian Woolnough's One Night Noticeboard. "This milk saga is stopping me from working. And sleeping. Tom, you heartless b**t**d! Mat." At the end of your tether? As top rock combo The Gallaghers would say, go let it out - the.boss@theguardian.com.

Sky Sports 3: International Schoolboy Football - Live (8pm)
Young lads with a whole life of failure, speeding fines, money problems, alcoholism, gambling addiction and drug abuse to look forward to.

British Eurosport: Football (5.30pm)
Whoever is head of programme titles at Eurosport is a right slacker get.
