Meanwhile, relegation-haunted Wimbledon welcome back Ben Thatcher and Hermann Hreidarsson, but Carl Cort is still out of action. So where are the goals going to come from? Keep the warm water running! Watford v Derby Watford are as good as down, but you never know... a couple of good wins could help. What's that? Suspensions to Mark Williams and Paul Robinson and injuries to Paul Kennedy, Nordin Wooter and Heidar Helgusson have decimated their squad? Aaargh! Derby are unchanged after their pleasing 3-0 trouncing of Leicester, which means Dean Sturridge keeps his place up front alongside Branko Strupar. But they're not out of the woods yet and they're living on their nerves. It's hell living like that, we tell you, hell! Chelsea v Newcastle (Sunday) Not technically a relegation battle, because it's an FA Cup semi-final. But misery still waits in the wings. Frank Leboeuf and Jon Harley replace Emerson Thome and Celestine Babayaro in a Chelsea side on a high. The problem with feeling that good, though, is that you've got further to fall when everything goes wrong. As it inevitably will. Steve Howey, Nikos Dabizas, Kevin Gallacher, Nolberto Solano and Diego Gavilan all return to Bobby Robson's squad, but Newcastle, the FA Cup and inner torment always go hand in hand, don't they? Must these black clouds always follow us around? THE RUMOUR MILL Leeds will bid for Bayern Munich striker Carsten Janker, according to Planet Football. The striker is unlikely to leave his native Germany, however. Fenerbahce are stepping up their chase for Chelsea's Gianfranco Zola. NEWS IN BRIEF A man has confessed to stabbing one of the two Leeds fans killed in clashes before the Uefa Cup semi-final against Galatasaray in Istanbul on Wednesday. Ali Umit Demir told police "I stabbed him" and led them to the knife used in the attack. Police in Istanbul would not say whether Demir was suspected of stabbing Christopher Loftus or Kevin Speight. In all, 13 men are in custody over the trouble including seven being questioned specifically about the killings. Another man is said to be still at large and police are hoping to track him down via one of the other suspects. Meanwhile, the Turkish Football Association have written to Leeds United to express their sadness at the deaths of Loftus and Speight. "It is not in the spirit of sport and we do not want to see anything like this happening again," said the letter. The TFA's action comes after the FA branded Galatasaray's failure to hold a minute's silence or wear black armbands during last night's Uefa Cup semi-final as "inappropriate". Jean Tigana has confirmed he has been in contact with Fulham over the vacant manager's job. "If anything's going to happen it will be next week," said the former French midfielder and Monaco boss. Southampton goalkeeper Paul Jones will undergo surgery this weekend in a bid to cure a back injury that is threatening to end the Welsh international's career. Jones, 32, will have an operation over the weekend to have a disc removed from his back. He will be sidelined for at least the next three months and has been given an 80% chance of making a full recovery. Falkirk manager Alex Totten has won his third consecutive Bell's Scottish manager of the month award. TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm) Let nation bring fut onto nation. Cup Heroes (7pm, 11pm) Featuring David Mellor, Tony Banks and Sepp Blatter. Hold The Back Page (11.05pm, 3.30am SS2) In the absence of all things McCaff, it's time to wheel out Brian Woolnough's One Night Noticeboard. "This milk saga is stopping me from working. And sleeping. Tom, you heartless b**t**d! Mat." At the end of your tether? As top rock combo The Gallaghers would say, go let it out - the.boss@theguardian.com. Sky Sports 3: International Schoolboy Football - Live (8pm) Young lads with a whole life of failure, speeding fines, money problems, alcoholism, gambling addiction and drug abuse to look forward to. British Eurosport: Football (5.30pm) Whoever is head of programme titles at Eurosport is a right slacker get.

fields.headline: Hurly burly
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Watching the film... is like being in a room with people who have consumed a Mount Kilimanjaro of cocaine, while they shout for about seven hours
fields.body:
Directed by Anthony Drazan and scripted by David Rabe from his stage play, Hurlyburly is about three dysfunctional guys, played by Kevin Spacey, Sean Penn and Chazz Palminteri. They live in the Hollywood Hills and work in and around The Industry. Watching the film - particularly watching Sean Penn - is like being in a room with people who have consumed a Mount Kilimanjaro of cocaine, while they shout for about seven hours.

It starts off with a lot of snap and twang, with a smallish role for Garry Shandling as Artie, a creepy type who shows up at Spacey and Penn's appalling frat-house apartment with Donna (Anna Paquin), some teen jailbait he has picked up in an elevator and whom he now proposes they keep as a "pet". Meg Ryan also has an unlikely walk-on as a good-time girl who does an artistic nude dance act with a balloon. At first, it looks as if Spacey's cool, lightly ironic, infinitesimally camp presence will anchor all this hollering delinquency. But he is disappointingly edged out by the mega-decibel testosterone of Palminteri and Penn. Sean Penn ends up dominating the film, sweating anxiety and rage from every pore. His charisma and screen presence are undeniable, but they seem finally detached from any intelligible motivation or context: all that anger uncoils without direction or effect.

fields.headline: Poor marks
fields.standfirst:
An organic label may be less comforting than you think. There are six different authorities handing out certificates to food manufacturers in the UK - and the standards they set vary wildly. Joanna Blythman investigates

What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Buying organic food used to be so simple. When you saw an organic logo on a box of carrots or loaf of bread, you could relax. As the familiar green lettering on the brown paper bag said, organic food was "food you can   trust", a safe haven from a technofood world.
fields.body:
Buying organic food used to be so simple. When you saw an organic logo on a box of carrots or loaf of bread, you could relax. As the familiar green lettering on the brown paper bag said, organic food was "food you can trust", a safe haven from a technofood world.

It was the environmentalist's magic bullet, a seal of confidence that guaranteed the happiest farm animals, the purest, most natural food and sustainable farming, a brand with a definite feelgood factor. But that was back in the days when the organic food sector was small, struggling and run by people with integrity and a commitment to green ideas.

Now organic is big business. More organic food is being sold by supermarkets, and big industrial food companies are muscling in on the organic market. After BSE, UK shoppers have voted with their feet, fuelling an organic surge. Some 29% of us now buy organic food and it is the only farming sector that's booming.

There's a never-ending flow of new organic lines, many of them "lookalikes" of conventional brands. Some of them have a nutritional profile that is no better (and occasionally worse) than their conventional equivalent. Some even commit the "crimes" that have traditionally irked those in search of wholesome food: overpackaging, overprocessing and taking too many ingredients from far-flung corners of the globe.

Perhaps it was inevitable that when organic food hit the big time, our trust in a generic "organic" brand would be tested. That's what happened last year when the organic movement managed to see off an ill-informed and unjustified smear campaign which tried to link organic food to the E-coli bacterium. (The agri-industrial food establishment is sick of organic food occupying the moral high ground.)

But even organic mud sticks, and further question marks were raised earlier this year. A Channel 4 documentary showed that some 80% of "organic" eggs on sale in UK supermarkets are produced in semi-intensive circumstances, the only significant difference in production being that the birds receive organic feed.

Even the Soil Association's policy director, Patrick Holden, felt obliged to say that "consumers are being seriously misled when buying organic eggs in UK supermarkets".

His organisation has fought long and hard for tougher organic standards. But now many diehards are increasingly dismayed by the appearance of "organic" food produced to diluted standards. Significantly, the eggs in question did not bear the Soil Association's logo, but that of another body: Organic Farmers and Growers, one of six UK bodies permitted to certify organic food.

Each of these operates different standards which conform to the minimum legal requirements set by UKROFS (the UK Register of Organic Food Standards). Now, in the light of the eggs debacle, there is a growing feeling that these legal standards have been set too low, allowing the organic newcomers too much scope for exploitation.

The plot thickens when you consider that organic food is now being sourced from all around the world from a mass of different certifying bodies. In the US alone, there are more than 90. So if your company wants to source say, organic cheese to put on a new organic pizza line, you can shop around for cheese made to the low standards required by a "rent-a-cert(ificate)" organic body knowing that it will be significantly cheaper than a superior quality, Soil Association-approved equivalent.

This certification chaos can leave producers who work to the most rigourous organic standards in an predicament - victims of their own success. If they insist that they can't produce more food for less money, then supermarket buyers can sideline them. Many retailers are already reducing the shelf space for home-produced (more expensive) organic lines to make way for imports.

A case in point is Danish organic pork, now on offer to big buyers at the miraculously low price of £3 a kilo - a stick being used to beat UK organic pork producers into cutting their margins even further.

Some large buyers are also forcing the pace of supply by strongarming their conventional suppliers into coming up with organic lines in preference to using established organic suppliers. Unfortunately, these differences in product pedigree are lost on the consumer because they are lumped together under the "organic" label.

One way of dealing with this is to ensure that all organic certifying bodies around the globe are working to equivalent standards, a time-consuming process that involves checking out each.

But his sort of harmonisation is problematic. The European Commission tried it for conventional food but failed when it sought Euro-harmony over jam and the curiously contentious issue of whether a tomato is a fruit or a vegetable.

The movers and shakers of the UK organic movement will soon be discussing a new gold standard to be awarded to organic products of the highest quality - those with high nutritional value, great flavour, low packaging and no unnecessary "food miles".

Until then, consumers should be aware that some products are more organic than others.

Stamp of approval: which is best?

The UK Register of Organic Food Standards (UKROFS) is the government body responsible for organic standards in this country. Its rules are generally in line with those set by the EU, although it goes further in some respects - for example, the EU permits conventionally reared animals to be converted to organic up to the age of 12 months; in the UK this is forbidden.

The six bodies responsible for inspecting and certifying organic producers and processers in the UK may use the UKROFS logo alongside their own, and may also set standards above those required by UKROFS. All have an EU code number (UK1, UK2, etc), which must appear on produce:

UK1: UKROFS's own rating.

UK2: Organic Farmers and Growers Ltd, the second-largest UK certifying body after the Soil Association. UKROFS standards.

UK3: The Scottish Organic Producers Association. UKROFS standards.

UK4: The Organic Food Federation, an organisation of producers, manufacturers and importers. UKROFS standards.

UK5: Soil Association Certification (SA Cert). The largest body, it certifies around 70% of UK-grown organic foods. Its standards are stricter than those of UKROFS: it takes a harder line on preservation of wildlife habitats in plant production, cross-contamination from GM crops and the housing of chickens. The SA allows its logo to be used on imports that meet its standards.

UK6: Demeter (the Bio-Dynamic Agricultural Association, or BDAA) has certified bio-dynamic production since 1927. It operates stricter rules than UKROFS and subscribes to the bio-dynamic philosophy of the relationship between man and universe.

UK7: The Irish Organic Farmers and Growers Association (IOFGA) has higher standards than those of UKROFS.

Imports from outside the EU: EU regulations conform to those set by IFOAM (International Federation of Organic Agricultural Movements), which groups together 750 organic institutions worldwide and ensures some equivalency of standards in 103 countries. IFOAM does not certify organic foods but its standards form the basis for many national organic requirements.

webTitle: "I killed policeman in self-defence," Noye tells jury

fields.headline: "I killed policeman in self-defence," Noye tells jury
fields.standfirst: Court hears how Kenneth Noye, the man accused of the M25 motorway killing, stood trial for the stabbing to death of an undercover police officer in 1985
fields.trailText: The man accused of the M25 motorway killing, Kenneth Noye, told a jury today that he had stood trial in the 1980s for the  stabbing to death of undercover police officer Detective Constable John Fordham.
fields.body:
The man accused of the M25 motorway killing, Kenneth Noye, told a jury today that he had stood trial in the 1980s for the stabbing to death of undercover police officer Detective Constable John Fordham.

His defence then was self-defence and the jury acquitted him.

Noye, who is also claiming he killed Stephen Cameron in self-defence during a fight on the M25 in Kent in 1996, told the jury in his Old Bailey murder trial that he had found the camouflaged officer in his garden at 6.10pm on January 26, 1985 after his dogs had barked.

He gave details of the incident as he explained to the jury why he fled to Spain the day after Mr Cameron was stabbed to death.

Noye said he had never been convicted of violence - but in July 1986, after the Dc Fordham stabbing, he was jailed for 14 years for dishonestly handling stolen Brinks Mat gold.

Noye claimed the way the press had reported his acquittal in the Fordham case was "absolutely scandalous". They had not accepted the jury's verdict. He told the jury that he did not believe he would ever receive a fair trial.

He had discussed leaving the country with "someone not in the family" and with his wife. "She said if you go into the police station you know what is going to happen. I knew. I decided I would never be believed in the police station or get a fair trial.

"I personally cannot ever see me getting a fair trial."

He said that police had not told the truth in the Fordham case. Noye also claimed that in the Brinks Mat trial, the jury were given police protection but were not supposed to talk to officers guarding them.

Noye said one of the jurors had been seen "laughing and joking" with two officers in a car. He had no idea how police would react to him after Mr Cameron's death.

"If I went in and they knew it was me, I think all those witness statements without a shadow of doubt would have been tainted against me."

Noye said after his release from serving nine years four months for handling, he started carrying a knife with him because he feared for his life. Earlier today, he told the Old Bailey how he "just struck out" with his lock-knife and stabbed electrician Stephen Cameron to death.

Demonstrating an underarm jab from the witness box, the grey-haired 52-year-old told the court: "I can only ever remember striking out once, but I accept it was twice."

He said his much younger victim had subjected him to a flurry of kicks and punches on an M25 slip road at Swanley, Kent, and repeatedly threatened to kill him.

Explaining how Mr Cameron had already knocked him to the ground, Noye told the jury: "I thought if he catches me again and I am out, he will take the knife out of my hand and really definitely use it so I struck out with the knife.

"I remember I had my head down...I can't remember exactly how I done it, but when I struck out I had my head down and we were moving about close together and I just struck out."

Noye, of Sevenoaks, Kent, denies murdering Mr Cameron in May 1996, claiming that he acted in self-defence.

But the Crown claims he stabbed him out of "anger and maybe pride" because the younger man was getting the upper hand in the fight.

The case continues.

fields.headline: Brother
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw:This is a film which unremittingly shows the real ugliness of Russian gangsterism... Balabanov manages the tension and suspense with style
fields.body:
Alexei Balabanov is a Russian director whose reputation here continues to grow. Last year his 1991 feature Happy Days had a UK release; next week his excellent Of Freaks and Men is coming out; this week it is Brother, his study of Danila (Sergei Bodrov), a demobbed soldier who is sent by his mother to St Petersburg in search of his adored brother, Viktor, played by the sinister, bald, grinning Viktor Sukharov - a virtual Balabanov repertory player. He discovers that Viktor is now a gangster known as "The Tartar" and Danila - weirdly deadpan and cherubic - discovers an unearthly talent for this calling too, carrying out a hit on a Chechen gang boss at Viktor's request.

This is a film which unremittingly shows the real ugliness of Russian gangsterism, with Danila's sneering anti- semitism and his loathing for foreigners, though, ironically, he adores his Sony Discman and makes an unlikely ally of a German tramp. Balabanov manages the tension and suspense with style, but piercingly discloses the squalor and dullness of Danila's outlaw existence.

webTitle: Bank checks out to cash in

fields.headline: Bank checks out to cash in
fields.standfirst: The financially motivated decision by Barclays to close 171 of its rural branches is a disaster for country dwellers, writes Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Barclays Bank has a snazzy website listing all its wonderful  services: investments, loans, offshore accounts and so on.
fields.body:
Barclays Bank has a snazzy website listing all its wonderful services: investments, loans, offshore accounts and so on.

You can even look up your nearest branch - whoops, sorry, no you can't. That page, understandably I suppose, is being rebuilt, with 171 locations electronically Tippexed out.

Still, there is a useful press release pointing out that soon, very soon, Barclays account holders who no longer have a branch within easy reach will be offered basic services - cheque encashment, paying in, that sort of thing - at their local Post Office.

Good-oh, I thought, with a sigh of relief - until I tried to find out where my local Post Office is. I went to the equally snazzy website of Post Office Counters and, sure enough, there was a helpful page where I could type in my postcode and hey presto! It tells me my nearest Post Offices are in Spelsbury, Kingham, and Adlestrop; all a 'handy' five miles away (or slightly less).

But in actual fact, those are not my nearest Post Offices at all. My nearest one is five minutes' toddle away, in the middle of Chipping Norton (a couple of doors away from the (surviving) branch of Barclays, in fact).

My point is this: website access to vital services is not, yet, quite all that it's cracked up to be. And yet Barclays would have us believe that we don't really need all those branches cluttering up the rural landscape, when we can simply log on and click.

That argument is, at best, fatuous. Three-quarters of the nation has no access to the internet. And even for those who have access, there will be a substantial proportion for whom over-the-counter banking will remain essential. Nowhere is that more true than in the countryside, where basic services, both public and private, are under relentless threat.

Bank closures are part of a dismal pattern of rural atrophy. Village schools, shops, Post Offices, and public transport have all been whittled away.

That may not be much of a deal for the new class of country dwellers, with their Range Rovers and converted barns. But for true locals, it is a disaster.

What about the old, the poor, and those who need help with their finances? Does Barclays really believe that it can service such customers through automated screens or automatons in call centres?

Of course it doesn't. The fact is, the bank wants rid of such awkward, low-return custom. It wants to be shot of all that messy real estate, staffed by real people who insist on being paid real money.

Barclays retail banking director John Varley, in his spirited bid to become Media Prat of the Year on this morning's Today programme, delivered the ritual assurance that rural bank customers would be able to use the Post Office network to carry out their business.

webTitle: Man confesses to stabbing Leeds fan

fields.headline: Man confesses to stabbing Leeds fan
fields.trailText: A man has confessed to Turkish police that he stabbed one of the two Leeds United fans killed in Wednesday's clashes in Istanbul before the Uefa Cup semi-final against Galatasaray.
fields.body:
A man has confessed to Turkish police that he stabbed one of the two Leeds United fans killed in Wednesday's clashes in Istanbul before the Uefa Cup semi-final against Galatasaray.

Ali Umit Demir told police "I stabbed him" and led them to the knife used in the attack, according to local media reports. Police in Istanbul would not say whether Demir was suspected of stabbing Christopher Loftus or Kevin Speight.

Earlier today there were remarkable scenes at Istanbul's police headquarters as the Turkish men held over the violence were paraded before the media.

In all, 13 men are in custody over the trouble, including seven being questioned specifically about the killings. The media, tipped off that access would be given, swarmed around the men as they were taken from the interrogation suite to be fingerprinted.

One of the suspects lost his footing and almost fell as photographers and camera crews pursued him and his police escort down some steps, while a man, understood to be a ringleader, covered his face as he was escorted back from fingerprinting.

Another man is said to be still at large and police are hoping to track him down via one of the other suspects. Local journalists briefed by the police said the interrogation could last another three days.

Meanwhile, Leeds Central MP Hilary Benn warned against moving the return match away from Elland Road. He said: "I don't think that would be sensible. Crowd control could be more difficult. Many Leeds supporters, indeed the whole community, will want the opportunity, to do what they went to Turkey in expectation of doing - which was to support their team and to be able to do so safely."

Assistant Chief Constable of West Yorkshire Police Paul Garvin added: "Our attention in the pre-planning for the event in two weeks time is very much focused towards keeping an eye on the hard core supporters who do cause difficulty.

"We are monitoring the intelligence, we are continuing to review and develop plans and our paramount concern is public safety."

fields.headline: The wrong trousers
fields.standfirst: This gender-reversal love story has violence and despair, but true romance too, says Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: In her through-the-looking-glass Madame Butterfly fable of the mid-west, Kimberly Peirce has found transgression and transcendence, and brought love into sharper focus... a gripping film
fields.body:
"Why can't you just admit you're a dyke?" yells Teena Brandon's cousin. "Because I'm not a dyke," Teena screams back. In that exchange is the genesis of Kimberly Peirce's compelling debut feature, Boys Don't Cry, based on the true story from 1993 of a teenage girl who reversed her surname, first name and sexual identity to become Brandon Teena, with a balled-up sock down her shorts and taped-up breasts, a likeable bright-eyed ingénu(e) who turns up in the no-horse town of Falls City, Nebraska.

This is a place of incredible boredom, where the big deal is to chase bats, go bumper-surfing (hanging off the back of a pick-up from a rope) or lie on your back in the yard hoovering up the compressor gases from a solvent spray. John (Peter Sarsgaard) is a wild local dude, and Tom (Brendan Sexton III) is his cringing buddy; both of them are on the margins of trouble with the police, both have issues with "impulse control". It is under their malign scrutiny that gender outlaw Brandon persuades Lana (Chloë Sevigny), a sweet local girl, to fall in love with him/her - with tragic results.

Brandon Teena considers herself to be a man, and Lana feels the same way, even when the truth is revealed. And Peirce's direction endows their love with an exquisite element of fantasy, role-playing, romance and escape: a secret masked ball of forbidden love in this dire trailer-park world. Brandon has entered into the male role of heterosexual love more intensely, more fervently, than any biological male could, because this is what Brandon has chosen . It is a gesture at once of love for Lana and of ecstatic self-realisation, and this moves Lana profoundly, and makes this such an affecting love story.

As Brandon, Hilary Swank has won golden opinions, quite rightly, and now an Academy Award, with a performance of enormous courage and conviction. With her new short hair, which Brandon is always nervously flicking and adjusting in the mirror, and a coltish, loose-limbed persona, she is engaging and lovable. And this vulnerability is almost unbearable when she is brutalised and killed by the moronic good ol' boys who can't handle the truth about the guy they've been hanging out with and who's been dating a local girl.

Swank is undoubtedly powerful but I think she is actually matched, and perhaps even subtly outclassed by Sevigny, who has here given a performance in advance of anything she has produced so far. Her slightly pallid, petulant presence can often seem ungenerous and opaque, but here she is just right: the quintessence of normality to set against this exquisite Ganymede whose destiny is hitched to hers. Sevigny handles the love-making scene with Brandon - after she/he has enticed Lana to skive off her terrible factory night-shift - with style and abandon.

It is part of Peirce's achievement in this film discreetly to subtract any suggestion of the grotesque or bizarre in the love affair between Brandon and Lana, and replace it with sweetness and tragedy. Their romance is starcrossed in an intensely modern way. Lana is a Capulet and Brandon - well, the problem is Brandon is a Capulet as well.

But this just makes it more erotic - and more desperately sad. In Brandon and Lana's story, Peirce defamiliarises and makes strange the act of love; she foregrounds the social stratagems and the choreography that express and liberate love. In her through-the-looking-glass Madame Butterfly fable of the mid-west, Kimberly Peirce has found transgression and transcendence, and brought love into sharper focus.

If there is a weakness in the picture, it is probably Peirce's omission of Brandon's existence before she found fulfilment in the role of a man; her life of what she calls being a " girl -girl" - and thus of a sense of process. (The time-lapse photography sequences of the rushing city nights are a little cliched, too.) But this is still a gripping film. In the promotional material, the producers suggest a literary antecedent in Truman Capote, and this is probably true. But the shock Lana feels in seeing Brandon Teena's name switched into "Teena Brandon" in a local newspaper report is not a mile away from Humbert Humbert's fetishistic ecstasy in Lolita in seeing his beloved name reversed into "Haze, Dolores" in a school record, the names transposed like gloves. There is violence and despair in Boys Don't Cry, but rapture and romance as well.

fields.headline: SA captain charged with match-fixing
fields.trailText: South Africa captain Hansie Cronje has been charged with match-fixing in the recent one-day series against India by New Delhi police.
fields.body:
South Africa captain Hansie Cronje has been charged with match-fixing in the recent one-day series against India by New Delhi police.

Delhi's joint commissioner of police, KK Paul told a press conference that Cronje and team-mates Nicky Boje, Herschelle Gibbs and Pieter Strydom had: "Illegally amassed huge sums of money in both Indian and foreign currenciesby wrongful means and by clearly deceiving the cricket fans and the general public."

He claimed that police had recordings of a telephone conversation between Cronje and Sanjiv Chawla, a London-based Indian, which backed up their allegations.

"We will seek the help of Interpol because the crime has been committed by a foreign national and money has been paid in London bank," he added.

Similar charges have also been filed against two Indians. One of them, Delhi-based businessman Rajesh Kalra has already been arrested, and police are also hoping to question the London-based Chawla.

But Cronje today insisted that match-fixing charges made by the Indian police were "absolute rubbish".

Dr Ali Bacher, managing director of the United Cricket Board (UCB) of South Africa, said: "I have spoken to Hansie Cronje and he says it is absolute rubbish. There is nothing at all in it."

A statement from Bronwyn Wilkinson, communications manager at the UCB, added: "The United Cricket Board of South Africa is certain that no South African cricket player has ever been involved in match fixing.

"UCB managing director Dr Ali Bacher has spoken to South African captain Hansie Cronje, who is adamant that the allegations contained in press reports in India are completely untrue.

"Cronje is known for his unquestionable integrity and honesty."

The charges relate to the five one-day international series South Africa played against India between March 9 and 19. The hosts won the series 3-2

fields.headline: Northern Ireland's truth commission
fields.standfirst: Observer Northern Ireland correspondent Henry McDonald on the truths the republicans have to fear from the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: Friday, 1pm: Observer Northern Ireland correspondent Henry McDonald on the truths the republicans have to fear from the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.body:
The Bloody Sunday Inquiry is the closest Northern Ireland has to a South African style Truth Commission. And like the more widespread investigation of the crimes of Apartheid in South Africa, in which not only the Afrikaner clique who ran the racist state but also their black opponents faced uncomfortable questions, the Bloody Sunday investigation is throwing up embarrassing facts, allegations and revelations not only for the British political and military establishment but also the republican movement.

The most sensational claim so far in the Saville Inquiry was the allegation that Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's chief negotiator and former IRA commanding officer, fired a number of shots before the Paratroopers opened fire killing 14 innocent civilians. Until now, the Mid-Ulster MP has hesitated in stepping forward to give evidence at the Inquiry in Derry's Guildhall. The claims - made in a British intelligence document which is sourced from an IRA informant codenamed "Infliction" - however may prompt Mr McGuinness to change his mind. He has dismissed the claims in the 1984 intelligence briefing as a "pathetic fabrication". Yet regardless of the veracity of the document, the upshot of this segment of the inquiry will be the chance for lawyers to grill Mr McGuinness in public about his role inside the Provisional IRA during the early 1970s. In recent years, particularly when he was appointed Minister of Education in the short-lived power-sharing executive last year, Mr McGuinness has downplayed his role in the Derry IRA.

The main object of the inquiry must be the clearing of the names of the 14 people murdered by the Parachute Regiment 28 years ago. However, the forensic investigation of one of the most seminal and tragic events in Northern Ireland's history has thrown up fresh questions not only for the British and unionists but also the IRA and its relationship with the wider nationalist community. Earlier this week a former Derry priest and secret negotiator between the Provisional IRA and the British government for many years, Denis Bradley, told Saville he was concerned about the role of the Official IRA before the Civil Rights march in the city that ended in the massacre. Mr Bradley was worried about the volatility of the Official's Derry Brigade and whether they were planning to open fire on police and troops at the anti-internment demonstration. Evidence such as this bolsters a widely held but unspoken belief in many quarters that republicans were planning to fire on British troops in the city during the demonstration - a view that might have coloured the Parachute Regiment's attitude on the day.

None of this is to deny the central and fatal role British troops played on the day when they went beserk, firing live rounds at unarmed marchers. Nor should allegations and claims of republican gunmen opening fire on soldiers exonerate the Paras from blame or indeed smear the 14 innocents slaughtered on the streets. What, however, this complex anatomy of a day in Derry at the height of the Troubles shows is that truth is not selective and contains embarrassing elements for all those involved in the Northern Ireland conflict over the last three decades. After only eight days of Saville, will this persuade republicans that perhaps a fully blown Truth Commission into the entire history of the Ulster Troubles might not be such a good idea after all?

fields.headline: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: The Lord of the Rings trailer gets internet preview, Richard Dreyfuss to create webisodes, Cannes contenders on show, and, on the casting couch, Catherine Zeta Jones, Michael Douglas, Keanu Reeves, Kieran Culkin, and Billy Bob Thornton
fields.body:
 The Lord of the Rings film site launched an exclusive internet preview of the eagerly anticipated movie. A quicktime trailer reveals fleeting glimpses of the $190m production, plus interviews with director Peter Jackson and star Elijah Wood. Watch it at www.lordoftherings.net. You can see screen grabs from the trailer on Ain't It Cool News.

 Richard Dreyfuss will provide content for Goosehead.com, a teen-oriented website run by 14-year-old Los Angeles resident Ashley Power. Dreyfuss will create at least two webisodes for the site, the first of which will debut this summer and will incorporate interactive elements that allow viewers to determine the outcome of the story.

 A list of this year's Cannes contenders can be seen on Screen's website

 A new X-men trailer has just been released on the internet; click here for details

Casting couch

 Catherine Zeta-Jones and fiance Michael Douglas announced yesterday that they will be working together again on Smoke and Mirrors - their next project after Stephen Soderbergh's Traffic.

 Keanu Reeves has committed to star in Hardball, a drama about an inner-city Little League baseball team. Reeves will play a baseball coach..

 Macauley's younger brother Kieran Culkin, has been cast as a lead alongside Jenna Malone and Jodie Foster in The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys, a black comedy produced by Foster's Egg Prods. Kieran, 17, was most recently seen in a supporting role in The Cider House Rules.

 Billy Bob Thornton has committed to co-star with Frances McDormand in the Coen brothers next project.

fields.headline: Barclays closes swathe of branches
fields.standfirst: Listen to Barclays retail banking director John Varley defending the closures and the large payments he and other directors stand to gain. Mr Varley was being interviewed by John Humphrys on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, and the clip is from the BBC website. To hear Mr Varley, fast forward the clip to 2 hours, 12 minutes and 45 seconds.
fields.trailText: Up to 40,000 Barclays Bank customers across the country will today lose their local  Branches.
fields.body:
Up to 40,000 Barclays Bank customers across the country will today lose their local Branches.

The bank is closing 171 branches, arguing they are uneconomic to run.

Customers and politicians from all parties have condemned the move, which comes in the same week that the bank revealed top directors are in line for lucrative pay increases.

People living in rural areas have complained the move will leave some communities with journeys of up to 20 miles to a bank.

Barclays has confirmed that there would be some job losses among staff but said it did not have a precise figure.

However, just hours before the closures were due to take effect, the company attempted to appease customers by announcing that a deal had been struck with the Post Office to offer some level of service in affected areas.

Barclays retail banking director John Varley said that people using the 171 branches set to close would be able to carry out basic banking transactions at their local post-offices.

He told the BBC's Watchdog programme: "We have had a pilot with the Post Office in Cornwall to try to help customers where we are withdrawing from certain areas.

"After listening to our customers, we will have, within three weeks, in collaboration with the Post Office, arrangements in each of the areas where we are closing banks to help those customers cash cheques, pay in and withdraw money."

While the move is unlikely to pacify those bitterly opposed to the closures, it might help calm the furious row ignited by environment minister Chris Mullin's comments that Barclays customers should "vote with their feet" over the closure plans.

Barclays will now have 1,550 branches, compared with 2,000 in 1995 and more than 2,400 in 1991.

Last year the bank made record profits of £2.4bn and last week it revealed it had paid its new chief executive, Matthew Barrett, £1.3m for just three months in the job.

But Barclays argues it needs to move with the times, claiming that less than 40% of customers now use its branches because of an explosion in the use of cash machines, telephone and online banking. Company bosses are instead putting more resources into other branches and into telephone banking and online banking.

Mr Varley said he apologised for the inconvenience caused to customers but insisted it was important for the bank to make a profit.

"There has been a sea change, a seismic change in the way in which customers choose to bank in the United Kingdom.

"If we ignore that then we will go out of business and this country is littered with the carcasses of businesses that have failed to move with the times.

"Look at NatWest, our biggest competitor - taken over. Look at Rover - going out of business. It is in the interest of Barclays, it is in the interests of Barclays' customers and its employees to be successful.

"If we are profitable, that is a good thing, not a bad thing."

In an angry encounter with a presenter on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, Mr Varley refused to confirm that directors were to get up to £40 million in bonuses. But he said Barclays "had to compete for the best intellectual capital in the world".

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: The glass-lidded cabinet that runs the length of this basement bar near Liverpool Street shows off a tapas selection that wouldn't look out of place in, well, Barcelona.
fields.body:
Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15

Barcelona 1a Bell Lane, London E1, 0171 247 7014

The glass-lidded cabinet that runs the length of this basement bar near Liverpool Street shows off a tapas selection that wouldn't look out of place in, well, Barcelona. Which is just as it should be; the whole point of such places is to eat what catches your eye. So it's a Russian salad, heavy with tuna (£2.75); breaded king prawns in spiky chilli oil (£4.95); patatas alioli (fried spuds in garlic mayo to you and me - £2.75); and fabada asturiana, a stew of white beans, belly pork and chorizo (£3.25). And that's only a fraction of what's on offer. With bread, beer, water and coffee, you can swim in under £15. What's more, if the laid-back barman got himself into gear, the place would qualify as a quick bite, too.

Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Eyre Bros, 35 Charlotte Road, London EC2, 0171 739 5345

It's brought to you by David Eyre, ex-chef of the legendary gastro-pub The Eagle, so this tiny sandwich bar on one of Shoreditch's most fashionable streets starts out with plenty of credibility. Top-notch lunch fodder with hefty sandwiches (rare beef and fresh horseradish, pork loin, and so on, on crusty home-baked bread, all at £4), fresh soups and salads (£3) and Med-inspired bigger dishes for around £6-£7. The staff are decked out in chef's whites to add that extra dash of professionalism and class, helped along by the well-thumbed collection of cookbooks stacked haphazardly behind the counter. A quick bite out of necessity - its four stools doesn't make for a leisurely lunch break.

Food on the net

www.camisa.co.uk

Website of the Fratelli Camisa delicatessen (established in Soho in 1929), and the place to stock up on top-notch pastas, mozzarella and salami. You can even purchase the Camisa cookbook.

Pros: The site is easy to use, if unexciting in design. Great range of oils and vinegars.

Cons: The range of produce available online is more limited than that in the London store - but the company welcomes email suggestions from shoppers.

Delivery: Within seven days, but usually a speedy 72 hours across mainland UK.

Charges: Free for orders over £30; otherwise £6 per order.

Coming soon: Italian Easter cakes.

On the menu: cavolo nero

What is it? Literally, black cabbage. It fact it's dark green, with long, lancet-shaped crinkly leaves.

Err. Cabbage. Leave it out. You may, but followers of Italian gastro-fashions won't.

How do the Italians make cabbage edible? Tuscans put it into ribollita, a kind of mega-vegetable soup. Further south they braise it with garlic, chilli, lard and water.

But I thought long cooking was death to vegetables? Not with cavolo nero, it isn't. It needs quite a lot of firm treatment to soften it up.

Where do I find it? Discerning supermarkets and specialist greengrocers. But don't go around asking for cavallo nero, which, you won't need to be told, means black horse.

fields.trailText: The Farrelly brothers, the duo behind There's Something about Mary and Dumb and Dumber, have joined producer Larry Gordon on a project to make a film of the Six Billion Dollar Man.
fields.body:
We can rebuild him... we have the technology...

The Farrelly brothers, the duo behind There's Something about Mary and Dumb and Dumber, have joined producer Larry Gordon on a project to make a film of the Six Billion Dollar Man.

Variety reports that the film, which was once going to be a revised dramatic action story based on the 70s series The Six Million Dollar Man, has now become a comedy. The film will tell the story of a man who attempts to master his newfound high-tech limbs while doing battle with an adversary who has $1bn more worth of cybernetic stuff.

Those of you feeling nostalgic for the original 70s TV series can listen to the theme tune here, and find images and an episode guide here

fields.headline: Hanks backs war of words
fields.trailText: The Oscar-winning actor Tom Hanks is to back a government drive to revive British youngsters' interest in the second world war.
fields.body:
The Oscar-winning actor Tom Hanks is to back a government drive to revive British youngsters' interest in the second world war.

Hanks, who starred in Steven Spielberg's 1998 blockbuster Saving Private Ryan, has agreed to help to judge an essay competition sponsored by the American and British governments, which will be launched in London next Tuesday.

The contest is the brainchild of the US ambassador, Philip Lader, who since taking up the post has been struck by how little teenagers know about the "special relationship" between America and Britain and the role it played in the allied forces' victory over Germany.

Hanks, one of America's top box office earners, won Oscars as best actor for Philadelphia in 1993 and Forrest Gump in 1994.

He was nominated for an Oscar for his role as John Miller, the shell-shocked infantry captain in Saving Private Ryan, which recreated the horror of the Normandy D-Day landings.

The essay competition will be open to an estimated 600,000 14-16 year-olds at state and independent schools. They will be encouraged to interview their grandparents and other relatives about their memories of the war, and in particular the impact of Anglo-American co-operation on their local communities.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, will attend the launch at the Imperial War Museum next Tuesday.

In addition to Hanks, the judges are expected to include politicians and historians from both sides of the Atlantic.

webTitle: The continuing case of the missing Oscars

fields.headline: The continuing case of the missing Oscars
fields.trailText: It's a plot worthy of any Hollywood movie. Another missing Oscar turned up yesterday - in the office of a celebrated Los Angeles lawyer, who has not yet revealed how he got hold of it
fields.body:
It's a plot worthy of any Hollywood movie. Another missing Oscar turned up yesterday - in the office of a celebrated Los Angeles lawyer, who has not yet revealed how he got hold of it.

The Oscar was one of a batch of 55 that went missing on March 8. A few days later, a junk salvager found 52 of the missing gold statuettes, still in their boxes, in a dumpster behind a supermarket in the Koreatown district. He turned them over to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, winning a $50,000 reward, a prime seat at the awards show, and a full 15 minutes of fame.

Civil rights attorney Stephen Yagman said today that he had one of the three missing Oscars in his possession and would reveal how he got it in an upcoming press conference. Until then, he said, the mystery of the missing Oscar would remain just that.

Yagman said he intends to use the statuette in a lawsuit against the Los Angeles Police Department that he will file on behalf of a trucking company worker who was arrested, but never charged, in the theft of the Oscars.

fields.headline: Kidman and Rush are among Australia's richest entertainers
fields.trailText: Nicole Kidman did very well, but Mel Gibson's been removed from the ranking all together. Russell Crowe trailed a faux-Abba band and two life-sized bananas.
fields.body:
Nicole Kidman did very well, but Mel Gibson's been removed from the ranking all together. Russell Crowe trailed a faux-Abba band and two life-sized bananas.

Every year, Business Review Weekly estimates the top-50-earning entertainers in Australia. Pop duo Savage Garden led the list for the second year, and Kidman and Geoffrey Rush shared second place with $11.3m each.

Cate Blanchett is at number seven (earnings of $5.7 million), Insider star Russell Crowe came in at eleventh place, and Guy Pearce is at 16.

As for directors, Bruce Beresford was the top earner with $3.5m for 14th place, followed by Baz Luhrmann at No 19.

While Forbes estimates Mel Gibson's earnings at $45.5m, he was kicked off Business Review Weekly's list last year after he said he'd never live in Australia again.

webTitle: Paris paper fooled by Moscow spoof

fields.headline: Paris paper fooled by Moscow spoof
fields.trailText: The authoritative French daily Le Monde was forced to admit yesterday that it had fallen hook, line and sinker for un gros poisson d'avril - a monumental April fool - in publishing what purported to be the first instalment of Boris Yeltsin's eagerly awaited memoirs.
fields.body:
The authoritative French daily Le Monde was forced to admit yesterday that it had fallen hook, line and sinker for un gros poisson d'avril - a monumental April fool - in publishing what purported to be the first instalment of Boris Yeltsin's eagerly awaited memoirs.

On the front page of its Wednesday edition it carried a report based on what the Russian newspaper Moskovskii Komsomolets claimed on April 1 was an exclusive preview of the ex-president's diaries.

Among the revelations in the piece was Mr Yeltsin's assertion that he had recognised the potential of his successor, Vladimir Putin, when he proved to be a cool shot at a hunting party in 1994.

"Camouflage clothing suited Vladimir Vladimirovitch and he held his rifle firmly, as one holds in one's arms a woman one loves," Le Monde said, quoting Moskovskii Komsomolets quoting - allegedly - Mr Yeltsin.

At the end of the day "everyone gathered round a table in a clearing". "They all dived under it, however, when a wild boar suddenly appeared at the edge of the forest. Two shots rang out, and on examination it proved to be Putin who had shot the beast through the heart."

At that moment, Mr Yeltsin was purported to have continued, "we all raised a glass to the sure arm of Vladimir Vladimirovitch. And I said to myself: Moscow needs such men!"

Le Monde apologised yesterday for failing to spot the joke, explaining that such pranks were "a long and occasionally amusing tradition" in the Russian press, and that the story was "well-crafted, cited some well-known episodes, and written in a style close to Yeltsin's habitual declarations".

Its correspondent added: "As it was, one had to slalom that day between stories announcing the end of mixed sex classes, the marriage of the tennis player Anna Kournikova, the installation of saunas and bars in public housing estates, and the existence of a squadron of robber falcons specially trained to whip the fur hats from Moscovites' heads."

He had waited three days for someone to deny the story, but no one had. "So we present our readers our humble apologies, and promise to wait with more patience and caution for the real presidential memoirs," the paper concluded.

fields.headline: Scorned towns round on critic
fields.trailText: The guide, Home Truths - a Jaunt Around the Decaying Heart of England, also describes Stevenage as "a nice place if you like hideous architecture and don't mind getting beaten up", apologises to the inhabitants of the Third World for comparing it to Stoke-on-Trent, and remarks of Slough: "There are some places that have always been dreadful. Slough is one of them."
fields.body:
A new guidebook claiming to expose "just how dreadful England has become" has angered town councils who labelled the author "the most hated man in England".

Among the places scorned by the guide is Braintree in Essex, whose inhabitants are branded as "the ugliest collection of people in the UK outside Wales" and where "a good number of its female inhabitants resemble sea monsters".

The guide, Home Truths - a Jaunt Around the Decaying Heart of England, also describes Stevenage as "a nice place if you like hideous architecture and don't mind getting beaten up", apologises to the inhabitants of the Third World for comparing it to Stoke-on-Trent, and remarks of Slough: "There are some places that have always been dreadful. Slough is one of them."

Bill Murphy, the unrepentant author, claimed to have spent a gruelling eight months visiting seaside resorts, new towns and crime-ridden estates across England to research his highly personalised guide, published yesterday.

He insisted he was not pleasantly surprised by any of the 30 towns he visited, saying: "They were all awful in their own way. People who live in these places are blinded to their true horrors."

But his remarks about Braintree, including a claim that its dwellers are also "the most humourless collection of people outside Germany", were dismissed as "extraordinarily wrong" by the town's head of publicity Chris Trim.

Other towns attacked include Brighton where people look like "rejects from the Dr Who props cupboard".

The guide adds: "If you ever want an excuse for not paying taxes come to the Costa del Dole, or Brighton. It is the beggar, junkie, alkie paradise of England."

The comments prompted Ivor Caplin, MP for neighbouring Hove, to remark: "This is just a cynical stunt to promote a poorly researched book."

Southport council was also at pains to dismiss as "a load of rubbish" the suggestion that people who live there are hideous and every girl over 16 looked like a pensioner. "Many a northern beauty from round here has had a successful modelling career," a council spokesman said. And to the suggestion that Southport was so dead "not even the sea turns up anymore", he responded helpfully: "The tide comes in here twice a day just like it does anywhere else."

fields.headline: To Nelson Mandela: A Tribute
fields.standfirst: Poet laureate's verse for Mandela
fields.trailText:
That straight walk from the
prison to the gate -
that walk the world saw, and
which changed the world -
fields.body:
That straight walk from the
prison to the gate -
that walk the world saw, and
which changed the world -
it led you through to life from
life withheld,
from broken stones with your
unbroken heart.

To life which you imagined
and then lived,
which once we shared in your
imagining
but soon shared in the
present that you shaped:
the life which gave each
human hope its chance
of turning into truth and
staying true;
the life which understood
what changing takes;
the life which showed us we
become ourselves
in part by watching you
becoming you.

fields.headline: End Elian's trauma, father pleads
fields.standfirst:
Miami family dig in to stop Cuban doorman taking son home

More about the Elian Gonzalez case
Campaign to keep Elian in US
Let Elian go home
fields.trailText: The father of Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old Cuban boy at the centre of a trial of strength between Miami's anti-Castro Cuban community and the Havana government, flew to the US from Cuba yesterday and appealed for the return home of his son.
fields.body:
The father of Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old Cuban boy at the centre of a trial of strength between Miami's anti-Castro Cuban community and the Havana government, flew to the US from Cuba yesterday and appealed for the return home of his son.

But in Miami the boy's relatives and their backers refused to hand him over, paving the way for a showdown between local and federal authorities.

Two local mayors have declared that their police would not assist any attempt by the immigration service to remove the child from his uncle's house in the Little Havana district of Miami. Exile groups have kept up a vigil there, threatening to form a human wall around the house if anyone arrives to take custody.

Juan Miguel Gonzalez flew into Washington's Dulles airport just after dawn on a private jet paid for by a US church group trying to mediate in the emotive conflict.

Speaking to reporters on the airport apron, Mr Gonzalez - a hotel doorman from the Cuban coastal town of Cardena - read a statement denouncing his uncle and other Miami relatives for their treatment of his son, who has become an icon for anti-communist exiles since he was shipwrecked off Florida last November.

"It has been an agonising experience to see my son submitted to cruel psychological pressures aimed at influencing his personality already weakened by the terrible trauma," the boy's father said. "Worse still, Elian has been paraded and exhibited in public rallies and by the media with a clear intent to obtain political advantage from this tragedy."

Elian lost his mother - who had separated from his father - when the small boat taking her, Elian and 12 other Cuban emigrants to the US sank. Elian clung to an innertube.

After consulting his Washington lawyer and Cuban officials on Wednesday night, Mr Gonzalez agreed to fly to the US with his present wife and baby boy, but without the 28-strong entourage which Havana had originally demanded, following US government assurances that it would do its utmost to grant him custody of Elian.

Eric Holder, a US deputy attorney-general, said yesterday: "I believe that reuniting Elian with his father is not only a matter of federal law. It is not a matter of immigration law. It is simply the right thing to do.

"The father and the son need to be together and in the coming days we will do all that we can to ensure that that happens."

Officials from the justice department and the US immigration and naturalisation service held talks with lawyers for Elian's US relatives in a Miami court building yesterday, trying to get them to hand the boy over peacefully.

But the relatives, led by Elian's great uncle Lazaro, are resisting. Lazaro Gonzalez told journalists yesterday that Elian knew about his father's arrival, but he also knew that "his mother had died bringing him to freedom", away from the regime of Fidel Castro.

"We aren't going to take the boy anywhere," he declared. His lawyers have questioned Juan Miguel Gonzalez's relationship with his son and demanded that the boy undergo an independent psychological examination.

Elian made a brief appearance yesterday to play on a slide in the garden of Lazaro Gonzalez's small house in Little Havana. Behind barricades 50 metres away, a group of Cuban exiles cheered and chanted Elian's name each time the little boy looked in their direction.

Juan Miguel Gonzalez and his wife and baby yesterday moved into the comfortable suburban house of the chief Cuban diplomat in Washington, who moved out to make room for the visitors and to defuse exile claims that Elian's father was being manipulated by the Havana government.

Cuban officials told journalists in Havana that they had wanted Mr Gonzalez to be accompanied by his close family to disprove rumours that the regime would hold the wife and baby hostage to prevent him defecting. For Miami's fiercely anti-Castro groups, a defection would be a triumph.

The child's fate has become a battleground against the Cuban leader. This is likely to have been stoked by Mr Castro's claim that: "The battle of Elian has been won - in judicial terms, in legal terms, in political terms."

webTitle: No more three-sweater days as Old Trafford warms to the fleece

fields.headline: No more three-sweater days as Old Trafford warms to the fleece
fields.trailText: County cricket's commitment to modernisation has left traditionalists feeling increasingly uncomfortable, but the launch of the first-class season at Fenner's today may provide them with their greatest shock yet: the traditional ribbed cricket sweater may be on the way out.
fields.body:
County cricket's commitment to modernisation has left traditionalists feeling increasingly uncomfortable, but the launch of the first-class season at Fenner's today may provide them with their greatest shock yet: the traditional ribbed cricket sweater may be on the way out.

When Lancashire brave one of the earliest starts to a first-class season on record, against Cambridge University, they will become the first county to abandon the cricket sweater in favour of a newly designed fleece which they will wear in all competitions this summer.

Jack Simmons, Lancashire's chairman, gave the fleece a warmish welcome at Old Trafford yesterday as he held it guardedly against his avuncular girth.

"We used to wear so many sweaters that we went out to field like a flock of sheep," he said. "Not forgetting the Norwegian thermal underwear I managed to get one season from a contact at Middlesex."

Lancashire's fast bowlers have eyed the fleece most suspiciously, fearing that it might prove too restrictive, but a few design alterations by the cricket manufacturer, Duncan Fearnley, have convinced them of its benefits.

It should undergo the stiffest of tests in the next few days, as a week of widespread floods, snow on the hills and a switch back to the bitterly cold winds more associated with midwinter have provided the usual harbinger of the cricket season. Some things, at least, never change.

It is perhaps merciful that EW Swanton, doyen of cricket traditionalism and a man who once ticked off Chris Cowdrey for diving around in a one-day game and dirtying his flannels, did not live to see the day.

Add a few pairs of thermal gloves and perhaps we have seen the last of the famous scorebook entry Cold Stopped Play.

Instead of doing their annual April impression of Michelin men, England's county cricketers now have the chance to resemble athletes. It is not before time.

fields.headline: Parents that heads dread
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Violent and abusive behaviour by "parents from hell" is on the increase, headteachers warned yesterday, and is interfering with with their main job of running schools and educating their pupils.
fields.body:
Violent and abusive behaviour by "parents from hell" is on the increase, headteachers warned yesterday, and is interfering with with their main job of running schools and educating their pupils.

In a survey of more than 3,000 primary and secondary school heads, which looked at the obstacles to their work in teaching youngsters, violent and abusive parents came near the top, lagging behind only Ofsted inspections, bidding for funding and government paperwork.

More than two-thirds of heads surveyed by the National Association of Head Teachers said the work of their schools had been put in jeopardy by parents behaving in an abusive and violent manner. "We need to make sure that the police and the crown prosecution service prosecute these people. At the moment, they don't always do so," said the NAHT's general secretary, David Hart. "The sad fact of life is that incidents of violence and levels of abusive behaviour from parents are on the increase."

More than nine out of 10 of 3,200 heads surveyed felt their workload had increased, and that they should be able to drop duties which contributed little to the education of children such as home-school contracts and "baseline" testing of five-year-olds. "We recognise some workload brings benefits to children. But some does not," said Mr Hart.

The NAHT said Ofsted inspections remained a bete noire for most heads, with high stress and workload for weeks before, during and after the inspection.

In a related move yesterday, the government was urged by one of its own task forces to relax its grip on schools and allow head teachers to "take more risks" in the way they run their schools and spend government cash. A report from the Better Regulation Task Force found that although headteachers were committed to the government's drive to raising standards, they were tangled up in too much red tape.

Lord Haskins of Northern Foods, who is chairman of the committee, proposed a clarification of the role of local education authorities, which could see them lose some of their funding role for schools, and a reduction in the scope of governing bodies.

Schools should be given three year rolling budgets, rather than making them bid for funds for specific initiatives, he said.

The DfEE has 60 days in which to issue a formal response - but yesterday promised to issue more paperwork and documents via the internet.

webTitle: Ofsted stress too much for teacher who killed herself

fields.headline: Ofsted stress too much for teacher who killed herself
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A dedicated primary school teacher killed herself after being devastated by a bad Ofsted report and criticism of her classroom performance, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A dedicated primary school teacher killed herself after being devastated by a bad Ofsted report and criticism of her classroom performance, an inquest heard yesterday.

Pamela Relf, 57, could not take the pressures of modern teaching after an otherwise trouble free career spanning 36 years.

She jumped into a river on a January day, leaving a note addressed to a coroner making her plight clear. "I am now finding the stress of my job too much. The pace of work and the long days are more than I can do," she wrote.

The teacher who had devoted her life to her profession found the large number of government and local initiatives difficult to reconcile, the inquest at Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire, was told.

As the longest serving teacher at Middlefield primary school in Eynesbury she could not bear to return to work after criticism by Ofsted inspectors, which left her stressed and tearful.

After the inquest, her brother David Relf attacked the way teachers were treated. "I think her death says something about the role of teachers in our society and the pressures in terms of paperwork," he said. "Society has changed and the education system is not coping with the way it has changed and has put the burden of stress on teachers."

The school's head, Brian Rayner, was equally critical of the mounting pressures on staff. In a statement he said: "Like her colleagues in this and all schools, there was often the feeling of running to stand still and like all of us, she felt the pressure that resulted."

After one of her lessons had been inspected, Mr Rayner found her to be "in a stressed state. She was tearful, having been told by the inspector that she lacked pace in her lesson. I have never before seen Pamela in such a state and consoled her as best I could. It concerned me that the school's most senior teacher had been reduced to such a state at this early stage of the inspection.

"Pamela seemed unduly nervous for the rest of the week, especially when the inspectors were in her classroom. Pamela looked particularly demoralised during a feedback session. I recall thinking how drawn and stressed she looked." He was critical of the Ofsted inspection, two months before her death, which had highlighted several areas of concern.

Miss Relf's body was discovered in a river at a nature reserve close to her home in Eaton Ford seven weeks after her car was found abandoned at a beauty spot at Little Paxton, the inquest was told. She had disappeared on her way to work on January 4, a day before the start of the new term.

Her 92-year-old father, who lived with her, heard her leave their house as usual at 8.20am for a staff meeting. But she never arrived at work and worried colleagues later raised the alarm.

Her disappearance sparked a search involving more than 20 police officers, five tracker dogs and the Cambridgeshire force helicopter. Teaching staff and other colleagues at the school were among those who turned out to search for her.

She died from cold water immersion, the inquest heard. The shock of the cold water had caused her heart to stop.

Recording a verdict of suicide while she was suffering from depression, the coroner, Colin Latimore, said Miss Relf had clearly become depressed over the preceding months. "Inspections of any type are stressful by their very nature, sometimes more stressful than others," he said.

The 247-pupil school was inspected at the end of November last year and was found to have serious weaknesses that affected the standard of education. The inspectors found that reading standards among younger children were below national averages and writing was well below. In 23% of the lessons, they observed, the teaching was unsatisfactory or poor.

They concluded: "Leadership and management of the school is unsatisfactory overall."

fields.headline: Third of young Scots 'carry weapons'
fields.standfirst:
Educationists surprised by findings and deny violence problems in schools Education Unlimited

London's gun violence: special report
fields.trailText: Around a third of 11- to 16-year-old boys and 8% of girls in Scotland have carried weapons ranging from flick knives to replica pistols and knuckle-dusters, according to a survey carried out in schools.
fields.body:
Around a third of 11- to 16-year-old boys and 8% of girls in Scotland have carried weapons ranging from flick knives to replica pistols and knuckle-dusters, according to a survey carried out in schools.

The study, published in this week's British Medical Journal, found that those who used drugs were more likely to carry weapons. Boys tended to be more heavily armed the more drugs they used, the researchers from Glasgow University say.

Researchers point out that the survey was carried out by questionnaire, so there will have been under-reporting by some young people and over-reporting by others. They also note that their 3,000 subjects were asked only if they had ever carried a weapon - not if they carried one all the time.

None the less, the results "must give cause for concern", say Neil McKeganey from the Centre for Drug Misuse Research and John Norrie of the Robertson Centre for Biostatistics. "Whatever the reasons, having a weapon potentially increases the risk of harm.

"It is possible that a proportion of young people in Scotland who use illegal drugs will become involved in violence, and some of these may carry weapons."

But the report was greeted with a degree of perplexity yesterday by educationists and youth workers. Ray Murphy, education officer for north Lanarkshire where much of the research was carried out, said he would note the findings, but he did not believe there was any great problem with offensive weapons in schools.

"It implies we are going down the American road and we could not be further from going down the American road," he said. "Offensive weapons are really not a problem and I have never heard of an incident where they have been connected with drugs."

Even in schools in the most deprived areas, Mr Murphy said, it would be extremely unusual for a school to have more than one incident involving a weapon in a year, and that weapon would almost never be more than a stick.

The researchers call for organisers of events for young people to be aware that they might be armed and take steps to reduce the likelihood. They argue that national information and awareness campaigns are needed to warn young people and their parents of the dangers of carrying weapons.

And they suggest that home secretary Jack Straw's call to adults to exert their authority and make young people who are misbehaving toe the line may be a poor idea. "We suggest the need for caution as some young people may be carrying an offensive weapon," they write.

The study was carried out at 20 schools in central Scotland, Lanarkshire, Perth and Kinross. Some 3,121 students in classes selected at random in each school and school year completed a questionnaire under examination conditions, answering on their use of drugs, carrying weapons, social activities and family circumstances.

Researchers found that 34.1% of boys and 8.6% of girls had carried weapons. The proportions increased with age and drug taking. Nearly two thirds of boys (63.5%) who took drugs had carried a weapon. Nearly all of those (92%) who used five illegal drugs carried a weapon and over half of them carried two. The weapons named were knives of many varieties - flick, switch, Stanley, craft, and hunting - as well as machetes, swords, razors, air rifles, pistols, replica guns, clubs, metal pipes, baseball bats, snooker cues, screwdrivers, hammers, catapults and knuckle-dusters.

The west of Scotland has long had an association with weapon carrying and gang fighting, write the researchers. "The culture of weapon carrying among young people seems to be continuing although it is not confined to any one city. It is far from clear why a substantial proportion of young people in Scotland feel the need to carry a weapon and this needs further investigation."

The study, published in this week's British Medical Journal, found that those who used drugs were more likely to carry weapons. Boys tended to be more heavily armed the more drugs they used, the researchers from Glasgow University say. fields.headline: England elite take central line
fields.standfirst: Hussain's men agree to sign contracts for seven-Test summer
fields.trailText: Peace has returned to the upper echelons of the game after Nasser Hussain's men agreed to sign contracts for a seven-Test summer.
fields.body:
So it is peace in our time. The contract dispute which had threatened to disrupt the preparations of the England team for an arduous summer has been resolved and the 12 players selected for six-month contracts by the England and Wales Cricket Board have agreed to sign on the dotted line. Normal service will be resumed with a training camp in the west country at the start of next month.

Although the contracts were supposed to come into effect from the start of the month, the players had been given a final deadline of yesterday to agree to the terms of a far-reaching and complicated document, and it is understood that any individual's failure to comply might have meant the offer being withdrawn.

However, after discussing the final offer with their legal representatives over the past two days, all of them will sign. The team's spokesman Dean Headley yesterday contacted Simon Pack, the board's international teams director, with the good news and when they next all meet, after this week's fitness assessment in Cheshire, it will be as the first centrally contracted players in Britain.

"We are pleased to have reached this agreement because central contracts represent an important step forward for English cricket," said Pack. "The discussions we have had have been constructive and positive throughout and, contrary to some reports, there has been no acrimony between the board, the team or their representatives.

"The contracts are very comprehensive and it was important to ensure that both sides were happy with the details. We have achieved this and the players can now concentrate fully on preparing for the forthcoming international season."

Although the players had agreed the bulk of the contract some three weeks ago, the question of image rights, and more specifically whether these players and their successors should receive a cut of future online broadcasting deals negotiated by the board, had proved a stumbling block, with the board believing that an unmanageable precedent, involving rights in other broadcasting areas, would be created if it agreed.

The outcome appears to be that the players have climbed down and the issue has been settled to the board's satisfaction. Now Nasser Hussain and his men come under the board's jurisdiction rather than the counties', with the England coach Duncan Fletcher able to decide where and when his squad will play their cricket in preparation for a summer that will see seven Tests, against Zimbabwe and West Indies, and 10 one-day internationals in a triangular series involving the same three sides.

"We talked about it as a team," Headley explained, "and it's just a question of everybody signing the contracts and sending them to the board now."

It was, he continued, never the same as the dispute over money that disrupted the preparations for the World Cup last year. "This was handled more professionally from the start with lawyers looking carefully at the deal. I think both sides are happy."

 The England and Wales Cricket Board has named seven experts to act as pitch liaison officers and match referees for the new season. They are Mike Denness, Raman Subba Row, Alan Smith, Tony Brown, Peter Walker, Phil Sharpe and David Hughes. They will be backed up by three technical advisers, Chris Wood, Harry Brind and Tom Flintoft.

 Lance Klusener is to consult an eye specialist after his spectacular loss of batting form in the recent Sharjah tournament. The South African all-rounder recorded three ducks in succession in the limited-overs competition, prompting him to complain that he could not see the white ball clearly. He was player of the tournament in last year's World Cup.
