webTitle: Downing Street acts after landfill tax dodge revealed

fields.headline: Downing Street acts after landfill tax dodge revealed
fields.standfirst: Landfill tax scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Downing Street has intervened to review the country's waste policy following the Guardian's disclosure of abuses of the £1bn landfill tax and of widespread illegal dumping across Britain, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Downing Street has intervened to review the country's waste policy following the Guardian's disclosure of abuses of the £1bn landfill tax and of widespread illegal dumping across Britain, it emerged last night.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, was due to announce government plans for the future of waste disposal on the day the Guardian revealed details of the scams happening under the new tax regime.

Yesterday's disclosures of large scale illegal dumping have added to serious concerns in the No 10 policy unit, in customs and excise, the Treasury, and the environment department, about the effectiveness of the present waste policy.

Leaked pages from the government's white paper on waste reveal that Mr Prescott was about to praise the role of the private company Entrust, which is in charge of policing £250m of donations from the waste industry for environmental schemes in lieu of paying 20% of the tax.

The key paragraph reads: "An important strength of the scheme is that it encourages private sector involvement in projects to protect the environment and improve local amenities. We do not wish to undermine that. Given the current nature of the scheme, it is not possible to fund either commercial activities or local authority operations."

On Wednesday the Guardian disclosed that the waste industry appeared to be able to distort the funding of environmental projects to benefit landfill operators and their commercial activities - without breaking any regulations.

The paper also revealed that 1,100 approved environmental bodies had never received any cash from landfill companies, and many of the environmental bodies which did receive large sums of cash had been set up by waste companies.

One body, Canford Environmental, had given money to projects which appeared to benefit two companies that between them had five directors on the Canford board - although the rules permit this.

The paper is to back up its revelations with a 30,000 word report detailing funding made by other environmental bodies set up by waste companies and trade associations. The report will also list many local authorities which appear to have used funding from waste firms' donations to pay for schemes that normally would be funded from public spending. Some councils signed agreements with waste firms.

The report also covers the huge scale of illegal dumping and tax evasion across the country, naming golf courses, rifle ranges, cricket and football pitches, riding stables and go-kart circuits, where waste has been dumped.

Last night environment ministers, Michael Meacher and Chris Mullin, asked to see the report. Mr Meacher was reported to be furious with his own officials for not keeping him properly briefed about the situation, particularly about the disclosure that there are now 32,000 unchecked dumping sites in England and Wales compared with previous figures showing 14,000.

The report is also to be sent to Andrew Bennett, the chairman of the Commons environment sub-committee that examined landfill tax earlier this year." Mr Bennett said: "The disclosures are very disturbing. They confirm some of our own findings earlier this year and also our concerns about how effective the environment agency has been in discharging its job in policing the dumping of waste."

Tom Brake, Liberal Democrat MP for Carshalton, a member of the committee, said: "In view of your disclosures I shall be asking for the inquiry into landfill tax to be re-opened."

Customs and excise will also receive a report naming firms involved in alleged landfill tax scams. A report will be sent to the national audit office and the audit commission, which polices local government.

fields.headline: McGuinness 'said he sparked Bloody Sunday'
fields.standfirst: The Bloody Sunday inquiry: special report
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein MP Martin McGuinness admitted he was the IRA gunman who sparked Bloody Sunday with a single shot, according to an informer, the Saville inquiry was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein MP Martin McGuinness admitted he was the IRA gunman who sparked Bloody Sunday with a single shot, according to an informer, the Saville inquiry was told yesterday.

Christopher Clarke QC, counsel for the inquiry into the 1972 killings, revealed three security force documents detailing an informer's claims on Mr McGuinness's role in Londonderry at the time, and pleaded with him to give evidence at the inquiry. He has so far refused to offer a statement.

Mr McGuinness, minister for education in the short-lived power-sharing executive at Stormont, yesterday labelled the informer's allegations "a pathetic fabrication", a British military ploy to divert attention from the Parachute Regiment's killing of 14 civilians.

Sinn Fein said Mr McGuinness would welcome the opportunity to give evidence, although only last week he said he wanted to wait and see if Lord Saville's inquiry was a genuine attempt to get at the truth. He said then: "I have never hidden my past from anyone."

Mr Clarke, on the eighth day of his opening statement, disclosed a confidential document on the debriefing on an IRA informer, code-named Infliction. It was dated April 6, 1984. The crucial passage read: "Martin McGuinness had admitted to Infliction that he personally fired the shot from a Thompson sub-machine gun from Rossville Flats that precipitated the Bloody Sunday episode."

A classified message of May 15, 1984, sent to the RUC, Northern Ireland Office and the British embassy in Dublin, read: "Speaking in confidence, a leading member of the Provisional IRA who no longer has access to the organisation commented that Martin McGuinness personally fired the shot (from a Thompson machine gun on 'single shot') from Rossville flats in Bogside that precipitated the Bloody Sunday episode."

Another document said: "At the time of Bloody Sunday 30 January 1972, McGuinness was a senior member if not OC (officer commanding) of Londonderry PIRA. Although we have no collateral for the above report (the Infliction claim) there is intelligence that McGuinness was actively inolved in PIRA attacks in the city shortly after Bloody Sunday."

Paratroopers shot dead 13 unarmed Catholics, seven of them teenagers, during an illegal anti-internment march in Derry on January 30, 1972. A man who was wounded died five months later.

fields.headline: BNFL admits 'near fatal' safety lapse
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels yesterday admitted breaching safety regulations after three of its workers were burned during a leak of corrosive acid at its Sellafield reprocessing plant.
fields.body:
British Nuclear Fuels yesterday admitted breaching safety regulations after three of its workers were burned during a leak of corrosive acid at its Sellafield reprocessing plant.

The men were injured at the Cumbrian plant in March last year when seven cubic metres of concentrated nitric acid escaped from a valve.

The accident happened because managers had allowed a culture to grow in which working practices were not checked, Whitehaven magistrates heard.

One worker would have suffered fatal burns had he not worn a protective chemical suit which was not routine for repair work, the court was told.

British Nuclear Fuels plc and BNFL Engineering Limited pleaded guilty to failing to ensure safety of workers during commissioning and maintenance work.

The court case came as it emerged that the government may decide to abandon reprocessing the remaining spent nuclear fuel at the Dounreay nuclear plant in Caithness, and instead store it - the first time in 50 years of the nuclear industry that storage and disposal has officially been considered an alternative to reprocessing by ministers.

At Dounreay, the two experimental fast breeder reactors and other protoypes are already being dismantled, but Helen Liddell, energy minister, has yet to decide what to do about the reprocessing lines.

Whitehaven magistrates heard yesterday that workers at BNFL's solvent treatment plant had taken to using their own system because procedures put in place by management were "complicated and unworkable".

The case was subsequently adjourned to Carlisle crown court for sentencing to a date yet to be fixed.

Yesterday Ms Liddell announced that in effect ministers will be letting the public decide what happens to the fuel at Dounreay by inviting the people to choose from three options.

The Dounreay works, which employs 2,000 people, was created at one of the remotest spots in mainland Britain because of the potential danger.

The three alternatives are to repair the lines and complete the reprocessing of 25 tonnes of fuel; close the plant and send the fuel to the Thorp reprocessing works in Cumbria to be dealt with; or to dry store the fuel and eventually, in around 50 years, find an underground vault in which to dispose of it.

This third option is what environmental groups have been demanding for years - not just at Dounreay but at Sellafield.

Their argument is that reprocessing is more expensive than storage and recovers pure bomb-making plutonium from the fuel, which would otherwise remain locked up and be no use to anyone.

The nuclear industry has resisted an end to reprocessing because it says that to store and dispose of fuel is a waste. The plutonium is too valuable as a potential energy source not to recover it.

The government has yet to decide between the two arguments - particularly a recommendation by the House of Lords science and technology committee that plutonium should be reclassified from the most valuable metal in the world to a nuclear waste.

webTitle: Zimbabwe tells Britain to compensate white farmers

fields.headline: Zimbabwe tells Britain to compensate white farmers
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's parliament yesterday amended the constitution to allow the government to seize white-owned farmland without compensation for redistribution to poor blacks.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal in Harare and Andrew Meldrum in Ruwa
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's parliament yesterday amended the constitution to allow the government to seize white-owned farmland without compensation for redistribution to poor blacks.

But cabinet ministers, who told parliament the bill was "unfinished business" from the colonial era that would "put the land issue to rest", were divided over whether the government's new powers would bring an end to the invasions of white-owned farms by large numbers of blacks or encourage more of them.

The new provision, which will take effect as soon as President Robert Mugabe puts his signature to it, says it is Britain's responsibility as the former colonial power to pay dispossessed white farmers for their losses.

The amendment nearly failed after the ruling Zanu-PF party only mustered exactly the 100 votes required to change the constitution, apparently because some of the party's members of parliament stayed away out of pique at being dropped as candidates in next month's elections.

The minister of industry and commerce, Nathan Shamuyarira, led the charge over the land issue: "The land we are talking about was occupied entirely by our people, the indigenous people of the country, until 1890. They [the British] reserved the best resources - land, cattle, forest-ation, what have you - for themselves ... What the bill simply states is that Zimbabwe belongs to the indigenous people of Zimbabwe. It does not belong to anyone else."

One cabinet minister told parliament there was no racial element to the proposed redistribution even as another said only black Zimbabweans should own land. Another noted that the government was being accused of land grabbing and asked who had grabbed the land first.

Mr Shamuyarira repeated his government's contention that responsibility for compensating the farmers lies with Britain, not just as the former colonial power but because Harare claims that Margaret Thatcher agreed to provide the funds as a condition of Mr Mugabe signing the Lancaster House agreement, which finalised Zimbabwe's independence 20 years ago.

"That agreement was abruptly abandoned when the Blair government came to power," he told parliament. "Mr Cook has now indicated that the British government would contribute to a resettle ment programme. That is a good change of position. But there must be certain very basic understandings. We will compensate the farmers for the development they have made on the farms (such as buildings) but there will be no payment for the land that belongs to us in the first place."

Zimbabwe's beleaguered white farmers expressed dismay at the passage of the amendment. "This now gives Mugabe the power to help himself. This obviously is not good for the country," said Rob Brown on his farm in Ruwa. "In the short term, he might satisfy a few people. In the long term it will send this country downhill."

The minister without portfolio, Eddison Zvogbo, indicated to parliament that the constitutional amendment might bring an end to the land invasions and siege of white farms by armed men, evidently encouraged by the government.

"This bill is the only way out. Let's get done today so we can repair our race relations. Once we get over today, law and order will return," he said. "Even white citizens in this country should love this bill because it is going to restore order and good governance in the country. Without it, forget it. The turmoil will continue."

This obviously is not good for the country," said Rob Brown on his farm in Ruwa. "In the short term, he might satisfy a few people. In the long term it will send this country downhill." The minister without portfolio, Eddison Zvogbo, indicated to parliament that the constitutional amendment might bring an end to the land invasions and siege of white farms by armed men, evidently encouraged by the government. "This bill is the only way out. Let's get done today so we can repair our race relations. Once we get over today, law and order will return," he said. "Even white citizens in this country should love this bill because it is going to restore order and good governance in the country. Without it, forget it. The turmoil will continue."

webTitle: Shares in DNA firm soar after 'breakthrough'

fields.headline: Shares in DNA firm soar after 'breakthrough'
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: The frantic business versus public sector race to decode the full biological recipe for human beings speeded up yesterday with the claim by the US firm Celera to have reproduced all the genetic fragments needed to map a person's DNA.
fields.byline: James Meek  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
The frantic business versus public sector race to decode the full biological recipe for human beings speeded up yesterday with the claim by the US firm Celera to have reproduced all the genetic fragments needed to map a person's DNA.

Celera's shares on the New York stock exchange rocketed 21% after the head of the company, Craig Venter, announced the landmark achievement.

But John Sulston, head of the British end of the joint UK-US Human Genome Project, Celera's public sector rival, said the announcement meant little as long as Celera was keeping its data a commercial secret. "The difficulty is that we can't see what they've actually got," he said. The Human Genome Project makes all its data freely available on the Internet.

Ed Black, director of corporate relations for PE, Celera's parent company, said that the announcement confirmed Celera was further along in mapping out the entire genome than any other business or public organisation. The company would release its in its own time.

The epic struggle to decipher the human genome, the chemical "book of life", written into the nucleus of our cells which takes the raw elements of the universe and turns it into people, has consumed hundreds of millions of pounds.

Once the genome has been decoded scientists hope to conquer many, if not most, diseases - even ageing.

Unlike the two projects to which it is most often compared, the building of the atom bomb and the race for the moon, the rivals in the genome race are not two warring camps but two opposing philosophies, commercial and public. Celera, which hoped to turn its subscription-only genome database into a money-spinning resource, was thrown on the defensive after a joint statement by president Bill Clinton and prime minister Tony Blair, calling for genomic data to be in the public domain.

Celera made its announcement yesterday to coincide with Dr Venter's testimony in congressional hearings on the human genome project.

Dr Venter, a highly regarded former public sector scientist turned entrepreneur, announced "the sequencing phase of one person's genome" - the partial decoding of thousands of DNA fragments which will, once assembled by computer, make up the full human genome. The public project claims to have fully decoded more than two thirds of the full genome. If the genome is the book of life, then the public team has read two thirds, while Celera has all the chapter headings.

There was resentment yesterday at the public project's UK base in Cambridge at what they perceived as Celera's attempt to steal a march using, in part, the Human Genome Project's own freely-available data. The public project is not expected to announce its own rough draft of the human genome for several weeks.

"Celera clearly felt the need of an urgent announcement," said Dr Sulston. "They've chosen to make it very dramatic: 'We've finished.' They haven't."

"There's no race, because we're heading for different goals. They want to make a profit. We want to make data publicly available."

Scientists said that even without full decoding of the genome, Celera's DNA fragments would make it possible to map most of the tens of thousands of human genes.

"I would describe this as a significant step towards making available all the important information in the human genome," said Richard Turner, a senior editor at the scientific journal Nature.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: • Sad to report, my so-called rival at the Independent may have missed a little scoop... the paper's new picture researcher is one Astrid Proll. Readers may also remember her as "Miss Terror" from a spirited stint with the German anarcho-terrorist group Baader-Meinhof in the 70s, when she helped plan bank heists ("Lots of people have done that, haven't they?" she tells the Wharf newspaper), and later picked up a five-year stretch for armed robbery. Understandably, Miss Proll, whom colleagues describe as nice but strong-minded, is not keen to discuss her previous career, and we take our hats off to the Indie for being so civilised towards someone who has done her time and rebuilt her life. Doubtless the rest of the press will take a similar line, especially the Sun, which once shown similar generosity to a reporter who killed his wife.

 Sad to report, my so-called rival at the Independent may have missed a little scoop... the paper's new picture researcher is one Astrid Proll. Readers may also remember her as "Miss Terror" from a spirited stint with the German anarcho-terrorist group Baader-Meinhof in the 70s, when she helped plan bank heists ("Lots of people have done that, haven't they?" she tells the Wharf newspaper), and later picked up a five-year stretch for armed robbery. Understandably, Miss Proll, whom colleagues describe as nice but strong-minded, is not keen to discuss her previous career, and we take our hats off to the Indie for being so civilised towards someone who has done her time and rebuilt her life. Doubtless the rest of the press will take a similar line, especially the Sun, which once shown similar generosity to a reporter who killed his wife.

 My friend Stephen Glover may have time to consider this news from his his old paper, should his interest in the "IRA cell running the Guardian" have been sated by his endless Spectator profile of "revolutionary-turned-novelist" Ronan Bennett. Ronan, the partner of our deputy editor, is the man Steve identified as the Republican hand guiding the Guardian, but by his own standards this is an unwontedly balanced, smear-free and accurate effort. And how sweet of him to invent a sister for Ronan! Fingers crossed we can replicate this form when we return the honour by exploring Steve's past, notably that all too brief stint as launch editor of the Independent on Sunday.

 Michael Winner is the latest to sport the Oooh You Amaze Me! T-shirt, and I haven't seen him looking more gorgeous. Thanks to Michael, who posed in his bedroom (just the two large tellies?), for so gamely cramming himself into the Frank (size XL) garment. Franks and Kens (size L) are available at £7.50, cheques payable to Guardian Media Group.

 An enchanting exchange was overheard in the government lobby on Wednesday as MPs queued to vote on the freedom of information bill. Fiercely loyal Labour MP Claire Curtis-Thomas to foreign office minister Peter Hain: "Peter, I just want to say that reply you sent me on Iraq was the best ministerial reply I've ever received in my time in parliament... so good I've sent it out to everybody on my database, which is 500 people." Gosh. Peter: "Well, Claire, we thought your letter was so good, it deserved a good long reply." Ahhh! What a sweetheart not to mention that his three-page reply is the standard response sent in answer to complaints about FO policy on Iraq.

 Also overheard, later on Wednesday night in the Commons tearoom, was this from Fatty "Nicholas" Soames: "Well, I keep all my guns in London." It sounds terribly stylish, no doubt at all. But, Fatty, why?

 Apparently that splendid German carmaker BMW has been involved in some controversy recently. I don't know anything about that. All I know is that BMW press officer Jo Slater agreed to loan us the new M Coupe, after we point out to her that I'm popping over to France and feel it's important to test the 155mph top speed claim on an empty French motorway. "Oh no," shrieks Jo. But to be serious for a moment, the M Coupe is a snip at £40,000 because it's beautifully engineered and it really is a driver's car! Plenty more like that, Jo, don't you worry about it.

webTitle: $525m loss marks new low for Softbank

fields.headline: $525m loss marks new low for Softbank
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Japanese internet investor Softbank Corp issued a profits warning yesterday that delivered a further blow to wavering investor confidence.
fields.body:
Japanese internet investor Softbank Corp issued a profits warning yesterday that delivered a further blow to wavering investor confidence.

It said it would post a 55bn yen ($525m) consolidated loss in the year to March 31, partly reflecting a ¥47.5bn foreign exchange appraisal loss in yen-denominated debts held by its US holding company.

The company had reported a ¥15.45bn group loss the year before. The warning, issued after the market closed, coincides with mounting investor scepticism about the company's true value. Softbank's shares have already been badly hit in recent weeks by volatility in the Nasdaq market and by fears that it faces a funding crunch.

Softbank ended down 3.92 % at ¥73,500, and has shed more than 60% of its value from mid-February's record of ¥198,000. Unrealised profits on investments are likely to support a Softbank share price around ¥60,000 to ¥70,000, analysts said, but both its market capital and unrealised gains were vulnerable to further declines in wobbly hi-tech shares.

webTitle: Scramble for a slice of the IP pie

fields.headline: Scramble for a slice of the IP pie
fields.standfirst:
American newcomers intend to survive shakedown among business service providers

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A year ago there was a paucity of bandwidth available for small and large businesses wanting to gain a toehold in the new "webcentric" economy.
fields.body:
A year ago there was a paucity of bandwidth available for small and large businesses wanting to gain a toehold in the new "webcentric" economy.

Now it seems that there is a glut of suppliers of such bandwidth in the guise of KPNQwest, BT, AT&T, Cable & Wireless, Colt, Global Crossing and Level 3 Communications - which are all fast rolling out internet protocol (IP) technology that will deliver high-speed data transmission and internet access.

In fact, research by the Yankee Group Europe suggests there are at least 21 major players in the European IP market today. Another set of forecasts values the e-business service market at £33bn by 2003 - a big pie of which each of those 21 operators wants a slice.

The question is whether there is sufficient demand from internet service providers for large corporations to support such a number of IP suppliers.

Gail Smith, president of Level 3 Communications Europe, a lesser known operator in the market, expects to survive any competitive shakeout of IP providers.

She says there is so much demand that Level 3's concerns are not customers but being "supply constrained".

"It's a hot market," Ms Smith says. "We were concerned about coming into Europe as we were unsure if the phenomenon we were seeing in the US was happening here. So far, we've been pleasantly surprised and Europe is moving very fast."

Level 3 was listed on Nasdaq three years ago and is now capitalised at $32.5bn. It has dug trenches in 32 capital cities to lay its fibreoptic links to supply high-speed connections and intends to increase that number to 70 cities by 2001. It plans a global fibre-optic network stretching from the US to the Asia-Pacific region and then Europe - a total of almost 20,000 miles.

Ms Smith will not reveal the level of Level 3's investment, given that laying fibre networks is costly, but she does admit the company has raised $13bn since its stock market debut.

Level 3 counts among its clients the BBC, Sony Europe, Cello and Scoot.com. Some of those clients outsource their information technology requirements to Level 3's warehousing centres, which also act as e-service consultancies. Many IP providers are building such centres in addition to their high-speed network links.

IBM and KPNQwest announced plans this week to roll out some 18 cybercentres throughout Europe, while BT and AT&T said they intended to increase the number of their data centres from 14 to 44 globally in the next three years. Ms Smith expects the shake-out not to occur by market share but in the prices charged by the IP providers.

Level 3 intends to slash the cost of high speed connections by 50% annually.

Ms Smith claims Level 3 can do this by constantly upgrading its fibreoptic network at a very low cost, thus multiplying its traffic carriage capacity.

When Level 3 laid its fibreoptic cable network it installed "access chambers", which enable it to thread additional fibre through its pipes as demand dictates without having to rip up pavements again.

"By continually pooling a new generation of fibre we will be able to drive down the cost of the service as fast as we want to," Ms Smith says.

"In the long term it will be the underlying cost per bit that you can deliver - not how much theoretically you can do - that will decide competition."

fields.headline: T-Online defends low-level float price
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A senior executive at T-Online International, Deutsche Telekom's net service provider, yesterday defended its decision to set a lower price range for the company's flotation.
fields.body:
A senior executive at T-Online International, Deutsche Telekom's net service provider, yesterday defended its decision to set a lower price range for the company's flotation.

In the wake of the battering suffered by technology stocks in Europe and the US recently, T-Online is pricing the sale of a 10% stake at between 26 and 32 euros a share, compared with initial market expectations of 35 to 50 euros.

At the top of the indicated price range T-Online would be valued at just over 30bn euros.

Yesterday Wolfgang Keuntje, chairman of the managing board, said it would be for investors to determine whether the price was high or low.

"We believe [the range] is fair," he said. The flotation was not aimed at wringing the last euro from the offer for sale but to provide T-Online with a public listing which would give it "the currency to make acquisitions".

Mr Keuntje said the industry was in a "consolidation phase" and argued that that would provide more opportunities for acquisitions than at a time when valuations were higher.

T-Online claims to be Europe's biggest ISP with some 4.7m customers in Germany and, despite the recent shake-out among hi-tech markets, there are indications that the issue is likely to prove popular.

According to a recent survey in Börse Online magazine, one in five Germans is planning to buy T-Online shares.

Interest in the sector climbed again yesterday when freenet.de - Germany's third largest ISP - said that France Telecom might buy a stake.

The French company - arch-rival of Deutsche Telekom since the collapse of their alliance when the German group sought to acquire Telecom Italia - is France's biggest ISP through its Wanadoo subsidiary. Last month it bought 28.5% of freenet.de's parent company, Mobilcom.

The buy, underlining the increasingly international nature of competition in Europe, benefited as freenet.de's shares climbed by almost a fifth in value yesterday.

fields.headline: Queen gleans royal profits
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The Queen, who has expressed regret over the pace of modern life, had cause to change her mind yesterday after a £100,000 investment in an internet company four months ago turned into a holding worth some £870,000.
fields.body:
The Queen, who has expressed regret over the pace of modern life, had cause to change her mind yesterday after a £100,000 investment in an internet company four months ago turned into a holding worth some £870,000.

Shares inGetmapping.com, in which she has a 1.5% stake, were set at 200p each ahead of the company's stock market debut this morning.

Getmapping.com is compiling an aerial photography map of Britain which it aims to sell over the internet to estate agents, civil engineers and local authorities, as well as private individuals.

The business is raising £6.5m through the float to complete its picture of Britain by the end of the year and begin a drive overseas. The offer price values it at £57.7m.

The Queen's attention was drawn to Getmapping in November when the company dedicated its Millennium Map, designed to provide a Domesday book-style snapshot of the country at the turn of the century, to her. Half the investment is by way of a loan, which means the Queen's equity stake of £50,000 has grown seventeenfold.

Lord Fellowes, the Queen's private secretary from 1990 to 1999, became a non-executive director of the company after the investment was made.

The placing of 5.5m shares with institutions was four times oversubscribed - despite the turbulence among internet stocks.

Managing director Tristram Cary said he was confident the shares had been priced conservatively. "The market for internet stocks could be wobbly for quite a long time," he said. "But then we are not a typical internet stock. Our content is very valuable and we have a proven market.

"The royal connection has helped with publicity, but really I think it's the idea behind the business that attracts people." Getmapping also has a licence to reproduce the original Domesday book.

fields.standfirst:
The government did the right thing, if not the popular thing, on the pensions question

Welfare reform: special report
fields.trailText: The government did the right thing, if not the popular thing, on the pensions question
fields.body:
Imagine this news story: "Labour Restores the Link Between Pensions and Earnings! Twenty years after Mrs Thatcher axed the link between earnings and the state pension, Tony Blair yesterday restored it for the country's 10m pensioners, under pressure from Tony Benn, Jack Jones, Barbara Castle and Age Concern."

Imagine the scene in the Commons, the celebrations among the 41 Labour MPs who rebelled against the social security bill this week. MPs quivering nervously in marginal seats, fearing an anti-Labour swing will sweep them away, would rise to their feet, stamping, shouting and waving order papers. The Tories would sit there like a row of popped balloons. Labour heartlands would throw their hats in the air, Roy Hattersley would have to eat his again.

But it didn't happen. Instead that pathetic 75p increase made sour headlines, lifting the basic pension to just £66.75 a week. Why, flush with money, did Labour go for the bad news story and eschew a good news quick hit? Was it simple Treasury parsimony? No, not at all. Here is a truly remarkable fact: if Labour had decided to restore the link the day they came to power it would have cost less, not more, than they are currently spending on pensioner benefits. They would have saved a huge £800m over the last three years - and won the hearts of the pensioner lobby by spending less. So why didn't they?

Because they did the right thing and not the popular thing. They redistributed wealth from rich to poor pensioners and spent £800m more on the poorest, as well as offering free TV licences, letting claimants keep more savings and cutting their tax rates. It should have pleased the left - but they seem to have lost the plot on this. The basic pension is withering away because it goes to growing numbers of newly retired people who are well off, each cohort retiring richer than the last. Only read the Saga brochures aimed at their disposable wealth for cruises and leisure of every kind. How much better than in Beveridge's day when to be old was almost universally to be poor.

In the last 20 years, as with all incomes, a huge gap has opened up between poor and rich pensioners: it no longer makes sense to pay them all the same. Far too many are pitifully poor - but increasing the state pension wastes money on the one-third who don't need it, while it doesn't put an extra penny more into the pockets of the poorest third who don't get it.

The government's minimum income guarantee (MIG) for the poorest ensures no one gets less than £78.45 a week (and more for the older ones). It isn't enough and pensions minister Jeff Rooker admits it. "It's not comfortable," he says, plainly embarrassed by the Lord Falconer's flippant claim that he could live on it, no problem. Rooker hopes it will rise faster over the next years and so it must. Age Concern points to the 60% of pensioners who live on less than £100 a week: they reckon MIG should be set at £90. Labour has indexed MIG to earnings so it will rise far faster than the basic pension - but it still needs more. However, Labour has made the poorest pensioners a real £5.40 a week better off already under MIG - money they wouldn't have had if the government had chosen the populist route, earnings-linking the basic pension instead.

All this is complicated. Eyes glaze over, few bother with the intricacies of the social security system or even of their own pensions. That's the government's headache. How do they explain they've done well for the neediest pensioners if no one understands it? Every vox pop has punters saying things like "How can a pensioner live on just £66.75? It's disgusting." But no one was ever expected to live on the basic pension. Even Beveridge, at the start of national insurance, didn't make the basic pension reach national assistance level: every poor pensioner was always means tested and topped up. Those against targeting pretend it's a Thatcherite phenomenon, but there was never a halcyon time when the basic pension was enough to live on. Sometimes explaining this fact seems like a hopeless cause. The idea that this government is good at spin is bonkers. They are completely hopeless at it.

The anti-means-test lobby, however, has one good point. Although 1.6m pensioners fill out their forms and get their MIG, as many as 700,000 may miss out, perhaps trying to survive on the non-survivable basic pension - a horrible thought. Finding the missing pensioners has now become top priority, with Thora Hird kicking off a TV take-up campaign next month.

Research suggests it is not pensioner pride but ignorance that stops them claiming. Trawling through records, the DSS is looking for all who have no other source of income. Many may be living with their families, wrongly assuming this disqualifies them from MIG. A new help-line* brought in 11,500 inquiries in just three days and all pensioners will get a letter. The 40-page income support form is a nightmare, but soon local pensions offices set up in libraries or local Age Concern facilities (definitely not in stigmatising benefits offices), will answer queries and a new hotline will do all the form filling.

A new pensions ministry, completely separated from other benefits, will pay out and give pensions advice to old and young, urging everyone to save more for their old age. The most startling change will be a written annual statement for every worker, listing all their private and state entitlements so everyone can be warned in time if they are not saving enough. Stakeholder pensions will offer a very good deal, kite marked private pensions with very low administration charges. People can move in and out of them freely, watching how well they are scoring in league tables in a very competitive market.

But there is a trap - an intellectual problem the government cannot resolve. If MIG rises to a civilised level - say £90 a week - it's not worth people on lower incomes paying into a stakeholder pension which will never lift them above that. Yet it's the lower income people the government means to target. These new pensions offices will need to be watched like a hawk for any sign of mis-selling to them. Ah, says Rooker, of course low earners should still buy stakeholders since no one can trust governments to provide enough pension in some 40 years time. Governments often renege: saving privately with a stakeholder is the only guarantee. But if we are entering Blair's new social democratic century in a time of plenty, then low earners deserve to spend their meagre money here and now (or on a mortgage, perhaps) and let the better off pay for their old age later.

Meanwhile, every year at up-rating time the ritual dance of old Labour MPs demanding the restoration of the universal pension will continue. They seem to be campaigning for the rich who have soared ahead of the rest to get more, instead of pressing for far more MIG for the poor to redress this inequality. Odd, isn't it?

* MIG helpline: 0800 0281111

webTitle: Relatives of GP's victims may shun private inquiry

fields.headline: Relatives of GP's victims may shun private inquiry
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: Families of the victims of the serial killer Harold Shipman threatened yesterday to seek a judicial review of the government's decision to hold an inquiry into the deaths in private, and indicated that they might boycott the inquiry.
fields.body:
Families of the victims of the serial killer Harold Shipman threatened yesterday to seek a judicial review of the government's decision to hold an inquiry into the deaths in private, and indicated that they might boycott the inquiry.

"All the relatives feel they've been fobbed off," said Ann Alexander, the families' solicitor. "It was due to [them] that the murder inquiry got off the ground. Now they've had the door slammed in their faces."

Shipman, a GP who had a surgery in Hyde, Greater Manchester, was jailed for life in January for the murder of 15 women. Their relatives, and the relatives of other victims - whose deaths did not lead to further charges against him - are among 49 families represented by Ms Alexander.

The inquiry is expected to begin its formal hearings in Manchester next month.

The families reacted angrily when they learned evidence would not be taken in public. They say they will not be entitled to read written statements or hear the verbal evidence.

webTitle: $2m plot to discredit smoking study exposed

fields.headline: $2m plot to discredit smoking study exposed
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette manufacturer, mounted a $2 million concerted campaign to halt or undermine a scientific study on the dangers of passive smoking, targeting researchers, the media and government, it is revealed today.
fields.body:
Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette manufacturer, mounted a $2 million concerted campaign to halt or undermine a scientific study on the dangers of passive smoking, targeting researchers, the media and government, it is revealed today.

The tobacco industry is accused in the Lancet medical journal of attempting to subvert the normal scientific processes. An editorial in the journal goes on to warn scientists generally against putting too much trust in companies intent on profit. "Tobacco is not the only aspect of medicine open to twisted corporate communications strategies," it says. "All policymakers must be vigilant to the possibility of research data being manipulated by corporate bodies and of scientific colleagues being seduced by the material charms of industry. Trust is no defence against an aggressively deceptive corporate sector."

An investigation into its tactics by Elisa Ong and Stanton Glantz from the Institute for Health Policy Studies at the University of California charges that scientists in the pay of the tobacco industry attempted to infiltrate the largest-ever European study on the effect of passive smoking and that it was successful in a strategy to get the study's findings discounted in the media. Much was at stake. The tobacco industry was afraid that the ten year European study, run by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) affiliated to the World Health Organisation (WHO), looking at the health of non-smokers exposed to other people's cigarette smoke would lead to a clamp-down on smoking in public places.

There has been pressure in the UK and elsewhere for smoking bans which the industry had fought on the grounds that there was no real evidence of harm. "The massive effort launched across the tobacco industry against one scientific study is remarkable," says the Lancet article. "The elaborate plans were developed by Philip Morris's top management, implemented by an elite task force and designed to coordinate the international tobacco industry."

The authors examined confidential documents belonging to the Philip Morris company which have been revealed in tobacco litigation in the United States and interviewed the scientists who worked on the IARC study. They found that by 1993, the company was afraid the IARC study would do for Europe what the Environmental Protection Agency's 1992 report had done for the United States and trigger moves to enforce clean air inside public buildings. Philip Morris decided not to wait for the results, but be proactive and drew up a list of "IARC Objectives".  Delay the progress and/or release of the study

 Affect the wording of its conclusions and official statement of results

 Neutralise possible negative results of the study, particularly as a regulatory tool

 Counteract the potential impact of the study on government policy, public opinion, and actions by private employers and proprietors.

By September 1993, Philip Morris had a task force and a budget of $2 million for the IARC plans - about the cost of the entire ten-year IARC study. A further $4 million was set aside for research projects to contradict the IARC study.

The industry worldwide, including British American Tobacco (BAT), was brought on board. Philip Morris' Washington-based law firm Covington and Burlington was asked to mobilise scientists to find out what was happening in the study. A few years before, these lawyers "had established a network of sympathetic scientific consultants in Europe" in what had been called Project Whitecoat to help the industry "produce research or stimulate controversy", says the article. These scientists, on the tobacco payroll, probed anyone they knew connected with IARC for information "reporting back to the tobacco industry on the study's design, questionnaire, progress and authors' scientific viewpoints," says the Lancet.

The industry tried to set up a "sound science" organisation of sympathetic scientists in Europe to advance its views on the harmlessness of second-hand smoke, but few were willing to play. "Philip Morris realised that the tobacco industry had little credibility in Europe, and it turned to the media to promote its messages," says the article. British American Tobacco took the lead, putting together a package of materials which put its own spin on the IARC study before it had been published.

"On March 8 1998, the London Sunday Telegraph reported that WHO was withholding a study that not only failed to show that passive smoking caused lung cancer but also might even demonstrate a protective effect," say the Lancet authors.

Documents written by Matthew Winokur who led Philip Morris' efforts against IARC say that the "publicity generated by BAT" started with the Telegraph article, which was then picked up in the US, Australia, Brazil and elsewhere. "Winokur noted that the timing of the Sunday Telegraph story seems to have been designed to precede the release of the UK's Scientific Committee on Tobacco and Health report on passive smoking three days later," says the Lancet.

The result was that the IARC study's message became confused and the subject of controversy. It showed a 16 per cent increase in risk of lung cancer for non-smokers exposed to other people's cigarette smoke, which was consistent with earlier studies. But on its own the IARC findings were not conclusive, which allowed the industry to interpret them as failing to prove passive smoking was a danger.

The Lancet authors say there are lessons for the scientific community. "Scientists and policy makers need to understand that they function in an environment that is heavily influenced by covert tobacco industry efforts to subvert the normal decision-making processes."

In an editorial, the Lancet warns that the tobacco industry, facing tougher restrictions from the US Congress, will not lie down and that "the dirty war of misinformation in academic and more public settings is likely to continue". Journal editors, who cannot investigate the connections and funding of scientists who submit papers, are especially vulnerable to being duped, it says.

webTitle: Sharif sentenced to life for Musharraf plot

fields.headline: Sharif sentenced to life for Musharraf plot
fields.standfirst: Pakistan: special report
fields.trailText: Pakistan's deposed prime minister Nawaz Sharif was last night beginning a life sentence after a court convicted him of plotting against the man who subsequently ousted him from power in last October's military coup, General Pervez Musharraf.
fields.body:
Pakistan's deposed prime minister Nawaz Sharif was last night beginning a life sentence after a court convicted him of plotting against the man who subsequently ousted him from power in last October's military coup, General Pervez Musharraf.

The anti-terrorism court found Sharif guilty of hijacking and terrorism, but cleared him of attempted murder and kidnapping. He was spared the death penalty. His brother Shahbaz and five former senior government officials were acquitted. The defendants had denied all charges.

Sharif's lawyers immediately announced that they would appeal against the verdict, which effectively ends the political career of a man twice elected prime minister, and ensures that the most troublesome opponent of Pakistan's new military regime remains behind bars.

Last night his wife, Kulsoom Sharif, said he was the victim of a "personal vendetta" by Pakistan's military leader and accused the judge of delivering a verdict written by someone else.

"My husband is innocent. He has done nothing wrong. This is a politically motivated judgment under pressure. Only my husband was targeted. That is what they wanted. Such a judgment will make the nation hang its head in shame," she said.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday expressed his concern. "From the outset we have called for a fair and transparent trial. But we are disturbed about a number of aspects," he said.

"These include changing the terms of the trial to include hijacking in the anti-terrorist laws after the alleged event, and the questionable judicial climate given the forced oaths of allegiances for the senior judiciary."

Under Pakistani law Sharif, who is 50, will serve 25 years if his life term is not reduced by either the high court or the supreme court.

"We feel we have a very good case to fight because the others accused were all acquitted on the same charges," defence lawyer Naveed Malik said.

Prosecutors during the two-month trial had claimed Sharif tried to stop a commercial aircraft with Gen Musharraf on board from landing in Pakistan, risking the lives of 198 passengers. The general - whom Sharif had just sacked - only landed after the army took control of Karachi airport, staging a coup hours later on October 12 last year.

Before the hearings - during which a defence lawyer was shot dead - Pakistan's judges were forced to swear an oath of allegiance to Gen Musharraf. Those who refused, including the chief justice, lost their jobs.

Giving judgment in a packed courtroom in Karachi, Judge Rehmat Hussain Jafri said Sharif had ordered three fire engines to block the runway and had the landing lights switched off.

"If the plane had landed in the presence of these things it would have crashed," he said. "The effect of the hijack was to create terror and insecurity in people and the passengers on board."

Several of Sharif's relatives wept when the verdict was read out. Others began to chant "Nawaz Sharif zindabad " (Long live Nawaz Sharif). The former prime minister looked grim.

"We are just devastated," Saadia Abbasi, the sister of one of the defendants, said. "This is a ridiculous judgment. The evidence is biased."

The prosecution yesterday announced they would appeal against Sharif's sentence and demand the death penalty - an option which Pakistan's military rulers were well aware would have provoked international outrage. Twenty-one years ago, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Pakistan's first elected prime minister, was executed by the military after a coup.

Speaking outside court, Javed Jabbar, Gen Musharraf's national adviser, said: "We want Nawaz Sharif to be subject to the same law he formulated and promulgated", a reference to the draconian anti-terrorism law the prime minister introduced after his election victory in 1997.

The court also fined Sharif 3m rupees (£40,000), including 10,000 rupees compensation to each of the passengers on board the Pakistan International Airlines flight from Colombo in Sri Lanka to Karachi - Gen Musharraf among them.

The judge also confiscated all Sharif's property. Technically he owns none - the Sharif family estate in Lahore is not registered in his name. "He does not even have a bank account in his name," a relative said.

Yesterday's verdict consolidates Gen Musharraf's position as chief executive of the world's most precarious nuclear nation and leaves the country's democratic parties headless and in disarray.

While loyalists from Sharif's Pakistan Muslim League insist he will continue to lead the party from prison, others will attempt to find a new leader.

The verdict provoked little reaction on the streets of Pakistan. Public demonstrations were banned last month by Gen Musharraf in advance of a brief visit from President Clinton, who had urged the military regime to show clemency towards its deposed ruler.

Sharif's daughter Mariam said her father would become an even greater leader from jail.

"We were born in Pakistan and we will die in Pakistan," she declared. Sharif still faces two outstanding corruption charges and investigators are preparing 16 other cases against him.

Road to conviction

October 8 1999 Relations worsen between Pakistan's prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, and his army generals. Three resign, criticising the government for the economic crisis and religious killings

October 12 Sharif sacks his army chief of staff, Gen Pervez Musharraf, and allegedly prevents the plane carrying the general back from Sri Lanka from landing in Pakistan. Musharraf stages military coup, deposing Sharif

October 28 Pakistan army throws open the Sharifs' palatial family home near Lahore - with its private zoo and marble-clad villas - in an attempt to discredit Sharif

January 20 2000 Sharif formally charged with terrorism, hijacking and conspiracy to murder, offences which carry the death penalty

January 26 Sharif trial opens in Islamabad

February 26 In an interview smuggled out of his cell, Sharif claims the West acquiesced in the dictatorial destruction of democracy

March 10 Three gunmen shoot dead Sharif's lawyer, Iqbal Raad, in his Karachi office

April 6 Sharif sentenced to life after being found guilty of terrorism and hijacking. Acquitted of conspiracy to murder

Under Pakistani law Sharif, who is 50, will serve 25 years if his life term is not reduced by either the high court or the supreme court. "We feel we have a very good case to fight because the others accused were all acquitted on the same charges," defence lawyer Naveed Malik said. Prosecutors during the two-month trial had claimed Sharif tried to stop a commercial aircraft with Gen Musharraf on board from landing in Pakistan, risking the lives of 198 passengers. The general - whom Sharif had just sacked - only landed after the army took control of Karachi airport, staging a coup hours later on October 12 last year. Before the hearings - during which a defence lawyer was shot dead - Pakistan's judges were forced to swear an oath of allegiance to Gen Musharraf. Those who refused, including the chief justice, lost their jobs. Giving judgment in a packed courtroom in Karachi, Judge Rehmat Hussain Jafri said Sharif had ordered three fire engines to block the runway and had the landing lights switched off. "If the plane had landed in the presence of these things it would have crashed," he said. "The effect of the hijack was to create terror and insecurity in people and the passengers on board." Several of Sharif's relatives wept when the verdict was read out. Others began to chant "Nawaz Sharif zindabad " (Long live Nawaz Sharif). The former prime minister looked grim. "We are just devastated," Saadia Abbasi, the sister of one of the defendants, said. "This is a ridiculous judgment. The evidence is biased." The prosecution yesterday announced they would appeal against Sharif's sentence and demand the death penalty - an option which Pakistan's military rulers were well aware would have provoked international outrage. Twenty-one years ago, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Pakistan's first elected prime minister, was executed by the military after a coup. Speaking outside court, Javed Jabbar, Gen Musharraf's national adviser, said: "We want Nawaz Sharif to be subject to the same law he formulated and promulgated", a reference to the draconian anti-terrorism law the prime minister introduced after his election victory in 1997. The court also fined Sharif 3m rupees (£40,000), including 10,000 rupees compensation to each of the passengers on board the Pakistan International Airlines flight from Colombo in Sri Lanka to Karachi - Gen Musharraf among them. The judge also confiscated all Sharif's property. Technically he owns none - the Sharif family estate in Lahore is not registered in his name. "He does not even have a bank account in his name," a relative said. Yesterday's verdict consolidates Gen Musharraf's position as chief executive of the world's most precarious nuclear nation and leaves the country's democratic parties headless and in disarray. While loyalists from Sharif's Pakistan Muslim League insist he will continue to lead the party from prison, others will attempt to find a new leader. The verdict provoked little reaction on the streets of Pakistan. Public demonstrations were banned last month by Gen Musharraf in advance of a brief visit from President Clinton, who had urged the military regime to show clemency towards its deposed ruler. Sharif's daughter Mariam said her father would become an even greater leader from jail. "We were born in Pakistan and we will die in Pakistan," she declared. Sharif still faces two outstanding corruption charges and investigators are preparing 16 other cases against him. Road to conviction October 8 1999 Relations worsen between Pakistan's prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, and his army generals. Three resign, criticising the government for the economic crisis and religious killings October 12 Sharif sacks his army chief of staff, Gen Pervez Musharraf, and allegedly prevents the plane carrying the general back from Sri Lanka from landing in Pakistan. Musharraf stages military coup, deposing Sharif October 28 Pakistan army throws open the Sharifs' palatial family home near Lahore - with its private zoo and marble-clad villas - in an attempt to discredit Sharif January 20 2000 Sharif formally charged with terrorism, hijacking and conspiracy to murder, offences which carry the death penalty January 26 Sharif trial opens in Islamabad February 26 In an interview smuggled out of his cell, Sharif claims the West acquiesced in the dictatorial destruction of democracy March 10 Three gunmen shoot dead Sharif's lawyer, Iqbal Raad, in his Karachi office April 6 Sharif sentenced to life after being found guilty of terrorism and hijacking. Acquitted of conspiracy to murder

webTitle: New train fleet tested after fire

fields.headline: New train fleet tested after fire
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Four train companies are to test the safety of a fleet of 60 new trains worth more than £100m after fire broke out in the air conditioning and heating system of one train at the weekend.
fields.body:
Four train companies are to test the safety of a fleet of 60 new trains worth more than £100m after fire broke out in the air conditioning and heating system of one train at the weekend.

The fire followed a similar problem on a testing vehicle. Executives of Midland Mainline, on whose train the fire was reported, and of ScotRail and Central Trains, who also operate the trains, have cut off the heating system on all trains pending results of the tests.

The problem occurred when a train pulled into Peterborough station and smoke was noticed coming from the air conditioning system. The train was withdrawn from service.

ADtranz, the Derby based company which built the trains, said: "All passengers and crew safely left the train at the nearest platform. We have identified the system which caused the fire and have isolated it. An extensive investigation is going on. Conclusions are expected within the next few days."

ADtranz said the design of the Turbostar vehicles was "fundamentally fire safe". The electrical equipment under investigation was situated in a stainless steel housing in a fireproof cupboard.

It said the Peterborough fire was contained in the cupboard.

Midland Mainline, which operates intercity services between London, Leicester, Nottingham and Sheffield, said notices had been posted at stations warning passengers of the inconvenience.

All trains were being tested as a precaution.

Passengers would be aware of the loss of heating but this would be offset by heating from the engine.

 A power struggle for the leadership of the train drivers' union Aslef will come to a head in the high court in London today, when three executive members plan to accuse the general secretary, Mick Rix, of organising a coup and locking them out of part of the union's headquarters.

The three, all allies of the defeated former general secretary Lew Adams, are seeking an injunction to overturn the suspension of the executive ahead of a special Aslef conference on April 17 called to settle the dispute over who controls the union.

Supporters of Mr Rix, who was until recently a member of Arthur Scargill's Socialist Labour party, in turn accuse the trio of attempting to disrupt the union and unseat the general secretary on behalf of Labour's Millbank headquarters and the private train operators.

webTitle: The Golden Age of Tony and other fables

fields.headline: The Golden Age of Tony and other fables
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown was furious. He spent the morning pawing the ground like an ageing bull that has had its Viagra prescription refused. He slammed the dispatch box and roared at the Tories, lowering his head as if about to charge. It was a fine and stirring sight.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown was furious. He spent the morning pawing the ground like an ageing bull that has had its Viagra prescription refused. He slammed the dispatch box and roared at the Tories, lowering his head as if about to charge. It was a fine and stirring sight.

The first Treasury question yesterday came from Betty Williams of Conwy, one of those Labour MPs who can't wait to share with us their boundless enthusiasm for this government.

"The Tories," she said, "would scrap working families tax credit and bring back all the despair, the distress and the heartache caused to so many people before May 1997 after 10 years of a Tory government!"

I realised once again that in the minds of many Labour MPs, the period 1979-97 is seen as a mythic wasteland of the kind TS Eliot and Sir James Frazer wrote about. The land was desolate and barren. Under the rule of an old impotent king (the Tory philosophy of the time) no birds sang, no crops grew, no animals bred.

Then on that magical day in May 1997, the old king was ritually killed, and a new, youthful monarch brought peace, prosperity and plenty to the land. I don't think it is wholly fanciful to suppose that the new Blair baby brings a powerful subconscious metaphorical import to some Labour MPs, for whom it symbolises rebirth and virility.

(My optional discussion group on the metaphysical anthropology of tax credit rollovers meets in the Lamb & Flag on Tuesdays. All welcome, cash bar.)

If the chancellor was a bull, Senor Portillo was a matador, swishing his cape, trying to dance elegantly around him. "I know the chancellor likes to swagger and boast," he said, "but for a clever fellow he has made this into the most unholy mess."

Mr Brown snorted angrily. Worried picnickers could be seen heading for the stile.

"They are very restive this morning," he snarled. "They are on edge about a measure which is very popular!

"I would have thought," he went on, hot steam and saliva billowing from his nostrils, "that you would have thought twice after you told the Sunday Times in 1998 that the Conservative party was identified with uncaring social attitudes, selfish behaviour and sleaze."

It's the matador who is supposed to look immaculate to the point of effeminacy, but it was Senor Portillo who accused the chancellor of "preening himself". Mr Brown looked about as preened as a slag heap.

He claimed to be helping working families, said Mr Portillo, and so he was - but only families who don't drink, smoke, drive, save, pay for a mortgage, happen to be married, have a pension or go on holiday. "Why can't he be more honest? Why must Mr Toad be so slippery?"

A great roaring noise filled the house (well, it didn't, but it should have). Bellowing with fury, brick red in the face, Mr Brown shouted: "We are on the side of working families. They are the enemy of working families!"

Nothing would stop him. Under Labour, pensioners would all be millionaires and live on tropical islands (I may have misheard some details). "The Conservatives forever are guilty of selfish attitudes: yesterday, today and tomorrow!"

Christopher Chope, a Tory, tried to accuse him of misleading pensioners over the change in savings limits.

The bull raged terribly. "You should congratulate us on the 11,000 pensioners in your constituency who are going to get free TV licences."

Eleven thousand free licences in a single seat? I don't think so. But it doesn't matter. In the new, restored, Golden Bough Britain, we will all be rich and happy and well-fed every sun-filled day.

webTitle: Anti-Russia vote puts Europe's tough talk to test

fields.headline: Anti-Russia vote puts Europe's tough talk to test
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Russia was last night facing suspension from the Council of Europe after furious denunciations of its brutality during the war in Chechnya.
fields.body:
Russia was last night facing suspension from the Council of Europe after furious denunciations of its brutality during the war in Chechnya.

The parliamentary assembly of Europe's top human rights body, which is separate from the EU, voted to punish Russia if it did not immediately agree to a ceasefire and to talks with rebel leaders.

Crucially, however, suspension has to be approved by member governments, which have so far proved conspicuously reluctant to match verbal condemnation of Russia with practical measures.

In the course of weeks of campaigning, human rights lobbyists expressed disquiet at the role of the British government in seeking to moderate criticism of Russia, which joined the council in 1996.

A suspension would be unprecedented in the 51-year history of the Strasbourg-based council - and would be a symbolic blow to Russian aspirations for closer ties with European institutions.

It could also affect financial assistance from bodies such as the World Bank.

"This is a real milestone," said one delighted official. '"It sends a very clear signal that Russia must act. But now it's down to governments to follow the parliamentarians."

Electronic voting equipment broke down, but council sources said the vote was carried by an overwhelming ma jority of the 290 assembly members. Emotions ran high during the debate, with a Russian delegate trading punches with a Chechen representative.

The vote was preceded by an intensive propaganda campaign by Russia. This included a video showing horrific pictures of atrocities purportedly carried out by Chechen rebels.

Last month the New York-based Human Rights Watch issued a report accusing Russian forces of torturing, beating and raping prisoners at a detention camp. Moscow has denied such accusations, but promised to investigate.

The council vote came as the EU's foreign policy supremo, Javier Solana, headed for Moscow for talks with the Russian president-elect, Vladimir Putin. The EU has imposed mild sanctions on Russia over the Chechen war but has limited its response to try to keep relations on track.

Mr Solana and the Portuguese foreign minister, Jaime Gama, whose country currently holds the rotating EU's presidency, will be the first major western leaders to meet Mr Putin since he won last month's election.

"Clearly what happens in the Council of Europe will be an element of discussions," an EU spokeswoman said. Moscow has repeatedly warned that relations with Europe would suffer if the council approved the proposal.

fields.headline: Africa needs democracy and freedom
fields.trailText: We respectfully beg to differ with President Mandela (Interview, April 5). As Africans, we believe the time has come to stop blaming others for our ills. Debt is a major problem for Africa, its economy and development, but we believe our ills are firmly rooted in lack of freedom. Democracy and accountable government is the only base on which sound and sustained development can occur.
fields.body:
We respectfully beg to differ with President Mandela (Interview, April 5). As Africans, we believe the time has come to stop blaming others for our ills. Debt is a major problem for Africa, its economy and development, but we believe our ills are firmly rooted in lack of freedom. Democracy and accountable government is the only base on which sound and sustained development can occur.

Fifteen years after Live Aid Ethiopia is facing another famine; 20 years after freedom and democracy crowned their struggle, the people of Zimbabwe are sliding into one-party dictatorship; 50 years after their independence, more than 40 African states could not muster more than five helicopters to rescue people after floods in Mozambique. Not to mention civil war and genocide (Lake countries), ethnic and religious intolerance, disease, lack of education etc.

This is a far cry from Mr Mandela's description of African leaders as "rising to the challenge". The Organisation of African Unity, like its sister Arab league, is a club, with a handful of exceptions, for ruling regimes which lack any popular support or democratic mandate. It is for President Mandela to spearhead the change towards democracy and accountable governments in Africa.
Dr IH Fahal
Dr MO Karrar
New Malden, Surrey
ihf@webstar.co.uk

 I lived in Tanzania from 1958 to 1990. Up to independence, Julius Nyerere did not permit non-Africans to be come members of the main political party Tanu and after independence instituted a programme of Africanisation that received much criticism. But those of us committed to Africa understood that privileged whites had no right to impose our view of the world. The psychological impact of colonialism had to be dealt with by allowing Africans to take total control and to make their own mistakes.

White Zimbabweans should recognise that the land they claim is African land. It is neither here nor there whether an African farmer can farm as well as the whites, who have all the advantages - plus the probability they will be airlifted to safety by their kith and kin if things take a nasty turn.
Jean Reynard
London

webTitle: Don't bank on Barclays... or on its rivals either

fields.headline: Don't bank on Barclays... or on its rivals either
fields.trailText: Barclays boss Matthew Barrett could receive a £30m bonus, no doubt in recognition of his seven months' loyal service (As Barclays closes 172 branches, April 6). As the father of someone who gave more than twice that number of years to Barclays, this is obscene.
fields.body:
Barclays boss Matthew Barrett could receive a £30m bonus, no doubt in recognition of his seven months' loyal service (As Barclays closes 172 branches, April 6). As the father of someone who gave more than twice that number of years to Barclays, this is obscene.

Institutional investors may oppose the bonus scheme, but may I suggest that they go further and recommend that the £30m he would have received is shared out among the hundreds of middle managers who have been cheated by Barclays over the past decade of at least that amount?

When my son worked for Barclays, he and his management colleagues had a shared experience in having to put in extra working hours, for which they received no payment, in order to deal with their workloads. My son took staff into his department from five other branches which were closed down. Naturally, his responsibilities in staff size and budget increased dramatically and he also had the burden of dealing with the personnel problems raised by this process. Nevertheless, he achieved all the agreed targets set for him.

Because of the extra responsibilities, my son's job was regraded so that he should have had a significant increase in pay. However, although the job was regraded, Barclays refused to pay him this grade as they said they had a rota for staff to be upgraded and he would have to wait his turn! He waited for more than two years. The final straw came under the performance-related pay deal Barclays offered. He achieved all his targets and exceeded the profit levels set. But, together with other managers, he received a note saying that because his boss had failed to achieve his performance target, none of the managers in his division would get bonuses. This grossly unfair decision was upheld when my son appealed, pointing out that but for the excellent performances of managers such as him, his boss's failure would have been even worse. There was no excuse for Barclays' parsimony at this time - they were showing a healthy trading profit. In disgust my son resigned, even though he had no job to go to.

Having rewarded its loyal staff at 172 branches with redundancy, Barclays may at last be shamed into doing the decent thing for its employees - but I wouldn't bank on it.
Ted Dutton
Hereford

 Ignoring the bonus, no business tycoon can possibly believe that two days of Mr Barrett's superb management activity are worth about the same as a year's work by an average doctor, much more than a year's work by a senior university lecturer and he needs to work only one day to achieve as much as the average teacher or nurse does in a year. The salaries are set by the recipients themselves and demonstrate unbridled greed. To say they could be stopped from setting their own salaries so high by shareholders is also nonsense. Their biggest shareholders are corporations whose managers have a vested interest in not rocking the boat. It's time this government (it is, after all, a Labour government, I believe?) set the tax rates for salaries and commission/bonuses above say £500,000 at such a level as to make nonsense of them.
IJ Gibson
Ullapool, Ross-shire

 If bank managers need so much money to live on, then they can't be very good managers - what on earth do they spend it all on?
Ted Prangnell
Ashford, Kent
ted@tprangnell.freeserve.co.uk

 Is it not time for the debate concerning the purpose, content and structure of core company law to reach an audience far wider than it has thus far received?
Robert Goddard
Cambridge

 You report (Labour accused in banks dispute, April 5) that banks are closing large numbers of branches in rural areas. Perhaps this is to be expected among institutions responsive to shareholder rather than consumer interests. Research at the University of Newcastle shows that between 1995 and 1998 building societies, which do not have shareholders, were more likely than banks, or former societies that have converted to banks, to maintain their branch network and that, if they did close branches, societies were less likely than banks or converters to withdraw services from more socially deprived locations. During this period building societies added to their branch network; banks reduced theirs.

A similar comparison can be made on ATM charges. The vast majority of ATM cards issued by building societies have always given access to the Link network free of charge. Those few societies that did make charges have announced these are to disappear shortly - the opposite trend exhibited by banks.
Adrian Coles
Building Societies Association

 Last Thursday morning I telephoned the Co-op bank to request a transfer of funds to my Tesco bank account. That afternoon I posted a clipping from the Guardian to my son in Japan. Monday afternoon I received an email from my son thanking me for the clipping. That night I bought some food in Tesco, but payment via my Tesco card was refused - the money hadn't arrived. I can't help wondering how much of our money the banks have "in transit" every night and how much they earn from it.
Gerry Mewton
Reading
GMewton2@aol.com

Robert Goddard Cambridge  You report (Labour accused in banks dispute, April 5) that banks are closing large numbers of branches in rural areas. Perhaps this is to be expected among institutions responsive to shareholder rather than consumer interests. Research at the University of Newcastle shows that between 1995 and 1998 building societies, which do not have shareholders, were more likely than banks, or former societies that have converted to banks, to maintain their branch network and that, if they did close branches, societies were less likely than banks or converters to withdraw services from more socially deprived locations. During this period building societies added to their branch network; banks reduced theirs. A similar comparison can be made on ATM charges. The vast majority of ATM cards issued by building societies have always given access to the Link network free of charge. Those few societies that did make charges have announced these are to disappear shortly - the opposite trend exhibited by banks.
