That afternoon I posted a clipping from the Guardian to my son in Japan. Monday afternoon I received an email from my son thanking me for the clipping. That night I bought some food in Tesco, but payment via my Tesco card was refused - the money hadn't arrived. I can't help wondering how much of our money the banks have "in transit" every night and how much they earn from it. Gerry Mewton Reading GMewton2@aol.com

fields.headline: The city on the blink
fields.standfirst: It survived the bug. But now this ...
fields.trailText: Perhaps we should look on the bright side. At least Wednesday's great stock exchange crash was technological rather than financial. Even so, deep embarrassment has been caused to the image of the City and to Andersen Consulting which was managing the computer programmes on behalf of the London stock exchange (LSE).
fields.body:
Perhaps we should look on the bright side. At least Wednesday's great stock exchange crash was technological rather than financial. Even so, deep embarrassment has been caused to the image of the City and to Andersen Consulting which was managing the computer programmes on behalf of the London stock exchange (LSE). Andersen also got egg on its face over technical problems on the government's new system for managing social security. No one comes out of this affair enhanced - except possibly the Chancellor of the Exchequer because he will collect more tax revenue from the inability of some investors to take their tax-free capital gains on the last trading day of the financial year. It's an ill wind that blows no one any good.

It is tempting to dismiss the affair as one of those things that inevitably happen with complicated computer systems, as everyone knows who has been involved with them. The Frankfurt stock exchange - with which the LSE is planning to merge - had a mini meltdown (about 10 minutes) in February, as did the Swiss exchange in November. But that is far too deterministic. This is a very expensive system: people can, and must, be held accountable both for the glitches themselves and for the lack of an efficient back-up system to take over when the main system crashed. It is ironic that the City, which somehow managed to survive the millennium bug unscathed, should be humiliated by the effects of a single heavy trading day.

It is particularly sad because London's embarrassment may jeopardise the stock exchange's plans to merge with Frankfurt to create the basis for a pan-European stock market. This is one of the essential things that must be done to make the European Union work more efficiently as a single market to rival that of the United States. The malfunction in London is bound, at the very least, to alter the terms of the proposed merger. It would be tragic if it scuppered it.

fields.headline: Help for the hungry
fields.standfirst: Why do we let all this food go to waste?
fields.trailText: We are better than we used to be at feeding those in Britain who have too little to eat. New networks of charities are becoming linked to local supermarkets to help distribute unsold edible food - past its "display-until" date, but within its "best before" date - to poor and homeless people. In hundreds of hostels, night shelters and soup kitchens, meals have dramatically improved.
fields.body:
We are better than we used to be at feeding those in Britain who have too little to eat. New networks of charities are becoming linked to local supermarkets to help distribute unsold edible food - past its "display-until" date, but within its "best before" date - to poor and homeless people. In hundreds of hostels, night shelters and soup kitchens, meals have dramatically improved. Our environment editor went to an east London centre for the single homeless this week and tasted a curried soup which included ostrich, chicken, lentils, baked beans and burgers. Specialist distribution charities - Crisis FareShare and Grocery Aid - which collect surplus food from retailers, processors and manufacturers and then redistribute it through refrigerated vans, continue to expand. FareShare now has seven branches delivering to 100 charities, which provide over 22,000 meals a week. Grocery Aid delivers to 374 charities.

According to a report this week from Sustain, an umbrella organisation which brings together 100 groups dealing with poverty, health and the environment, food surplus donations have risen from almost nothing in 1993 to 8m meals a year. Yet, as our special news feature on Tuesday documented, the amount of surplus food saved is still a mere fraction of the amount wasted - less than 1% of the 500,000 tonnes, worth about £400m, thrown away every year. Forget Europe's food mountain: it is time we tackled waste on our own doorstep. Some supermarket chains - Sainsbury, Asda, Marks & Spencer - have actively promoted donation programmes but Tesco does not take part and Safeway only gives food away to animals. More incentives and more organisation are needed.

In the US, tax breaks for retailers and processors have helped to promote schemes of this kind. EU regulations, which are likely to ban the dumping of food in landfill sites within the next few years, will provide a different form of incentive. Some people will argue that charitable food donations only serve to perpetuate poverty. Their warnings should be ignored. Charities have a well-founded reputation for being able to reach people whom state services are unable to touch. Food poverty is a serious problem - three out of five homeless people have no fresh fruit or vegetables in their daily diets. Surplus food schemes will not put an end to that - but they can significantly relieve it.

fields.headline: Campaign notes
fields.trailText: The Which? report on mobile phones does not dispute the Specific Absorption Rates (SAR) test done by the industry and our test was not set out to argue with the SAR test (Letters, April 6). The SAR tests the harm of mobile phones to your health which is a far broader test. Which? Specifically tested hands-free kits for radiation levels to the head. To date, we do not know whether radiation harms our health but if consumers are buying these devices because they think they are reducing radiation levels, our test concluded that the devices we tested increased radiation by three times. That is the message of the report.

fields.headline: Those other elections
fields.standfirst: There is more at stake than a mayoralty
fields.trailText: As everyone knows, London will vote a month from now to choose its first mayor. There are 11 candidates in the field, but on most assessments only three matter. Frank Dobson: is he facing humiliation? Steve Norris: can he establish himself as the clear alternative? And Ken Livingstone: how much will he win by?
fields.body:
As everyone knows, London will vote a month from now to choose its first mayor. There are 11 candidates in the field, but on most assessments only three matter. Frank Dobson: is he facing humiliation? Steve Norris: can he establish himself as the clear alternative? And Ken Livingstone: how much will he win by?

But a lot of other contests are also due on May 4, far less glamorous but still important. As well as electing the authority which will work with (or sometimes against) the mayor in London, we have to fill seats in all 36 metropolitan districts of England, 27 of the 46 unitary authorities and 89 of the 238 shire districts. It will not be surprising if the turnouts here are lower than ever. There is an increasing sense that local government belongs to a time that has passed, that all the decisions which matter are taken elsewhere. That assumption is too near the truth, as this government's centralising tendencies increasingly erode what used to be the territory of the local. Some who might once have been tempted by the chance of running a big authority look now on what local government is empowered to do and wonder if it is worth it. Even the mayors whom Tony Blair is keen to create will exercise powers which, compared to those of the great municipal moguls of Victorian Britain, appear pitiful. Mere councillors have far less clout: an endless round of chores, powers which grow ever more limited, and very few thanks from anyone.

It is symptomatic too of the diminished state of local politics that such speculation as there is over May 4 concentrates on the implications for Tony Blair. That is true of every contest, from the mayoralty downwards: many confess that their main incentive to vote for Mr Livingstone is the hurt it will do to Mr Blair. In other battles, Labour is bound to do badly: after all, it is defending seats won in the bumper local election year of 1996. But the signs are that apathy in its heartlands may hit Labour much worse than that.

Yet projections built on the May results will miss an important truth. It used to be true that the way people voted in local elections was a useful pointer to how they might vote in an early general election. It is probably not so true now. People shift their allegiances far more than they did, not just between general elections, but between one kind of contest and another. The mayoralty, again, is the best example of that. This is a kind of clash we have simply not seen in Britain before. Staunch Conservatives will entrust their support to Mr Livingstone who, however much trouble he causes New Labour, is certainly no Conservative. Where voting used to be seen as a kind of civic duty, it is now a much more take-it-or-leave-it affair: see the levels of turnout in most recent byelections and in last year's race for places in the European Parliament. Which way people vote (or abstain) next month may tell us less than we would like about Labour's present standing.

In any case, what the May elections should be about - again from the London mayoralty downwards - is choosing those equipped to deliver good government and discarding the rest. When the best-equipped see no further purpose in standing for local elections, when voters increasingly shun them, when government rhetoric and action alike seem to endorse that attitude, a slide has begun which, unless we are careful, could soon make these institutions redundant. We need to reverse that trend, replacing the current vogue for centralisation with the pluralism that was once one of the prouder traditions of British politics.

fields.headline: Hain reply on Iraq (again)
fields.trailText: Ewen Macaskill seems to have fallen for Iraqi propaganda about UN policy (Comment, April 3). There was barely a mention of Saddam's culpability. Fashionable though it is to claim that the "rest of the world has little enthusiasm" for the UN's policy on Iraq, the fact is that nine of the 10 elected members of the security council supported the British-sponsored Resolution 1284 and all members are committed to it, including France, Russia and China. There was unanimity on the US-sponsored Resolution 1293 which doubled investment in oil so Iraq can fund new humanitarian programme.
fields.body:
Ewen Macaskill seems to have fallen for Iraqi propaganda about UN policy (Comment, April 3). There was barely a mention of Saddam's culpability. Fashionable though it is to claim that the "rest of the world has little enthusiasm" for the UN's policy on Iraq, the fact is that nine of the 10 elected members of the security council supported the British-sponsored Resolution 1284 and all members are committed to it, including France, Russia and China. There was unanimity on the US-sponsored Resolution 1293 which doubled investment in oil so Iraq can fund new humanitarian programme.

Macaskill claims that "opening Iraq to the outside world would do more to undermine Saddam than sanctions". The last time Iraq was open to the outside world in the 1980s opposition to Saddam was brutally repressed - who can forget Halabja? Saddam's power rests on a comprehensive and insidious system of terror. Would that change? Macaskill also wants us to lift sanctions unconditionally when the UN weapons inspectors return to Iraq. How much would they get done? How long would they stay?

What is the ethical course? Implement a humanitarian programme to provide food, medicine, clean water, agricultural supplies, educational material and electricity. Rebuild Iraq's oil industry so they can export the oil to pay for it. Suspend sanctions to relieve the economic burden on the Iraqi people and allow them access to the outside world. Secure Iraq's cooperation with the UN weapons inspectors so they can prevent Saddam developing new chemical and biological weapons. Maintain the arms embargo. Stop the smuggling of oil but maintain the UN's control of the oil revenue to ensure it continues to be spent on the needs of the Iraqi people and not on Saddam's weapons. This is the UN's new policy articulated in Resolution 1284. All members of the security council are committed to it.
Peter Hain MP
Minister of state, Foreign & Commonwealth Office

webTitle: Breathtaking secret: How whales stay under water so long

fields.headline: Breathtaking secret: How whales stay under water so long
fields.trailText: Biologists at the University of California, who fitted cameras to whales (including a 100 ton blue whale), dolphins and seals, think they have cracked one of the secrets of how mammals stay under water for an hour or more on a lungful of air.
fields.body:
Biologists at the University of California, who fitted cameras to whales (including a 100 ton blue whale), dolphins and seals, think they have cracked one of the secrets of how mammals stay under water for an hour or more on a lungful of air.

The answer is: they do not. Whales and seals expel the air from their lungs shortly after diving so they are no longer buoyant. The rest is squeezed out by increasing water pressure. They are able to remain under for so long by oxygenating their blood and the myoglobin in the muscles.

The secret of seal staying power, revealed in nature documentaries made by the mammals themselves, is in the first few powerful strokes. Once heading straight down, the mammal simply goes on gliding. The secret is in the relaxation, the researchers report in the US journal Science today.

At depth nitrogen in the lungs increases the risk of nitrogen narcosis, the "bends", in humans. Elephant seals can dive to 1,500m, but because they carry down no air, there is no risk of the bends.

webTitle: BBC's secret film was invasion of store's privacy

fields.headline: BBC's secret film was invasion of store's privacy
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC was guilty of invading the privacy of Dixons when Watchdog, its consumer affairs programme, secretly filmed sales in the electrical retailer's stores, the court of appeal in London ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
The BBC was guilty of invading the privacy of Dixons when Watchdog, its consumer affairs programme, secretly filmed sales in the electrical retailer's stores, the court of appeal in London ruled yesterday.

Three judges overturned an earlier high court decision that only individuals, and not companies such as Dixons, were entitled to complain about infringements of privacy under the broadcasting standards commission's code of conduct.

Restoring the commission's original ruling against the BBC, two of the judges nevertheless stressed that corporate bodies could only expect a right to privacy in certain circumstances.

Watchdog researchers went undercover to film 12 sales transactions in an attempt to establish whether Dixons, which had 10 convictions for selling second-hand goods as new, was still doing so. They found no evidence of wrongdoing and the filmed footage was not broadcast.

But DSG Retail, owners of Dixons, complained that the clandestine filming was unnecessary because basic research would have established that new procedures were preventing the misdescription of goods in the stores.

The commission, while accepting the valuable public interest role played by programmes such as Watchdog, upheld the company's complaint. That was quashed by Mr Justice Forbes in the high court last July. He ruled that a company had no right to privacy, either under the 1996 Broadcasting Act or the European convention on human rights, because the privacy rules were established to protect individuals.

He also upheld the BBC's argument that there was no private element in the filming because it was carried out in places to which the public had access.

Yesterday, Lord Woolf, master of the rolls, sitting with Lady Justice Hale and Lord Mustill, allowed an appeal by the commission. "In this case, it is reasonably clear that, if Dixons had been aware of the filming, they would have regarded it as objectionable. The filming was on their property and, although the public were invited to the premises, the invitation was not in relation to secret filming," he said.

The judge added that the courts should be particularly hesitant about intervening in the commission's role, which was to set standards of acceptable conduct and not to make legally binding decisions.

However, Lady Justice Hale and Lord Mustill cautioned that companies could not enjoy a similar right in other circumstances.

The commission welcomed the ruling. Lord Holme, its chairman, said secret filming could only be justified when there was an "overriding public interest".

The BBC is seeking leave to appeal to the House of Lords.

fields.headline: Nurses urge access for families
fields.standfirst: TV dramas encourage relatives to stay with patients
fields.trailText: Relatives should have the opportunity to be present when efforts are being made to resuscitate their loved ones, nurses said yesterday as they called for guidelines on the issue.
fields.body:
Relatives should have the opportunity to be present when efforts are being made to resuscitate their loved ones, nurses said yesterday as they called for guidelines on the issue.

Television hospital dramas like Casualty and ER had created an expectation that family members would be allowed to witness resuscitation attempts, the RCN's annual congress was told.

Some nurses spoke bitterly of having been denied the right to be present when unsuccessful efforts were being made to save their own parents. But others warned of the dangers of relatives interfering in life or death procedures.

Peter Wilson, a casualty nurse from Buckinghamshire, said his unit had had groups of up to 20 people crowding in and relatives "throwing themselves on the patient" in grief.

Up to 600 resuscitation attempts take place in British hospitals every week, but few are witnessed by relatives. A 1994 survey found that fewer than one in four casualty departments allowed family members or friends to be present.

Although the RCN congress in Bournemouth did not go as far as to demand an automatic right of witness, it mandated the college to talk with other organisations on practical guidelines.

Ann Baker, from Gwent, said people's expectations had been raised by shows such as Casualty and ER.

Relatives were also often convinced that the dying patient was helped by them being there, Ms Baker said. "This suggests that the family believe that the patient has some awareness of the situation and therefore finds the presence of the family reassuring and comforting."

Recalling parents who had witnessed failed attempts to save their children, Ms Coulter said: "Many felt that being there to see what was happening, rather than being left in a relatives' room, waiting and wondering, was extremely beneficial in helping them to grieve despite being distressed."

"Many are in favour, but many more appear to be against."

Mike Hayward, who chairs the Portsmouth RCN branch, said the proposed guidelines should not endorse relatives' presence in all cases but set a framework "to facilitate those who choose to be present and support the staff involved".

Opponents of witness resuscitation are concerned not only at possible disruption, but also about witnesses being traumatised, upset by anything seen or heard during the process, or later making complaints or even taking legal action.

"It was a privilege to support this obviously close family through what was a very difficult situation for both them and us," he said. "After he died, his parents thanked the team and stated their appreciation."

webTitle: Melting Arctic ice will mean chillier Britain

fields.headline: Melting Arctic ice will mean chillier Britain
fields.standfirst: Scientists predict end of Gulf stream's warmth
fields.trailText: Warming in the Arctic could be about to "turn off" the Gulf stream - which brings tropical heat to British shores - with catastrophic consequences for the climate of northern Europe in the long term, scientists warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Warming in the Arctic could be about to "turn off" the Gulf stream - which brings tropical heat to British shores - with catastrophic consequences for the climate of northern Europe in the long term, scientists warned yesterday.

Peter Wadhams, of the Scott Polar Research Institute, said that for the fifth winter in the last seven years, a huge tongue of shelf ice had failed to form in the Greenland sea. Arctic ice is both thinning and dwindling.

The loss of ice in the Arctic could have dramatic knock-on effects because its formation is an important part of the ocean "conveyor belt" which sends cold salty water plunging to the seabed and heading south, allowing warm water to flood in from the tropics.

One US climate scientist has warned that if the Gulf stream was turned off, Britain and Ireland would experience temperatures familiar on the Arctic island of Spitsbergen.

"That was too dramatic," said Dr Wadhams yesterday. Temperatures in Britain would drop about 5C and Norway would suffer a 10C fall. "It would not make us like Spitsbergen but it would be a very dramatic, serious change in the climate."

The Gulf stream flows north from the Caribbean, keeping Britain at least 5C warmer than expected at its latitude. Britain's chief scientist, Sir Robert May, once calculated that it delivered 27,000 times the warmth that all Britain's power stations could supply.

It merges with the north Atlantic current and the encounter of this giant, warm surface river with the Arctic winter ice is a powerful part of the convection machine which keeps the ocean swirling.

Ice is fresh water - so the sea that remains is increasingly cold, salty and dense. It sinks, beginning a kind of submarine river, 30 times the volume of the Amazon, flowing south again.

But the Arctic ice cover is in retreat - shrinking by an area the size of the Netherlands every year. It is also thinning, from more than three metres thick to less than two metres in 30 years.

What worried Dr Wadhams and his Arctic colleagues meeting in Cambridge yesterday was the failure, once again, of the huge Greenland ice tongue. It was a powerful agent in the ocean mixing system - and there were signs that the ocean circulation had begun to flag.

"Climate models predict that this process will continue, that there will be a continued loss of convection from the Greenland sea and also the Labrador sea," said Dr Wadhams. "When these both turn off, which will happen within the next 30 years, then the result will be a much slower transport of heat by the ocean from the tropics to our latitudes. And that will mean a cooling for Europe, and especially north west Europe."

This week climate scientists announced dramatic losses in the ozone layer over the Arctic, and blamed global warming in the lower atmosphere. Paradoxically, although the Arctic is warming - driven by the "greenhouse effect" of carbon dioxide from worldwide use of coal, natural gas and petrol - Britain could be condemned to a much colder future. Nations signed up to agreement in Kyoto in 1997 to reduce carbon dioxide emissions - but that may not be enough.

"If nations don't do what they say they are going to do, carbon dioxide emissions will be greater," said Dr Wadhams. "So the assumptions built into all this modelling is that CO2 will reach a peak eventually, and then fall off according to the Kyoto agreement. The Kyoto agreement enshrines what nations think they can manage. So I don't think there is anything anybody can do to fend this off."

Because the world is warming - glaciers everywhere are in retreat, springs are arriving earlier and autumns later, and six of the 10 warmest years ever recorded occurred in the 1990s - the effects would be slow.

"Europe won't see a dramatic cooling until the beginning of the next century," said Dr Wadhams. "It is just that we won't warm as fast as everybody else. The dramatic changes are already beginning to happen in the ocean but the greenhouse effect will stave it off. It will take 100 years for the climate of Britain and Norway to start to cool."

fields.headline: Opto-chip promises computer revolution
fields.trailText: US chemists and engineers have developed a polymer which could trigger another revolution in computing and communications - and bring Star Trek style 3D hologram fantasies a step nearer reality.
fields.body:
US chemists and engineers have developed a polymer which could trigger another revolution in computing and communications - and bring Star Trek style 3D hologram fantasies a step nearer reality.

Using the new material, they promise an "opto-chip" that will process signals at 100 gigabytes a second. This is the equivalent of War And Peace, multiplied 80,000 times, every second.

The material could accelerate information processing speeds 10-fold, but needs only a fraction of a volt of electricity to operate, according to the journal Science today. Microscopic devices made from it would translate electrical signals - from television, radar, computer and telephone - into optical signals to run down fibre optic cables, or to steer radiowaves and microwaves to telecommunications satellites.

"These electro-optic modulators will permit real time communication. You won't have to wait for your computer to download even the largest files," said Larry Dalton, a chemist who led teams from the University of Washington and the University of Southern California.

The scientists found that a chip measuring a thousandth of a millimetre across could provide 300 gigahertz of bandwidth - enough to handle all the telephone, computer, television and satellite traffic of a major corporation. The chips could make possible a three dimensional holographic projection with no flicker - a step nearer the "holodeck" in which characters from Star Trek: The Next Generation, created their fantasy worlds.

It could be used in aircraft navigation, and anticollision radar in cars. "It has the potential of revolutionising the way we function," said Prof Dalton.

webTitle: Four horses killed at National meeting

fields.headline: Four horses killed at National meeting
fields.trailText: Four horses were killed in the space of two hours on the opening day of the Grand National meeting at Aintree yesterday, prompting animal rights campaigners to renew their calls for new safety rules.
fields.body:
Four horses were killed in the space of two hours on the opening day of the Grand National meeting at Aintree yesterday, prompting animal rights campaigners to renew their calls for new safety rules.

One horse, Rossell Island, was killed on the course that will be used for Saturday's big race, during a multiple pile-up at the first fence in the Martell Fox Hunters Chase. Two more horses, Strong Promise and Lake Kariba, died in the Martell Cup Chase over the much easier Mildmay course. A fourth horse, Architect, also had to be destroyed.

Peter Webbon, the Jockey Club's chief veterinary officer, described the deaths as "a statistical blip". He said: "What has happened here can be put down to genuine accidents."

Elaine Toland, of the Animal Aid Society, said: "This just reinforces what we have been saying about the dangers of horse racing."

webTitle: Shocked supporters pay tribute to mates who loved their team

fields.headline: Shocked supporters pay tribute to mates who loved their team
fields.standfirst:
Murder hunt as match goes on
History of intimidation and violence
Tragedy that awaited two fans
Brian Alexander on Peter Ridsdale
fields.trailText: Spag and Lofty came from opposite ends of Leeds but they had the same dream of the Uefa cup glinting in the sun in June from the top of a double-decker Leeds United bus.
fields.body:
Spag and Lofty came from opposite ends of Leeds but they had the same dream of the Uefa cup glinting in the sun in June from the top of a double-decker Leeds United bus.

Instead, to the grief and anger of thousands of fellow fans and neighbours, the fibre optics engineer and the scooter-loving pub landlord paid for their love of the club with their lives.

Neither fitted the pattern of a skinhead hooligan: Christopher Loftus was 37, single and "quiet but a good laugh" according to friends in Burmantofts, an inner city area of tower blocks and 1960s terraces where he lived with his parents.

Kevin "Spag" Speight, who was three years older, ran the Bay Horse in Farsley, living with his family - Sue, 36, George,7, and Holly, 3, - in a flat upstairs.

"He was a mate not a landlord," said one of a group of regulars who turned the saloon bar into a huge floral tribute to Spag. Lofty's main shrine was at Elland Road, United's home ground, where his club shirt, inscribed with farewells - "A true fan never to be forgotten" - was knotted to the railings.

Both men, who were part of a 40-strong group which made its way independently to Istanbul, were well-known at the ground. Mr Loftus, who travelled to Turkey with his three brothers, had reckoned to have spent £4,000 following United's progress to the quarter-finals and Mr Speight regularly organised flights and coach trips to follow the club.

"Of course I knew Spag," said Mark Stannard, a fan from York who spent more than £100 yesterday on train and bus fares to get to Elland Road and buy a United home strip to hang on the fence scrawled with the word "Why?". The small slogan beneath - "Keep the white flag flying high".

Leeds's small Turkish community was also aghast at the tragedy. Al Kaht, a businessman, said: "I watched the Turkish TV last night and I don't know how to describe my feelings - devastated, shocked. I just want to extend my sympathies to Chris and Kevin's families on behalf of Turkey and Galatasaray supporters. This has never happened in Turkish football before. Fights between lads after a couple of drinks, yes, but not people getting killed."

Pubs and bars across Leeds held a minute's silence before the game last night, but the appetite for European cup glory had been dealt a body blow by the murders. Fans who were turned back from the cancelled Air 2000 charter flight to Istanbul from Leeds/Bradford airport almost all wanted the club chairman, Peter Ridsdale, and the manager, David O'Leary, to pull out of last night's game. Others at Elland Road, where the statue of former captain Billy Bremner was fitted with a black armband and covered in flowers and scarves, added that Galatasaray fans would be unwelcome at the return leg of the fixture. There were cheers when Mr Ridsdale's request that no Turkish fans travel to Elland Road was relayed from the club souvenir shop to the knots of sympathisers.

Another message on a spray of flowers - "It's only football, for God's sake" - was echoed at the Bay Horse, which usually shows Spag's heroes on satellite TV screens. "Who cares about tonight's game now?" said a regular. But another, a friend of Spag's for more than 20 years, disagreed. "I don't think that's how Kevin and Christopher Loftus would have seen it," he said. "I hope Leeds stuff them tonight, two or three-nil."

webTitle: Murder hunt as match goes on

fields.headline: Murder hunt as match goes on
fields.standfirst:
Shocked supporters pay tribute
History of intimidation and violence
Tragedy that awaited two fans
Brian Alexander on Peter Ridsdale
fields.trailText: Leeds United's match against Galatasaray went ahead in Istanbul last night at a football ground surrounded by thousands of police, as investigations got under way into the murder of two Leeds fans following rioting.
fields.byline: Vivek Chaudhary and Rory Carroll in Istanbul
fields.body:
Leeds United's match against Galatasaray went ahead in Istanbul last night at a football ground surrounded by thousands of police, as investigations got under way into the murder of two Leeds fans following rioting.

Turkish police made 13 arrests, and last night the Foreign Office said there were unconfirmed reports that a suspect, named by the Anatolia news agency as Ali Umit Demir, had been charged over at least one of the stabbings in Wednesday night's fatal attack, which has shocked players and supporters of the West Yorkshire club and the rest of British football.

Around 4,000 police were on duty outside the ground to try to prevent more trouble at the Uefa Cup semi-final. Claims and counterclaims erupted as to who started the trouble.

Specially protected buses took all Leeds fans to Galatasaray's home ground at the Ali-Sami Yen stadium. The authorities had urged them not to leave their hotels during the day for their own safety. They carried flowers into the stadium and at kick-off turned their backs on the pitch to protest at the killings. Leeds lost the match 2-0.

Afterwards the plan was that they be escorted to the airport and put on special flights back to England.

Wednesday night's trouble at Taksim Square in the centre of Istanbul led to the deaths of Kevin Speight, 40, and Christopher Loftus, 37, both from Leeds. Another six Leeds fans are being treated in hospital for injuries; two of them have serious stab wounds.

Around 1,000 Leeds supporters were originally expected in Istanbul for the match but charter flights arranged by the club were cancelled yesterday and fans were urged not to travel to Turkey.

The return match is to be held in two weeks at Leeds United's home ground, Elland Road, but the Football Association announced yesterday that it was considering a ban on Galatasaray fans attending because of safety concerns.

However Uefa, European football's governing body, insisted last night that Galatasaray fans should be able to attend the second leg. "We fully trust the English authorities and we feel that they are capable of taking care of the situation," a Uefa spokesman said.

Around 3,000 fans of the Turkish club are expected to attend the match, most of them London-based fans of the team.

The two Leeds supporters were believed to have been stabbed to death after an argument with a group of workmen. This arose, according to reports, because the Leeds men - after drinking all day - insulted the Turkish flag.

The killings have overshadowed the Uefa semi-final, and back in Leeds scores of mourners left mementos at Elland Road.

Sixteen Leeds United fans returned home yesterday afternoon after failing to get beyond Istanbul airport. They flew back into Manchester protesting at the way they had been treated.

Elizabeth McAndrew and David Brown, both 32, complained of "appalling treatment" by Turkish police. "We went to watch a game of football and instead I had my jewellery, including my engagement ring, taken from me," said Ms McAndrew. "I was strip-searched and left in a cell for three hours on my own."

Trying to establish who exactly was responsible for the knifings, Turkish police have taken witness statements and are planning a number of identification parades in the coming days.

The sports secretary, Chris Smith, last night ordered an urgent report into the killings, and sent condolences to the families of the murdered men. Tony Blair appealed for calm.

A Downing Street spokesman said: "While the facts are being established his [the prime minister's] thoughts and the thoughts of everybody in the government are with the families of the two men."

The chairman of Leeds, Peter Ridsdale, called the killings "one of those black nights in history". One of the fans who died, Christopher Loftus, was landlord of the Bay Horse Inn in Farsley, Leeds, and regularly organised travel to Leeds away games. The other dead man, Kevin Speight, leaves a wife and two children.

fields.headline: History of intimidation and violence
fields.standfirst:
Murder hunt as match goes on
Shocked supporters pay tribute
Tragedy that awaited two fans
Brian Alexander on Peter Ridsdale
fields.trailText: Galatasary are one of Turkey's most successful teams but, as Vivek Chaudhary reports, off the pitch their fans have acquired a reputation as being among the most passionate and intimidating in Europe.
fields.body:
Galatasary are one of Turkey's most successful teams but off the pitch their fans have acquired a reputation as being among the most passionate and intimidating in Europe.

Although there is no suggestion that Wednesday night's violence in Istanbul stemmed from a prearranged clash between two rival hooligan gangs, over the years Galatasaray supporters have been involved in a number of violent incidents, particularly against English clubs.

The club's success has fuelled a reputation for fans who pride themselves on intimidating and at times attacking visiting teams and supporters.

It has become a tradition for Galatasaray supporters to greet teams arriving at Istanbul airport for European matches with insults and threatening banners, the most famous of which reads "Welcome to Hell".

Extremist fans - who like to be known as the "fans from hell" and taunt the opposition with the chant "there is no escape from here" - congregate up to six hours before kick-off at the Ali-Sami Yen stadium, Galatasaray's home ground, working themselves into a frenzy in preparation for the match.

Many footballers who have played at Galatasaray's stadium say it is the most hostile atmosphere they have faced.

It is not simply bravado. In 1993, when Manchester United played Galatasaray in Istanbul, visiting fans were attacked in their hotels while others were rounded up, arrested and beaten by police.

Over the years the team have acquired a reputation for hooliganism within Turkey, during domestic league matches and European football's governing body Uefa have threatened them with expulsion from playing abroad.

For their part, Leeds United also have a history of hooliganism, at home and abroad.

During the late 1970s and early 1980s, violent fans became known for their close links with far-right groups and much of the chanting by fans was directed at black opponents. Racist literature was also openly distributed at Elland Road, Leeds' home ground.

In 1975 fans rioted in Paris during a 2-0 defeat against Bayern Munich in the European Cup final. Consequently, Leeds were banned from European competition for three years.

There were also serious outbreaks of trouble in the 1980s. During one match against Chelsea rioting caused around £100,000 worth of damage.

fields.headline: £100,000 bill in noise case
fields.trailText: A businessman who had the tranquillity of his country retreat shattered by the roar of planes circling overhead was yesterday faced with a legal bill for £100,000.
fields.body:
A businessman who had the tranquillity of his country retreat shattered by the roar of planes circling overhead was yesterday faced with a legal bill for £100,000.

Graham Farley had successfully sued a local surveyor who told him the peacefulness of his £420,000 home at Blackboys, East Sussex, was unlikely to be affected by its proximity to Gatwick.

Yesterday, the court of appeal ruled he should not have been allowed to sue and his damages of £10,750 were quashed. He was ordered to pay lawyers costs amounting to £100,000. A spokesman for Irwin Mitchell, representing Mr Farley, said: "Mr Farley paid for professional advice in connection with the purchase of a property. [It] was negligent that issue has not been challenged by the other side in the court of appeal.

"The astonishing result is that, notwithstanding there was negligence by a professional man, the court has held that our client is not entitled to damages for his physical discomfort, annoyance, vexation and distress [from] aircraft noise at the property." An "important issue of principle", relevant to every homeowner was at stake, he said.

Mr Farley had claimed that the proximity of his house to an aircraft navigation beacon meant he was badly affected by circling planes.

But yesterday, Lord Justice Stuart-Smith said the law did not compensate for distress, frustration, anxiety, displeasure, vexation or aggravation.

Mr Farley's representative said they would be seeking permission to take the case to the House of Lords.

webTitle: IRA dissidents blamed for new bomb attack

fields.headline: IRA dissidents blamed for new bomb attack
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Dissident republican terrorists yesterday fuelled fears that they are blooding new recruits for a concerted campaign of violence after their fourth bombing attack in two months.
fields.body:
Dissident republican terrorists yesterday fuelled fears that they are blooding new recruits for a concerted campaign of violence after their fourth bombing attack in two months.

No one was injured in the early morning attack at Ebrington barracks in Londonderry, which caused extensive damage to an unmanned guardhouse. It is thought the device, containing 5lb of home-made explosives, was lowered over the fence. It is the third attack on an army base in six weeks. Three soldiers escaped injury at Shackleton barracks, 15 miles away in Ballykelly, on February 25 when a device failed to detonate fully.

Terrorists were disturbed four days later as they attempted to mount an attack with a rocket launcher at Killymeal army barracks in Dungannon, Co Tyrone. Security forces are increasingly fearful of a fresh wave of terrorism and have increased their activities in republican areas.

David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, said: "There have been a number of incidents recently which have been attributed to dissident republicans.

"This may be another one. And there is reason to believe that dissident republicans are trying to launch a sustained campaign."

Gregory Campbell, a Democratic Unionist party assembly member for the area, said: "When you look at the past few months, it is as plain as the nose on your face these people are developing terror ist capability. It is obvious they are working towards an attack with loss of life. Within a few months, we are going to be faced with a major onslaught."

Mr Campbell said security at the base had slipped since the IRA's second ceasefire, announced in July 1997. Mitchel McLaughlin, chairman of Sinn Fein, blamed the political vacuum following Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson's decision to suspend the fledgling institutions of government two months ago. He said the attack was the work of dissidents. Bertie Ahern, Irish premier, told the Irish parliament:"I condemn this futile attack. It is also an attack on peace. Such actions are anti-republican and will not overturn the democratic will of the Irish people."

There were no claims of responsibility for the latest attack. Continuity IRA was said to have admitted the earlier bombing attempts on army bases before later saying it had nothing to do with them.

Unlike the Real IRA, responsible for the Omagh atrocity, it has never called a ceasefire.

webTitle: Censors fight to ban hardcore porn videos

fields.headline: Censors fight to ban hardcore porn videos
fields.standfirst:
Film Unlimited
British Board of Film Classification
fields.trailText: Britain's film censors yesterday launched a high court battle to ban the sale of explicit hardcore videos in licensed sex shops.
fields.body:
Britain's film censors yesterday launched a high court battle to ban the sale of explicit hardcore videos in licensed sex shops.

In a test case that could clarify whether or not videos featuring shots of sexual penetration are legal in Britain, as they are in many other parts of Europe, the British Board of Film Classification yesterday argued that such videos should remain banned until more is known about the possible harm caused to children who might watch them.

The case centres on a decision by the independent Video Appeals Committee to overturn the BBFC's refusal to give a special R18 certificate to seven "hardcore" videos produced by two firms, Sheptonhurst, and Prime Time (Shifnal), for restricted sale in 80 licensed sex shops in Britain.

Behind the case lies the home secretary's decision, two years ago, to clamp down on the production of hardcore pornographic videos after the discovery that the BBFC ,under its previous president, Lord Birkett, had started to license "stronger" videos for sex shops to try to put the cowboys of the trade out of business.

But after Mr Straw appointed Andreas Whittam Smith as president of the BBFC, the board changed its policy and refused to license the seven videos - called Horny Catbabe, Nympho Nurse Nancy, TV Sex, Office Tart, Carnival International Version (Trailer), Wet Nurses 2 Continental Version, and Miss Nude International Continental Version - unless "all shots of penetration by penis, hand or dildo as well as shots of a penis being masturbated or taken into a woman's mouth" were removed.

Lord Lester of Herne Hill, QC, for the BBFC, argued in the high court in London yesterday that the decision by the Video Appeals Committee should be quashed as it had wrongly interpreted the law and had failed to take into account the risk of "real and significant harm" to children if the videos were sold for home viewing.

He said the videos comprised "a seemingly endless sequence of energetic, joyless sex which appears consensual but in which there is no pleasure expressed except the occasional feral grunt" and added that their general effect was dehumanising and mechanistic. Lord Lester told Mr Justice Hooper that unless the committee's decision were quashed all hardcore videos would have to be given a certificate unless they were criminally obscene or it could be shown they did cause "devastating harm to more than a minority of children and young people".

Lord Lester argued that the Video Recordings Act 1984, introduced to ban "video nasties", said it was accepted that some videos would be watched by children and that it was better not to run the risk of causing real and significant harm until more was known.

But David Pannick QC, for Sheptonhurst, argued that the committee panel, which had been chaired by a former deputy director of public prosecutions, John Wood, had been acting legally, that the videos involved were, by the standards of the industry, not "hardcore" but "mediumcore", and that the risk of their being seen and causing harm to children was "insignificant".

Mr Pannick said the child psychiatrist Gordana Milavic, who gave evidence on behalf of the BBFC, had seen during 19 years of treating children fewer than six cases where there was a direct link to pornography. He said the committee had also found that while there was much evidence of the impact of violent images on children, there was no systematic evidence or concern from psychiatrists about the impact of pornography on children. The case had to be judged in the modern world where any reasonably intelligent 11-year-old knew how to obtain graphic material from the internet.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Mountain sale plea fails
fields.body:
Mountain sale plea fails

The National Trust of Scotland said yesterday that it should become the custodian of the Isle of Skye mountain range put on sale last month for £10m. But it has failed to reach any agreement with the owner.

John MacLeod of MacLeod, 29th chief of the clan MacLeod, is selling it to raise money for repairs to nearby Dunvegan Castle and to fund conservation and tourism projects.

Law website forced offline

A website set up by Kamlesh Bahl, the former Law Society vice-president, has been shut down by the internet service provider Freenetname after a complaint that it contained defamatory statements.

Ms Bahl, who resigned after findings by an independent inquiry that she bullied five members of staff, posted a statement on her site claiming the society had breached natural justice in its treatment of her.
Clare Dyer

Smoker wins back cigarettes

An 80-a-day smoker yesterday won his battle to have 5,000 cigarettes returned after they were confiscated by customs and excise officials at Dover last July.

Gary Mullen, 41, a lorry driver from Beckton, east London, said the cigarettes were for his own use and provided Dover magistrate John Waring with 12 witness statements backing his heavy smoking habit.

£15m profit on envoy home

The Foreign Office has paid IR£8m (£6m) for a new official home for the ambassador in Dublin - making IR£20m (£15m) profit following the sale of the envoy's previous residence for IR£28m.

The newly purchased house, Marlay Grange, is on the southern outskirts of the city. It needs work costing IR£2m.

Heart deaths payout tops £1m

Damages payouts to parents of children who died after heart surgery at Bristol Royal infirmary have now topped £1m.

The national health service litigation authority - which is handling 199 claims from parents - said that 53 claims have been settled at an average of about £20,000 each.

webTitle: House hit by falling BA plane part

fields.headline: House hit by falling BA plane part
fields.trailText: A 25lb metal seal fell from a London to Glasgow British Airways passenger plane, smashing the door of a house, an accident report revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
A 25lb metal seal fell from a London to Glasgow British Airways passenger plane, smashing the door of a house, an accident report revealed yesterday.

Three days later, a 3 sq ft panel fell from another BA aircraft, the air accidents investigation branch said.

In the first incident, the crew of the Boeing 757 had been "completely unaware" that the seal had come off.

The owner of a house in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, had reported that a large metal object had fallen on his house and smashed his back door on the afternoon of December 3 1999.

Two days later, an inspection of the Boeing 757 at Heathrow had revealed the missing seal. An analysis by BA revealed it had fallen as the plane passed over Mansfield. The airline had now made modifications to ensure there was no repeat of the incident.

On December 6 1999 a panel fell from a BA Boeing 757, with 125 passengers on board, flying from London to Manchester as it climbed over Woburn in Bedfordshire. The flight crew experienced a jolt and the cabin crew reported that a passenger had heard a thud from the right side of the plane.

At Manchester, neither an engineering inspection nor a look around by the co-pilot could find the cause of the problem. But a passing engineer noticed a panel which smoothes the join between wing and fuselage was missing. It has not been found.

webTitle: Plastic wrap warns when food is off

fields.headline: Plastic wrap warns when food is off
fields.trailText: Consumers should soon be able to see whether their food has gone bad without even opening the pack.
fields.body:
Consumers should soon be able to see whether their food has gone bad without even opening the pack.

A plastic wrap being developed by Canadian company Toxin Alert will change colour if the contents become contaminated with food poisoning bugs.

The wrap uses tests using standard antibodies fixed to the inside of the wrapping to warn of salmonella, campylobacter, E coli or listeria, according to a report in New Scientist magazine. But it could be modified to detect pesticides or proteins characteristic of genetically modified food.

But Mike Doyle, director of the centre for food safety at Georgia University, warned the methods used would not detect very low levels of organisms.

fields.headline: Comedian's son jailed for shooting
fields.trailText: The unemployed son of comedian Roy "Chubby" Brown was jailed for 10 years yesterday for the attempted murder of Trevor Finn, a passerby he wrongly believed was part of a gang trying to extort money from him.
fields.body:
The unemployed son of comedian Roy "Chubby" Brown was jailed for 10 years yesterday for the attempted murder of Trevor Finn, a passerby he wrongly believed was part of a gang trying to extort money from him.

At a retrial at Teesside crown court, the jury heard how Martin Reilly, 27, of Billingham, believed he was being targeted by local villains. He said he was carrying a shotgun for protection.

Reilly said criminal elements wrongly thought he had benefited from his father's wealth. He had received threatening phone calls and demands for money.

On the day of the shooting last June, Reilly told the court, he had been followed all day and when a Fiat driven by Mr Finn pulled up alongside him, he thought he was under threat. "I was terrified and felt trapped," he said. "I picked the gun up off the passenger seat and fired it. I had no intention of hurting anyone."

Following the shooting Reilly, a drug user, hid in a friend's caravan before turning himself in five days later.

The jury at an earlier trial had failed to reach a verdict.

Judge Peter Fox QC, told Reilly he had shot at a perfectly innocent man. "He felt the burning sensation of a shot passing his face. He could not have come closer to having his brains blown out."

Reilly, who had admitted four other firearms offences, was also sentenced to five years to run concurrently.

webTitle: Blair's plea to activists in Welsh valleys

fields.headline: Blair's plea to activists in Welsh valleys
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night travelled to the Welsh valleys - the epicentre of the Labour heartlands - and warned party activists not be be driven into a "Tory trap" of imagining the government must choose between Middle Britain and its core supporters.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night travelled to the Welsh valleys - the epicentre of the Labour heartlands - and warned party activists not be be driven into a "Tory trap" of imagining the government must choose between Middle Britain and its core supporters.

Making his first visit to Wales since the troubled Welsh assembly was set up, Mr Blair said the party must never allow itself to become once again the champion of a minority cause.

He said: "The Opposition has a vested interest in trying to drive a wedge between the so-called heartlands and first time New Labour voters."

Labour has suffered a series electoral reverses in Wales especially in the valleys, traditionally one of its strongholds.

Mr Blair initially decided to make the trip at the time Alun Michael was first secretary, but his resignation and replacement by the free-thinking Rhodri Morgan gave the prime minister's two-day sweep through Wales extra spice.

Mr Morgan met Mr Blair privately last week at Downing Street, sharing a six pack of beer, where the two men agreed to bury the hatchet. Mr Blair used the union block vote last year to squeeze Mr Morgan out of the leadership in favour of Mr Michael, landing the prime minister with the control freak tag.

In a speech in Merthyr Tydfil Mr Blair said: "There are people - part of the media, and many of our Conservative and nationalist opponents - who tell us to choose between the so-called heartlands and middle Britain.

"These were the people who said that by putting extra money in the schools and hospitals, middle Britain would be dismayed. What nonsense. Everyone in this country wants decent schools for our children, good health care when we are sick."

Mr Blair also used the speech to confirm the extension nationwide of a £270m New Deal scheme to help the unemployed over-50s back into work.

fields.headline: Shoplifting spree by ex-pop star
fields.trailText: Former pop star Steve Strange had already committed four shoplifting offences the same day when he was caught stealing a doll, a court in Bridgend, South Wales, heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Former pop star Steve Strange had already committed four shoplifting offences the same day when he was caught stealing a doll, a court in Bridgend, South Wales, heard yesterday.

Strange, lead singer of the 1980s band Visage, was arrested for stealing a £10.99 Tellytubby, magistrates heard. Police then discovered that Strange, 40, unemployed, of Porthcawl, had also stolen cosmetics and clothes.

Strange, who appeared in court under his real name, Steve Harrington, was said to have been arrested after being caught stealing the doll from the Family Value store in Bridgend, South Wales.

He admitted stealing a £25 Cerruti Image cosmetics gift set from Boots in Bridgend and asked for three other offences to be taken into consideration. When he was arrested he was already on bail for stealing a £15 women's jacket from Marks and Spencer in Cardiff.

Mel Butler, defending, said Strange was a man suffering from a "myriad of problems". He appealed to magistrates not to send Strange to prison, saying there was a risk that he might try to kill himself.

Strange was given a three month suspended prison sentence. He declined to comment as he left court.

fields.headline: Stately sell-off: Masterpieces may fetch £10m
fields.trailText: Many of the treasures of Luton Hoo are to be sold off to save what remains of one of the country's greatest art collections.
fields.body:
Many of the treasures of Luton Hoo are to be sold off to save what remains of one of the country's greatest art collections.

Old Master paintings, furniture and sculptures from the Wernher collection - gathered by the German-born diamond magnate Sir Julius Wernher, using the fortune he amassed in South Africa - are expected to make £10m when they go under the hammer at Christie's in July.

It is another chapter in the decline of one of the country's more exotic aristocratic families. Last year, Lucy Phillips was forced to sell off the Adam mansion in Hertfordshire which had housed the collection since the war.

She has struggled for nine years to keep the estate and collection intact after the death of her husband in 1991. Nicholas Phillips, a godson of the Duke of Edinburgh, was found in his fume-filled car when the value of the business park he sank millions into just outside the estate slumped during the property crash. It has since more than tripled in value.

Five years ago she sold St Michael Triumphant, a painting by the 15th century Spanish master Bartolome Bermejo, to the National Gallery for £10m, and a sale of some of silver raised nearly £5m the same year.

The money is believed to have gone to fending off her husband's creditors. Two banks had sued her for £21m in 1993.

The highlights of the Christie's sale are two rare gothic Augsburg silver figures of St Sebastian and St Christopher, which are expected to make £1m apiece, while a Titian portrait of Giacomo Doria could also make a seven-figure sum.

A painting by Rubens, Diana with her Nymphs Hunting, and a work by the Renaissance painter Filippino Lippi, The Rest on the Flight to Egypt, will also go under the hammer.

Almost everything is likely to be snapped up by overseas buyers.

A Christie's spokeswoman said that a large part of the money realised by the sale would go towards preserving and displaying the remains of the Wernher collection in a house run by English Heritage.

fields.headline: Body found after two years
fields.trailText: The remains of a pensioner reported missing more than two years ago have been found in his garage, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
The remains of a pensioner reported missing more than two years ago have been found in his garage, police said yesterday.

The body of Walter Bellman, who was 82, was not found despite police searching his home in Brighton in January 1998.

A police spokeswoman said officers at the time had searched another garage nearby, which a neighbour who reported the pensioner missing said belonged to Mr Bellman.

She said the officers involved had followed procedure and the case will not be investigated.

The neighbour called police as she had not seen Mr Bellman for five days. The spokeswoman said the dead man lived in a block of flats which have a row of garages behind them.

"We went in and searched the flat, but found nothing. All the furniture was covered with dust sheets. We searched a garage at the time, which the neighbour thought was his. As there was no car in this garage, we thought Mr Bellman had gone away."

She added: "He was a very private man, almost a recluse.

"In January this year we were contacted by his nephew, who lives in Kent and was concerned about him, as he had not received a Christmas card from Mr Bellman for two years. He seemed only to keep in contact with his family by Christmas cards."

After being contacted by the nephew, police issued media appeals to try to find Mr Bellman. The death is not being treated as suspicious and an inquest will take place at a later date, police said.

webTitle: Who are you? What the VW Bora ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you? What the VW Bora ad says about you
fields.trailText: This is a nice little no-frills car ad that shows a bit more imagination than lingering overhead shots of a motor snaking its way round a bendy mountain pass. It features a scruffy hitchhiker standing at the roadside holding a sign for Penzance.
fields.body:
The ad: This is a nice little no-frills car ad that shows a bit more imagination than lingering overhead shots of a motor snaking its way round a bendy mountain pass. It features a scruffy hitchhiker standing at the roadside holding a sign for Penzance. Eventually someone stops for him - a Bora driver - and as he jumps in the front seat he turns to say hello to his fellow passengers in the back. They look decidedly cheesed off, however, as their signs say "Norwich" and "Edinburgh". We cut to the driver, who grins smugly as he pulls away. "Bora. Any excuse" reads the endline.

The jargon: VW advertising tends to be quieter and more intelligent than most car ads. The Bora is VW's proper driving saloon, and this ad aims to give the car pukka motoring credentials by showing that people will do anything to spend more time behind the wheel, however silly their reasons.

Personality: You are a company car driver, probably male, who spends loads of time on the road. You probably drive a Vectra or a Mondeo, like all your colleagues, but dream of something rather more fancy than a Ford or Vauxhall, such as a BMW 3-series.

Financial status: You are a middle manager, probably earning between £25,000 to £30,000 (hence a Bora is rather more in your price bracket than a BMW).

Telling lifestyle detail: Chances are you are a bit younger than a typical Passat driver, aged around 25-35, play footie and a bit of golf with your mates and live in a major city.

Other relevant data: Quite possibly one of the least glamorous car shoots in history, the ad was filmed in a lay-by off the A40 and was directed by first-time director Ed Sayers.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Life behind the screen can be incredibly mundane. The media may sound like a glamorous calling but many working in TV and radio suffer huge amounts of stress, working to crazy deadlines and a laughable budgets. Okay, so there are zillions of parties and awards do's to go to (including the prestigious Baftas) but, believe me, it's a slog. No, really.
fields.body:
Life behind the screen can be incredibly mundane. The media may sound like a glamorous calling but many working in TV and radio suffer huge amounts of stress, working to crazy deadlines and a laughable budgets. Okay, so there are zillions of parties and awards do's to go to (including the prestigious Baftas) but, believe me, it's a slog. No, really.

What brightens everyone's day as they schlep into the office is the thought of what goodies might be in the post - advertising yet another doomed sitcom in a desperate bid to get some researcher to smuggle the latest bit of ersatz hype on to the set of Thank Freak It's Not Monday.

Top of our list last week was Woody Woodpecker - nicely cute in prime-coloured velour with in-built giggle (just squeeze that tummy). And the best line of all on the rolling circuit of Woodpecker noises that emanate from said region? "Come to papa".

Why?

Woody has already earned his stripes, getting a mention and several squeezes from the Chris Evans breakfast team on Virgin Radio on Thursday. Yes, the Woodster is back - this time on Fox Kids, a cable and satellite channel, starring as part of the channel's spring line-up. Feels like he's never been away.

More intriguing things lurked in the postbag this week, however. A bar of Politically Incorrect Soap. Yes, soap on a rope has slipped through to the 21st century, but it's so postmodern it knows it's politically incorrect. This comes courtesy of Bill Maher, a US TV star, who's fronting five shows from "America's Toughest Prison" in Arizona from May 1. The series isn't even being shown over here. So why are they sending us bars of soap?

So that it'll be written about of course. Ditto the bird. So, TV mavens, consider it done.

Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Home and away
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: If he's unsure about his drugs policy, Jack Straw should watch EastEnders (BBC1). Steve Owen has started popping amphetamines, and now looks healthier than he has done since he last buried a girlfriend in Epping Forest.
fields.body:
If he's unsure about his drugs policy, Jack Straw should watch EastEnders (BBC1). Steve Owen has started popping amphetamines, and now looks healthier than he has done since he last buried a girlfriend in Epping Forest.

In fact, his chemical breakfast put Steve in such a sunny mood that he didn't mind when Gianni sidled up for some advice. Seems that Steve's sister Jackie suffers from PMS. And Gianni - expert on women that he is - wondered if Steve had any tips on "how to handle it". Across the land, men smote their foreheads in sudden realisation. Ask her little brother! Why didn't I think of that?

Over the Square, grizzly Phil was also in need of stimulants. After pestering pregnant girlfriend Lisa to move in, he gave only a moody shrug when she agreed. "I'd buy a bottle of champagne to celebrate," he muttered, "only neeva of us could drink it." Indeed, Phil. And no-one would care to watch. We should, however, pay tribute to Lisa. This was the latest in a string of gripping dilemmas, including Should I Date Phil?, Should I Shag Phil? and Should I Give Birth To A Descendant Of Phil? For one who spends so much time deliberating, that girl makes a lot of duff decisions.

Did you know that our ancestors spent their summer hols on the Cote d'Azur? They slept on the beach and ate rhinosceros. This was 500,000 years ago. Now the only rhino there is worn as handbags by Eurotrash duchesses, which is curious since, according to Great Excavations (C4), the European aristocracy invented archaeology. In 1736, a king of Naples wondered why giant holes kept appearing on his land, and sent a servant down to investigate. He found the Roman city of Herculaneum. Which was nice. Presenter John Romer's an inspired choice for this series - clad in a selection of comedy hats like a hybrid of Dr Who, Patrick Moore and Steven Berkoff, he gesticulates with psychotic enthusiasm, rendering a dusty old subject extremely addictive.

I had a chemistry teacher like Ray Mears. He spent every lesson telling us about the horrific ways in which we could die if we ignored safety requirements in the lab. Ray Mears' Extreme Survival (BBC 2) transferred this ghoulish alarmism to the desert. Ray was fun when he was drinking his own widdle and barbecuing witchety grubs, but he's been on a diet and gone all serious. Any viewers planning a joyride in their local desert were hauled up sharply, as Ray treated us to the haunting diary extracts of an airman who perished in the Sahara, mad with thirst.

Without a flicker of irony, Ray then led us through the basics of wadi-survival, adding a shiversome anecdote about a man whose shins got cut to the bone. A more cheery account came from a German survivor, who'd sensibly remained with his vehicle and waited until help arrived. But Ray would not be upstaged. "One more day and he'd have set off on foot," he pronounced snootily, upon not a shred of evidence. "Then his chances would have been nil."

At least Ray has found his niche. Less fortunate were Seth and Peter, one half of the couples in Love And Money (C4). Both chaps are house-husbands, and the producers wanted us to know it's no bed of roses. But they didn't quite pull it off. Certainly, neither man had an enviable lifestyle. But not because there's anything intrinsically wrong with blokes doing the ironing, more because the blokes in question were just crap at life. Peter claimed to be skint and happy - so why did he cherish the ludicrous goal of becoming an opera singer? Bronchitic polecats have sounded sweeter. And why he did he swap, halfway through, to becoming a songwriter? Because, perhaps, reality wasn't much fun?

Seth's flaw was loving his wife Jan, who kidded herself she didn't want a rich husband. After much careful phrasing and many Freudian slips, she came clean. "Respect for a partner is bound up in their ability to make money," she faltered.

Small wonder that Seth, bound to such a partner, lacked the self-respect necessary to get his act together. Jan agreed that she should earn big bucks while Seth raised the child, but then she got resentful and chucked him out. We saw a poignant shot of their hallway, blank spaces where Seth's photos had hung. How did this make Jan feel? "Not as sad as I thought." Little saddens Jan, one suspects, except pay cuts.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: While Feedback takes a break, John Humphrys hosts Food Court (1.30pm, Radio 4), six programmes looking at what goes on to our dining tables and how it gets there. Genetic modification looms large, of course, with contrarian farmer Oliver Walston rolling out his well-known impression of a bull on the rampage. The spotlight will also fall on some of the dodges practised in food processing and on exactly what is meant by "fresh". Just as well the programme comes on after lunch.

While Feedback takes a break, John Humphrys hosts Food Court (1.30pm, Radio 4), six programmes looking at what goes on to our dining tables and how it gets there. Genetic modification looms large, of course, with contrarian farmer Oliver Walston rolling out his well-known impression of a bull on the rampage. The spotlight will also fall on some of the dodges practised in food processing and on exactly what is meant by "fresh". Just as well the programme comes on after lunch.

Where Gateshead commissioned a statue of the Angel of the North, the London borough of Kensington and Chelsea asked composer Frederick Stocken to write a Symphony For The Millennium. Classic FM In Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM) presents the world premiere of the work, recorded at the Royal Albert Hall in February. The symphony generated mixed reviews. The council's leader thought it "a gift to all classical music lovers". Music critics' reactions ranged from "bizarre" to "banal".

fields.headline: All right on the night
fields.standfirst: Every comedian knows what it's like to die on his feet. But they don't want it to happen live on television in front of other professionals. So why on earth, asks  Jack Docherty  , did he agree to host next Sunday's Bafta awards?
fields.trailText: Every comedian knows what it's like to die on his feet. But they don't want it to happen live on television in front of other professionals. So why on earth, asks Jack Docherty , did he agree to host next Sunday's Bafta awards?
fields.body:
As every good comic knows, awards ceremonies can be instant death. So respect is due to Tony Hawkes for taking on a 20-minute cabaret slot at the British Press Awards. A roomful of 800 hacks at the London Hilton is surely the most cynical audience in the world. You've corpsed before you've even started.

Not that there's anything new about dying on your feet. When Morcambe and Wise played the Glasgow Empire, Ernie opened with 10 minutes of songs and banter on his own. And when Eric chose his moment to creep on at the back, someone shouted, "Oh Christ, there's two of them". Difference is, at an awards ceremony you're dying on your feet in front of an industry.

Which reminds me. I'm hosting Saturday's Bafta film awards to an audience of 1,600 at the Odeon cinema in Leicester Square - and live on TV. I've never compered before in my life. Maybe this is something I should see my psychiatrist about. In fact, I've turned down various offers which would at least have given me a chance to practise. Going straight in for the big one instead.

So why did I accept the job? Well, because I was intrigued. And because it seemed like a good gig. Twenty-five awards in two and a half hours, so there's no time for the indulgence of the Oscars. You don't get to cancan to the latest film scores. The brief is to keep the audience entertained and rattle through as fast as possible. No written list of rules and no restrictions on what you can say. Just keep telling yourself they're not there to see you, they're there to see who's won the prizes. You're there to shut people up and keep them moving.

And the fear of something going wrong does, of course, make for a good show. When I was doing my chatshow, I was desperate for a Grace Jones/Rod Hull and Emu moment. I'd have loved someone to physically attack me. In fact, my dream bill would have been Rod Hull and Emu, Grace Jones and Oliver Reed on the same programme. You long for those nightmare moments.

After doing the show for a year and a half, I was comatose. There was just no confrontation. And there are people you can't face interviewing because you have absolutely no interest in them whatsoever. Max Clifford comes on with his relentless "I do everything for charity" answers, and you're just sitting there thinking, "I've got nothing to say to you. I'm wondering whether to have mashed or boiled potatoes with my tea".

Anyway, back to the awards. Preparations started with a faxed list of "citation readers" - award-speak for envelope-carrying celebrities. The line up includes Dustin Hoffman, Faye Dunaway, Leslie Nielson, Sydney Pollack, Kate Winslet and Hugh Grant. Each celebrity has a "person" to look after them in the wings and eventually push them on to the stage. At which point I do a nod and a smile, step back and let them give the award.

There's no time to chat. You don't get to ask Elle Macpherson where she got her dress. You do one short paragraph of "general film banter" between envelopes and maybe the odd gag to resurrect someone's past. Which can be difficult. Hugh Grant, for instance. Can't think of anything to drag up about him.

Celebrity envelope-openers are notorious for nerves. So it's your job to "candidly" remedy hideous but inevitable blunders. Like someone announcing the winner before they've read the nominations. The producer will be shouting down the earpiece, "The clips! The clips!". And you'll have to say, "No, Dustin, let's just have a look at a few clips of the nominations before we hand out the award." And celebrities are prone to reading out the wrong names, too. Or the most common problem of all - forgetting their envelopes. In the event of which, there's always my 10-minute jazz-dance improvisation.

The script itself goes through about five rewrites. Someone writes a functional skeleton script with all those "... and now we come to the best actress awards" lines, then I put in a few jokes. A roomful of 800 hacks at the London Hilton is surely the most cynical audience in the world. You've corpsed before you've even started. Not that there's anything new about dying on your feet. When Morcambe and Wise played the Glasgow Empire, Ernie opened with 10 minutes of songs and banter on his own. And when Eric chose his moment to creep on at the back, someone shouted, "Oh Christ, there's two of them". Difference is, at an awards ceremony you're dying on your feet in front of an industry. Which reminds me. I'm hosting Saturday's Bafta film awards to an audience of 1,600 at the Odeon cinema in Leicester Square - and live on TV. I've never compered before in my life. Maybe this is something I should see my psychiatrist about. In fact, I've turned down various offers which would at least have given me a chance to practise. The brief is to keep the audience entertained and rattle through as fast as possible. No written list of rules and no restrictions on what you can say. Just keep telling yourself they're not there to see you, they're there to see who's won the prizes. You're there to shut people up and keep them moving. fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Truman Show
fields.body:
The Truman Show

(Peter Weir, 1998)

10am, Sky Premier

For those who find Jim Carrey a little hard to take, this is an eye-opener: his Truman Burbank is played worryingly straight, but is maybe all the better for it. Truman lives in Seahaven, not knowing that he is the subject of a round-the-clock TV show, his friends and family merely actors playing roles. But little doubts start to form, and he has to fight for his freedom. It's an inspired idea, and Weir plays it out superbly: an extremely sharp satire on the media-mad 90s, which manages to be emotionally stirring as well.

The Hunchback Of Notre Dame

(William S Dieterle, 1939)

4pm, Sky Cinema

An exemplary screen version of Victor Hugo's gothic classic. Brilliantly conceived and beautifully acted by the likes of Cedric Hardwicke as Frollo, Maureen O'Hara as the gypsy girl, Esmeralda, and Charles Laughton, who expresses the selfless nobility of the misshapen Quasimodo through the monster make-up.

Assault On Precinct 13

(John Carpenter, 1976)

10pm, FilmFour

Carpenter's low-budget thriller is a cult masterpiece. Transposing Howard Hawkes's Rio Bravo to modern LA, it has a motley handful of cops and crooks besieged in a police station by a street gang of crazies who come on like extras from Romero's Night Of The Living Dead. Some murky photography and Carpenter's own soundtrack enhance the edgy atmosphere. And Darwin Joston's convict, Napoleon Wilson, is as cool a hero as they come. Whatever happened to Darwin Joston? He should have been a superstar.

Midnight Express

(Alan Parker, 1978)

11pm, Carlton Cinema

Sordid and nasty account of a young American hash-smuggler banged up in a hell-hole of a Turkish jail. It's based loosely on the experiences of one Billy Hayes, whose book was adapted by Oliver Stone, not someone known for pulling his punches. Brad Davis plays the brutalised lad; John Hurt and Randy Quaid are fellow inmates.
