webTitle: Spend job savings on boosting BBC1 output, says Smith

fields.headline: Spend job savings on boosting BBC1 output, says Smith
fields.standfirst: BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The culture secretary, Chris Smith, yesterday urged the BBC director general, Greg Dyke, to devote more resources and attention to BBC1, claiming that programme standards had slipped.
fields.body:
The culture secretary, Chris Smith, yesterday urged the BBC director general, Greg Dyke, to devote more resources and attention to BBC1, claiming that programme standards had slipped.

He called for more "hum-dingers" along the lines of Wives and Daughters and Walking with Dinosaurs, and disclosed that he had pressed Mr Dyke to cull management jobs to divert up to £200m a year to programme-making.

His intervention provoked an acknowledgement from the corporation, which blamed programme budget cuts for a drop in standards.

Mr Smith offered comfort to the corporation when he praised the quality of last autumn's scheduling - singling out the Royle Family as an example of strong programming.

Mr Dyke's decision, announced last Monday, to sweep away a layer of BBC management - the legacy of his predecessor John Birt - was moving in "exactly the right direction", Mr Smith said. He added: "I very much welcome Greg Dyke's taking of an axe to the bureaucracy of the BBC.

"It is something we specifically asked him to do when we set the funding settlement in place for the BBC and I think he has made a very good start in doing that."

He criticised BBC1 output during spring and summer last year as "not particularly exciting", but praised the autumn scheduling as dramatic and added: "I want to see that as the norm rather than the exception for the BBC."

A BBC spokesman said: "Greg Dyke has made it no secret that BBC1 is a main priority for an injection of extra funding as the channel's programme budget had fallen to £120m below that of ITV. By last summer that deficit had started to show on screen."

He added that the BBC was determined to present more quality programmes. "There are no shortage of good ideas deserving investment."

Mr Smith also called for the restoration of News at Ten on ITV, saying he believed access to "good quality impartial news" had been diminished since its demise. Up to 2m fewer people now watch TV news than before News at Ten was axed.

webTitle: Key Mandelson concession on police badge

fields.headline: Key Mandelson concession on police badge
fields.standfirst:
Ulster secretary seeks to shore up unionist leader's position with assertion that British symbols should be incorporated in new design

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, yesterday offered a concession to unionists when he declared that British symbols, possibly including the crown, are to be incorporated in the cap badge for the new Northern Ireland police service, to be set up within the next year.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, yesterday offered a concession to unionists when he declared that British symbols, possibly including the crown, are to be incorporated in the cap badge for the new Northern Ireland police service, to be set up within the next year.

In a move which was designed to shore up the position of David Trimble, Mr Mandelson rejected a central proposal in Chris Patten's policing report that badges should be "entirely free from any association with either the British or Irish states".

During a Commons debate on the Patten report, which was called by the Ulster Unionist leader, Mr Mandelson told MPs: "I am not convinced that [the badge] needs to be entirely free of association with either tradition, as recommended."

Mr Mandelson insisted that he had decided, "after a lot of thought", to accept Mr Patten's other main recommendation that the name of the RUC should be dropped in favour of the more neutral Police Service of Northern Ireland. The Northern Ireland secretary believes that a name change is a crucial element in encouraging nationalists to join the police.

But in another gesture to unionists, Mr Mandelson announced that he would honour the RUC name "in perpetuity" through "suitable initiatives". These are likely to include a memorial garden to commemorate the 302 RUC officers killed during the troubles, and an RUC bursary scheme to fund police officers who want to attend the Bramshill training course in Britain.

Mr Mandelson's gesture was designed to assuage the fears of unionists and to offer some encouragement to Mr Trimble as the government intensifies its efforts to resolve the disarmament deadlock.

Ministers, who are hoping that the Ulster Unionist leader will agree to re-establish the power-sharing executive ahead of actual disarmament, believe that a gesture on the RUC may strengthen Mr Trimble's position against the hardliners within his party who are determined to wreck any agreement. However, Mr Mandelson's insistence on removing the RUC's name will anger Ulster Unionists, who voted last month to link Sinn Fein's admission to the power-sharing executive to retention of the force's name.

Government sources indicated that the new cap could include a symbol of the crown. Another possibility, which Mr Mandelson hinted at in January, would be to include the George Cross, which the Queen awarded to the RUC last year to mark the force's bravery in fighting terrorism.

Unionists were deeply angered by Mr Patten's recommendation because they believe that his proposal to remove the crown from the existing badge severely undermined Northern Ireland's position within the United Kingdom. Their anger was exacerbated because unionists believe that the existing RUC badge, which features a crown and a harp, represents both British and Irish traditions.

Mr Trimble described the Patten proposal as a "grievous insult".

Most Labour MPs support the Patten proposals, seeing them as an important way of encouraging nationalists to join the police. But former minister Frank Field voted against the government, saying more progress should be made on decommissioning before further concessions were offered.

fields.headline: Speaker extends ban on breastfeeding
fields.trailText: MPs and members of the public have been banned from breastfeeding their babies in much of the Houses of Parliament.
fields.body:
MPs and members of the public have been banned from breastfeeding their babies in much of the Houses of Parliament.

The Commons Speaker, Betty Boothroyd, has decreed that existing rules ban "refreshment" from committee rooms, so breastfeeding is off-limits. The Commons chamber is already a no-go zone for breastfeeding, but that ban will now be extended to committee rooms and to the public gallery.

In a letter issued on behalf of Ms Boothroyd, her deputy, Sir Alan Haselhurst, said: "Bringing refreshment into the [committee] room and the presence in the non-public area of the room of persons other than members of the committee and specified officers and officials are prohibited: application of either rule should be taken to include babies and the feeding of babies.

"Nor would I feel it is appropriate that babies should be fed in the public gallery."

Sir Alan has informed the security of the ban.

The decision provoked criticism from women MPs who have pressed for a more baby-friendly environment.

A number of the new Labour MPs - including the public health minister, Yvette Cooper, and Gloucester MP Tess Kingham - have had babies since winning their seats.

The Swindon Labour MP, Julia Drown, who had a baby boy five months ago and gained permission from the chairman of a standing committee on which she served to breastfeed in the committee room, pledged to press Ms Boothroyd to change her mind.

In the event, Ms Drown said, she had not needed to feed her baby during committee, but had been doing so in the committee corridor or the Commons family room "as and when his little mood takes him".

She said: "No one wants people to be disturbed, but babies are quiet when they are being breastfed and I don't think there would have been a problem. The general rule should be if it does not disturb anyone it should be allowed."

Other MPs pressing for modernisation of Commons hours and facilities supported her. Labour's Caroline Flint, who chairs the Commons childcare group, said: 'If we have got MPs with young children wanting to fulfil their parliamentary activities we need to provide services so their babies, and those of Commons staff, can be looked after."

The row came as Margaret Beckett yesterday gave limited succour to MPs pressing for more family-friendly working hours, including a normal end to their working day at 7pm.

Many MPs, frustrated by the slow progress towards modernisation, have been infuriated by an upsurge in late night debates. A total of 187 MPs have signed a petition calling for a rethink on hours.

fields.headline: Rebel applauds 'somersault'
fields.standfirst:
Clark says concessions mark milestone

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: For David Clark, parliament's chief standard bearer for the public's right to know, this week's Commons debates on the controversial freedom of information bill have been "the most remarkable two days I have spent in parliament in 25 years".
fields.body:
For David Clark, parliament's chief standard bearer for the public's right to know, this week's Commons debates on the controversial freedom of information bill have been "the most remarkable two days I have spent in parliament in 25 years".

The former cabinet minister, who drew up radical draft legislation pushed aside in favour of Jack Straw's watered down version, voted against his government on Wednesday night for the first time in his parliamentary career. And yet, far from feeling anger and betrayal, the South Shields MP is optimistic that Mr Straw's now modified bill will spread a new culture of openness in England and Wales.

Mr Clark believes that two days of debate during the Commons report stage of the freedom of information bill have seen significant improvements in the legislation, which was judged by campaigners at first as a betrayal of promises to shed light in Britain's dark corners."For the first time, I really felt that the collective voice of everyone who spoke actually had an impression, culminating with Jack Straw doing a somersault to introduce the new clause."

In the face of a threatened backbench rebellion, the home secretary offered fresh concessions on Tuesday night, decreeing that powers to override the new information commissioner and block the release of information should be confined to cabinet ministers or the attorney general, rather than made widely available to other ministers and local councillors.

Mr Clark and other campaigners have pressed for ultimate power to order disclosure to reside with the commissioner, with no ministerial override - the option contained in the former chancellor of the duchy of Lancaster's 1997 white paper. But Mr Clark said: "I think Jack's concession is a massive step forward."

New warmth between the two men contrasts with earlier locking of horns in cabinet. Their differences are said to have reached the stage where Derry Irvine, the lord chancellor, offered to "hold their coats" when they appeared on the brink of fisticuffs.

While a core of Labour MPs have expressed concern at the bill, party strategists still believe that the openness issue is a preoccupation of worthies and pointy-heads, neither gaining nor losing heartland votes.

On Wednesday night, Labour whips shunted their MPs through the government lobbies, saying "other way for Tories, Liberal Democrats and leftwing intellectuals".

Thirty-six MPs ignored the goading and rebelled anyway, Mr Clark among them. "I was very concerned to remain true to what I told the House of Commons when I introduced the white paper," he said.

The whips are wrong to argue that openness does not excite Labour constituents, he says, arguing that his own constituents frequently complain at lack of access to local council information, something that will change as a result of the new legislation.

The Freedom of Information Act will be a milestone, he argues. "I wanted revolution and this is evolution. We have got less than perfection but still at the end we have got the makings of a pretty good act.

"Ultimately, the individuals involved are not even a footnote in hostory. It is what is on the statute book that is important."

webTitle: Short blocks Cuba push for EU market preference

fields.headline: Short blocks Cuba push for EU market preference
fields.trailText: The international development secretary, Clare Short, is blocking moves, supported by foreign secretary Robin Cook, for Cuba to be given preferential access to European Union markets, according to ministerial sources.
fields.body:
The international development secretary, Clare Short, is blocking moves, supported by foreign secretary Robin Cook, for Cuba to be given preferential access to European Union markets, according to ministerial sources.

Cuba is seeking to join the Lomé convention, which gives 71 former European colonies trading rights and development aid.The issue will be discussed by EU ministers next week. But Ms Short is insisting that Cuba's application should be refused because of its human rights record. Most EU states want Cuba to be allowed to join immediately, despite hostility from the United States to any rapprochement with its Caribbean neighbour. But encouraged by Ms Short, the UK government continues to resist Cuba's application.

One minister said yesterday that the government's policy needed to be changed to help Cuba "come in from the cold".

A spokeswoman for Ms Short's department said that while there was no "objection in principle" to Cuba becoming a Lomé signatory, respect for human rights formed an essential element of the Lomé treaty.

One minister said yesterday that the government's policy needed to be changed to help Cuba "come in from the cold". A spokeswoman for Ms Short's department said that while there was no "objection in principle" to Cuba becoming a Lomé signatory, respect for human rights formed an essential element of the Lomé treaty.

fields.headline: John Green
fields.standfirst: Radio talks producer who smuggled controversy into the BBC
fields.trailText: The radio producer John Green, who has died aged 90, made serious, even challenging, discussion acceptable to a BBC still trammelled by Sir John Reith's fear of arousing controversy or being accused of partiality. What's more, he did this from a career which began and ended as a specialist in farming and gardening matters. In a rare pleasantry in his massive History Of Broadcasting In The United Kingdom, Asa Briggs says of Green that "he was, to use farming metaphors, both down-to-earth and cultivated."
fields.body:
The radio producer John Green, who has died aged 90, made serious, even challenging, discussion acceptable to a BBC still trammelled by Sir John Reith's fear of arousing controversy or being accused of partiality. What's more, he did this from a career which began and ended as a specialist in farming and gardening matters. In a rare pleasantry in his massive History Of Broadcasting In The United Kingdom, Asa Briggs says of Green that "he was, to use farming metaphors, both down-to-earth and cultivated."

Ironically, Green was recruited by Reith in 1933, when a pupil barrister at the Inner Temple, after winning a place there from Cambridge University, where he had been president of the union. Reith was apparently worried by the underlying leftwing attitudes of some talks producers, and wanted to hire someone of the right. Green's first assignment was to set up a regular gardening talk for the rising number of listeners, who, as the suburbs spread, had gardens to tend.

His choice of expert to deliver the hints and advice was inspired. CH Middleton, soon to be universally known as "Mr Middleton", was one of four gifted sons of the farm bailiff at Renishaw Hall, seat of the Sitwell family, and the only one to pursue a similar career, as gardener to the younger son, Sacheverell Sitwell, at Weston Hall, in Northamptonshire, and pillar of the local horticultural society. His quiet, friendly chat at 12.15 on Sundays, just ahead of Sunday dinner, swiftly became an institution. "He seemed," wrote the critic Peter Black, "to enlarge the business of cultivating one's garden into a serene and comforting philosophy."

Green also started a farming programme bluntly called For Farmers Only, which, on the outbreak of war in 1939, was crassly taken off - only to be reinstated at the urging of a Ministry of Agriculture desperate for an extra channel of communication to the growers of the nation's food. With the Dig For Victory campaign, Mr Middleton likewise acquired national importance.

Green now launched further speakers to give practical advice. Notably, there was the radio doctor, Charles (later Lord) Hill, and John Hilton, who handled what would now be regarded as social services issues, such as service married allowances, wartime separation and war pensions.

The BBC had steadily become bolder in its general editorial policy. The Sunday night Postscript was famously accused, when JB Priestley delivered it, of being a manifesto for postwar socialism. As the end of the war approached, however, old misgivings arose again, sharpened by implications of wartime propaganda.

In a signed chapter in the 1945 BBC Yearbook, Green defended the Englishman's right - he was quoting Dr Johnson - to be informed, but looked ahead apprehensively to those who might one day "bombard words against the privacy of the home with all the concentrated force of modern organisation and technique".

In 1950, he was the logical choice to head a BBC working party set up to determine how the BBC should aim its factual output: which was more important - to be topical and newsy or to aspire to "more abiding themes"? Green was subsequently put in charge of the current affairs side of talks, and set up a panel of 12 experts to provide background information, suggest speakers and sometimes take part themselves - in other words, an attempt to provide the immediacy that listeners seemed to want, but ensure that it was wise and informed as well.

One of the first fruits was the regular series At Home And Abroad, whose rollcall of speakers in its first year included Pandit Nehru, Christian Dior, the Archbishop of Canterbury and the Chinese premier Chou En-Lai. There was also an interview with Archbishop Makarios, leader of the Greek Cypriot independence movement, which drew a protest from Sir Winston Churchill, possibly the last of many he chalked up before he retired from office in 1955.

Later that same year, Green took over as controller of the whole talks division, remaining in this post until it was abolished in 1961. By now, he found himself regarded as an expert on rural broadcasting, and wound up his BBC career with a mission to Australia and New Zealand to report on their local radio. He retired to Gloucestershire, becoming chairman of the Agricultural Advisory Council for five years.

His wife, Judith, died in 1996.

 John Dennis Fowler Green, broadcaster and agriculturist, born May 9 1909; died March 25 2000

fields.headline: Widdecombe patrols New York
fields.trailText: Police officer Michael Light was patrolling some of the meanest streets in Manhattan this week when he was accosted by a small, stout figure, dressed in a bright red suit and swinging a handbag.
fields.body:
Police officer Michael Light was patrolling some of the meanest streets in Manhattan this week when he was accosted by a small, stout figure, dressed in a bright red suit and swinging a handbag.

"What has been the worst thing to happen to you?" demanded Ann Widdecombe. The fresh-faced member of the NYPD looked helplessly at the shadow home secretary and stammered: "Nothing really. I only came out of the academy in February." An obviously disappointed Miss Widdecombe smiled faintly before turning on her heels.

Miss Widdecombe made it clear during her day-long visit to New York's beleaguered police department that she wanted to see the worst it had to offer. She was on a three-day tour of duty in the US to pick up tips on law and order.

The tour started with a day in Washington DC where smiling communities had left her unmoved. "Unfortunately, they did not show me the worst. You can't tell anything unless you see the worst," she said before sitting down to a stale cup of coffee in the Lubyanka-like headquarters of the NYPD.

In search of the worst and how to deal with it, she had come to New York. The city was the first, under Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, to adopt a zero tolerance policy that effectively cut serious crime by clamping down on all misdemeanours.

With the mayor too busy to see her, Miss Widdecombe had to be content with Howard Safir, the NYPD commissioner who has faced calls for his resignation over the shooting of four unarmed black men in 13 months. Mr Safir brushed off reports that police officers themselves worry about the increasingly bad relationship with local communities and said: "[The policy] is a success story," before hurrying off, leaving Miss Widdecombe to tour some of the city's so-called "model blocks".

This two-year-old programme calls for a full-out assault on areas of high crime. Villains are rounded up and incarcerated and then hundreds of police officers keep a watch in conjunction with local community groups.

The problem with this plan was that once again, Miss Widdecombe's lust for discomfort was to be met with cleaned-up streets full of flags proclaiming them a drug-free zone.

Miss Widdecombe pointed out that her tour of duty in the UK had just taken her to a London block with the same name: the Arden estate in Hoxton.

"This compares very favourably with Hackney," she said with a disappointed sniff.

fields.headline: Habib Bourguiba
fields.standfirst: Flamboyant visionary who steered Tunisia to independence, but whose autocratic rule was undermined by senility
fields.trailText: There was much that was unusual about the long career of Habib Bourguiba, the former president of Tunisia, who has died aged 96. Two moments stand out. The first was his achievement of power; the second was the manner in which he was deposed.
fields.body:
There was much that was unusual about the long career of Habib Bourguiba, the former president of Tunisia, who has died aged 96. Two moments stand out. The first was his achievement of power; the second was the manner in which he was deposed.

In 1954, Bourguiba was in prison, having been transferred by the French government from the lighthouse rock of Galita, north of Bizerta, to the island of Groix, off the Britanny coast. Tunisia was in a state of growing revolt, with thousands of fellaghas creating widespread insecurity throughout the countryside and Gamal Abdel Nasser's Cairo Radio calling from Egypt for more intensive revolution.

The power of French settlers had prevented successive governments in Paris from introducing any meaningful reforms, and the outlook in north Africa seemed set for continuing unrest and repression. It was therefore a great surprise when Pierre Mendès-France, who had become prime minister of France in June - with the aim of ending the war in Indo-China - succeeded in bringing together the French political left, the Gaullists, and the senior serving officer of the army, Marshal Juin, in order to give Tunisia a form of internal self-government.

When he made his dramatic announcement at Carthage on July 31, Mendès-France had the full support of the still imprisoned Bourguiba, who urged caution and stated that it would take 15 years for the Tunisians to digest these innovations. But things moved more quickly than anyone expected. Bourguiba made a triumphal return home in June 1955, and less than a year later, in March 1956, Tunisia became fully independent. In July 1957, Bourguiba was proclaimed first president of the Tunisian republic.

Thirty years later, the man who was known as the "supreme combatant and the father of the nation" - and, since 1974, president for life - had become an embarrassment. At the age of 84 (and rumoured to be at least two years older), his failing health meant that he was increasingly controlled by a controversial entourage, especially by his niece Saida Sassi, and his policies had become unacceptably uncertain, suspicious and repressive - at a time when political, trade union and religious oppositions were gathering force in an explosive economic situation.

Bourguiba had divorced his second wife Wassila (his first wife, Mathilde, also divorced, had been French and died in 1976), because she had supposedly supported a democratisation of the political system; he had broken off diplomatic relations with Iran because Tehran was allegedly supporting Islamic fundamentalists; the prisons were full (Madame Mendès-France intervened personally to secure the release of the president of the Tunisian League of the Rights of Man, who had been accused of spreading false news); unemployment was rising; investments were low; violence was everywhere. It was said that Tunisia was neither governed or governable.

General Zine el Abidine Ben Ali, who became prime minister in October 1987, afterwards claimed that, ever since 1984, Bourguiba suffered from intermittent senility and was incapable of exercising power. In November, the general instituted a committee of doctors, who agreed. The president was declared deposed and a constitutional council was set up. After this medical-legal coup, Bourguiba was allowed to return to his native town of Monastir to live the life of an invalid under supervision.

It was in 1932 that Bourguiba first became prominent. A French-trained lawyer, together with his brother he founded the Néo-Destour party in opposition to the Destour, or constitution, which was the organisation favoured by the traditional Tunisian élite when they wanted to win concessions from the local French administration. But it was on his return to Tunisia, in September 1949, that he began to demonstrate the nature of his mature policy.

Bourguiba had had many contacts with communism, but had not been attracted. During the war, the Germans had released him from the prison where the French had put him, and had handed him over to the Italians, who had hoped for his cooperation - but he had rejected them. He had spent some time in Cairo, but had not been impressed either by the court of King Farouk or the intrigues of the Arab League. He believed in moderation, cooperation with the French, and the force of world opinion.

When he heard of the Mendès-France initiative in 1954, Bourguiba is supposed to have said: "I knew that I was right to trust the French". But this did not mean that he was docilely pro-French.

Later, he liked to show visitors to his palace the framed official form that attested to his being an inmate of a French prison. He gave credence to what were almost certainly exaggerated accounts of French atrocities in Algeria, and he saw to it that the French bombardment of the frontier village of Sakiet in 1978, which caused the deaths of 80 Tunisians, was given maximum publicity. He firmly believed that the French army in Algeria was ready to invade his country and to make it a prisoner, which encouraged him all the more to obtain American arms.

It must be said too that Bourguiba's desire to act as a mediator in the Franco-Algerian conflict was not wholly disinterested. At one point, he hoped that General de Gaulle would free the imprisoned nationalist Ben Bella - but only so that he could take him back in triumph to Tunis.

Bourguiba wanted a change in the desert frontiers, so that Tunisia would acquire oil at the expense of Algeria. In 1961, he sought to exploit de Gaulle's weakness by forcing French troops out of their base at Bizerta, a move which led to a fierce French riposte. In later years, he nationalised the property of French settlers, for a time he agreed to discontinue the teaching of French in primary schools, and he banned French publications that were critical of his regime.

But Bourguiba always saw the French as his ultimate protectors - against Colonel Gadaffi, of Libya for example, whom he knew to be the inspirer of an unsuccessful coup at Gafsa in 1980. His ideal was to keep Tunisia as a halfway-house somewhere between France and Africa, a presidential republic that would be lay in matters of religion, and possessed of an educational system that would ensure a high standard of literacy. This ideal was often lost sight of as he changed the personnel of his government, and altered policies in a restless and personal manner.

Bourguiba was a flamboyant character with few inhibitions. "It will not be easy to replace a man like me," he told a journalist in 1970. His birthday, August 3, was Tunisia's national day; he liked to see his statue in prominent places; and, in his palace, he displayed portraits of the four men, distinguished in North African history, whom he most admired: Jugurtha, Hannibal, St Augustine and Ibn Khaldun - but, above them all, was a large portrait of Bourguiba.

Inevitably, one is left with a touch of megalomania. But, as General de Gaulle once said of the brave man who sought to monopolise the conversation: "He is somebody, your Bourguiba."

Bourguiba is survived by his second wife and a son from his first marriage, Habib Jr, a retired diplomat, who had, at one time, served as his father's foreign minister.

 Habib Ben Ali Bourguiba, politician, born August 3 1903; died April 6 2000

webTitle: Ministers face more defeats in Lords

fields.headline: Ministers face more defeats in Lords
fields.standfirst:
Lib Dems 'bloody-minded' as reform talks stall

Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: The government is deadlocked in its efforts to negotiate a backstairs consensus with the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats on final reform of the House of Lords. It may be forced to impose a unilateral solution after the coming general election.
fields.body:
The government is deadlocked in its efforts to negotiate a backstairs consensus with the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats on final reform of the House of Lords. It may be forced to impose a unilateral solution after the coming general election.

Senior ministers admitted the impasse yesterday as angry Lib Dems warned that they will get even more "bloody-minded" in key votes in the upper house if the government tries to take them for granted.

Still sore at Tony Blair's refusal to grant them more than nine new peers last week - because they are "not loyal enough" - Lib Dem peers say they will not ambush Labour measures without notice, as the Tories do.

But they will vote accoprding to their consciences on issues of principle like jury trial, freedom of information and NHS reforms. "If they expect our good will to continue, they must acknowledge the nature of our independence," said one.

The impasse means that the cabinet is likely to soft-pedal further change in the half-reformed upper house - where it has suffered 10 defeats this year - and to concede elections for up to 100 of the 665 peers after the election.

That would reduce charges of Blairite cronyism. But reports that it will be done within a year of a second Labour victory were dismissed yesterday as premature - even though ministers are rattled by Opposition claims that ejection of all but 923 hereditary peers has made the Lords more "legitimate".

The "tundra-like" relations between Lady Jay, leader of the Lords, and Lords Strathclyde and Rodgers, her Tory and Lib Dem counterparts, comes as ministers try to put out feelers to establish a tripartite consensus on implementation of the Wakeham royal commission report on further reform.

Mr Blair is willing to concede either of Lord Wakeham's limited election models, up to 100 peers elected directly or by regional list.

But the Lib Dems want a fully-elected house, as do some - but not all - senior Tories, at least while they have little hope of winning power.

After complaints about the half-reformed Lords from MPs on all sides yesterday, Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons, told reporters: "We have always wanted to proceed by broad consensus, but the attitude of the Opposition has made that improbable."

Labour still has 32 fewer peers than the Tories, she pointed out.

Both sides agree that, with Labour's overwhelming majority in the Commons and no party having a majority in the Lords, the upper house is going to be a crucial battleground on disputed or defective legislation.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Weizman escapes charges
fields.body:
Weizman escapes charges

The president of Israel, Ezer Weizman, was partially restored to his former state of grace yesterday when police recommended against charging him with corruption for accepting hundreds of thousands of dollars from a French textile tycoon.

Although police cited a lack of evidence to support a charge of bribery, Mr Weizman's reprieve on charges of fraud and breach of trust is due to a technicality: a statute of limitations whose time limit has expired.

Police challenged the president's contention that he had no business dealings with the French millionaire, Edouard Saroussi, who is alleged to have funnelled some £200,000 into a family trust between 1988 and 1993, and to have given Mr Weizman a £40,000 car. At the time, Mr Weizman was an MP and defence minister.

"Saroussi identified the worldwide business potential inherent in the Weizman 'brand name' and was prepared to invest large sums of money for this purpose," the police report said.

Yesterday, there was no immediate comment from Mr Weizman. However, the ambiguous nature of the reprieve - coupled with Mr Weizman's refusal to stand down as president when the investigation began in January - is bound to affect the legacy of a man who was one of the heroes of the pioneer days of the Jewish state.

Israel has recently experienced a series of political scandals.

The deputy prime minister is under investigation following allegations of sexual harassment and assault, and the spiritual leader of the second largest party in the ruling coalition is being investigated for incitement after a diatribe against the education minister. Suzanne Goldenberg, Jerusalem

Victory for landless movement

A prominent leader of Brazil's landless peasants has been acquitted of murder in a judgment hailed as victory for the international human rights community.

A seven-member jury overturned Jose Rainha's 1997 conviction for killing a police officer and a landowner in a dispute over land, making it the first high profile victory in a criminal court for the Marxist-based Landless Rural Workers Movement.

"This shows that Brazil is increasingly less in the hands of the big landowners and that more and more justice is being made," said Brazil's agrarian reform minister, Raul Jungman.

Brazil's international reputation as a country emerging from authoritarian rule has been tarnished by its slowness in solving conflicts over land. The richest 20% of the people hold 90% of the land, while the poorest 40% own just 1% - the unfairest ratio in the world.

More than 1,000 people have died in the last 10 years in land disputes and yet landowners and their armed supporters go largely unpunished. Last year the case against 150 policemen accused of shooting 19 peasants collapsed despite TV footage of the massacre.

Human rights organisations believe that Mr Rainha's original conviction was politically motivated to try to criminalise the Landless Movement, a direct action organisation which has gained title to land by organising mass squats.

Supporters erupted in cheers as the verdict was read and carried Mr Rainha, 39, on their shoulders to a nearby square, where thousands had camped to watch the proceedings on a giant screen television.

"The truth is like divine justice," Mr Rainha said after the verdict. "It may take a while to arrive, but it always emerges." Alex Bellos, Rio de Janeiro

Minding its language - for now

Air France temporarily backed away yesterday from a plan to force pilots to speak English at Charles de Gaulle Airport, but said it would study how to put the controversial policy in place.

"We used English for about 10 days and the company is analysing this period to assess its implications and define with air traffic officials and other professionals how to put the move to English in place," a spokeswoman said.

The rule was put in place to make it easier for pilots from other countries to understand conversations between the control tower and other planes, but it caused an uproar among French pilots and ripples as far away as the Canadian province of Quebec.

The unions said they were not opposed to the principle of speaking only English but said flight security would be threatened by a "hasty decision". Reuters, Paris

Iran seizes Iraqi oil tanker

The Iranian government said on Wednesday that it had seized a tanker illegally exporting Iraqi oil as it passed through Iranian waters, two weeks after the US warned that increased oil smuggling from Iraq could not be stopped without Iran's help.

The Iranian national news agency said that revolutionary guards boarded an Iraqi ship sailing under a Honduran flag last Saturday. The ship was reported to be carrying 2,500 tonnes of smuggled oil. Its captain and crew were in Iranian custody.

"If the reports are true, we are pleased to see that Iran is taking measures against this illegal traffic," said James Rubin, a spokesman for the state department.

Mr Rubin said the US had not confirmed the arrest, which follows more than 18 months during which Iran allowed what US officials say is significant growth in the illegal coastal trade.

"In the past, Iran has taken measures to halt smuggling along its coast, and we hope this is an indication they intend to do so vigorously again," Mr Rubin said.

Under UN security council sanctions imposed in 1990, after Iraq invaded Kuwait, President Saddam Hussein's government is prohibited from selling oil without UN supervision.

Since December, Iraq has been allowed to sell as much crude oil as it wants, with profits going to a UN account to pay for food, medicines and equipment for a range of public services. A third of the money goes to compensate victims of the invasion. New York Times

Ethiopia to get second food airlift

The United Nations yesterday worked to provide a second stopgap airlift to drought-stricken Ethiopia, where millions face starvation after three years of almost no rain.

Aid agencies are increasingly stressing the urgency of their appeals, saying disaster is weeks away unless massive aid comes now. "It is not too late to save lives if we respond at this point," the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, said on Wednesday in Rome.

"We have to have the pledges confirmed now, we have to get the ships on the high seas immediately," Judith Lewis, chief of the UN's World Food Programme in Ethiopia, said yesterday. "Everything's got to be in the works now."

The WFP was trying to arrange a second airlift, with a donor country providing biscuits, oil and transport. The US provided an earlier airlift of high-protein biscuits.

The European Union has also pledged to step up aid for the Horn of Africa and on Wednesday Canada set aside £2.7m for aid.

Ethiopia complained this week the world had waited to see "skeletons on screens" before helping. But EU officials in particular complain that Ethiopia's 22-month border conflict with neighbouring Eritrea is hampering aid efforts. AP, Addis Ababa

webTitle: Traders say profit can be motive for preservation

fields.headline: Traders say profit can be motive for preservation
fields.standfirst: Today the world debates a crucial question: do you best conserve rare species by allowing some to be killed?
fields.trailText: A battle between African states for the future of the elephant begins in Nairobi today. On one side are the countries of the south with increasing elephant herds, which want to trade ivory, hides, meat and trophies; on the other those of the north and west, which rely mainly on the tourist trade.
fields.body:
A battle between African states for the future of the elephant begins in Nairobi today. On one side are the countries of the south with increasing elephant herds, which want to trade ivory, hides, meat and trophies; on the other those of the north and west, which rely mainly on the tourist trade.

The latter are afraid that the resumption of trading would restore black market prices for ivory and encourage poachers to destroy their herds and their livelihoods.

But the argument in Nairobi is not just about elephants. For the next two weeks the 150 countries which have signed the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (Cites) meet for the first time in three years to decide which animals, birds and plants to protect, and how to do it.

And it is not a simple matter of deciding whether to ban trading in species that are disappearing. Rather, the argument is whether the future of many of the world's favourite animals and plants can be better protected by controlled trading.

Twenty years ago there was still a substantial body of opinion that large areas could be fenced off, either literally or legally on paper, where tigers could romp and nature could continue unmolested.

In practical terms this often meant not consulting the people who lived in these places, and evicting them from their homes and traditional way of life, without considering that these tribes and animals may have coexisted for centuries.

Elephant and tiger were both given fenced-off areas in their home ranges, but both species need a lot of space to forage and hunt, and their needs compete with those of ever increasing human populations which want to plant crops where these animals once freely roamed.

Conservationists and some Africa states will argue in Nairobi that unless local people are given an interest in keeping the elephants alive by being allowed to profit from their ivory and eat their meat, then the elephant will come off second best.

There is a slightly different approach to whales. The Norwegians argue that the minke is in direct competition with man for fish species which are in short supply, and that they should be culled as a food resource to keep their numbers limited.

The same argument applies to Hawksbill turtles. Trade in their shells is banned, but Cuba, which has a well managed population and a tradition of eating turtle meat, much of it now farmed, has a stockpile of shells which it wants to sell to Japanese craftsmen.

The argument is that if fishing villages can profit from the sale of shells they will have an interest in protecting wild turtle stocks.

Opponents ask how, if trading is allowed, it is possible to tell whether the shell came from a farmed or wild turtle, whether the ivory came from a licensed country or was poached in another state.

Those in favour of total bans say that halting official ivory sales brought a dramatic drop in poaching. In the 1990s black market prices collapsed and many poachers turned to other ways of making a living.

Cites lists fully protected species in which all international trade is banned in appendix I. Those in which a limited, highly regulated trade is allowed are in appendix II. The southern African states want their elephants listed in appendix II; Kenya wants them in I.

A similar battle surrounds whales. Norway and Japan believe that minke in the North Atlantic, Antarctic and parts of the Pacific, currently in appendix I, are now sufficiently numerous to be hunted and eaten under strict quota rules.

They want the minke "downlisted" to appendix II. Conservationist countries, including Britain and the US, are appalled.

Another international body, the International Whaling Commission, controls whale hunting but it is a much smaller organisation, with fewer than 50 member states, and it is in the hands of conservationists, who have blocked the resumption of whaling.

Japan and Norway have been accused of using aid money and other political levers, like support for the ivory trade, to get Cites to take over the role of controlling whaling. They deny it.

A problem with whales, turtles, elephants, and the basking shark (which Britain wants to protect) is that they do not respect national boundaries. The basking sharks from which Norway cuts the fins to send to Japan for soup are the very fish that attract Japanese tourists to the Isle of Man, where they can be seen sailing past in the clear water.

webTitle: Stocks and shares in the earth's vanishing treasures

fields.headline: Stocks and shares in the earth's vanishing treasures
fields.trailText: Minke whale
fields.body:
Minke whale

Acording to the latest figures, there are 240,000 minke in the Antarctic, and unknown numbers elsewhere.

Japan and Norway, which have kept the trade alive by "scientific" catches, say that some minke and grey whale populations are so big that controlled commerical whaling should be resumed. They want control switched from the International Whaling Commission - which is in the hands of conservationist states which want whaling confined to "lifestyle" catches by indigenous coastal communities - to Cites.

Japan denies buying support from some Caribbean and landlocked states by means of aid.

Basking shark

A tourist attraction on the west coast of Britain, where shoals of up to 50 have been seen cruising along feeding on surface plankton, the basking shark is becoming increasingly rare, but there are no exact population figures.

Britain, which along with a number of other countries legally protects sharks, wants indiscriminate killing halted by a quota system.

Norway and Japan object. Norwegians hunt the basking shark and sell the big back fin to Japan for highly prized shark fin soup.

A vote to regulate catches would make it necessary to carry out research to justify quotas.

Hawksbill turtle

Only one in 500-1,000 of the eggs turtles lay on beaches reaches maturity, and half the known nesting populations are in decline. Since it takes 20-40 years for the turtle to reach maturity, no one knows the true state of the population at large in the world's oceans.

Trading in turtles is banned by Cites, but Cuba is seeking the right to sell its stockpile of shells from wild and farmed harvests of a traditional local meat.

Other Caribbean states are divided: those opposed to the sale ask why Cuba should profit from killing a shared resource which benefits the region's tourist trade.

Monkey puzzle tree

Thousands of these trees, popular as an ornamental garden species in Europe and North America, grow along the Argentina-Chile border in the Andes, but the illegal collection of seeds is preventing the forests from regenerating.

The wood is of high quality, the bark has medicinal properties, and the seeds provide local people with a high protein food.

Chile gives the tree total protection and Argentina bans the collection and sale of seeds, but they are nevertheless exported and traded internationally.

An international trade ban is sought.

webTitle: 'As long as there are people to buy ivory, the poachers will find a way'

fields.headline: 'As long as there are people to buy ivory, the poachers will find a way'
fields.trailText: Commander Jeremiah Kurgat looks tired. He has spent the night leading an anti-poaching patrol through the bush of Tsavo national park in eastern Kenya and he has just received another radio call-out.
fields.byline: David Gough in Tsavo national park
fields.body:
Commander Jeremiah Kurgat looks tired. He has spent the night leading an anti-poaching patrol through the bush of Tsavo national park in eastern Kenya and he has just received another radio call-out.

Two of his park rangers are recovering in hospital after being charged last week by a herd of buffalo. Three others are on leave, and the commander is heavily understaffed.

"Poachers don't keep regular hours so neither can we," he says, pulling his camouflage cap over his head.

Commander Kurgat is the leader of an anti-poaching unit - part of the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS) - for whom such missions are becoming commonplace.

After a 10-year lull, the ivory poachers who wreaked havoc in the 1970s and 1980s are back, say KWS officials, and once again Kenya's elephant population is under threat.

In the last 18 months Kenyan authorities have seized more than two tons of illegal ivory, a clear indication, says the KWS director, Nehemiah Rotich, that poachers are once again stalking these most human of animals, which bury their dead and periodically return to the site of burial to pay their respects.

"We have noticed a very major reawakening of the ivory trade in the last 18 months," says Mr Rotich.

"We have now seized nearly as much ivory since last year's sale as we seized during the eight years that the ban [on the ivory trade] was in place."

Senior KWS security officer Josiah Achoki lifts the lid of one of scores of metal boxes in the underground store of KWS headquarters in Nairobi.

Pointing to the dozen elephant tusks inside, he shakes his head. "I thought this was a thing of the past," he said.

Some of the ivory in Mr Achoki's store comes from Tsavo, one of the biggest game parks in Africa. Its 8,000 square miles of scrub and forest play host to the greatest concentration of elephants in east Africa.

In the early 1970s more than 40,000 elephants roamed this park but during the following two decades, spurred on by a seemingly insatiable demand for ivory, poachers killed more than 80% of the elephants. Nationwide as many as 120,000 elephants were killed.

Corporal John Kamau has been with the KWS for 25 years and remembers the worst years. "It seemed like every day that we would find elephant carcasses with half the face cut off," he says. "In recent years poaching became quite rare but in August last year we found the bodies of 20 elephants here in Tsavo."

Wildlife officials say that Kenya is particularly prone to poaching because widespread conflict in east Africa means that guns are cheap and readily available.

Bandits from neighbouring Somalia are believed to make up many of the poaching gangs. The absence of the rule of law in Somalia also makes smuggling the ivory out of Africa to its export market in Asia a relatively straightforward affair.

Daphne Sheldrick, whose husband David was Tsavo's first warden, has spent 22 years running a shelter for orphaned baby elephants.

Their tusks have not yet grown, and they are of no interest to the poachers, who murder the adults and leave their traumatised offspring to their fate. The lucky ones are rescued by KWS rangers and brought to the orphanage.

Every day at noon the elephants and their keepers trundle down towards a small crowd of tourists who come to watch the animals playing at a water hole. To the delight of the tourists, they lollop around in pursuit of a football, which they kick or knock around with their trunks.

By opening the orphanage to visitors, Ms Sheldrick hopes to remind people of the realities of poaching. She says the fact that she is caring for more orphans than ever before proves poaching is back.

"The ivory trade has never been controlled - not by Cites [the convention protecting endangered species], not by anyone. A complete ban is the only thing that works."

When Cites agreed to the limited sale of ivory, it was agreed that a monitoring body should be set up, but it never materialised and so it remains the task of rangers such as Commander Kurgat to fight the poachers.

"We are only 50 men here in the park trying to cover 8,000 square miles" he says. "We do our best but so long as there are people to buy ivory then the poachers will always find a way."

webTitle: Creatures are becoming extinct at a frightening rate. So who cares?

fields.headline: Creatures are becoming extinct at a frightening rate. So who cares?
fields.trailText: Life began on earth around 3.8bn years ago. From the first, death and extinction were part of the story.
fields.body:
Life began on earth around 3.8bn years ago. From the first, death and extinction were part of the story.

For more than 2bn years, the planet was occupied only by microbes - bacteria, fungi and yeasts - forming a thick slime in ponds, clinging on to ocean reefs, forming thick mats in rivers and eating minerals in rocks.

Around 600m years ago, complex life suddenly arrived, and so many new forms of multicellular creatures appeared - and disappeared - that evolutionary biologists called it the "Cambrian explosion". Mostly, they disappeared, randomly weeded out by evolutionary pressures.

Life went on, creatures came and went. Sometimes they disappeared en masse. There have been five major "extinction events" in the last 600m years, and a larger number of minor ones.

Every now and then, conditions would change, and species that couldn't shape up, shipped out. Each time, biodiversity would be dramatically reduced. Each time, life would bounce back over a 10m-year interval, with a new suite of creatures to thrive in new conditions.

Most of the creatures that have ever lived are now extinct, leaving only the imprint of their bones in sandy or muddy rocks as testament that they lived at all. Palaeontologists had seen the pattern so often they even arrived at a natural lifespan for a species: two million years, they said, maybe as many as 11m years. Life was an unfolding story, and extinctions were part of the background.

Until about 1980, that was the orthodoxy. Biologists calculated that there might be 2m species on the planet, and said that they had names and descriptions and specimens for more than 1.5m of them. They also said that thousands were threatened with extinction because of human activity.

Then one of them spread a collecting net under some tropical trees and sprayed toxic smoke aloft, and counted the things that fell into his collecting funnels.

The consequences were astonishing. So many strange little arthropods - little things with skeletons on the outside and jointy legs - fell into his hands that he had to think again. He proposed that, if the undreamed-of creatures of the canopy were any guide, there might be 10m species to be named. Or 30m.

At that point, experts began to realise the cost of razing the tropical forests, draining the mangrove swamps or polluting the coral reefs. If there were so many plants, mammals, birds, bees, beetles, reptiles, ants, spiders and fungi on the planet, then they must compete for tiny specialised niches. If a lot of forest was cleared, then thousands would go.

Campaigners, anxious to create a sense of public urgency about the dangers of extinction, began to make strident claims. Biologists started taking cool, measured looks. They found that the campaigners weren't being strident enough.

The great US biologist Edward O Wilson started as a doubter and changed his mind: he recently calculated that at least 27,000 creatures were disappearing from the tropical forests before the bulldozer and blowtorch every year.

Britain's chief scientific adviser, Sir Robert May, believes that creatures are now perishing at 1,000 times, or even 10,000 times, the "background rate" of extinction over the past 600m years.

Most biologists call what is now going on "the sixth great extinction". The tiger and the panda are only a tiny part of the story. Half of all the planet's occupants could perish in the next century or so.

The cruellest aspect is that all biologists now recognise that they will never know anything at all about most of the creatures that will slip into oblivion.

webTitle: Murder charges await leaders of massacre cult

fields.headline: Murder charges await leaders of massacre cult
fields.trailText: The Ugandan government yesterday issued six arrest warrants on 10 counts of murder each for the leaders of the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God cult, more than 700 of whose members have died.
fields.body:
The Ugandan government yesterday issued six arrest warrants on 10 counts of murder each for the leaders of the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God cult, more than 700 of whose members have died.

The warrants are for the cult leader, Joseph Kibwetere, the "programmer", Credonia Mwerinde and four of the "apostles", Catholic priest Dominic Kataribabo, and three leaders named only as Kasaburai, Kamagara and Komuhangai.

"There are 10 counts [each] for now, but it could be more. The investigations are still going on. This is just to get them arrested," the director of public prosecutions, Richard Buteere, said. "This is a holding charge. If they are arrested, the proper charge shall be preferred."

It is not clear what prompted the police to issue the arrest warrants, other than the need to appear to be doing something to solve what looks as if it may become the largest cult-related massacre on record.

Although the Ugandan police have admitted that the demands of the investigation are beyond their under-resourced capacity, pressure is mounting on the force and government officials to explain how the cult could have gone unchecked for so long.

Reports emerged yesterday that, weeks before the doomsday cult's fiery end, top authorities in Kampala sent local police a "very urgent" warning that the sect was reported to be kidnapping children and burying those who died in mass graves. Police have denied the existence of the children's graves, but the disclosure follows the arrest of a local government official for covering up a previous security report.

Also, in the spring of 1999, officials who were investigating a series of sudden deaths among the cult's children at a compound in Rushojwa called of their inquiry after being told they had died of malaria.

The bodies of 725 cult members have been found since the start of an investigation that was at first thought to be mass suicide.

At least 330 - and possibly as many as 500 - were killed in a fire on March 17 at the cult headquarters in Kanungu, western Uganda. A further 395 bodies have since been exhumed from four sites operated by the cult in the western Ugandan districts of Rukingere and Bushenyi.

Police believe that there are still more bodies in other sites in the area, but they have temporarily halted exhumations because of a lack of funds and expertise.

One body, sprawled out by the rear exit of the church in Kanungu, had been identified as that of Father Kataribabo. But the harried director of the criminal investigation department, Erasmus Opio, declared yesterday that there was no evidence that any of the cult leaders had died.

"We are looking for them all, both within the country and outside," Mr Opio said. "We believe they are alive. There is no evidence that they are dead."

webTitle: Top female officer 'was groped at the Pentagon'

fields.headline: Top female officer 'was groped at the Pentagon'
fields.trailText: A few months ago, Major General Larry Smith was given responsibility for driving out sexual harassment from the US army. Today he stands accused of groping the army's first female three-star general in a case which has put male military mistreatment of women back into the headlines.
fields.body:
A few months ago, Major General Larry Smith was given responsibility for driving out sexual harassment from the US army. Today he stands accused of groping the army's first female three-star general in a case which has put male military mistreatment of women back into the headlines.

Lieutenant-General Claudia Kennedy, the highest ranking woman in the US army and its top intelligence officer, says that in 1996 Gen Smith made an unwanted sexual advance in her office at the Pentagon. She mentioned the issue informally to superiors at the time but did not make a formal complaint.

However, in August 1999, when Gen Smith was appointed the army's deputy inspector general, a post whose responsibilities include military discipline and the investigation of sexual misconduct allegations, Gen Kennedy raised the issue again.

This time the complaint became formal and the case has since become the most high profile of a succession of sexual harassment cases dogging the US military's attempts to enforce gender equality in the forces.

The case is particularly embarrassing for the military because Gen Kennedy, 52, has regularly been promoted in Pentagon public relations as a role model for women seeking a career in the US armed services. Her 1997 appointment as the army's first three-star general was heavily publicised as a breakthrough for women career soldiers.

Gen Kennedy recently told her staff that she intends to retire from the army this summer.

Some 14% of US army active service personnel are female, a total of around 71,000 out of an army strength of nearly half a million.

Two women in other branches of the services have been promoted to equivalent rank to Gen Kennedy - Vice-Admiral Patricia Tracy in the navy and Lieutenant-General Leslie Kenne in the air force.

Gen Kennedy's complaint meant that Gen Smith's appointment last year to the key oversight job was quickly frozen. Instead of being put in charge of people, he is now in charge of stores, and is serving as special assistant to the commander of US army materiel in Virginia, a holding appointment while the army inspector general conducts an investigation into the incident.

When Gen Kennedy's complaint of sexual harassment was first made public last week, the identity of the man she accused of groping her was kept secret. Pentagon officials only later revealed that the accusation is against Gen Smith.

Gen Kennedy and Gen Smith have spent their army careers in different fields. She has worked mostly in intelligence, while he has been a land combat officer and an expert in armour.

Their careers crossed briefly for three months in 1993 when Gen Smith was director of operations at Fort McPherson in Georgia and Gen Kennedy was director of intelligence at the same base.

The accused general is a former Vietnam war combat soldier who worked his way up through the ranks of the US military after enlisting in 1966. Before reaching his present rank in 1996, Gen Smith was in charge of providing military training and assistance to the Saudi Arabian national guard.

The details of exactly what happened between the two generals in in October 1996 remain largely unknown, although Pentagon officials say informally that the alleged groping was a brief encounter involving physical contact and was an unrepeated one-off.

"All sides wanted to handle this informally," a Pentagon of ficial says. "That's what you do to avoid ruining someone's career."

Nothing concerning the incident was entered on Gen Smith's career record files at the time, and superiors now claim that they were unaware of his involvement in an action which would presumably have precluded his promotion to the deputy inspector general's post.

The investigation into Gen Smith is now said to be nearing completion. Whatever the outcome, the case is certain to be a setback in attempts to portray the military as providing a model career path for women recruits.

The US army has had to endure a succession of sex scandals in recent years, including rape and assault cases at a Maryland recruitment base and the demotions of two top male commanders for having affairs with the wives of subordinates.

In one of these cases in 1997 Major General David Hale, who was also deputy inspector general of the army, the post to which Gene Smith was appointed last year, was charged with 17 counts of misconduct after the wife of a colonel under his command brought a complaint against him. After being found guilty of some of the charges, he was demoted.

webTitle: Young radicals show a clenched fist to Milosevic's state machine

fields.headline: Young radicals show a clenched fist to Milosevic's state machine
fields.standfirst: Activists' peaceful message could marginalise Serbia's divided opposition
fields.trailText: Along the walls of the Plateau, a student area just off the main pedestrian street in the heart of Belgrade, three young men with a bucket of glue, a paint-roller, and a pile of posters are moving rapidly along a wall.
fields.body:
Along the walls of the Plateau, a student area just off the main pedestrian street in the heart of Belgrade, three young men with a bucket of glue, a paint-roller, and a pile of posters are moving rapidly along a wall.

On each poster is a clenched fist, the word Otpor, which means Resistance, and the slogan "Because I love Serbia."

Otpor, which was formed by a group of 15 friends at Belgrade University in 1998, has grown into a national network of activists with a simple message of resistance to President Slobodan Milosevic and his government.

It is the latest star in the opposition sky over Serbia - but one that is growing in importance so rapidly, that it threatens to eclipse the others.

It now claims between 5,000 and 10,000 activists in 102 towns across Serbia.

It has no members, only "activists", many of whom are still at secondary school. They shun the idea of leaders, and seek peaceful confrontation with the authorities by spraying graffiti, leafleting public places and staging colourful events, such as street theatre.

A basic condition of joining is the willingness to be arrested, and the authorities have been swift to oblige. There have been 300 arrests and 9,000 hours in police custody for activists so far, they say proudly.

A more sinister development is physical attacks on activists by groups of well-organised men in black leather jackets, who frequently disrupt opposition gatherings.

"We do not just represent resistance to Milosevic's regime," says Milja Jovanovic, a Belgrade activist. "But resistance to this whole . . . chaos that's been on our shoulders for the last 10 years."

We are sitting in Otpor's Belgrade HQ, a first-floor flat decorated mainly with the stencilled fist. Mobile and landline phones are ringing, and eager young men and women are bent over computer screens.

Ms Jovanovic has pigtails, wears the obligatory Otpor T-shirt, and is, at 25, old for the movement. The average age of activists is 20 to 21.

One year after the Nato air strikes, the authorities are keen to remind the public of Serbia's resistance to "the Nato aggressors" and to paint their domestic political opponents as Nato puppets. A rival poster campaign has begun in Belgrade, showing the Otpor fist clutching a wodge of dollars, beside pictures of the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, and the former Kosovo Liberation Army leader Hashim Thaci.

Otpor's response is typically bold and provocative - to stage a commemoration for all the Serbian policemen who died in Kosovo.

But the actions of Otpor activists have also won them friends.

"Otpor now has a significant role in the political life of Serbia, particularly when we're faced here with such a weak and divided opposition," said Bratislav Grubacic, a respected political commentator. "Otpor is kind of a virus that might spread all over Serbia."

The next united opposition rally in Belgrade is due on April 14, although preparations were marred as usual by bitter recriminations between the two main opposition groups, the Serbian Renewal Movement, led by Vuk Draskovic, and the Alliance for Change.

Otpor activists have sharply criticised the opposition as well as the government.

"They're very young and radical towards everyone, including the opposition," said Ognjen Pribecevic, adviser to Mr Draskovic, "but their main target is Milosevic, and we accept this."

And for all the radicalism, the movement's efforts will soon swing to that most dull and necessary of democratic tasks - trying to persuade the electorate, especially the young, to turn out and vote in the local and federal elections due later this year. Otpor activists will not be standing themselves, but they will urge voters to choose opposition parties.

Opposition councillors occupied a town hall in the northern Serbian town of Zrenjanin to demand punishment for the abductors of a colleague, a councillor said yesterday.

In a telephone call from the town hall, Bojan Kostres, of the opposition League of Social Democrats, said the councillors would remain in place until their demands were met.

They also wanted the reinstatement of two colleagues who were stripped of their mandate. The abducted councillor was freed after missing an important council session.

fields.headline: Home for Joe
fields.standfirst: Row surrounds DiMaggio memorial
fields.trailText: Where will you go, Joe DiMaggio? That is the question that is currently perplexing his fans and family in a bizarre and unseemly row over a memorial for the legendary baseball star and ex-husband of Marilyn Monroe.
fields.body:
Where will you go, Joe DiMaggio? That is the question that is currently perplexing his fans and family in a bizarre and unseemly row over a memorial for the legendary baseball star and ex-husband of Marilyn Monroe.

The city of San Francisco, where DiMaggio grew up and retired to, is anxious to pay tribute to the man once known as the greatest living baseball player. Plans were made to rename the North Beach playground where "Joltin' Joe", who died last year, first learned his elegant skills.

Then some of his family intervened to say that they did not feel the playground was a suitable memorial and that Joe deserved something bigger, such as the San Francisco International airport or the Bay Bridge.

The family's attorney, Morris Engelberg, even threatened to sue if the city proceeded to rename the park without the family's permission. Mr Engelberg said that, before his death at the age of 84, DiMaggio had indicated that he would have liked his name attached to the airport or the bridge, and Mr Engelberg was thus just doing his late client's bidding.

DiMaggio was well known for jealously protecting his name, refusing to sign baseballs if he thought they would be resold on the sport memorabilia market.

The family, and the legal intervention, has upset the San Francisco mayor, Willie Brown. If the family did not like the idea of the park, which stands in the old Italian neighbourhood adjoining Chinatown, then there would be no memorial at all. The city supervisor, Gavin Newson, has said that the city will not give in to the demands.

Now Joe's brother has entered the arena. Dom DiMaggio, 84, said that the playground would be fine as a tribute to Joe.

"This city has been very good to my family, starting with my immigrant parents and continuing to this day," said Dom DiMaggio yesterday. "As far as I am concerned, the city can determine for itself the way it wants to honour its native son."

He reckoned that his late brother would have supported the idea of the playground being renamed, particularly if it meant that the now slightly run-down playspace was modernised.

At the North Beach playground yesterday, there was clear support for the city's plan. Sitting in his wheelchair outside, Marco Turchino, who had known DiMaggio as a boy, said that a renamed park would be the best memorial.

"This is where he came from," said Mr Turchino, a former fisherman who remembered DiMaggio's fisherman father. "This is where he played. Who's going to go all the way to the airport to see a plaque? He was a helluva good player and this is the place he should be remembered."

Slinging a cheroot into the gutter, Mr Turchino said that he would like to tell the people who thought the park was unworthy as a memorial to an American sports idol what to do to themselves.

The row highlights the delicate business of renaming and honouring; William Hague's suggestion in the wake of Princess Diana's death that Heathrow be renamed comes to mind. But at least Joe's admirers know that, whatever happens, no one is ever going to rewrite what he achieved as a New York Yankee.

Then some of his family intervened to say that they did not feel the playground was a suitable memorial and that Joe deserved something bigger, such as the San Francisco International airport or the Bay Bridge. The family's attorney, Morris Engelberg, even threatened to sue if the city proceeded to rename the park without the family's permission. Mr Engelberg said that, before his death at the age of 84, DiMaggio had indicated that he would have liked his name attached to the airport or the bridge, and Mr Engelberg was thus just doing his late client's bidding. DiMaggio was well known for jealously protecting his name, refusing to sign baseballs if he thought they would be resold on the sport memorabilia market. The family, and the legal intervention, has upset the San Francisco mayor, Willie Brown. If the family did not like the idea of the park, which stands in the old Italian neighbourhood adjoining Chinatown, then there would be no memorial at all. The city supervisor, Gavin Newson, has said that the city will not give in to the demands. Now Joe's brother has entered the arena. Dom DiMaggio, 84, said that the playground would be fine as a tribute to Joe. "This city has been very good to my family, starting with my immigrant parents and continuing to this day," said Dom DiMaggio yesterday. "As far as I am concerned, the city can determine for itself the way it wants to honour its native son." He reckoned that his late brother would have supported the idea of the playground being renamed, particularly if it meant that the now slightly run-down playspace was modernised. At the North Beach playground yesterday, there was clear support for the city's plan. Sitting in his wheelchair outside, Marco Turchino, who had known DiMaggio as a boy, said that a renamed park would be the best memorial. "This is where he came from," said Mr Turchino, a former fisherman who remembered DiMaggio's fisherman father. "This is where he played. Who's going to go all the way to the airport to see a plaque? He was a helluva good player and this is the place he should be remembered." Slinging a cheroot into the gutter, Mr Turchino said that he would like to tell the people who thought the park was unworthy as a memorial to an American sports idol what to do to themselves. The row highlights the delicate business of renaming and honouring; William Hague's suggestion in the wake of Princess Diana's death that Heathrow be renamed comes to mind. But at least Joe's admirers know that, whatever happens, no one is ever going to rewrite what he achieved as a New York Yankee.
fields.bylineHtml: Duncan Campbell in San Francisco

webTitle: UK at risk of 'rogue' reprisals if it gives space to US missile shield

fields.headline: UK at risk of 'rogue' reprisals if it gives space to US missile shield
fields.trailText: Britain would become a target of "rogue" states if the government allowed the US to use its bases for a proposed national missile protective shield, senior defence sources admitted for the first time yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain would become a target of "rogue" states if the government allowed the US to use its bases for a proposed national missile protective shield, senior defence sources admitted for the first time yesterday.

Ministers, including Tony Blair, have been approached by Washington about upgrading the Fylingdales early warning radar station in north Yorkshire.

By admitting that Britain may become a target, defence sources are warning Washington that it would expect some financial or security guarantees as a quid pro quo. The government also appears to be preparing parliamentary and public opinion for a decision to accede to Washington's request at a time when an increasingly intense debate is taking place across Europe.

The US national security agency base at Menwith Hill, also in north Yorkshire, would also play a key role in the proposed system, sometimes called the "son of star wars".

The large eavesdropping base, which receives and transmits signals from satellites, is being upgraded, although defence sources say that this is necessary whether or not the US goes ahead with its missile shield. The base monitors missile launches as well as diplomatic, military and commercial communications.

Fylingdales and Menwith Hill, along with Thule in Greenland, would be needed by the US in the first phase of the controversial project, which Washington says is directed particularly at North Korea. The second phase, for which the US congress is already being pressed to commit funds, would involve the construction in Britain of a new radar system.

Such a system, the housing for which would be the size of a 15-storey building, would provide early warning of mis sile launches from Middle Eastern countries, including Iraq and Iran, the sources said.

The government, acutely aware of opposition to the US project in Britain and elsewhere in Europe, says it wants to promote a debate about the "consequences" of what it recognises is a highly sensitive and complex issue with potentially enormous ramifications for arms control agreements, as well as the security relationships between the US and its Nato allies. It would also be hugely expensive, costing tens of billions of dollars.

Washington has been trying to persuade sceptical European allies that they need anti-missile systems. Many European allies - notably France and Germany, believe that the US is exaggerating the threat proposed by North Korea and other "rogue" states. That scepticism is shared by many policy advisers and strategists in Whitehall.

They also fear that a US national anti-missile system, which would require an amendment to the anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty between the US and Russia, would unleash a new arms race.

Washington is trying to persuade Moscow to agree to an ABM treaty amendment, offering anti-missile technology to the Russians.

A crucial test for the first phase of the US project - an arsenal of 200 interceptor missiles based in Alaska and North Dakota to be deployed in 2005 - was due to have taken place this month, but technical problems forced a delay until the end of June.

A debate is now taking off in Washington about whether the US president, Bill Clinton, should decide whether to go ahead - spiking the guns of Republicans who want a more extensive and, as far as global security is concerned, more destabilising system - or leave it to his successor.
