webTitle: Lockheed accused of helping arm China

fields.headline: Lockheed accused of helping arm China
fields.trailText: The US government has charged its largest defence contractor with illegally helping the Chinese to develop satellite rocket technology that could be used to launch missiles against Taiwan and US itself.
fields.body:
The US government has charged its largest defence contractor with illegally helping the Chinese to develop satellite rocket technology that could be used to launch missiles against Taiwan and US itself.

The state department's defence trade controls office has told the Lockheed Martin corporation that it has 30 days to respond to civil charges of breaching the arms export control act.

If found guilty, the defence giant could be barred from the lucrative satellite-technology export business for up to three years and be fined up to $15m.

Authorities allege that Lockheed provided an assessment of a Chinese-made satellite motor to a state-owned company in China, thus potentially breaching export controls.

Lockheed says it sent experts to China in 1994 to assess test firings of the "kick" motor which the Asia Satellite Telecommunications Co - partly owned by the Chinese state - intended using to put its Asiasat-2 communications satellite into final orbit. The 1995 launch was a success.

"National security was not harmed and no technology was exported" to China, said a Lockheed spokesman.

The state department alleges that Lockheed failed to tell Washington what it was doing in China, in breach of the law, and so failed to ensure the requisite presence of a Pentagon observer at the test firings.

Copies of Lockheed's 50-page report on the firings were sent to China without letting Pentagon censors black out sensitive passages. When they saw the report, the Pentagon experts deleted all but five pages, the Washington Post reported.

"The company made no effort to retrieve the exported information," James Rubin of the state department was quoted as saying.

"In our view any assistance to Chinese technical capabilities in space launch[es] has the potential to be applied to missile development."

fields.headline:
No: 1611
 Anna Kournikova
fields.body:
Age: 18.

Appearance: Barbie's little sister, Skipper.

Occupation: Russian tennis idol and model for the Berlei Shock Absorber bra.

Phwoar! Actually, she believes that "only the ball should bounce".

Like a bit of action, does she? Steady on, she's just been dumped by her fiancé, Pavel Bure.

Good-looker? He's the Russian Rocket.

Met on Mir did they? Don't be so stupid. He's a 29-year-old ice hockey ace with a £30m, five-year contract with the Florida Panthers.

Likes to flash it about does he? Apparently, the ring cost £650,000 and the couple celebrated with a £2,000 bottle of champagne.

Well-matched? The manager of the Miami restaurant where Bure proposed said the couple would have "beautiful, strong, fast, perfect babies". Russian geneaologists agreed.

Brilliant. Everyone's happy then. Not exactly. Bure left her after five weeks, saying: "No one's going to marry anyone."

Did he give any reason? "At the moment," he said, "I love ice hockey more than anything."

Is he serious? According to the Russian press, Bure didn't like his future mother-in-law.

What's she like? Alla, 37, prefers to stay behind the scenes advising her daughter on how to bump up her £10m fortune with more advertising contracts.

Sounds really useful to me. What was the problem? Russian papers say Alla turned the girl into a "money-making machine". She takes up to 50% of Anna's advertising earnings.

Will the "Lolita of tennis" walk out on her mum? Not likely. She brings her mother along to matches and interviews, and they live together in a Florida condominium.

Not to be confused with: Monica Seles, Anna Karenina, Rapunzel.

Do say: "New balls, please."

Don't say: "It's love all."

webTitle: Should an agnostic get baptised just to please her dying father?

fields.headline: Should an agnostic get baptised just to please her dying father?
fields.trailText: My father, who is in his 80s and suffering from emphysema, was brought up as a Catholic. His schooling in a monastery put him off setting foot in a church for 50 years. However, as his health has deteriorated he has returned to his Catholic roots. He prays every day, and has become agitated over not having had me baptised. He is terrified he may have condemned me to hell, and is desperate for me to be christened.
fields.body:
My father, who is in his 80s and suffering from emphysema, was brought up as a Catholic. His schooling in a monastery put him off setting foot in a church for 50 years. However, as his health has deteriorated he has returned to his Catholic roots. He prays every day, and has become agitated over not having had me baptised. He is terrified he may have condemned me to hell, and is desperate for me to be christened.

I am a 30-year-old woman, who not only finds it impossible to believe in any institutionalised god, but is also repelled by many of the things the Catholic church has done and stands for.

Should I stick to my beliefs or go through with this to make an old, sick man happy?

It's a mockery of faith

Anyone who returned to their "Catholic roots" and talked to a priest would soon be told that we don't believe that the unbaptised go to hell.

An adult can't just go and get sprinkled with the waters of baptism like a wash and blow-dry. The point of adult baptism is belief. It is an affront to any religion (or any secular society) to go through a ceremony without any belief or intention of carrying out one's promises.

Enquirers - those who want to know about Catholic belief or wish to be baptised - are now asked to participate in a befriending group; only after weeks of discussion and coming to some understanding of Catholic teaching would a candidate be thought ready for baptism.

Name and address supplied

He needs help, not you

I am the daughter of parents in their 80s, one of whom has lately returned to the Anglican church of which I am a member, the other of whom is an avowed atheist. In my professional life I have experience of elderly people who, facing their mortality, renew their faith but have misgivings about past omissions. Your father has a medical condition which may affect the flow of oxygen to his brain and confuse his thought processes. Moreover, you are only 30, born when he was over 50, and he may still perceive you as a child rather than an independent adult.

Whatever your personal views and your father's past experiences, he clearly needs the support of a caring church. Encourage your father to seek counselling from his priest. If he does not have one, with your father's permission, contact the local priest and ask him to visit your father. This is something you could do for him whether you believe or not.

You might consider suggesting to your father that, together, you see a priest he knows and trusts, so that you can explain your point of view that, as a grown woman, it is not his, but your decision whether or not to be baptised. If your father continues to dwell on his guilt (which, with his medical condition, he may) you and his priest may have to continue to reassure him that it is not his problem.

Name and address supplied

You're in good company

Stick to your beliefs and point this out to your father: Myra Hindley, the murderous cult leaders in Nigeria and Hitler all had parents who ensured they were christened in the Catholic faith. Socrates and Mahatma Gandhi did not. Which ones, in his opinion, are more likely to end up in hell?

If he is still not convinced, ask a Catholic priest to pay him a visit and reassure him that if you are condemned to hell, it will be because of your own sins, and not because of someone else's omission.

Claude Shields, Aylesbury

Take the plunge

Writing as somebody who strongly objects to all things religious I would advise you to do as your father wishes. If you really are a non-believer, going through the ceremony of baptism would be a meaningless ritual for you. All you have to provide is a small amount of your time. Why do you hesitate? This view is based on the fact that your father has not got much longer to live. If you were much younger, the need to assert your own views and values might, of course, be a necessary part of developing an adult relationship with your parent.

If, on the other hand, you suspect that you might be committing yourself to something that has a meaning for you, the situation is different. In this case, your own peace of mind is probably more important than that of your father - and remember, you are likely to have to live with your decision for longer.

Anke Neibig, Newcastle- upon-Tyne

Next week

I am currently in a loving and mutually supportive relationship with a man who has a history of infidelity. It began before his separation from his second wife. He is some years older than me and it seems to me that much of the explanation for his philandering was due to a different generational approach to remaining in a marriage no matter how unhappy it was.

However, whatever the reasons for his constant infidelity I now find myself becoming increasingly distrustful of him. He knows that I suffer with insecurity in sexual relationships and tries to reassure me, but I can't help feeling that I am a fool to believe that after a lifetime of profligacy he can commit himself to a monogamous relationship. Despite this, in all other areas of life he is an honourable and compassionate human being who is respected and admired.

I strongly believe that people have the capacity to change but I can't seem to apply this view to him. I have now reached the stage where I am starting to question him about his activities and I brood on the situation in self-destructive ways.

Is it possible to trust someone with such a history? If so, how?

Each Friday we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 0171 239 9935, email privatelives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

webTitle: The town that will not die

fields.headline: The town that will not die
fields.standfirst: Ford said yesterday that if profits continued to slide at its Essex plant, it would pull the plug.  Roy Greenslade  , who grew up in the shadow of the belching, stinking chimneys, says there's a lot more to Dagenham than a car factory
fields.trailText: Ford said yesterday that if profits continued to slide at its Essex plant, it would pull the plug.  Roy Greenslade  , who grew up in the shadow of the belching, stinking chimneys, says there's a lot more to Dagenham than a car factory
fields.body:
It was, I remember, a bitterly cold day, so we were delighted when the guide announced: "Foundry next." Ten minutes later, gazing down from the steel walkway overlooking the furnace, we were desperate to rush back out into the icy winds sweeping across the Thames marshes.

How did those men in their thick overalls and visors feel as they stoked the huge fires or poured molten steel? Apart from the heat, how did they put up with the noise, stench and filth? We had already wondered at the horrors of the assembly line, shaking our heads in sympathy with the men carrying out their repetitive tasks, hour after hour, day after day. For many of us, boys and girls from Dagenham county high school on an obligatory trip around the Ford factory in the early 1960s, it was a turning point.

Our teachers had often told us that we, the offspring of largely blue-collar workers, were "privileged" because we were enjoying the benefits of a grammar school education. It didn't mean much until we went to Ford. I have long suspected that we all made a silent vow that day: whatever happens, we will not work here.

Now, 40 years later, it is Ford making the vow: there will be no work here at all if profits continue to slide. Ford of Europe chairman Nick Scheele announced in late February: "I can't guarantee the Dagenham plant won't shut." That threat may only be a bargaining ploy to cow the unions as the company seeks to cut more than 3,000 jobs from the existing 8,000. Or could it be, as the Barking and Dagenham Post suggested, the end of the line, the start to a process heralding the inevitable closure of one of Britain's most famous manufacturing landmarks?

Whatever the outcome, the short-term future of Dagenham is in the balance. In the long term, as we undergo a hi-tech revolution while global capitalism continues to demand the relocation of engineering companies to countries where labour is cheaper, it looks decidedly dodgy.

As I drive through the familiar streets of the giant Becontree estate on my first visit for almost a decade, I wonder what the future holds for Dagenham. Outsiders may well answer: who cares? I concede that it isn't the kind of place to inspire affection. It's an aesthete's vision of hell. But Dagenham has a special place in my memories and, yes, in my heart. I went to school there for six years and spent the best part of the next four as a junior journalist on one of the local newspapers. I was not "from" Dagenham but I consider I am "of" Dagenham. It is my adopted home town.

When Tony Blair pointed out, in a recent speech on Britishness, that we are a geographically mobile people who are rarely "from" one place, I understood what he meant. Born in Dulwich, south-east London, I moved to Walthamstow when I was six and, by the time I was seven, we were living in a council house on an estate near South Ockendon, Essex. After passing the 11-plus, I was sent to Dagenham county high, a grammar school in the poorest of Essex boroughs for the poorest of academic performers.

Against the odds, and to my mother's chagrin, I enjoyed Dagenham, with its vibrant street life and edgy atmosphere. I was 14 when my parents bought a house in the more upmarket area of Leigh-on-Sea, but I refused to switch schools, happily enduring the daily 50-mile round trip to Dagenham. It was indeed a grim area, but I soon discovered that the people were far nicer than the surroundings. Gangs of teddy boys with razor blades tucked into the lapels of their velvet-collared jackets were a media myth. Their clothes were always sharper than their knives.

I found myself nestling in the warmth of my schoolfriends' parents, almost all of them part of the east end diaspora dislodged by the Blitz. These people, like my own parents, were eager for their sons and daughters to succeed, to escape from the drudgery they and their parents before them had endured. They recognised that education was the door to a world of opportunity opening up for the baby boom generation of the early 1960s.

Ford, where a lot of my friends' fathers worked, seemed like a step backwards. The insistent message of our youth was not to do as our dads had done. We must "better" ourselves: wear white collars, avoid manual work, get a life. A father of one of my friends, a Ford foundryman for 20 years, once told me: "It's awful. I hate it." He was determined that his son wouldn't enter Ford's gates.

Some 15 years later, when I hunted down my 128 former co-pupils, I found that only three had taken jobs at Ford, all white-collar, and none of them at Dagenham. We, the brightest of the local kids, had turned our backs on the company that symbolised our area. Thousands of others didn't, and there are plenty of families in Dagenham now that boast three generations of Ford employees.

Only later did I come to realise that there was nothing intrinsically wrong with Ford, with any manufacturing industry. We had been conditioned by a mixture of snobbishness and a mistaken belief that factories of any kind represented the past.

In the back of my Cortina.

He was also amazed by the mean streets with their terraced houses, once impossible to tell apart, now a riot of cladding, inappropriate bay windows and glass porches.

Why, he wondered, would anyone buy such houses in such a place? One answer is money: Dagenham has the lowest average household income in London (£19,569 to Kensington's £33,492) and the cheapest housing, with an average price of just £68,500. They have little choice.

But that doesn't explain why new generations are staying on. I suspect from my conversations with residents that the real reason Dagenham has a settled population is that many people like it. Without wishing to indulge in false romanticism, it is a kind of transplanted, pre-war east end of London. What has developed in Dagenham is a quasi-cockney community, a recreation of the Poplar, Stepney and Limehouse roots from which so many residents sprang and which has also influenced the offspring of the estate's original intake from Manchester.

Myth-makers like to cast the old east end as some kind of paradise. It wasn't, and neither is Dagenham. But just as the moral core of the east end resided in the people rather than the buildings and streets, so it does in Dagenham. This was my unconscious discovery as a boy and it has taken me almost 40 years of a love-hate relationship to rediscover it.

That's why, even if Ford does drive off into the sunset, Dagenham will not suffer as Flint in Michigan did when General Motors deserted in favour of Mexico. In any case, council leader Charlie Fairbrass is convinced that Ford is staying for the moment. He has also been assured that the company will invest in a £468m project to regenerate part of the ugly Thameside area into a Canary Wharf-style business zone. But Fairbrass's main aim has been to improve the borough's educational standards, and there is no doubt that there has been a major transformation since five years ago, when it had one of Britain's worst records for exam passes. fields.headline: Julia Roberts
fields.trailText: Julia Roberts
fields.body:
Early Julia

Huge lips, huge hit. Credit card Cinderella in Pretty Woman. Married Lyle Lovett, engaged to everyone else.

Mid-period Julia

Bad choices in increasingly desperate multiplex fodder: hotshot law student (The Pelican Brief), hotshot reporter (I Love Trouble), twinkly Tinkerbell (Hook), dowdy maid (Mary Reilly).

Late Julia

Back in box-office rom-com heaven with My Best Friend's Wedding, Notting Hill and Runaway Bride, reprising Early Julia (insecure girl with dazzling smile) and making overt fun of Middle Julia (fame, tabloid hell and a jittery relationship with altars and commitment). Bums-on-seats quotient rarely matched by critical praise though, until...

New Millennium Julia

Erin Brockovich, in which box-office rule (number one US film with $55.9m in the first 10 days) combines with critical drool. David Thomson says: "We look at Julia and marvel and sigh and are grateful to be there in her dark whether we think she's terrific, lovely and desirable - or so shrewd it ought not to be allowed." "Roberts has kissed a lot of frogs on the way to this satisfying triumph," says the LA Times. America's sweetheart is back, it seems, with a frankly Hello Boys-style uplift and similarly inflated bank balance: from $300,000 (Pretty Woman, 1990) to $20m (Erin Brockovich, 2000).

Post-Millennium Julia

Next up is the action comedy The Mexican with Brad Pitt and James Gandolfini, directed by Gore Verbinski, whose last film was Mouse Hunt.

fields.headline: The Russian is coming
fields.standfirst: A study of 19th-century sexual perversion and a 90s gangster thriller: director Alexei Balabanov tells Isobel Montgomery about his new films
fields.trailText: A study of 19th-century sexual perversion and a 90s gangster thriller: director Alexei Balabanov tells Isobel Montgomery about his new films
fields.body:
You wait for years to see a Russian film, and then two come along at once. They are wildly different in style and content but share the same writer-director, Alexei Balabanov.

Of Freaks and Men is a costume drama set at the turn of the 20th century, a sepia-tinted story about sex and the bourgeoisie. The other, Brother, is a modern story of mafia hitmen, grimy apartments and what it takes to survive in the chaos of a country that has lost its way. Of Freaks and Men - all about power and perversion - is an arthouse movie while Brother is stylish and violent, and was a huge commercial success in Russia.

You would think from Brother - released here today - that Balabanov is trying to make Die Hard in St Petersburg, and claw back some box-office share from Hollywood. When baby-faced hero Danila pulls a gun to defend a tram conductor from Chechen fare-dodgers, audiences in Russia applauded. Brother is a film they could relate to.

Of Freaks and Men, on the other hand, with its prolonged scenes of a nice middle-class girl being whipped and a blind aristocrat raising her skirts while Siamese conjoined Mongolian twins sing folk songs, is unlikely to get an audience to its feet, except, perhaps, to walk out in disgust. There are, none the less, similarities. Both films share a St Petersburg setting, are photographed with grace by Sergei Astakhov, and give full rein to Viktor Sukhorukov's artlessly charming supporting roles as a psychopath. And both have ruffled audiences' sense of political correctness and good taste.

Balabanov admits to making films which provoke: "When I started making films, it was possible to do anything you wanted." He is part of the first generation not limited by censorship.

By the time his first film, Happy Days, based on Samuel Beckett, was released in 1992, the old certainties of 70 years of Russian film-making had been swept away. Free to make whatever they liked some, like Nikita Mikhalkov, readily adapted to the new climate while others, including Balabanov's mentor, Alexei German, struggled. All of them were faced for the first time with having to compete with the Hollywood blockbusters which in the early 1990s crowded Russian films out of cinemas across the country.

Balabanov's second film - The Castle, an adaptation of Kafka - made the rounds of film festivals while Balabanov wrote the script for Of Freaks and Men. "I had a very good script, but a film about the 19th century was very expensive to make. So I decided to make a low-budget film. I did not care what film, so I decided to write Brother," Balabanov explains laconically. "Some find Brother immoral, some find it moral, but I don't actually care," he adds.

In Russia, Brother created the same kind of shock waves as Natural Born Killers did in the west. "It is imbued with destruction," Nikita Mikhalkov commented. "You should understand where, when and why you make a film about the discreet charm of murder." Balabanov's mentor, Alexei German, disowned his protégé, accusing him of sharing Danila's anti-semitic, xenophobic views, while the press saw its phenomenal success as a reflection of young Russians' disaffection with their country after the disastrous first Chechen war.

"It is the same syndrome as in the United States after Vietnam ," says Balabanov. "I don't worry about being criticised for the attitudes to Chechens and Jews that Danila shows in my films. It is true. He says things which people of his generation think and say. Why should I not say it in my films? I don't care. People in cinemas applaud and critics criticise."

Foreign viewers admire the film's dark humour, its low-budget stylishness and the naturalness of Sergei Bodrov's portrayal of Danila, who embodies all the contradictions of contemporary Russia. For Balabanov, the most important thing was that Brother, made on a budget of $200,000 and shot on location in the apartments of Balabanov's friends, gave him enough money to finance his next film, Of Freaks and Men, a project much closer to Balabanov's heart.

"I am more interested in looking at the past than at the present. I like the aesthetic of the time," he explains. Of Freaks and Men lingers lovingly on 19th-century St Petersburg, its strangeness and its apparently comfortable bourgeois life.

But despite the samovars and pianos, this is definitely not Chekhov; Balabanov portrays how a pornographer, Johann - another cool criminal - and his sidekick, played with devilish charm by Viktor Sukhorukov, inveigle their way into two households and force the young women to pose for their photographic sessions.

Like Brother, Balabanov gets too close for comfort to the pair's horrible trade. The distancing is done through highly stylised use of sepia tints and silent-film caption boards, but the camera endlessly forces us to watch Liza and Ekaterina's humiliation.

Of Freaks and Men's sub-plot revolves around the use of photography and, as the film progresses, of moving pictures. "I'm a 19th-century film-maker, I would like to live in that period," the director explains. So is it his intention to conspire with Johann to make the audience enjoy what they are watching? Balabanov dodges the question. "It is possible," he says. "You watch the film, you decide."

To audiences brought up with notions of Chekhovian characters pondering their fate, Of Freaks and Men seems a deliberate attempt to overturn the myths of pre-revolutionary Russia, which Soviet film created. Again Balabanov has a ready defence. "I love this time very much. This part of life existed, but it never appeared in films. It is shown in the photographs of the time and I wanted to make a film about it. It existed and what is wrong about it?"

Balabanov cites Feodor Sologub, Russia's best-known "decadent" writer whose works were ignored in prudish Soviet times, and it is hard to argue against him. But the uneasiness remains. Whereas his predecessors would have critiqued characters like Danila and Johann, Balabanov seems to be half in love with them. In Brother violence is simply necessary to survive, while in Of Freaks and Men perversion and blackmail are seen as powerfully attractive.

It would be easy to dismiss Balabanov's work as morally repellent, yet both films contain elements of truth. Danila represents attitudes you can find on any Russian streetcorner, and there was more to the pre-revolutionary bourgeoisie than Soviet film-makers ever showed.

Balabanov can take pride in being one of the few Russian directors who can survive without turning to commercials and pop videos to make a living. He has managed to get Russian audiences interested in seeing Russian films again. He is busy in his St Petersburg studio finishing the sequel to Brother, in which Danila goes to the US to settle scores, and he is already planning the shooting of his next film, about a 19th century ethnographer. He affects not to care what audiences and critics think about his films.

"I do not think of a film's reception. I can afford the luxury of making what I want. That is why I am happy."

 Brother is released today and Of Freaks and Men next Friday.

In Brother violence is simply necessary to survive, while in Of Freaks and Men perversion and blackmail are seen as powerfully attractive. It would be easy to dismiss Balabanov's work as morally repellent, yet both films contain elements of truth. Danila represents attitudes you can find on any Russian streetcorner, and there was more to the pre-revolutionary bourgeoisie than Soviet film-makers ever showed. Balabanov can take pride in being one of the few Russian directors who can survive without turning to commercials and pop videos to make a living. He has managed to get Russian audiences interested in seeing Russian films again. He is busy in his St Petersburg studio finishing the sequel to Brother, in which Danila goes to the US to settle scores, and he is already planning the shooting of his next film, about a 19th century ethnographer. He affects not to care what audiences and critics think about his films. "I do not think of a film's reception. I can afford the luxury of making what I want. That is why I am happy."  Brother is released today and Of Freaks and Men next Friday.

fields.headline: Dread planet
fields.standfirst: Mars has always been a scary presence in sci-fi movies, and a new invasion of space-operas is continuing the tradition.
fields.trailText: Mars has always been a scary presence in sci-fi movies, and a new invasion of space-operas is continuing the tradition.
fields.body:
The first man on Mars is marooned when his landing party is zapped in a mysterious dust storm. In response to a garbled SOS, a rescue mission that includes a husband-and-wife team is dispatched to save our hero. Such is the premise for Disney's impending epic space-capade, Mission to Mars. It is also, as it happens, the set-up for a 1958 B picture called It! The Terror From Beyond Space.

Expect further recycling: more missions to our neighbouring orb are on the launch pad. Warners' The Red Planet (starring Val Kilmer) follows this summer, and next year there is a James Cameron Imax 3D project and a TV mini-series. Two other features - Mars and Beyond, and John Carpenter's Ghosts of Mars - are also in production.

Ever since Georges Méliès blasted his Rocket to the Moon in 1902, movies have been concerned with the question of (to quote Ming the Merciless) "hurling our bodies into the void". This according to Tom Jacobson, the on-the-defensive producer of Mission to Mars, is "because it's the next frontier. It's why the western was so popular. It represents the best, the most heroic and the most challenging in human nature."

It comes as a blessed relief that, after a cluster of asteroid movies (Armageddon; Deep Impact), film-makers are touching down again on that forgotten favourite, the Red Planet - once Earth's greatest bogey, but last glimpsed as an uninspiring mining colony preoccupying Arnold Schwarzenegger in Total Recall.

At one time Mars was the only place a self-respecting alien would lay his slimy hat (spoofed so marvellously by Tim Burton in Mars Attacks!). So much so that "Martian" and "alien" were virtually interchangeable: the "little green men" gleefully levelling our capital cities throughout the 50s as prelude to invasion. "Across the gulf of space on the planet Mars, intellects vast and cold and unsympathetic regarded our Earth with envious eyes, slowly and surely drawing their plans against us," warned the narrator of 1953's War of the Worlds.

From 1951's Flying Disc Men from Mars, Invaders from Mars (1953), Conquest of Space (1954) and The Angry Red Planet (1959) to our own Quatermass and the Pit (1967), scores of films have been devoted to our space nemesis. Being red and all, Mars was also conveniently emblematic of communism. Nowhere is this more evident than in Red Planet Mars, in which, after receiving cryptic broadcast messages from our closest rock, Jehovah himself addresses Earth over the radio ("You have denied God's words and worshipped false gods"), precipitating the collapse of the atheistic USSR.

It's a shame that as science-fiction got tinged with science-fact - not to mention increased audience sophistication - Mars drifted out of orbit and was treated more as an object of exotica, with films such as Santa Claus Conquers the Martians (1964), and Mars Needs Women (1968). By the time Mars returned, in 1978, it had become less a place of awe than the unwitting party in a clever paranoid thriller, Capricorn One - itself a response to rumours that the first moon landing was staged in a TV studio.

So why the renewed Martian mania? The big difference between now and, say, Flash Gordon's Trip to Mars in 1938 - when Buster Crabbe saved humanity from destruction by nitrogen-destroying lamp, and all the Martians spoke English - is that we have reasonable expectations of what we'll find when we get there. Which is why the makers of Mission to Mars secured the expertise of Nasa and consultant astronaut Story Musgrave (a Nasa veteran of 30 years with six spaceflights under his utility belt) to ensure verisimilitude. Every piece of hardware and the human habitats, we are assured, has been faithfully replicated from designs sitting on mission control's drawing-board. Nasa even had script approval.

"The film is very close to a trajectory that may exist in 2020, which is when Mission to Mars is set, but it's important to realise that it's not a documentary," Musgrave stresses. "The movie has, by nature, to create the reality."

In fact, there is something to pin it all on. The latest fleet of projects tracks its blast-off back to the "Martian meteorite" discovery and the 1997 Pathfinder mission which, as a ready-made marketing tool for Hollywood, secured 700m hits on its website. The additional publicity of recent Nasa exploits (despite the Polar Lander and Mars Climate Orbiter mishaps) certainly won't have hurt.

Though Nasa steps back from endorsing the movie ("We call it 'participating' in the making of the film," says Nasa spokeswoman Bobbie Faye Ferguson), the agency's logos, or "meatballs" as they are descriptively dubbed, adorn the spacesuits and all the equipment in the film - as they will in Clint Eastwood's forthcoming Space Cowboys, another movie made with Nasa's blessing.

"We had no financial interest in the making of that movie or any movie," Ferguson asserts of Mission to Mars. "Federal agencies cannot do that." But there's still plenty to gain. With its "faster, cheaper, better" robotic odysseys failing to capture public imagination in the way the flag-waving Apollo missions did, Nasa needs to raise its profile. A manned Mars mission would cost $55bn - around the same price as last year's Kosovo operation.

"One of the things we do is try to increase awareness of space and spatial exploration," says Ferguson. "Right now there is a lot of interest in a manned mission to Mars. There is no official manned mission listed, but that's not saying there's not a lot of people who aren't very excited about it. I certainly think that participating in films that reach a large number of people, and that are feasibly fictional, increases the awareness of space and the future."

James Cameron has made no bones about it, enlisting to his painstakingly researched projects Robert Zubrin, author of the bestseller The Case for Mars: The Plan to Settle the Red Planet and Why We Must. "I want to make humans- to-Mars real in the minds of the viewing public," Cameron said at the second annual conference of the Mars Society, a think-tank advocating manned exploration.

It cuts both ways. While the scientific community will only begrudgingly acknowledge it, Hollywood has supplied more than a few ideas of its own over the years, beyond bequeathing the name Star Wars to Reagan's satellite missile system. Indeed, those charged with the practicalities of Mars travel could do worse than watch Robert Altman's Countdown, which got James Caan safely to the moon a year before Neil Armstrong ("Try begging for some of that Hollywood money. They've been making money off of aliens for years," says Jodie Foster's astronomer in Contact as she tries to raise capital for a space-monitoring project).

In 1991 Vivian Sobchack, film studies professor at UCLA and author of Screening Space: The American Science-Fiction Film, was co-opted on to a body called the Search for Extra-Terrestrial Intelligence (Seti). Seti works with Nasa in formulating how to break the news to the general public if and when alien contact is made. "Ultimately," says Sobchack, "one of the things on the agenda of Nasa and Seti was to have closer relations with the movie industry so we'd at least be closer in accuracy when conveying certain kinds of things."

Conspiracy theorists go one further. Why, they ask, after years of vehemently denying the existence of the "face" on Mars - the mysterious rock formation dismissed as tricks of shadows and light - has Nasa given its backing to a film in which said face, albeit in absurd fashion, is the central issue? It is suggested that by allowing certain ideas to seep into factually based fiction, the public will become primed to accept whatever Nasa eventually reveals as fact, thus avoiding Orson Welles's radio broadcast-style panic.

"That's been our story for 50 years here - the fact that they put out disinformation and so forth," says Carol Syska, director of the International UFO Museum and Research Centre at Roswell, New Mexico. "They're very good at that."

Nasa denies anything so sinister. "We at Nasa do not tell people how to make their movies," states Ferguson. "A movie is fiction. This is not a documentary. It's fiction. It's a movie. Period."

 Mission to Mars opens next Friday.

fields.headline: Cinefile...
fields.standfirst: Natascha McElhone
fields.trailText: Natascha McElhone.
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw?

I was smuggled under-age into Jaws.

What's your favourite film?

Brief Encounter, a simple story exquisitely told.

The last film you walked out of?

Magnolia, to get more Maltesers. I'm pregnant and have this Malteser fixation.

Most erotic movie moment?

The chess scene in the original Thomas Crown Affair with Steve McQueen and Faye Dunaway.It's incredibly erotic.

What's the most annoying habit in a cinema?

People who make crumpling sounds with their Malteser packets. I try very hard not to.

When was the last time you snogged in the cinema?

Last Friday, when we went to see The Talented Mr Ripley.

Favourite snatch of dialogue?

The opening to Manhattan. Woody Allen is trying out the first chapter of his book: "He was as tough and romantic as the city he loved. Behind his black-rimmed glasses was the coiled, sexual power of a jungle cat." Then he says to himself, "I love this!" and continues: "New York was his town and it always would be."

Which actor would you most like to be?

Daniel Day-Lewis.

Which actress?

The great thing about being an actress is that you can pretend to be anyone for a day.

When was the last time you hid under your seat?

Manhattan Murder Mystery, when Diane Keaton is on the phone to her friend in the other guy's flat and he's about to walk in on her.

The last time you cried?

The Czech film, Kolya, when the little boy is dumped in the bath. He's trying to reach his granny on the shower head thinking it's a phone and is saying "Babushka, babushka".

What was it like being the director's love interest?

Branagh really does treat everyone the same, so I was just one of the company. Then the camera would roll and, as if by magic, he'd step in front of the camera instead of being behind it, and we'd act.

 Natascha McElhone is in Love's Labour's Lost, which is on general release. Interview by Justina Hart.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Eyes Wide Shut |  The Eternal | The Haunting | Thick as Thieves
fields.trailText: Eyes Wide Shut | The Eternal | The Haunting | Thick as Thieves
fields.body:
Eyes Wide Shut
Rental and DVD (£15.99) Warner Cert 18
**

You expected length from Stanley Kubrick, but where The Shining, for example, was adapted from a Stephen King doorstopper, his 152-minute final work comes from a light, provocative novella. Arthur Schnitzler's source work is less than 100 pages. It's a toss-up if you could get through book or film faster. Kubrick's movie is faithful to the book's plot but stretches it out by making everybody talk very, very slowly with long pauses. I think the aim is to make it seem dreamlike but it just seems somnambulistic and stilted beyond belief. Schnitzler's story was an anatomy of a marriage and the fantasies within it - very much a product of Freud's 20s Vienna - and the film's masked ball and cafe society seem to fit that era. It is updated to the modern day, but if it weren't for the mobile phones, you'd hardly know. Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman seem lost in this context, though Kidman's theatrical breakthrough was in The Blue Room, also by Schnitzler. Curiously, the casting coup of having a married couple in the lead roles is nullified because they never seem like a real couple. With all these factors against it, there's little doubt that, sadly, Kubrick's last film is also his least impressive, taking place in a curious upper-class Neverland that looks like something from a Ferrero Rocher commercial. It doesn't provide any insight into sexuality or the strains of monogamy, its narrative is limp and uninvolving and its nudity (women only, and frequently) is as out of its time as everything else in this strangely pointless film.

The Eternal
Rental High Fliers Cert 15
***

An extremely obscure horror film that belies its straight-to-video status and the fact that it seems to be on its third name (after Trance and The Mummy). That's usually a bad sign, but writer-director Michael Almereyda starts with a far more realistic couple than you usually get in a supernatural thriller, makes the most of the film's Irish setting and achieves a hallucinatory, out-of-kilter feeling in a cavernous old house that seems like madness expressed architecturally. An alcoholic couple trying to get straight for the sake of their daughter go to the wife's old family home. She's Alison Elliott, he's Jared Harris, American actor, son of the very Irish Richard, and Alex Higgins lookalike. "Guinness is not strictly speaking alcohol, it's food," he explains in a local, far from anywhere. The film, too, is dark-toned and comes to a head. The house is run by an eccentric, almost blind uncle (Christopher Walken). I think you get the picture.

The Haunting
Rental DreamWorks Cert 12
*

Another creaky old house but this time a creaky old remake to go with it: it's shocking that spanking new DreamWorks made it. Lili Taylor, Catherine Zeta-Jones and Owen Wilson arrive to undergo an experiment run by Liam Neeson. The film starts to give them personalities, then decides to let the effects do the work, with a nightgowned Taylor running around shouting "No" and "What do you want from me?" Wilson, who co-wrote the great Rushmore, also gets to say: "It's like those Teletubbies. They freak me out also." It gets ever harder to believe Jan de Bont once directed Speed.

Thick as Thieves
Rental Alliance Atlantis Cert 18
**

Good-natured, inconsequential movie about an underworld feud in which Alec Baldwin is set up by Michael Jai White after a food-stamps robbery. Baldwin spends most of his time worrying about his dog and his record collection, while White is a ridiculously pretentious restaurateur-crim, apt to lapse into bad French. Writer-director Scott Sanders has a nice sense of humour but, although the action flips frenziedly from Chicago to Detroit to Miami, he can't quite decide what to do with his plot. It's a debut effort and feels like it.

webTitle: Driving the City up the wall

fields.headline: Driving the City up the wall
fields.standfirst: Power, loathing and money in a furnishings drama
fields.trailText: Lurking in a corner of a Hemel Hempstead business park is the modern head office of Walker Greenbank - an unassuming little furnishings company specialising in very expensive wallpaper. Apart from a brief moment of fame three years ago, when it supplied £350-a-roll Pugin prints for the Lord Chancellor's opulent apartments, it has scarcely pricked the public consciousness.
fields.body:
Lurking in a corner of a Hemel Hempstead business park is the modern head office of Walker Greenbank - an unassuming little furnishings company specialising in very expensive wallpaper. Apart from a brief moment of fame three years ago, when it supplied £350-a-roll Pugin prints for the Lord Chancellor's opulent apartments, it has scarcely pricked the public consciousness.

However, behind the scenes, the company has played host to a quite extraordinary drama of power, loathing, money and ambition. The City is furious with the group, having watched its shares collapse from 105p to 36p over the last five years.

One of the few analysts still prepared to follow the company remarks: "If management schools ever want a case study of how not to run a business, this is it."

Even City financiers accustomed to hostile bids were startled by the slanging match last week when former chief executive Charles Wightman declared he was considering launching a £30m offer for Walker Greenbank.

The company's boss, Aidan Connolly, denounced him as "an obsessive" and "an amateur investor", saying: "He should put up or shut up - is disruptive tactics are costing shareholders money."

Mr Wightman's responded: "With the strategy they're following at the moment they might as well take all the money and pour it out of the window."

This is far from a one off - Mr Wightman has threatened three times to bid for the company, then backed down after a brief but ferocious exchange of insults.

The roots of the dispute go back to 1998, when Mr Wightman presided over the £70m sale of Walker Greenbank's commercial wallcoverings business - an unsexy operation supplying decorations for offices, airports and hotels.

After the disposal Mr Wightman stepped down with two other directors, taking away a combined payoff of £2.9m. In fact, Wightman had been acrimoniously ousted after a boardroom row. A delegation of staff, including Connolly, made allegations about Wightman to the group's non-executive directors.

Chequered past

One was that he had lost the confidence of shareholders. The other was that despite boardroom opposition, he was planning to buy a 16-bedroom Buckinghamshire mansion as the company's new head office. Wightman denies both.

Connolly took the top job despite his chequered past - his previous positions included a stint at a Turkish airline, Telia, which went bust after a fatal plane crash, and a period on the board of Baileys Blinds - a now defunct furnishings company.

Progress has been slow. The company issued a profits warning, blaming the strong pound. Then a new computer system failed, forcing staff to input details of every order manually. A number of customers took their business elsewhere.

"Things have been difficult," concedes Connolly. "We inherited a poor situation. It's been difficult to improve things when everywhere you turn you find misleading comments about yourself."

Walker Greenbank felt embattled - it threatened to sue the internet service provider Hemscott.com over a series of postings on its bulletin boards about the company and about Connolly - referred to as "the fat controller".

The allegations, posted by a friend of Wightman, were swiftly erased from the website, although Wightman insists that they were all true.

Wightman first threatened to bid for the company in July last year. A couple of days later the Walker Greenbank financial adviser SBC Warburg resigned, complaining it had not been informed of the approach.

Wightman's more recent attempt has been with the backing of PizzaExpress millionaire Luke Johnson - but that seems to have failed. It was conditional on shareholders blocking two acquisitions last week which took the company further into manufacturing. Wightman prefers a strategy of building high-end brands and contracting out production.

Wightman insists his interest in the company is "financial" rather than personally motivated, and he adds that he has friends within the business who are concerned at its direction.

Connolly fires back: "Wightman has had the same strategy for years. The world has changed. He hasn't."

Times are tough in the furnishing industry - cheaper retailers, such as DFS, are manufacturing in-house. Fashions are changing more rapidly, partly due to television programmes such as Changing Rooms, and wallpaper is lagging behind paint in terms of popularity.

Walker Greenbank can still boast that its paper hangs in the House of Commons, and in stately homes. But unless it can sort out its past it will struggle to rebuild credibility in the City.

fields.headline: Games Workshop
fields.trailText: As any of you with young children will know, Pokemon is an all-encompassing obsession. Think Top Trumps, think Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, think Playstation. Roll them all into one, and you will have something approaching the power of Pokemon.
fields.body:
As any of you with young children will know, Pokemon is an all-encompassing obsession. Think Top Trumps, think Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, think Playstation. Roll them all into one, and you will have something approaching the power of Pokemon.

Shorthand for Pocket Monsters, the craze encompasses playing cards, a television cartoon and computer games. The phenomenon was launched in Japan by Nintendo but embraces youth cultures around the world: the characters easily translate into youthful slang, irrespective of language, with global village names ranging from Pikachu - or the cute yellow one - to Abra - which evolves into Kadabra at level 16.

However, beyond the usual parental anxieties about such overwhelming pre-teen obsessions with pseudo-violent toys, Pokemon is stirring up troubles of another kind - at least according to the Games Workshop Group, whose shares slumped by almost 30% yesterday. Its claim: that Pokemon has taken children's pocket money which would otherwise have been spent on its products.

Games Workshop, which makes miniature figures and games, saw its share price fall by 91p to 222p, valuing the company at a shade under £100m. Two years ago it was worth more than three times that amount, suggesting that not just Pokemon is to blame.

Games Workshop said the British success of the Pokemon cards had resulted in a 15% fall in its own like-for-like sales since Christmas. "It has drained an element of the discretionary 'pocket money' spend which, we believe, would otherwise have been spent on Games Workshop products," said the company. Pokemon, which ended last year with about 150 characters who battle against each other rather like Top Trump cards, is said to be ready to add 100 characters this year, fuelling the collection craze.

The mania will go on and then probably fade away, leaving companies like Games Workshop to ruminate on the difficulties of serving one of the most fickle markets of all.

fields.headline: Austin Reed adopts casual attitude
fields.trailText: It has been a tough couple of years for Austin Reed. In May 1997 the shares topped 250p, but for the past 18 months they have languished at around a third of that.
fields.body:
It has been a tough couple of years for Austin Reed. In May 1997 the shares topped 250p, but for the past 18 months they have languished at around a third of that.

Yesterday, the shares leapt 19p to 104p, valuing the company at more than £30m. Still a long way from 1997's heights but an improvement, nonetheless. The fashion chain revealed that it is in talks which could lead to an offer for the company. In February Austin Reed rejected as too low an unsolicited offer from an unnamed predator.

It is an intriguing time in the increasingly competitive fashion and retail arenas, with once safe businesses becoming potential targets. If even the mighty Marks & Spencer can face takeover speculation because of a fall in profits, then what hope is there for smaller prey?

Whether Austin Reed represents a tempting target in such a climate is another question, however.

It yesterday reported a fall in post-exceptional pre-tax profits from £78.1m for the previous 12 months to £2m for the year to January 31. Turnover slipped from £120m to £114m. The dividend will be 7p, unchanged from the previous year. However, like-for-like sales rose by 7% in February and March.

Analysts have speculated that possible buyers could include a Japanese company or Malayan United Industries, the 40% owner of troubled retailer Laura Ashley.

Another difficulty for Austin Reed is the movement towards more casual attire at work. Yesterday the company described the dress-down trend as a "growth opportunity" and said it planned to exploit its brand in "this new and for some customerspotentially confusing, challenge". That means it expects to serve the same old shoppers who do not know where to buy trendy new gear. Austin Reed will offer them work-leisure wear to replace the suits they used to buy in the chain's stores.

Chairman Colin Evans said that swift adoption of smart casual has "reduced the group's exposure to the cyclical men's suit market" and announced a programme of upgrading the group's stand-alone stores.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
CGNU
New posts at merged CGNU (CGU and Norwich Union,) whose merger will create Britain's biggest insurer and one of the biggest five in Europe, moved quickly to cement their deal yesterday by making key appointments throughout the new CGNU group. Prudential said it had appointed Philip Broadley - a partner at Arthur Andersen - as finance director. CGU chief executive Bob Scott will be chief executive until he retires in June 2001, to be replaced by Norwich Union chief executive Richard Harvey.
fields.body:
CGNU
New posts at merged CGNU (CGU and Norwich Union,) whose merger will create Britain's biggest insurer and one of the biggest five in Europe, moved quickly to cement their deal yesterday by making key appointments throughout the new CGNU group. Prudential said it had appointed Philip Broadley - a partner at Arthur Andersen - as finance director. CGU chief executive Bob Scott will be chief executive until he retires in June 2001, to be replaced by Norwich Union chief executive Richard Harvey.

Lafarge says no to bidding war
French bidder Lafarge said yesterday it could not envisage raising its offer for Blue Circle Industries. Lafarge felt that Blue Circle had been tempted to exaggerate its cost-cutting measures, which were essential for any company wishing to remain competitive in the cement market.

Banker warns of tech risks
Investors should be aware that the heady growth of hi-tech stocks is often accompanied by acute financial risk, Federal Reserve vice-chairman Roger Ferguson said.

In a lecture at Widener University he said consumers have amassed debt at a pace faster than their personal income growth over the past five years.

"Individuals must exercise ongoing vigilance in their personal financial behaviour. In particular, individuals should recognise that in this era of technology-induced growth, high growth goes hand in hand with high uncertainty and, for newer companies, volatility in their financial performance.

"History demonstrates that for every start-up, the vast majority find success elusive."

PowerGen in regulatory deal
PowerGen yesterday avoided a competition commission inquiry by accepting a "market abuse" condition in its licence, as proposed by industry regulator Ofgem.

It became the latest company to agree to the change after receiving clarification from Ofgem about the precondition. PowerGen and four other generators had rejected the clause, proposed in an attempt to stem price manipulation in the wholesale market, because they feared it would give Ofgem too much power.

PowerGen said it had received a promise that Ofgem officials would consider advice from an independent advisory board on the use of the clause and recognition that the company could challenge any decision through judicial review. Royal chief's pay falls £1.3m Bob Mendelsohn, millionaire US chief executive of Royal & Sun Alliance, suffered a £1.3m fall in pay last year compared with 1998. The annual report published yesterday showed that neither Mr Mendelsohn, who admitted in March he had failed to meet his bonus criteria, nor his fellow directors received any performance-related pay in 1999. Mr Mendelsohn took home £976,000.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Back to business for the City yesterday after Wednesday's unexpected Bank Holiday status. Perhaps it was the start of a new financial year, the summer in the City, or possibly the perspective offered by a few hours away from those flashing numbers, but the FTSE was in a much more healthy and happy state of mind yesterday.
fields.body:
Back to business for the City yesterday after Wednesday's unexpected Bank Holiday status. Perhaps it was the start of a new financial year, the summer in the City, or possibly the perspective offered by a few hours away from those flashing numbers, but the FTSE was in a much more healthy and happy state of mind yesterday.

The main index closed up 71.8 points at 6,451.1. Moreover the Techmark index, on a roller-coaster ride in recent weeks, put in a spectacular performance as investors piled back into tech stocks, and closed the session up 383.7 at 4,148.53.

Volume was a hefty 1.795bn shares in 135,583 trades, boosted by a clump of early morning trades as investors who had failed to transact their business on Wednesday because of the stock exchange pricing debacle tried to turn their gains into profits.

Just as important for the health of the equities economy was the return to tech stocks on both sides of the Atlantic. Telecoms, media and hi-tech led the market's advance throughout the day as investors used the recent market volatility to cherry-pick the best of the "new economy" stocks, and as a consequence "old economy" issues suffered.

Logica led the pack higher, up 288p at £21.08, with Baltimore up 968p at £75.88, CMG up 510p at £45.60 and Thus up 43p at 422p. Sage Group added 69p to 705p and palmtop computer maker Psion, a recent victim, rose 363p to £37.04. Psion might be a major beneficiary of Microsoft's much publicised woes. Vodafone AirTouch was sharply higher, up 24p at 343p.

QXL.com rose a scarcely credible 340p to 606p. Durlacher joined the party, up 62p to 223p, Pace Micro rose 153p to 877p and Atlantic Telecom joined the upthrust, ending 100p higher at 900p. Another possible benificiary of Microsoft's woes, Filtronic, firmed 170p to £17.90.

Biotech stocks did well, too, with Celltech - 189p higher at £12.72 - topping the list of FTSE 100 risers.

At the other end of the scale the "old economy" stocks suffered a drubbing, particularly financial shares.

Halifax fell 56p to 638p and Abbey National closed 45p lower at 822p. Barclays, whose top executives are working to a lavish bonus payment scheme revealed in this paper yesterday, shed 78p to £16.18.

Glaxo Wellcome shed 95p to £18.41 and SmithKline Beecham lost 47p to 838p, although AstraZeneca bucked the drugs trend by rising 37p at £27.84.

fields.headline: Littlewoods joins the price cutters
fields.trailText: Littlewoods, the privately owned retailer, is to slash the price of hundreds of goods in response to a pronounced slowdown in trading since Christmas.
fields.body:
Littlewoods, the privately owned retailer, is to slash the price of hundreds of goods in response to a pronounced slowdown in trading since Christmas.

The group intends to lower prices permanently by 15% to 20% on a range of best-selling clothes, furnishings and electrical goods.

Littlewoods said it was "going aggressive", to present a challenge to other "value" high-street chains, such as Top Shop, Bhs and Matalan.

Chief executive Barry Gibson said: "We're making a significant, strategic pricing shift."

The Price Rewind programme has been tested in a handful of stores over the past few months. It will be implemented nationwide the week after next.

Mr Gibson said: "Littlewoods has always been known as a value retailer. We've seen a significant hardening of the market, particularly for fashion, and we're responding to it."

Under the new pricing regime, Ben Sherman shirts will fall from £25 to £21, unbranded T-shirts will go down in price by a third to £4 and ladies' blouses will be cut from £12 to £10.

Littlewoods said it was able to offer cheaper goods after renegotiating its purchasing terms with suppliers. The cuts will apply to the group's high-street chain as well as the catalogue retailing and internet shopping service.

Mr Gibson said Littlewoods had an "OK but not brilliant" Christmas. However, it had seen a significant deterioration in trading since January.

He warned that the company's profits for the year to April would be below last year's £118m. At the halfway point in November, underlying profits were level.

Retail analysts were unsurprised that Littlewoods was reporting tough conditions.

Nick Hawkins of Merrill Lynch said: "Most people are cutting prices - I don't think they're doing anything all that extraordinary."

Based in Liverpool, Littlewoods is controlled by the multi-millionaire Moores family.

However, there has been speculation over the past year that it might be preparing for a stock market flotation.

In April last year the Moores family announced plans to run Littlewoods pools with a separate board from the retail operation.

Littlewoods has consistently denied any intention to go public but some observers believe that because the Moores family now has little day-to-day involvement its members might be prepared to relinquish some control.

fields.headline: Asda phone scheme targets BT
fields.trailText: Supermarket group Asda yesterday launched its own telephone service, accusing British Telecom of levying "luxurious" prices for local, national and international calls.
fields.body:
Supermarket group Asda yesterday launched its own telephone service, accusing British Telecom of levying "luxurious" prices for local, national and international calls.

Asda said it would undercut BT's prices on domestic calls by 62% and international calls by 85%. The Asda pre-pay phone scheme will target its 7m customer base and expects to have 350,000 users within 12 months.

Simon Singleton, Asda's head of marketing, said: "Residential calls are worth £2bn a year and those that are currently pre-paid are less than 1% compared with 30% in Germany. There is plenty of headroom in this market."

A BT spokeswoman said Asda's comparison with BT prices was misleading because it took the highest prices in each category. Asda rejected that claim.

Asda has teamed up with Unitel, which is backed by NTL, to enable customers to buy vouchers and then call a freephone number to open an Asda telephone account. To make the cheap calls they dial a prefix and the number sought.

Asda and Unitel will split the revenues 50-50.

Mr Singleton said the move is an attempt to increase customer traffic through Asda's 234 stores.

fields.headline: Revenue rogue admits insider deals
fields.trailText: A rogue taxman, who misused sensitive official information to speculate on the stock market, has admitted 13 charges of insider dealing. The Inland Revenue was rocked yesterday by the guilty pleas entered by Lawrence Champion who now faces up to seven years in prison for his 15-month trading spree.
fields.body:
A rogue taxman, who misused sensitive official information to speculate on the stock market, has admitted 13 charges of insider dealing. The Inland Revenue was rocked yesterday by the guilty pleas entered by Lawrence Champion who now faces up to seven years in prison for his 15-month trading spree.

Champion - of Harborne, Birmingham - admitted trading in shares on the basis of information gathered through his work as a higher executive officer with the capital gains tax clearance section in Solihull. This is the three-strong revenue unit that advises any companies contemplating mergers or takeovers of tax implications for shareholders.

Forearmed with names of possible bidders and targets, Champion was in a prime position to deal ahead of any public announcement. It is thought he made £15,000 between August 1997 and December 1998, although this figure was not mentioned at his Warwick Crown Court trial.

Champion dealt in the shares of companies including Philip Harris, Menvier Swain Group, Betterware, Tunstall, Tele-Cine Cell and Jackson Group. His dealings appear to have alerted the stock exchange's "billion dollar brain", the Imas market-surveillance computer, and the exchange referred the case to the department of trade and industry, which launched a criminal investigation.

The revenue has acted swiftly to prevent a reoccur rence. Service in units such as CGT clearance will now be restricted to five years - Champion had served for 10 years - and all personnel dealing with commercially sensitive information must inform their manager of any share dealings.

"We deplore the criminal behaviour of Lawrence Champion," revenue board chairman Nick Montagu said yesterday. He added that "immediate steps" had been taken to ensure this - the first case of insider dealing in tax information - would be the last.

Champion's conviction is the most serious case of wrongdoing inside Inland Revenue since the conviction in February 1997 of Michael Allcock for taking bribes from the wealthy individuals he was supposedly investigating. Allcock was jailed for five years.

Staff have been given new guidance on handling conflicts of interest. City banks have helped the revenue put together this new regime, drawing on their experience of so-called Chinese walls and other barriers to unethical behaviour.

Mr Montagu said: "We...[want] to protect our relationship with the markets. That is why we acted firmly as soon as we learned what Champion appeared to have done".

He added that the revenue would be meeting representatives of the legal and accountancy professions to reassure them that "keeping confidential information safe is of crucial importance to us". The case has been adjourned for sentencing with Champion granted unconditional bail.

fields.headline: Rates relief for industry
fields.trailText: Manufacturers and homeowners sighed with relief yesterday as the Bank of England's interest rate-setting committee voted to leave borrowing costs on hold, adding weight to Gordon Brown's claim that the Budget does not add significantly to inflationary pressures.
fields.body:
Manufacturers and homeowners sighed with relief yesterday as the Bank of England's interest rate-setting committee voted to leave borrowing costs on hold, adding weight to Gordon Brown's claim that the Budget does not add significantly to inflationary pressures.

But with domestic demand still growing strongly, most City analysts expect industry's respite to be short.

Jeremy Hawkins of Bank of America summed up the mood in the Square Mile by saying: "This is likely to be just a pause, rather than a peak, in the rate cycle."

The nine-member monetary policy committee offered no explanation for its decision to leave rates unchanged at 6%. In the MPC's almost three years in existence it has moved rates more often than it has left them alone.

But the decision had been widely anticipated because of the pound's strength, which is keeping inflationary pressures at bay by choking off exports and lowering import prices.

Next month the MPC will carry out its more thorough, quarterly assessment of the inflation outlook - including a detailed examination of the Budget's impact - and this could trigger further monetary tightening.

Michael Saunders of Salomon Smith Barney Citibank said that, despite the weakness of manufacturing, growth was still too strong to prevent a breach of the government's 2.5% inflation target. "A slowdown which is chiefly dependent on weakness in manufacturing and the traded goods sector to offset strength in services and domestic demand may not be sustainable because the resultant deterioration in the current account balance may at some stage undermine sterling."

Kate Barker, the CBI's chief economic adviser, said yesterday's decision was right for manufacturers and the whole economy.

webTitle: Keeping a watch on the Rhine

fields.headline: Keeping a watch on the Rhine
fields.standfirst: More abrasive model emerges
fields.trailText: Suddenly Rhineland capitalism does not look so comfortable. Yesterday Bernhard Walter, the head of Dresdner Bank - Germany's third largest - announced his resignation just 24 hours after his board pulled the plug on the merger with Deutsche Bank, the country's biggest. Rolf Breuer's job at Deutsche Bank looks a bit dicey, too.
fields.body:
Suddenly Rhineland capitalism does not look so comfortable. Yesterday Bernhard Walter, the head of Dresdner Bank - Germany's third largest - announced his resignation just 24 hours after his board pulled the plug on the merger with Deutsche Bank, the country's biggest. Rolf Breuer's job at Deutsche Bank looks a bit dicey, too.

While it is tempting to see Mr Walter's departure as a sign that Anglo-Saxon capitalist culture is taking hold in corporate Germany, post Vodafone/Mannesmann, it is worth remembering that the Deutsche/Dresdner deal was straight out of the Rhineland text book, with Allianz using its shareholdings in both banks to pursue the matter.

Nor has life in the BMW boardroom been too comfortable of late. The car maker's decision to dismember Rover was accompanied by the announcement that three directors were being chopped. Locals assume the departures were linked to a boardroom battle over the future of Rover - not the first time the British car maker had cost BMW directors their jobs. Yet BMW is hardly subject to Anglo-Saxon shareholder-style pressures. Not with one family controlling almost half of the shares.

There are signs of a more abrasive approach elsewhere, too. Mannesmann's Atecs industrial business, now up for sale, is the subject of competing bids. Yet none of those involved - Thyssen Krupp, Siemens and Robert Bosch - is an Anglo-Saxon-style predator. Closer to home, Thomson Travel has suddenly found itself on the receiving end of a hostile offer from Germany's C&N.

Globalisation may force the demise of Rhineland capitalism but it might just force it to change into a more rumbustious model - and one for which the Anglo-Saxons will have to look out.

Wacky races

Predictions of the imminent demise of dot.com-ery have clearly been overdone. In fact, the world of internet punting appears to be as wacky as ever.

Take QXL.com, the online auctioneer whose dealings got so dotty the stock had to be suspended temporarily yesterday as the price flew from 267p to 800p and then back to 658p.

The fun was started by Thomas Bock, an analyst at a Wall Street brokerage called SG Cowen, who said the stock was worth $1,000. He was talking about its American depository receipt form, on a two-year view, and crucially the analyst had failed to take into account the recent three-for-one stock split.

In London, dealers were not even sure how many ordinary shares made up a QXL.com ADR and it took some time before a British "see through" target price of £44 was established.

Market antics aside, two themes are now becoming clearer - the emergence of a class of potential cyberspace blue-chips and the readiness of big American investors to take certain European dot.com plays seriously.

On the other side of the Atlantic they know the value of intelligent stock picking. They have also got their heads around the concept of companies making big losses as they expand, subsequently delivering exponential profit growth - such as Yahoo! which has just reported first-quarter earnings up more than 100% at $63m and a whopping great profit margin of 38%.

In London, meanwhile, there are still quite a few pitfalls for the unwary, such as Beeson Gregory, the broking house which has just floated, partly on the back of excitement over all the dot.com flotation business it has picked up. The shares sank from 300p to 270p on their debut yesterday. Where was chief executive Andrew Beeson? On holiday in the Bahamas, of course.

Biotech jigsaw

Wall Street caught the biotech bug yesterday, sending share prices rocketing on news of an encouraging breakthrough in the Human Genome Project.

Several months ahead of schedule, Washington biotech firm Celera Genomics declared it had sequenced the genes of a whole person for the first time. However, this needs to be put in context.

Celera has done the first part of the job - it has identified all 14,000 genes in the body. It now has to put them together. It has a big pile of jigsaw pieces which need connecting up. Even then, Celera reckons it needs maps of five different people to get the full picture. When the genome is readily accessible, it will lead to a new generation in drugs - for each disease, scientists will be able to see exactly how the body malfunctions.

However, pharmaceutical products take more than five years to reach the market and only 1% succeed. Biotech stocks have been yo-yoing violently recently - each time President Clinton makes a remark about patenting genes, prices in the US take another lurch. In London, despite recent falls, Celltech is valued at more than £2bn and KS Biomedix, with just two products in the clinic, near £400m. Celera's news is great for humanity, but is not a real reason to buy into biotech.

webTitle: Big four sabotage global trade deal

fields.headline: Big four sabotage global trade deal
fields.trailText: Resumption of global trade talks appear remote following the failure of the latest attempt at compromise. Hopes that concessions to the world's poorest countries will revive the talks were dashed yesterday when it emerged that the big four trading powers have refused to open important areas of their markets.
fields.body:
Resumption of global trade talks appear remote following the failure of the latest attempt at compromise. Hopes that concessions to the world's poorest countries will revive the talks were dashed yesterday when it emerged that the big four trading powers have refused to open important areas of their markets.

The World Trade Organisation had backed tariff-free access to western markets for goods from the 48 poorest countries to dispel some of the bad feeling between the developing world and the west which emerged after the collapse of negotiations in Seattle last November.

But yesterday Whitehall sources said the Quad trading blocs - the US, EU, Canada and Japan - had carved out so many exceptions and provisions for sensitive areas such as agriculture and textiles that the deal was considered by aid agencies to be almost worthless. The watered-down agreement will be presented to developing countries at a WTO meeting on Monday.

Agriculture and textiles are the most important exports for many developing countries and they had hoped western countries would lift their tariff and quota barriers.

"This was the litmus test of
the west's willingness to share the benefits of trade and they've failed it," said Penny Fowler, trade policy adviser at Oxfam. "I can't imagine that poor countries are going to get a fair deal out of a new round if [the west] behave like this."

The UK was one of the main promoters of the goodwill gesture, despite opposition from southern European states which wanted exceptions made for agriculture. British trade diplomats in Geneva were said to be despondent that the deal had collapsed.

A lobbying campaign by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, failed to persuade other EU nations to open all their markets to goods from the poorest countries. The EU insisted the words "essentially all" be inserted in the agreement to allow some exemptions.

But the final straw came in negotiations between the EU, the US and Japan. The Americans demanded that the deal be subject to international agreements which protect its textile industry, while Japan inserted the words "subject to domestic requirements" to protect its rice industry.

A WTO source said of the Quad's offer. "We would have liked to see more on market access." But he insisted that the deal contained concessions for developing countries.

fields.headline: Thomson refuses to meet C&N
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest holiday company, Thomson Travel, flatly refused to meet German bidder C&N Touristic yesterday despite hints of a higher takeover offer.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest holiday company, Thomson Travel, flatly refused to meet German bidder C&N Touristic yesterday despite hints of a higher takeover offer.

Thomson's management opted for a tough stance after big shareholders indicated they would reject C&N's existing £1.3bn proposal. Phillips & Drew, which owns 4% of Thomson, described the offer as "cheeky and opportunistic".

The Thomson family, which has a 19% stake, joined the opposition, as did two other big institutions.

A takeover would create Europe's largest holiday company, able to command better terms from hotels and airlines.

However, institutions want to give Thomson's new management time to turn around the struggling business, with new ventures proposed in e-commerce and interactive television.

C&N is yet to table a formal bid - it has merely said it would be prepared to pay 130p a share in cash.

The German company yesterday requested a meeting to hear why Thomson believed more money was warranted. It said that if a friendly deal was possible it would "consider whether or not" improvement of its offer could be justified.

However, Thomson's chief executive Charles Gurassa said he saw no reason to meet because the bid "dramatically undervalues" the business.
