webTitle: DTI accused of sacrificing textile industry to fashion

fields.headline: DTI accused of sacrificing textile industry to fashion
fields.trailText: Britain's textile industry, which employs more than 300,000, is in crisis and should be thrown a lifeline with a rescue package similar to the £130m offered to Rover in the west midlands, according to experts backed by the department of trade and industry.
fields.body:
Britain's textile industry, which employs more than 300,000, is in crisis and should be thrown a lifeline with a rescue package similar to the £130m offered to Rover in the west midlands, according to experts backed by the department of trade and industry.

The textile and clothing strategy group, comprising unions, academics and industry leaders, complains that although a significant number of companies are eligible for aid - so-called selective financial assistance - there is anecdotal evidence that some DTI officials "are not convinced of the merit in supporting investments in this sector".

It says the perception should be vigorously challenged by an industry, Britain's eighth largest manufacturer, which has an annual turnover of more than £14bn.

More than 40,000 workers, mainly women, have been thrown out of work during the past year, and the beleaguered trade secretary, Stephen Byers, is facing renewed pressure from restless Labour backbenchers and union leaders for multimillion-pound aid to save the crisis-hit industry.

With many of the factory closures taking place in the north and the midlands, Labour MPs believe ministers are increasingly vulnerable to the charge that they are abandoning traditional industries in favour of hi-tech clusters in the south.

In a new strategy document, to be published next month, the group underpins this criticism by claiming the government is quite prepared to provide substantial support "for the latest fashionable theories" such as clusters.

Redundancies in the industry, now running at more than 600 a week, have been fuelled by the decision of Marks & Spencer to end contracts with some clothing manufacturers.

Fears have been reinforced in heated correspondence between union leaders and Mr Byers and his junior minister, Patricia Hewitt, who represents a constituency - in Leicester - with large number of textile workers.

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB general union, believes the government would have been much more robust in defence of the industry if the jobs of blue collar workers were threatened.

But replying to Mr Edmonds, Mr Byers has said intervention is not an option and that "preferential treatment... simply is not on the agenda".

Patricia Hewitt has been similarly dismissive. "I appreciate the widespread concern ... about the number of job losses in this sector," she told Des Farrell, national secretary of the GMB's clothing and textile section. "The government has no locus to intervene in the commercial decisions of individual companies."

The unions, in turn, have accused the government of double standards. Mr Edmonds says the industry is "in freefall". He has asked Mr Byers to support a call for Marks & Spencer to compensate those losing jobs in firms once dependent on the chain.

Little-noticed, Jack Straw announced the latest review of the boundaries of English parliamentary constituencies recently. It will be done by the boundary commission for England, an independent quango which is due to publish provisional recommendations for several counties in June. Interest will grow as it gathers speed - someone is bound to lose.

The point of these reviews is to rectify imbalances, especially gaps between the size of constituencies and the "electoral quota", which will be very close to 70,000 voters per constituency in this review. The commission has a fair amount of discretion. As it goes round the country it matches irreconcilables: minimum variation in electorate size; minimum disruption to existing seats; and maximum public support.

In some places this may not prove difficult. Most English shire counties will keep their existing entitlement to parliamentary representation; boundary changes will be minor. A dozen - the "winners" in the chart - look to gain one seat, which will lead to disruption.

All six of England's metropolitan areas stand to lose a seat, with two or three likely to disappear from London. Indeed, the fiercest battles are likely to be fought in the capital. Last time round, the commission dealt with the small electorates in boroughs such as Kingston upon Thames, Kensington & Chelsea and Newham by recommending constituencies which (unprecedentedly) crossed borough boundaries.

The political parties will be very interested in new seats. Labour's victory in the "battle of the boundaries" during the last review won accolades for the author of its strategy, David Gardner. Redistribution of seats away from metropolitan England towards the shires inevitably favours the Tories.

Although Labour used the inquiry process last time to improve its electoral position compared with the commission's provisional recommendations, the review's net effect was to the Tory advantage. The Tories are unlikely to prove such a soft touch this time, resulting in further politicisation of ostensibly non-partisan local inquiries.

A cause for concern is how long it will take. The commission is using an "enumeration date" of February 16 2000. That means the constituencies it recommends to the home secretary will be based on electoral rolls compiled in October 1999, but the commission does not have to report until April 2007. Given that the next general election is likely to be held in 2001, with the following election in 2005 or 2006, it is possible that the constituencies it recommends will not be used until an election in, say, 2009. By then the electorate data will be 10 years out of date.

The boundary commissions for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland will probably not start their reviews for another year at least, with later enumeration dates. They, too, need not report until 2007. This matters a great deal in Scotland because the Scotland Act 1997 requires the boundary commission for Scotland to use the same electoral quota as that employed for England (during the forthcoming review only), in order to reduce Scotland's over-representation in the Commons after the creation of the Scottish parliament. This could mean that over-representation will not be removed for at least two more parliaments - but when it does, Scotland could lose as many as 12 of its current complement of 72 MPs.

Amazingly, no similar reduction of the over-representation of Wales was proposed when the Welsh assembly was established. Wales is already over-represented at Westminster. In 1997, the average MP in Wales represented 55,000 constituents while the average England MP represented about 70,000.

This disparity could even increase. The Wales commission's last report in 1995 argued that the combination of rules and geography makes a 41st seat almost inevitable this time, even if the electorate stays the same as in 1993. Northern Ireland already has the maximum number of seats allowed - 18.

There has to be a better way. When he was home secretary, Kenneth Clarke claimed that there was "no compelling need for any changes in the rules" which the boundary commissions must operate. This is not the view of experts. Reviews of the legislation have been promised by other home secretaries, but nothing has emerged and there is nothing in the political parties, elections and referendums bill introduced last December.

The commissions do an excellent job within a set of rules described as "confusing and contradictory" by elections expert David Butler: the upshot is "muddle and incomprehension". It is time these rules were removed. The process could be speeded up substantially.

Review would take no more than two years (longer than it took in 1885 and 1918) if two changes are made. First, the rules under which the commissions operate should be made unambiguous: in particular, the catch-all, largely subjective requirement to minimise the breaking of local ties should be removed. Secondly, time-consuming local inquiries should be abolished.

Without the need to consider local ties, decisions on which set of boundaries to adopt should be taken on objective grounds, notably the equalisation of electorates but also respecting local government boundaries and minimising the disruption to existing constituencies.

The unedifying prospect of political parties dressing up their partisan ends by reference to factors such as bus routes, school catchment areas and even (as occurred during the last review) the location of golf courses and regimental recruiting patterns, would be a thing of the past. Written responses to provisional recommendations would be sufficient, and the whole process more efficient.

 David Rossiter, Ron Johnston (both at Bristol University) and Charles Pattie (Sheffield University) wrote The Boundary Commissions: Redrawing the UK's Map of Parliamentary Constituencies (Manchester University Press, 1999)
fields.bodyText: Winners Avon Cornwall Derbyshire Devon Essex Hampshire Isle of Wight Norfolk Northamptonshire Oxfordshire Warwickshire Wiltshire Losers Greater London Greater Manchester Merseyside South Yorkshire Tyne & Wear West Midlands West Yorkshire Little-noticed, Jack Straw announced the latest review of the boundaries of English parliamentary constituencies recently. It will be done by the boundary commission for England, an independent quango which is due to publish provisional recommendations for several counties in June. Interest will grow as it gathers speed - someone is bound to lose. The point of these reviews is to rectify imbalances, especially gaps between the size of constituencies and the "electoral quota", which will be very close to 70,000 voters per constituency in this review. The commission has a fair amount of discretion. As it goes round the country it matches irreconcilables: minimum variation in electorate size; minimum disruption to existing seats; and maximum public support. In some places this may not prove difficult. Most English shire counties will keep their existing entitlement to parliamentary representation; boundary changes will be minor. A dozen - the "winners" in the chart - look to gain one seat, which will lead to disruption. All six of England's metropolitan areas stand to lose a seat, with two or three likely to disappear from London. Indeed, the fiercest battles are likely to be fought in the capital. Last time round, the commission dealt with the small electorates in boroughs such as Kingston upon Thames, Kensington & Chelsea and Newham by recommending constituencies which (unprecedentedly) crossed borough boundaries. The political parties will be very interested in new seats. Labour's victory in the "battle of the boundaries" during the last review won accolades for the author of its strategy, David Gardner. Redistribution of seats away from metropolitan England towards the shires inevitably favours the Tories. Although Labour used the inquiry process last time to improve its electoral position compared with the commission's provisional recommendations, the review's net effect was to the Tory advantage. The Tories are unlikely to prove such a soft touch this time, resulting in further politicisation of ostensibly non-partisan local inquiries. A cause for concern is how long it will take. The commission is using an "enumeration date" of February 16 2000.
